It was quite awful by itself - we thought it was meant to be consumed - but when eaten with the beignets they were very complimentary.  All I know is I've been wanting to come back ever since.

SUTWFZMeyBNubEKSn8QaOA.review_text: Beautiful spot.  Great service.  Romantic.  Really good food.- the cornbread rocks! i enjoyed the fried chicken, but was jealous of my partner's short rib.  Get the short rib!  I'm pretty sure you are safe to order everything!  We loved it!!!

OnhM-m4MHhgWGiBWd9apYg.review_text: When you have 10 angry salespeople, something is bound to go wrong at dinner; someone is going to be picky or unhappy or not impressed.  So when I got stuck with the 'event planning' stick I grimaced and figured if everyone simply had enough to drink it would be a success.  A year later, those angry salespeople are still talking about how good the 1300 was.  And if they never go back their memories will continue to exist in a culinary vacuum of perfection.    Unfortunately, two of us went back recently.  I can't say that we had a bad dinner, but neither of us were impressed.  I called in advance to make a reservation and the woman who answered the phone was just a wee glib.  When we showed up the offhanded nonchalance had morphed into something far more sinister.  The hostess was in no uncertain terms ANNOYED AS HELL that customers had come in to eat.  We were well dressed and friendly, but unprovoked she was angry and bitter.  If there's one reason why there were no customers I'm guessing it's because of her.    Anyhow....our waitress was wonderful.  The bar couldn't keep up with our second round of drinks (ordered before dinner and drink came as I was finishing).  Considering how empty it was I would hate to order a drink when it was busy.  The food that had been absolutely incredible the first time we went was now just 'good'.  Not good enough to justify the price (by any means), but not offensive.   Oh hell--I just realized we ordered (and presumably paid for) one bowl of bisque that never showed up.  The dinner gets worse the more I think about it.  So that would be: 5 stars last year -1 star for the hostess being mean and nasty  -1 star for the missing bisque -1 star for the food just being ok

ac0bVsCKbbB6bTiWvXfNyw.review_text: host-MEGAN-Rude!  She set the tone for the rest of our experience, unfortunately.  Corn bread w/jalepeno butter, amazing!  Food good, but nothing to return for

o89TnF0nOpsI6ztVF7f3lQ.review_text: I feel like I have to write a review for 1300 Fillmore as it's not often that I am in physical pain after a "nice" meal.  The two stars are for ambiance-- I thought it was a really well decorated/ swanky restaurant and bar.    HOWEVER, I had the Kaffir Lime Gimlet, a beet salad and the trout on Saturday night and before I even left the restaurant I had really horrible heartburn.  I have maybe had heartburn once before in my life, so something at dinner triggered it -- I suspect the overly sour, weak gimlet.   Either way, like many others have mentioned, the food was nothing special and thus over priced for you're getting.  My husband had the short rib with horseradish & chive mashed potatoes but there was not even a hint of horseradish.  And, despite a good portion size, the potatoes were also really starchy, like someone forgot the milk/ cream. The cornbread was supposed to be a highlight according to our server but even it tasted like I added water to some mix and made it at home.    I was pretty disappointed and in pain when I left... bummer.

eSU_HjKOA3Ppt8oS07oYkw.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore, located at 1300 Fillmore Street. I see what y'all did there, good job, guys.  Came here for a late-night classy dinner with a few friends. Immediately after entering the restaurant, you can hear the bustling of the restaurant crowd and the live jazz band in the back by the bar. Some of the walls are lined, ground to ceiling, with bottles of wine, all local/from California wine country. We decided on a couple bottles of the 2009 Meritage, from Sean Minor. Some people frown upon blended wines, but the Meritage was delicious and not too dry, so screw 'em. I don't profess to know much about wines, but if it tastes good, I'll drink it. Our waitress was very quick and had good recommendations.  Complimentary cornbread that came out was very good, and came with butter and jalapeño jelly. I was tempted to get the black skillet fried chicken, since it was one of their signature dishes, but given that I had eaten fried chicken earlier in the day, I reluctantly opted out. Instead, I ordered the pork "porterhouse", which was cooked to a perfect medium rare. I also tried the matchstick okra, which was like eating nori, but a bit more substantial. It lacked a bit of flavor, but with the aioli, the fried okra wasn't  too bad.  Prices are on the higher side, but given the ambiance and the good waitstaff, it's actually a decent value. I'll definitely be back if I'm feeling a classy dinner in SF.

uKphjI8nfHnwCbo85yGsFQ.review_text: This restaurant is SO good.  I love the fried chicken, the hushpuppies appetizer, the chocolate beignets for dessert - everything they make here is delicious.  And I love the lounge area!  So well-decorated and just a cool vibe.  Great wine list, too :)

CWX2TfgXKQlZrVrr4JsxKA.review_text: This place was crowded on a Saturday night, with a  live cover band playing (a bit loud for conversation). The decor was hip with upside down table lamps hanging from the ceiling and lampshades utilized as stage light cans. The the crowd was mostly 20-30 somethings. Unfortunately, the food was sorely lacking. We ordered the menu fixe, which was a southern style rack of lamb. I ordered mine medium, and my dinner partner ordered hers medium rare. My meat arrived shrunken and tough (about half the size of my dinner partner's). I tried hers and it was not very flavorful. Nothing else about the meal stood out to counter the dismal experience of the main course. The service was ok, but I was disenchanted after the waiter had raved about and recommended the special.  Not worth the price.

eIEE-h40qFVtc07030lqLg.review_text: Service is AWESOME. Great place to sit down and really enjoy dinner. Food is really good too. This is a good pre-yoshi's place.  Everything on the menu is solid. Fried chicken - must try. Corn-bread - bomb.   If you have not been, definitely check it out.

7igYjtQ2kI166vtqCBRnhA.review_text: I went for Gospel brunch...5 of us. Overall, food & service was good but other components were lacking.   Food:  Comp bread - mix of seasonal biscuits (strawberry), chive biscuits & skillet cornbread. The cornbread was amazing - perfect texture & taste. I wanted more. Strawberry biscuit was good, not too dense. Chive biscuit had flakes of chives all thru it so definitely a good flavor profile.   At the table: (2) fried chicken dishes, (1) savory brioche french toast with balsamic-glazed strawberries (very good - I had a small piece), (1) eggs benedict (my friend liked it) & (1) smoked salmon on a cornmeal pancake (also good - I had a bite & my friend liked it).  I had the fried chicken. Served on a large bed of mashed potatoes & 2 chive biscuits. What's it missing? VEGGIES!! Instead of 2 carbs, 1 of them (preferrably the mash) should be substituted for collard greens or another southern veggie dish. The dish is not colorful - brown on white. The biscuits were good, I was not impressed with the mashed potatoes (creamy texture but no flavor). However, the fried chicken was amazing!! 4 small pieces, spiced & breaded & fried to a yummy heaven quality. I had leftovers - reheated & cold - and it still was amazing! There is a spice mix they use in their breading that makes the chicken jump out in your mouth when you're chewing. Hard to describe unless you've had it, but worth trying. Not the KFC-type of spice that leaves you feeling sick (that could be the oil/nasty chicken/gross overall factor as well!).   Drinks - 1 mimosa (good), 1 hot tea & 3 Pimosas. Pomegranate juice & liquer mixed w/ sparkling wine & refillable (!!!) for $12. Too sweet & not enough alcohol for me. I had 2 glasses & that was more than plenty to make me feel that my $12 was well spent. It's pre-mixed so the servers just go around refilling when your glass is 2/3 empty (so no way to get it topped off w/ extra sparkling wine).   Our server was very nice - Nikki. I'd request her again. The band was good - not a lot of "Gospel" music & 1 singer who has a guest singer join him a few times (I think she sang 2 songs).   They sat us literally in front of the band which made conversation very hard & I wasn't thrilled with the location. A table shouldn't be that close to music/loud speakers even if that means you take 6 less people 2x each Sunday (2 seatings - 1 at 11am & 1 at 1pm). We had to shout to talk to each other, 1 of the girl's had her back to the band b/c it was a round table, & it was awkward in my opinion - not a good ambience/atmosphere creation.   I'd go back to try a few other items on their dinner menu but I'm not running back...it's good but not great.

VcPj1gchy48KWnMk4kMI-A.review_text: alright, so i went to this place the first week it was opened.  breast fricking fried chicken ever!  it was kinda spicy and crunchy, and minimal bones, which is good for a lazy-ass such as myself.  the cornbread with the jalepeno jelly was great.  so great, we asked for more, and got some biscuits instead.  a little dissappointed in that, but i should be sticking to my low carb diet anyway.  i wanted to order the pork belly, but i am not a cannibal, so back off!  the service was great...very friendly...maybe a little overattentive at times, but not at all creepy or anything like that.  other stuff: shrimp hushpuppies - more breaded shrimp than hushpuppies ,but good nevertheless warm poached egg salad - can we say egg yolk?  hell yeah!  (note: no salmonella poisoning this time) pork chop - i like chicory in coffee, so why not on pork?  although i didn't eat that, because like i said before, that would be SICK! fries - i'm a freedom frie connoisseur, so i'd give it an "average"  mac 'n cheese - good enough desserts were very good also, although i can't really remember what we had.    overall a great dining experience.  i'm sure it will be a bit harder to get reservations now than it was on the third day of its opening.

KKwoA05KP2amtHeU_tkzaA.review_text: Apparently this place has been open for over a month, right across the street from my apartment. It's so subdued-looking from outside that I hadn't even noticed it - a large wooden door and an iron "1300" are all that you'll see from the street.   Finally, last night, the girlfriend and I decided to go check it out. And I have a feeling this is going to become one of our regular places.   The service was truly outstanding - it feels like everyone there is really tuned in to doing everything they can to take care of you. The slightest needful glimpse at any of the staff was instantly noticed and attended to. Our waiter (George?) offered fantastic recommendations and was purely, sincerely friendly far beyond the call of duty.  For starters, we got the braised pork belly and the shrimp "hush puppies". The pork belly was absolutely amazing ... melt-in-your-mouth luscious, with a sweet cherry glaze that left me wanting to sop up every last drop. The shrimp hush puppies I would have probably called "fried shrimp" - where I come from, hush puppies are a deep-fried ball of cornmeal batter. But whatever you call them, they were executed quite well, albeit not quite as memorably as the pork belly.  My girlfriend ordered the braised short ribs, and I got the skillet fried chicken. A few minutes after we placed our order, our waiter came back with an apology: Apparently the ribs were a popular item that night, and there was only one order left. And, would you please accept the chef's apology, but that last one simply isn't good enough to serve as your entree - it's all fallen off the bone and ugly. If you could make another selection, the chef would be most happy to provide, gratis, a sampling of the ribs you originally wanted; he's simply unwilling to give you a less-than-perfectly plated dinner.  Wow. Um, okay.  So she changed her order to the tenderloin filet, and when all was said and done we had THREE complete entrees on the table. The sample of the braised ribs was, indeed, falling off the bone - and just bursting with meaty deliciousness (and honestly, I think many other restaurants would have served that "defective" plate without hesitation. It looked pretty good to me.) The fried chicken definitely is worth all the fuss, tender and moist on the inside with a lightly spicy, crunchy crust that didn't have a hint of greasiness to it. And the tenderloin - if there are "textbook examples" at the school of culinary arts, this is the way you cook a tenderloin. A perfect crisp sear on the outside, medium rare and oh so tender inside.  My neighborhood is looking better every day.

RP0LKJCyeTIMKT0ZGt-XZA.review_text: Service was perfect last night at our early dining hour. Spot on recommendations from my waiter.  Second tier staff couldn't have been more attentive and professional.  They must have been listening, reading and training.  Food was incredible.  Short ribs, fried chicken, fried okra as an app, shrimp and grits.  I'm going back ASAP for the my next round.  Can't wait.  The room had a great buzz, lots of happy patrons.

Zlj4ZJdgx3WJA7IZt7j0Qw.review_text: I really wanted to love 1300 on Filmore, marry it, and make it my own (and I had every right -- given the absurd amount of food and wine ordered, and money spent).  Alas, I'll settle for a long distance relationship, with lots of hot studs on the side.  Between the six of us, we ordered nearly appetizer and entree item on the menu.  Standouts for me: the ravioli appetizer and the warm poached egg salad (I was doubtful about the latter, but was pleasantly surprised).  I liked the extreeemely good, fall-off-the-bone, well-flavored short ribs, but not exceptional for me.  I guess I was hoping for a more unique flavor.  The service was very good though.  I appreciate when your server alerts you to an ordering faux pas (e.g., that wine wasn't good that year, I suggest this instead).  Not love at first sight, but 1300 Fillmore still set my heart aflutter.  Yay.  (3.5 stars)

bxPYREtZeH98clXftApGhg.review_text: do you guys wanna talk about this for a second?  because this was one of the better meals i've had in san francisco and i really want to discuss it.  my parents and i came here to celebrate my birthday (one week after my actual birthday).  cornbread triangles are brought to the table with honey butter and a jalapeño preserve and we also ordered a side dish of spiced fat fries which came with homemade ketchup.  everything was great and the fries were indeed spicy.  my mama and i both got the feist blood orange cocktail which was absolut mandarin orange, fresh orange, cranberry juice and sliced jalapeño.  the citrus made it super refreshing and the jalapeño gave it a great kick.  for dinner, the folks and i dined on some rather tasty food.  mama got the special that night which was pork ribs, macaroni and cheese and cole slaw with a few sauces on the side.  the macaroni and cheese was REALLY good and the pork was tender and the sauces were all types of tasty.  pops got the ribeye steak which came with carrot-cardamom puree, brussels sprout and applewood smoked bacon hash.  i haven't eaten cow in over 8 years but you better believe i took a bite of that steak and HOLY COW (oh, you see what i did right there?) it was GOOD and i will be eating more cow in the near future.  i ordered the spring pre-fixe menu which was the following:  - grilled asparagus and goat cheese beignets with a frisee lavender-honey vinaigrette - oven roasted salmon with a lobster-potato hash, meyer lemon preserve - strawberry-rhubard cobbler with housemade vanilla bean ice cream  as if you had to ask, my meal was super good.  the asparagus and goat cheese beignets were AMAZING.  my salmon was perfectly cooked and dessert was heavenly.  the staff was attentive and extremely nice and helpful.  we didn't tell the hostess or wait staff that we were celebrating me but i think they overheard my mom mention it in conversation because when they brought dessert out, there was a candle and "happy birthday" written in chocolate on the side of the dish.  how thoughtful.  i wouldn't go here on my own because hello prices, but hey, if the folks are in town and they're treating... absolutely!

RVKadMPQnfWj7CxyX_gaGQ.review_text: warm and cozy with a historic feel. the food is what i would call "San Francisco's take on soul food"  Hush Puppies, corn bread and of course, a GREAT selection of wine.   There is a wonderful lounge and bar area.  The dining room is very inviting.   I'd like to go back when they have live music....highly recommend it if you are in the mood to check out something other than the usual.   Also....spotted Willie Brown.

5NUhIaxXFrVPprgNPobarw.review_text: Can you say BBq Shrimp with Grits?!?!  Well when you order you should!!  Last night I had a lovely ladies night out at 1300 Fillmore.  We dined on the Shrimp and Grits, the hush puppies, and I had the fried chicken.  All of which was beyond expectations.  The ambiance is fabulous complete with live Jazz, and the wait staff was very accommodating, Adam our waiter didn't bat an eyelash with all our random requests for extra hot sauce and such, he was awesome!!  So I def will be back and for sure recommend 1300 to everyone thats into good food from the south!!!

SwjJhjrxqhqk3yyjXQPJ7Q.review_text: The 3-star rating shouldn't detract from this place's appeal - this place is a nice place to get a drink and a few appetizers.  I've been to 1300 twice now, and it has never been too crowded, and the cocktails (especially the Jazzberry) are top-notch.  The decor is chic, and the seats in the lounge are very comfortable.  That being said, both times the service was unprofessional, abrupt and generally sloppy.  The servers in the lounge were not friendly, and at both times, brought our bill before we had even finished our first round of drinks.  Also, we ordered the sliders which came with three mini-burgers - we asked if the kitchen could add a fourth burger because there were four of us and we said that we would pay extra for the fourth.  The waitress said she didn't think the kitchen could do this (come on, really?) and, after much prodding, finally agreed to ask the kitchen.  She never came back with a response and later, the sliders were delivered to our table with - guess what - only three on the plate.  In the end, it didn't really matter because the sliders were pretty dry and tasteless anyway.  I was still irritated though.  I hope they get their service issues sorted out because I really like the space and the bartenders are great.

OZRhAe-La1bX2xhLGJujVg.review_text: I've been trying to get to this place for over 5 years. Finally "all-the-stars-aligned" and we made it. In town for the weekend we went  to the 11am seating for the Sunday morning Gospel Brunch. My wife hade the Shrimp & grits ( their signature dish ) it was fresh and delicious with just the right amount of "kick". I had the fried chicken. Cooked perfectly with a nice crisp skin while being tender and moist on the inside. (My only suggestion would be to use bone-in pieces and not chicken tenderloins ). We also split a chop salad which was very tasty and fresh.  Service was great ! The hostess was very friendly and accommodating, our waiter was efficient and attentive and the bus-staff courteous & diligent. The only issue, keeping them from earning a 5 Star rating, was that their was not much Gospel Music at the Gospel brunch. The band was very talented but played more Jazz, R & B, and even some Blues. Entertaining, but not what we were expecting. I'm guessing the 1 pm seating gets more Gospel. We'll test that theory on our next visit.

Vm1aUvzG3APDJW2JV6Ovmw.review_text: I initially visited 1300 Fillmore for my 40th birthday celebration, only having a chance to sample the appetizers and finally made it back for a full meal.   Reservations were made via OpenTable for 8:30pm.  Partner and I arrived 30 minutes early on a Saturday evening and were seated at a great table with perfect views of the chocolate colored dining room.  Service came in the form of a very well groomed young man with just the right amount of attentiveness to not annoy, but meet our needs.  Our small plates, Barbeque Shrimp w/ Grits and Mussels in Dijon vinaigrette were yummy, with portions large enough to satisfy if not overly hungry.  Our entrees, Blackened Catfish over a bed of seasoned rice and Boneless Spare-Ribs (think mini-post roast cooked to perfection that fell apart as you cut into it, drizzled with a sauce of tangy sweetness) on a bed of collards and mashed potatoes were both flavorful and filling.  In point of fact, you'll need to bring your appetite, or expect a doggie bag afterwards as the portions are large.  We topped our meal off with a shared sorbet that was adequate.    My only nit is that the dining room was a bit loud, so be prepared to lean in a little during conversation.  All in all, a pleasant dining experience at almost exactly $100 bucks for two.

CmV4qbf74we-y1jkVAp50Q.review_text: The food was good. But we went there for the dessert last Sunday morning and were disappointed to find out their Sunday Brunch menu has a very limited selection of desserts - chocolate chip cookies, apple cobbler and sorbets. No beignet no cakes no macarons.  The music was pleasant but it cost $5 per person, which we hadn't known.

G9Vb6yQ047TC3O_-GG4WZA.review_text: What a fun place to enjoy a romantic and upbeat Valentine's dinner! I love spending V-Day somewhere lively, and jazz restaurants are always a favorite of mine. I was excited to check out this fairly new restaurant located next to Yoshi's in the Fillmore Heritage Center. (Best V-Day dinner so far was at Supperclub with Bebel Gilberto performing!)  The swinging live jazz band last night provided wonderful table-side entertainment throughout the evening. The chanteuse's voice was lovely, and the band even got the manager snapping his fingers as he came around to each table to check on how we were doing. The patrons were quite diverse, including the large party in the private dining area which looked like a distinguished bunch.  Our server, Ashley, was extremely sweet, and raved about the different selections on the menu as we enjoyed the warm cornbread triangles with jalepeno jam and butter. It made it so hard to decide whether to get the 4-course prix-fixe menu (special for Black History Month) or go a la carte. Actually, they prix-fixe menu was available a la carte, which is why it made the decision that much harder. In the end, we went with the regular menu. I got the Bourbon Braised Pork Belly with white bean puree to start, and the Fried Chicken with truffle whipped potatoes for my main entree. My valentine got the BBQ Shrimp with Creamy Grits as his appetizer, and the Maple Syrup Slow Braised Beef Short Ribs with crispy onion rings and buttermilk chive mashed potatoes for his main with a side of mac 'n cheese. Our appetizer selections filled our souls, but our entrees seemed to have missed the mark. Both the pork belly and bbq shrimp were delicious, but the goodness seemed to have hit a high note there and dropped way off when the entrees came out. My fried chicken (it seemed that every woman at neighboring tables ordered the fried chicken as well) looked way tastier than it actually was. There must have been some cumin or curry powder in the batter because I could have sworn it tasted like samosas. There was also something off about the flavor of the short ribs, however it was nice and  falling off the bone tender. The mac 'n cheese was more like a creamy pasta salad, and I would've preferred more melted cheese. I really wanted to like the rest of my meal, but I couldn't seem to stomach it.   The meal did manage to end on a high note, with the manager bringing over 4 chocolate covered strawberries for us to enjoy. We passed on dessert, which sounded good (chocolate beignets and banana cream pie - yum!), but my appetite was lost by then. The place's saving grace was the great ambiance and service. I'll definitely be back another time to skit-scat in the restaurant's swanky bar area.

IRGb3l6aKQJ47NGK3zi7Lg.review_text: 1300 Fillmore is awesome. This is a "class act' that's been missing from Western Addition for a while, and I'm glad they're there. You know you're witnessing something different from the large, wooden door to the sleek bar and waiting area. This restaurant is always clean and service is always positive and not condescending, which I love. (Some restaurants assume that African Americans are unsophisticated customers and that we don't understand quality.)  This restaurant's bar selection is incredibly diverse and they understand premium spirits. (Anyone who understands the difference between Hendrick's Gin and Bombay Gin is alright with me.)  I'm really not into neo-soul food because it's usually hit-or-miss, but the majority of the items I ordered were passable. I hate catfish and I don't order fried chicken at a restaurant; however, the beef shortribs that I got were pretty tasty --though a bit overpriced. (And, no, I wouldn't pay the same price at other restaurants either.)  Absolutely hated their collard greens which I ordered as a side, but my understanding is that they may have switched those up. Mashed potatoes were incredible and their vegetables (other than greens) and desserts are outstanding.  It can be a bit of scene --like most places in the city nowadays-- but the staff is friendly, helpful and knowledgeable.   Be sure to order a cocktail before your meal!  Parking sucks, but if you live in the city, just take a cab or hop on MUNI (22-Fillmore).

SeEg7Jr5lHM7MdKlyY1L0Q.review_text: I showed up for an 8:30pm reservation. The restaurant didn't seat us until 9pm. After 10 minutes of waiting at the table for someone to come by, we got up and left frustrated.

D0lEKtLwNJC_LH2q4pe-1w.review_text: Unique upscale soul restaurant.  Very downtown luxe atmosphere with fun people watching.  The pork belly appetizer and mac n cheese were to die for!  Moody lounge area is perfect for cocktails, IF you can find a place to sit!

RT8Y7PxPzC7DuAjAquNjng.review_text: What do you get when you have a Jamaican with a British upbringing and trained as a French Chef?  Oh and may I add a Jazzophile as well?  The answer is the chef/owner of 1300 Fillmore a burgeoning restaurant in the revitalizing jazz scene in the Fillmore deep-end.  Nestled alongside Yoshi's and the Jazz Heritage Museum (all on the same block) this new restaurant is a must visit for a night with someone special or when that blue note starts playing in your head.  The colossal doors reminiscent  of a 'grand staff', welcomes  you into an equally expansive dining area.  To the left is the bar area where leather seats and couches provide an intimate lounging area to listen to and appreciate the hall of fame jazz greats.  The Martinis from the bar were well made (just as I would have it but it could have been a bit colder ;-)  and potentially can be  a great place for happy hours- hmmm a DYL perhaps?  I love the interior, its modern yet comfy, sleek yet sexy- its an atmosphere that resonates an ambiance of 'blues' complete with a hearty fulfilling meal.    To start off- a complimentary honey corn biscuits with honey butter and jalapeno berry jam arrived courtesy of our vivacious waiter.  His enthusiasm and knowledge of the menu roused our anticipation even further.  Having read through the entire menu- it became clear that one cannot go wrong with any of the choices- it was the first time the 'moving inner voice' of the angel and the devilette sitting on my shoulders finally decided to agree on something...who knew!!! (Thank goodness for updates -so wait for that)!!!  In the meantime here were the dishes we tried that satisfied  the anticipation.  The Sauteed Assorted Mushrooms were composed of chantrelles, beach and trumpet mixture seasoned with fresh herbs and butter.  The hominy grits with mascarpone cheese was not overwhelming creamy- it was  'perfect harmony'.  The Bourbon Braised Pork Belly arrived on a bed of whole white beans and its puree.  It was tender and flavorful;  its simple garnish with 'sprigs' of pork rind was not only crunchy goodness but D-E-L-C-I-O-U-S-L-Y  'legit'!   One of the main courses we selected was the Maple Syrup Slow Braised Beef Short Ribs- mouth watering bbq smell (hickory) and the dark color of sweet caramelized juices.  Its accompanying mashed potatoes was thickened in to a velvety smoothness that veloute' (fr)would be an appropriate description.   My quest to find the best fried chicken was not disappointed by the Southern Exposed Black Skillet Fried Organic Chicken. I think that this process of frying the chicken one side at a time  in a half  oil filled skillet ensured that the chicken was cooked JUST done- the result is the golden yellow pieces of medal worthy succulent fried chicken! The light spicy and earthy flavor from the herbs were just 'groovy' ! The rendition of mashed potatoes with truffle and pan grayvay was decadently pleasing- no 'vamp' needed here!  Here's the breakdown: FRIED CHICKEN- Crunchy gold coating 1-Taste/Flavor- 9/10  2-Tenderness/Succulence 9/10 3-Crunchy factor 9/10 4-Overall appeal 9/10  I'd give their fried chicken 9/10 and sits on the throne of my BEST FRIED CHICKEN LIST.  Antiqus Syrah 2004- lush ripe cherries and plums, just like a 'whole tone' in its sweet finish and balanced tannins that went well with the chicken and pork.  I passed on dessert but  will be back to delve into those treats.  PS- Like a young wine this restaurant will improve over time- Like they say in the jazz world- ' let' em stay in the woodshed' to grow in experience through practice.  I can't wait for the live music venues to start and will definitely be back for this occasion.

GOBpLdkPcitt-PHDD-XSVw.review_text: I was really disappointed. I ordered the beef medium rare and it came so well-done I had to send it back (I hate doing that!). My two friends had the fried chicken and it was also over-done but they struggled through a piece and left the rest.   My booking was at 845. We arrived at 815 and asked if we could be seated earlier if possible. At 920pm, we still weren't seated and it was only as we started walking out that they rushed to find us a table. I'm surprised it was so busy with such awful food, but perhaps they don't cater to the late tables very well.   I was also looking forward to the jazz band but alas, there was a function on so there was no jazz - not even a recording.   I definitely won't be visiting again and am a little embarrassed to choose this restaurant as my friends weren't impressed.

kSrW-fDsCvSRzBBzegu9mw.review_text: As a Washington, DC area resident and frequent business traveler, I couldn't believe that 1300 Fillmore would be as great as I was told it would be.  I was SO WRONG!! This restaurant is a phenonmenal blend of class, jazz, San Fran history/culture coupled with the best gourmet southern cuisine I've ever eaten.     I started with shrimp and grits as an appetizer and I knew, I had hit the jackpot. The grits were "melt in your mouth" good and the shrimp were done perfectly. My friend ordered the fried green tomatoes and honestly, she stopped talking after the first bite!  Based on our appetizer experience, our table decided to order several entrees so we could taste multiple entrees.  Great decision! We had the fried chicken (I'm still stunned that the chicken breast was fork tender AND well seasonsed), iron skillet salmon and shrimp hushpuppies. Every single entree we ordered was fabulous!!  Even though we all felt we were too full to take another bite, the dessert menu lured us into another "group" order.  The pineapple bread pudding was hands down the piece d'resistance. Honorable mention goes to the peach cobbler and banana cream pie but in my opinion, the bread pudding is the winner!!   Seriously. If you come to the Bay area and don't visit 1300 Fillmore - you've made a huge mistake

pTuIHjknlZMEEONn8ptrhQ.review_text: I am very pleased to say I had my 40th Birthday party here. I had looked for some time for the right place The atmosphere at 1300 was perfect. The food is terrific!  I was introduced to the place by a friend and then went back again for dinner and cocktails with a couple of my girlfriends. One Sunday I went with my cousin to sit in the lounge and listen to the jazz trio and have cocktails and appetizers. Each time was a great experience.   I initially worked with Monetta , one of the owners, in putting together my dinner party. She was very helpful. One of my main concerns was being able to feed all my friends.....I ain't P.Diddy. (from what I hear P.Diddy ain't  got it like P.Diddy these days...) Anyway, I digress....Monetta suggested sit down dinner for family and a cocktail & appetizers hour afterward for the larger group. That plan worked out perfectly.   We had a sit down dinner in the main restaurant area. They have a special section for parties that can accommodate about 20-22 people at the table . The area is especially nice because you can choose your level of privacy depending on whether you leave the glass doors open or closed. For complete privacy you can close the curtains as well.   I found the special events staff easy to work with.   They have a list of items to choose from for your menu choices. I asked for something not on the list because mac n'cheese is my favorite and because I'm a diva like that...though, again, not P.Diddy...Not only did they accommodate my request I was also pleasantly surprised to see that they printed out a special menu for my birthday party and put on it that the mac n'cheese was my favorite! Too cute! The choices for my special menu were very well prepared. Everyone enjoyed their meal. Also, the dinner and the cocktail service was terrific.  We had the appetizers and cocktails in the lounge area. My friends had such a good time we stayed well after closing.   Besides all these wonderful things I think what impressed me the most was that the chef and owner came out to say hello to my family. For me, this kind of personal touch made the evening .  My party was in August but I am still hearing from everyone what a great time it was. A few have already went back for dinner and/or cocktails. I took this long to write a review because I am usually very critical. I wanted to be sure that my initial impression was correct and would the memory fade to a just "ok" experience. Needless to say, I am still very pleased with 1300. I'm thinking of turning 40 again next year just to do it all over again! ;)

dGYROfGS9GSWK8ldoodvfg.review_text: Wow, what a great place.  The female owner and her staff were super-nice to me and my family and paid special attention to my 9-month old kid, who is now a big fan of their corn bread.  The service was attentive but not obsequious, and the food was delicious.  I had the fish with asparagus, my husband had the veggie patties, and both were very tasty and flavorful.  The green beans were served with carmelized onions and were hands down our party's favorite item, although the chocolate beignets were delicious, too.  The only complaint from our group was that the hot chocolate one of the kids ordered was "not chocolate-y enough," but the beignets more than made up for that oversight.  Hefty portions of good food and a diverse crowd of diners make this a new favorite for us.

8WZV0Q4bkbA57gkkYW-EJw.review_text: Went here with some friends last night, and it was all around fantastic.   A couple of us got there early so we had some cocktails in the very cool lounge. Pics on the wall of old time Fillmore, nice pours, and generous olives in the martini made it a pleasurable experience. Had a few items on the bar menu to tide us over:  lamb sliders, hushpuppies. They were good, but I'd save room for the main courses if you had to choose, as they were phenomenal.  Tried a friend's fried chicken and ordered the short ribs myself. Both were delicious and very generously proportioned. Well worth the 7-8  adjectives used in the title. All the sides were also top notch.  The place itself is pretty swanky without being stuffy. Classy. I even wore a sweater.  So very happy for the Fillmore to have such great destinations coming up everywhere, I'd recommend this place to any and all comers.

ZB08RRQsPnShM-uAw9gs9Q.review_text: This place is pretty darn cool, soul food, dim lighting, and a live band; how can you not enjoy your experience here. Though, I will admit it was a tad noisy if you wanna have a decent conversation with your dinner dates. Started off our meal with oysters which were incredibly fresh, next came the oh so talked about fried chicken and I would say it was mediocre.... I think I hyped it up a bit too much because of the yelp reviews. Overall it was a delicious dish but not the best thing I have ever had. And we ended our meal with some tasty beignets, the coffee cream thing they give you with it is absolutely HEAVEN, especially for a coffee lover.  Our waiter was pretty attentive, front desk service could be better especially when we were seated after a large party that came after us. And we were an hour early for our reservation !

aWNagRU9zTbK7OIZm26nmQ.review_text: Went for drinks before a show at the Fillmore. Drinks were amazing. It reminds me of some of the nicest  lounges in Manhattan. With that said, it is very overpriced especially with the SF mandate and gratuity suggestion. I assumed it was expensive so that is not why i rated it 3....it is because all the imagery in the restaurant are of black jazz stars . I felt it was exploiting black American culture to sell high-priced drinks to rich white people. Just didn't feel balanced or conscious, in my opinion.

y3Gb0zhTZQO1SMS8xluoxA.review_text: found a few seats at the bar tonight, found good food, great service, gorgeous decor.  go check out.

DYdk9FsL3ebJ7JOsGIbfzQ.review_text: After another failed attempt at being a 'walk-in' at 'State Bird Provisions', and being too lazy to wait. (Some day I WILL eat there! ARGH!), we saw this near parking and decided to check it out.  I didn't have any time to Yelp this place before hand.  I'm such a risk taker!  After eating here, it is safe to say that on the 'Roulette of Dining', the ball landed in black (I always bet black)  I was quite interested to see that this was a 'higher quality' take on southern classics.  This style of food has been quite popular in the Dallas dining scene recently, but I haven't seen it so much in the Bay area, but then again, SF has so many more options, I just haven't been looking that hard.  It wasn't quite as good as the stuff I've had in Dallas, but I understand the circumstances for choosing this restaurant would be completely different than if I was in Dallas, after all, Southern food ain't exactly native to San Francisco (or maybe it is, I never took San Francisco history in school).  The service was nice, and as par the course for this style of food, it is priced higher than southern comfort food normally is, but it is priced around normal for the San Francisco 'nicer dining' scene.  'Tis good for those who want southern foods in the comforts of a nice atmosphere with good booze.  If you just want southern food, there are cheaper and better options.  The long bench seating was really fluffy and comfortable.  Fluffy!  Food: -Corn Bread & Fixin's:  Good corn bread and good stuff to go with it.  Honey Butter |Delicious|  Sweet Chili Sauce  |Delicious|  Getting a second plate & cups of stuff |Delicious|.  -Oysters: Have you had raw oysters before?  These prolly taste similar.    -Sea & Swine: Pork Belly, Scallops, Braised Cabbage.  One of those simple dishes composed of multiple elements that I am a great fan of.  I loved it by default, but I wouldn't really say any aspect of it made it some sorta spectacular experience.  I would, however, order it every time I'm here.  How can you go wrong with pork belly?  -Ribeye: High quality beef.  Meat itself had good beefy flavor, good tenderness, and despite being a ribeye, all the served weight was in meat, no fat caps.  Oddly, the ribeye was 'double cut' for a super thick steak, reminiscent of a filet mignon, instead of going wide like most ribeyes.  Unfortunately, the initial steak was overcooked, so it another steak had to be cooked for us.  -Smoked Baby Back Ribs with Jalapeño Cole Slaw:  'Twas a special, but I believe it is almost always available.  How tricky.  As a special, we didn't know the price and had no expectations for the portion.  Apparently, it comes with a full rack of baby backs (for me, apparently that is 13.5 ribs[one of 'em was tiny]).  Unexpectedly staring down so many ribs was quite the surprise.  This isn't a barbecue joint, so you gotta keep your expectations in check.  Served dry with the sauces on the side.  A very minimal smokiness to 'em, no bark.  However, tender and not overcooked to 'falling off the bone' mush.  Quite satisfactory, especially for a non-'que joint.  The tomato based sauce was too sweet.  The mustard based sauce was almost straight yellow mustard, not reminiscent of any South Carolina Mustard Sauces I am familiar with.  The Cole Slaw was nice enough.  Ultimately, food overdose for me!  Be prepared for lots of food if you get this.  -Truffle Mac N' Cheese: Fancy restaurant making Mac N' Cheese?  Using Truffle oil?  Using multiple types of cheeses?  How unimaginative.  (Yes, I still ordered it!  I'm such a hypocrite!)   Once I was past my lamenting, it was still an interesting take on Mac N' Cheese.  Not much truffle oil because of : Bleu Cheese!  Bleu Cheese overpowered the other flavors for my tasting abilities.  Not a bad thing in my mind.  I don't normally think of bleu cheese being melty, so having a gooey cheesy mess tasting of delightful bleu cheese(mmmm, Glutamate, Take that Parmesan!)  -Braised Green with Ham Hock:  This was a very traditional dish.  Greasy Greens with Ham Hock.  No attempts to fancify.  Why mess with a classic huh?  Anyways.  This is how I convinced myself my meal was healthy.  Any thoughts to the contrary will be denied by me, it is green!  Green is healthy!  -Bourbon Pecan Pie: Classic southern dessert!  Pecan Pie with Vanilla Ice Cream.  Not much to say.  -Apple Crumble:  Like an 'Apple Pot Pie'.  Apple crumble on bottom, pastry crust covering, vanilla Ice Cream on Top.  Desserts here seemed pretty standard.  -Wine List:  A reasonably sized selection, not tiny, but not massive either.  It does cover a good price range from 'reasonable' to 'expensive'.  Good selections on there as well.  Wine enthusiasts I was with were impressed with some choices and pricing.  ----[Shrimp Crusted Catfish]: I did not actually try this, but it sounds neat!  Shrimp Crust! SHRIMP! CRUST! ___________  Conclusion:  Southern Food without leaving the comforts of San Francisco, 'fine dining service' and quality booze.

_0yop1xzuts13d6BL9hmIg.review_text: Unenthusiastic to write this review, but I have to put my two cents in..  Chose this place to celebrate my brother's birthday.  Reasonable prices in a somewhat upscale atmosphere, so I thought why not?  Plus, all the yelp reviews were decent.  Ambiance/atmosphere:  slightly old fashioned, warm colors, no white tablecloths, and STUFFY.  Food:  mediocre.  Rib-eye steak lacked flavor.  My supposed medium-rare steak was mildly pink in the middle and was tough.  Short-ribs were tender and flavorful.  When I asked my friend how her fried chicken was, she responded with, "It's ok."  Mac n cheese had no real truffle flavor- there was only a very subtle hint.  Spiced fat fries were basically fat (large) fries that were underwhelming. Honestly, I would prefer red robin's bottomless steak fries!  The side of greens was tasty, though. Overall, I'd recommend the short ribs and greens.  Their complimentary corn bread was delicious too.  Service:  very, very underwhelming.  I asked the waiter if the restaurant did anything special for birthdays.  You know, maybe a small dessert, candle on a cake- just something to make the dinner a little nicer since it's a special occasion.  He replied with, "I can do a little chicken dance for you!" and thus he proceeded to do his chicken dance... Not exactly what I was looking for.  Well, we didn't get any candle on a small piece of dessert, but we did get a 5 second chicken dance.  I guess that will do.  I was sad at that part because even a cheap sushi restaurant would give a small scoop of ice cream.  Even if it's not an award winning dessert, it's a nice gesture to show appreciation to your patrons for choosing your restaurant to celebrate a special occasion.  Oh, and he didn't even wish my brother a happy birthday...   I will have to choose another place to celebrate next time!

ZbO96qTvvfSmFTkvkUBjkQ.review_text: Before I started this review, I did a rhetorical analysis of my past reviews, and I discovered that I started too many of them with "OK"--kinda like I am a cheerleader and the captain of the squad: "Ready, OK." SO this one I wanted to start with:  My Grandma Sadie use to cook cornbread in a cast iron skillet and serve it just about anything: black eyed peas, fried potatoes, and collard greens. I miss my Grandma Sadie, and when I sat down to dine at 1300, she was right there with me.  My GF and I ordered BBQ shrimp with creamy grits and the foie gras to start with which were both fantastic. For our entrees we had the fried chicken and the tenderloin steak--both were amazing, but I believe my tenderloin and grits were a bit tastier, but then again, I had my Grandma Sadie next to me cheering me on.  Another HUGE plus for 1330 was the diversity of patrons; I looked around the dining room and saw San Francisco--not all white, not all black, not all Asian, not all male or female, but the city, and I truly enjoyed that. We are just getting started with their menu,and we will definitely be back.  One last thing--BEST MEAL ON FILLMORE!

h0FPJR1jCDpwq0C4t8ArLA.review_text: I have mixed feelings about 1300 Fillmore. Overall our dinner was excellent, but there were a points that felt like a total miss.  1. The ribeye is tiny : High quality cut of beef no doubt, but a tiny portion more similar to a filet mignon than ribeye. Wouldn't even be an issue if they printed how many ounces the steak is on the menu, but since they don't - it's a bit of a disappointment.   2. Communal dishes are pretty small : The Bourbon-Hickory Smoked Duck Sausage & Duck Egg was incredible, but hardly a dish large enough to be shared.   3. Fried Chicken was So-So : I've had much better, and I've had much worse. I found the dish to be a bit try. But the chive herb biscuits were to die for.  4. Pan Roasted Brussels Sprouts & White Truffle Macaroni N' Cheese were amazing. Crispy and creamy respectively.   5. Let me bury my face in the Apple Cobbler : flakey, just enough sweet and practically perfect with vanilla ice cream.

v58aGL3xcKISGlGiUDxxtg.review_text: Went there for dinner. Service was good. Food was OK. Drinks were YUM! I had the pear flower drink which was very good.

YOftTGGf3y5-g-NmefNSLw.review_text: Unimpressed would be an understatement. DAT failure - we went on a Friday and apparently, Friday they don't do DAT. It would have been nice to have known this before booking, or better yet, not have been able to book it if they weren't participating! Anyway, the service was mediocre, the food was bland and overly fried / greasy and they brought us the wrong appetizer. Having lived in the South for a good portion of my life I can say that 1300's southern cooking is below average at best. All in all, not a success. The only thing this place has going for it is the atmosphere, high ceilings, cool art, funky furniture, etc.

f7sNeZpRDOXmbwUXM5GH_g.review_text: Came for the Gospel Brunch.  It was a solid experience.  I give it four stars for the entertainment, service and decor.  The food was good too, but not amazing.  I had the shrimp Po' Boy.  Well cooked, but I just couldn't finish it.  Something about it didn't have me craving the next bite.  The band was excellent.  The lead singer came around and had members of the audience sing along.  Everyone was awful, except for the lady sitting across from me.  She killed it.

rnfIwhDsaBkCySGBfRgaPA.review_text: Maybe I'd rate it a 4 but I went here a month or so ago with a slowly-assembling party of 11, then 12, then (I think) 14, and they handled us all with enormous grace through a long, crowded and raucous meal. They get another point just for that. Or maybe the extra point is for the shrimp and grits, which I'm still licking my lips over, or the wine list that gave us a great Lake County Tempranillo I made sure was near my plate until it was all gone. Some items were better than others, but between us all we had nearly everything on the menu, and every one of us looked up in serious pleasure after the first bite of something. We were happy enough when we came, but we left even happier.

F4X9y6m09efUduEDCRyakw.review_text: Unfortunately, I think this place is overrated. We went for a birthday of 6 around 8 and the food was just okay along with the service. I've had better.

Q_fw38tyjJO8RWsi4kx_6Q.review_text: This place is AMAZING! I threw my birthday party  there over the weekend and let me just say, I was not disappointed! The event coordinator totally hooked me up with a private area without charging me an arm and a leg. The ambiance was fantastic, the food was delicious and the drinks were reasonable. You could feel the glamour without the stuffiness. Our server was attentive even though he was working out in the main dining area as well. I coudl go on and on. I would recommend this place for an event or as a swanky date spot. Well done, 1300 on Filmore. Well done!

gpC3j_mSeAUNlO2zqro0nw.review_text: The ambiance and lighting is beautiful and very inviting.  The service however was horrible.  We were a party of 5 and were immediately seated at our reserved table.  I ordered a cocktail while the rest of our group decided to have wine.  My screwdriver took 30 minutes to receive when the bar was within view and not busy at all.  We reminded our waiter after 15 minutes and he seemed annoyed and said it was on the way.  20 minutes later and actually walked to the bar to pick it up.  Bizarre!  The beet salad is a waste of money so don't order it.   I ordered the salmon which was overcooked.  I asked for extra veggies as a substitution for the potato hash and they said no problem.  My plate arrived with no potato hash and 6 green beans underneath the salmon.  Needless to say, I went home and had a snack.  The ribs special was definitely the way to go.  This place has potential, but the portions are much too small and if we didn't have the 30% off coupon, it would have been an expensive disaster.  I would consider giving it another try, but I'd first watch what others ordered to see if it was more than 4 bites of food for the price!

fh5C2dLPt0m6AITsZnkVyA.review_text: Thank goodness for D.A.T or else we would have never gone here.  BUT, upon taking a look at the menu we decided to ditch the DAT Menu and order the regular entrees. The price isn't so bad, its actually affordable for a fine dining place! And the food is great, Ahh, i can't believe i forgot our server's name, my intent was to write a gracious review about him. I think his name may have been George?  George, is it you? Or maybe it started with a B. Whatever, he was amazing! He made great recommendations for the boyfriend and I. Thanks so much for an amazing experience!   What we ordered: APP & DRINKS: - BBQ Shrimp and Creamy Grits ---- The fluffiest grits! - Honey Sweet Iced Tea  ENTREES: 1: Black Skillet Fried Chicken -- Yes, everyone says this is gooood and it is. 2: Black Skillet Roasted Catfish -- THE BEST CATFISH I EVER TASTED, and its NOT deep-fried?!  DESSERT: 1. Warm Chocolate Beignets -- we wanted this with something cold, so our server gave us a scoop of ice cream on the side! Plus you dunk it in chocolate or the coffee sauce, its a piece of heaven.  The food is so great here. Plus, the decor and ambiance are also awesome! I mean, they have the picture frame wall (COOOL) and table lamps hanging upside down as ceiling lamps, pretttyy crafty!)

QnoN3SNip50oBtgjXmfGYQ.review_text: While I'd like to hit up every restaurant participating in Dine About Town, I had to narrow it down to a couple of special places to try. 1300 made the list.   I went with Brynn C. and between the 2 of us we had pretty much everything on the menu.   The grilled pear salad was good, but I would stick with the butternut squash soup with crème fraiche. The catfish is simply delicious- perfectly spiced with equally delish risotto. The fried chicken was moist, crispy and not greasy at all. For dessert we had the trio sorbet and the apple cobbler. The sorbet was light and refreshing after such a big meal. The apple cobbler tasted like something my southern grandma would make- not to be confused with a Paula Dean rendition- this cobbler was sweet and simple.   I'd also recommend the feisty blood orange cocktail- it starts off sweet with a kick of jalapeno at the end.

9jfXiDgGIfw0KkHTyAsg4w.review_text: My fabulous friends took me here for my birthday and it was a good time.  Although we waited an hour for our table to seat 12 people, we enjoyed the cool relaxing lounge space with enormous sofas and nice ambiance.  The appetizers were yummy and filled me up before dinner.  The hushpuppies and fries were great choices.  Their cornbread is to die for.  I found the entrees to be less satisfying but I would definitely go back to hang out and pig out in the lounge.

EVaW-GGDEbYrYhgGUmO0DQ.review_text: Nice place, great service, and the food was good too. Wasn't expecting much. A more upscale soul food place.   Started off with the corn bread. Came with 2 spreads. I couldn't stop eating them, but I didn't want to be too full.  Oysters on the Half Shell Carolina Mignonette-these were super tiny and didn't look that fresh, but they were sweet and yummy.   Sea & Swine Whiskey Smoked Pork Belly, Bay Scallops Braised Cabbage, Mustard Gastrique-Just a piece of each, but the pork belly was so tender. I love the smoky flavor of the pork. The scallops were cooked perfectly and the cabbage was very good. Super small, but this is a must get.  Barbecue Shrimp N' Grits-One of the house specials. Has a good amount of heat to it. Love it.   House Made BBQ Potato Chips, Pickles-super tender and flavorful. The chips were addicting.   Blistered Shishito Peppers Yuzu Lime Juice, Sea Salt-one of my favorite dishes. Was good, but a little more salt would have been better  White Truffle Macaroni N' Cheese Smoked Gouda, White Cheddar, Bleu Cheese-I could really taste the blue cheese, even though the waiter said it was very little. Had to stop eating it.

0flpeV-a7Zx8XaCF0roTDQ.review_text: Went here for Christmas Eve dinner. Our two person table was in a pretty busy location by the kitchen that I didn't like too much. It seems like most of the two person tables are on the side and in busy locations. Service was pretty lackluster; it seemed like we didn't have a specific hostess for our table.  I started with the butternut squash soup and it was very bland, probably the dish I liked the least. I also shared the ham hock and veggies dish and mac and cheese dish: both were excellent. My entree was the ribeye, tasty but maybe a little overdone. Desert was delicious: the beignets and the chocolate pot de créme were perfect.  Overall, a bit too expensive for something a bit too average. I'd go back for brunch but probably not dinner again.

bM5LF6NdmLJnl7gL8rlbXQ.review_text: Came here for drinks and live music. I had three Dark 'N Stormys.   The drinks were perfect and the live music was the best R&B music of the '90's!   Although I did not order food, I had a blast!

956u49_tWXzF54yqCMThOQ.review_text: This guy isn't even from New Orleans, but he can cook up some mean Cajun/Creole.   The shrimp and grits are really delicious. The cornbread with jalapeno jam is delicious. Everything is really delicious. I don't really want to say more lest I spoil it for you.   The only thing I'd stay away from are the fried okra. I normally LOVE fried okra, but these were not fully cooked - actually kind of hard and not really palatable at all.

An-apf27PxeLotGwbkpxXQ.review_text: Love this place.  Had my wife's birthday party there in a private room for 20 friends.  Having been here before and southern cooking is one of our favorite foods, we knew this would be a great evening.  Stuffed mushrooms, truffle mac & cheese, and cheese platter for appetizers.  Maple braised short rib, fried chicken, or salmon for appetizers were all amazing.  The short ribs are our favorites and everyone raved about all the food.  When I mentioned that my wife's favorite dessert is anything with peanut butter and chocolate, the chef offered to create a peanut butter and chocolate mousse cake.  Kyla at 1300 helped put the whole event together and did an amazing job and the service staff were so attentive.  Would definitely recommend it for dinner or private party.

_XFhTYX3wS0ftGc9u4pLqw.review_text: Came here for brunch.  I was immediately impressed by the decor and feel of this place but later underwhelmed by the food and the music. The food was seriously overpriced for how bland and plain the options were! I got the grits with bacon, sausage and eggs and none of it was memorable. My boyfriend got the eggs benedict, which was pretty good, so I would recommend that off the menu.     For a place that is open 11AM to 1PM, and charges a $5 cover for music, why did the band start past 12PM and end before 1PM? Half of that time the main singer spoke about his daughter and how she was graduating or something.. which is all very fine, and we're all proud of her too, but, didn't I come here to hear some live jazz? Why am I almost done with my meal by the time the band is setting up? Oh, and speaking of music, where was the live jazz? The music during brunch was not Jazz- it was more like gospel meets RnB... really not my style.  I wanted to give them props for their cornbread - which was good. But the jalapeno jelly it came with didn't even have a kick to it! :(

BBTFyjdgWSEdzhQFEQx65g.review_text: I am fully aware that a place that serves warm cornbread always ranks high but 1300 really deserves the solid four stars. Really, who doesn't love cornbread? Nazis, that's who.   I ordered the special that night, a full rack of ribs. The ribs were incredibly meaty, moist and tender. I would have liked more smoke in the meat but that is because I love anything slightly burnt. The portion was huge and it came with a crunchy elegant cole slaw. "Elegant" isn't a word I would normally associate with cole slaw but the knife work and light dressing were more sophisticated than you will find in your KFC.   We shared the pistachio creme brulee and found it difficult to taste the "pistachio" part of the dessert. However, the spiced crescent cookies were quite tasty.

CdK_tdDBrHBaEJ__DKkC3Q.review_text: The food.. well its good, its solid, but not outstanding. The main draw for 1300 is its co-location with Yoshi's Jazz club. So I can understand that their primary focus is their bar and their extensive wine list. That said, they do have soul food staples as a nod to the now gentrified and whitewashed Neighborhood that was once primarily inhabited by black folk.   The food is good, but not outstanding. Its upscale peasant food, but without the 'peasant' flavor. The seasonings are either muted, or heavy handed. I got the Pork, and it was so salty that I was begging for water after the first bite. The service, well it was a bit slow, but I'm willing to bet that it was due more to the fact that it was a rainy and early Sunday night, so they had understaffed. Regardless, the kitchen was not with it at all, sending out dishes at different times, so that one of our guests got her dish after everyone else had already finished.   This is the second time I've been there, and although I want to rep and say that this place is great... its just ok. Summing it up, if given a choice between here and Gussies (just catty corner to 1300) I'd probably go to Gussies, just off of of GP if for no other reason that Gussies has the same quality of food, but slightly tastier, and without all the pretense for less money.

E95wh8ssO3IVmQAdQKFYyw.review_text: My husband and I had our wedding reception here and it was FANTASTIC. Guests could not stop raving about the food, drinks, and service.  We had the pleasure of working with Stephanie Parker, who helped us make our event exactly how we wanted it.  The wedding cake, which was made by their in house pastry chef was so delicious that my mouth is watering just thinking about it! Everyone complimented the food and drinks, but the cake was such a surprise because usually wedding cakes are dry BUT this was the best anyone has ever had.  1300 on Fillmore has made our wedding an experience that we will absolutely never forget and I highly recommend this restaurant.

1VhTXtuIV8SDQBfe7JxMiQ.review_text: Amazinggg happy hour!!! 5-7:30 great hours.   1/2 off wells, beers, and house wine. Their specialty cocktails are delicious too.  1/2 off food on their happy hour menu.  Decor is great. Vibe is great. Our bartender could have been a little more attentive, but was generally good.   Definitely coming back.

e9UPHIeBJ54Z4kaaGSW7yQ.review_text: Recommend the shrimp and grits. Easy going atmosphere. Nice to come here before a show at Yoshi's next door. A little pricey for what you're getting

nUoxv7p79EmmZWvW8Vymsg.review_text: Ambiance - 4 stars Service - 5 stars Drinks - 5 stars Food - 2.5 stars  Unfortunately the entrees can be really hit-or-miss.  The appetizers I've had can be up to 5 stars.  We ordered the rib special the other night which lacked flavor and the sauces did not make up for it, and also the hanger steak could have used something.   It's unfortunate that the food doesn't quite hit the mark every time because it's a lovely restaurant.  I would go back for just small plates and drinks.

XuluRjchBe-sphv9-MGV5A.review_text: Pork belly - the food is good - but they closes too early. the bar becomes not too friendly when it is time for them to close (then again, who are?)  i was there after an opera (around 11:30) and went to another place instead after the cold treatment by the bar tender.

7zgArKDGT6W2aYLfU72dBQ.review_text: Could go here 1300 nights in a row. Went w/a few friends, my one friend had even been the night before and still wanted to go. Whether it's the bar menu and sliders, brunch and irish coffee, or dinner and ribs...this place has never disappointed me. Great ambiance and character- love the couches in the louge and the seating in the dining room. Perfect for a romantic night or group dinners. Great servers with an appreciation for the food that extends all the way to the cornbread. I keep meaning to try the chicken but the rest of the menu has been so good and they'll throw a rib special at me and the chicken is forgotten. However, my friends rave about the chicken so someday....

vH4ac_IkrPtVyBP-i0GTBw.review_text: soul food with a twist :)  our group started with a number of appetizers and sides to share:  sweet potato gnocchi with dungeness crab (tasty, and a good combination of flavors), mac n' white cheddar cheese (warm, cheesy, delicious), fried okra (could have used more flavor), and spiced fat fries (bland - where were the spices?).  the warm corn bread with honey butter and jelly was delish!  now onto the entrees - not quite as satisfying.  we tried the black bass, halibut and short ribs.  nicely presented and pretty reasonable serviing sizes but the flavors weren't quite there.  dessert (banana cream pie) did not disappoint, and my martinis were prepared just the way i like them :)  i would come back for brunch or loung dining.  stylish atmosphere and solid service

3qRovLbdNAPbrRwL4I7MNA.review_text: When I think about 1300, I think about this KFC commercial where the village idiot runs around screaming, "I ate the bones" when eats their new chick strips. However, KFC is not what I would call an innovator of food, or chicken.  So when 1300 prides itself on having some of the best chicken, guess how surprised I was to find a half a chicken on my plate, without any bones! Was this chicken born without bones?! In some ways, this makes it a bit convenient to not have to fight with my food, but at the same time, this was like eating a whole plate of white breast meat. The meat gets dry without the bone, and it all just gets less interesting.   Perhaps this is 1300 being innovative and putting a spin on a traditional dish, but I felt this was at the detriment to the plate.  Garlic shrimp and grits and their fries were nice though.  Nice place, nice environment and nice to try, but having had their signature chicken and some of their appetizers, I'm not sure I will be coming back just yet.

rLmjHupXGsDfDsD6ErwOVg.review_text: I came here with my boyfriend a couple weeks ago - it was a GREAT experience!  We drove to the valet ($12 - not bad) and found the restaurant on the corner.  Very swanky and busy and the hostess was extremely nice.  We especially liked the decor and the old school pictures, that gave the restaurant personality amidst a very trendy dining experience.  I ordered the ribeye and my boyfriend ordered the fried chicken.  we also got the shrimp hush puppies appetizer -- it was so good.  My ribeye was excellent.  however the fried chicken is the food to get - I don't think i have ever eaten fried chicken like that before.  the next time I come back here, I am totally getting the fried chicken.  i can't wait to come back again.

qimzFIVdO44dthP-zp_mIQ.review_text: It was one of those nights... when time just seems to... slow down... just..... a little.  Rickie Lee Jones said it best, when she sang, "..if grown ups could laugh this slow..."  Maybe it was the place. Or just the time. Maybe it was the black and white nostalgic photos on the wall, the warm leather-chair atmosphere, or perhaps the inner buzz created by the well-mixed cocktails and hush puppies. I don't know.  Could have been a lot of different things. But, hey, time did slow down. And... there was that almost cinematic feel, the way her head turned and slowly revealed that seductive smile, that silent laugh. The conversations were fun, light. But nothing existed outside that room that evening.   It was cosmopolitan and cool. Scotch and perfume. And it was all in that slightly sensuous... slightly slower... motion. When an awareness of even the smallest moment and the most subtle movements were just... so... elevated. Glancing across short, intimate spaces, our eyes would meet long enough to actually catch that sparkle that (right up until that moment) you thought was only a trick they did on the silver screen.   Hm. Making memories. Mental pictures.   Thinking back on that night, that place... "now you stay inside this foolish grin" ...  how it resonates even still.  If you only knew how much those moments meant to me...

3VGsxY6-3tjnul_bIFgjvA.review_text: been here for brunch before and always liked it. it is a bit pricey for brunch but i always felt worth it.  NOW, be careful on what day you go. they now have a Gospel brunch and feel compelled to charge you $5.00 per person for the pleasure of listening to their music.  so add $5.00 to each plate and not that a bit pricey becomes ridiculous for brunch. end of the world, no but i sure feel cheated when i unexpectedly get tagged with an extra five bucks for something we didnt even ask for.

X2eRW_1OOvgJXyD1vYSaSg.review_text: I graced upon 1300 lastnight for the Fillmore Cocktail Crawl event with 3 of my girlfriends. The event was a success , done in conjunction with 3 other restaurants along Fillmore, highlighting smallBites, free drinks, visits to 4 venues, mingling among the neighborhoods finest and audiophiles to varying jazz music trends.  I had the signature "free" drink of the night here, 1 sip only to taste, but still memorable, 4 stars for originality in presentation with a red little piece of pepper floating around the top.  The atmosphere was great, the jazz band playing was ON. A little Mediterranean or Cuban flavor thrown in, can't quite tell the cultural origin exactly, but a little beyond the traditional blues. Gorgeous to my ears and many others' as well, as the crowd gathered around the band were all women curving to the sound of the smooth hand drums and sexy singing.  Quite intoxicating again and its ambience is second to none. Just wished the crowd was a bit more diverse. :)

XrzkP-EPpql8cis-GlQ57A.review_text: Warm and inviting colors await you at this upscale venue. What a beautiful space!  You'll feel welcome right away and will also appreciate the sheer size of the restaurant.  For once, you won't feel like you're eating dinner with everyone else--elbow to elbow.  Service was topnotch--we even hugged our server, George, after dinner!   As usual--we ordered a lot of food because it was our first time there.  Our friend, Lawana, made reservations for the three of us--she had been many times before and we were psyched to try something new and let her lead the way.   We all shared the following:   Small plates--  Fried Green Tomatoes  Sweet Corn Bisque  BBQ shrimp/grits   Entrees--  Full rack of dry rubbed baby back ribs--special for the night.  Fried chicken  Pork Chop, creamy cheese polenta, wilted greens, and peach compote   Dessert--  Strawberry rhubarb pie  Chocolate beignets   Scotch on the rocks, rye (7 and 7's), and sidecars were our drinks of choice--all mixed well by the warm and friendly Nikki at the bar.   It was all very good. There were no complaints from any of us except for the fact that  we were completely stuffed.  The portions are good sized and we definitely ordered too much food.   Also, we were there to hear a live jazz group that was supposed to perform later that night, but the group unfortunately canceled their appearance.  We'll be back another time--looking forward to it.

mwXSs4maSjySf42SOx-6eA.review_text: Not the easiest place to find, as there is no sign outside. Instead, look for the big pictures of jazz icons on the outside. Street parking is difficult, but there's a couple parking lots nearby.   We were seated right away on a Sunday night and the waitstaff was attentive. My main issue was with the food. It just wasn't worth the price. The fried chicken isn't what I expected, for better or for worse. It tastes like the chicken katsu in japanese curry, so if you're not a fan of cumin, this dish isn't the way to go. The Mac&Cheese was not very flavorful...just...ehh. What i enjoyed most was the CORN BREAD. No need to order an appetizer; they'll keep bringing out the  excellent cornbread.  The place has room to grow because of the jazz bar portion that I haven't experienced. I look forward to trying it though because it did seem worth the hype there.   I DO commend the service b/c we were given a complimentary dessert b/c they were short in the kitchen staff, delaying our entrees. Great service, good experience...but subpar to my palette.

bq3Xewi5Uk9Md1KX83UQHA.review_text: Absolutely fantastic.  When was the last time everything looked amazing on a menu?  That never happens to me except at 1300.  To be fair, I'm a carnivore - so my review is intended for fellow carnivores - seafood, red meat, white meat - all excellently prepared and delivered.    Obviously like every other review on here, I agree - the fried chicken is unparalleled in this city, but there is so much more.  I'm partial to their shrimp and grits appetizer, but honestly - I haven't had a bad thing here and I keep going back - you will too.

229wh2r28DbFsiIPm7cGuA.review_text: Took my BFF to dinner before taking in Jimmy Cobb and the So What Band at Yoshi's.  1300 is a beautiful space and has great food.  I really like the menu and wine list.  Since my crib is on the East Bay side, I only make my way to 1300 when I'm headed to a show at Yoshi's SF.  Nonetheless, here's what I love: 1. the laid back vibe; 2. the food is tasty; 3. the patrons are diverse; 4. the servers are friendly and serve you with a smile. 5. if the server happens to get something incorrect, he/she apologizes and moves forward to accommodate YOU.  They don't catch an attitude; 6. much better than dining at Yoshi's (sorry Yoshi's, being honest); 7. it's a great spot to CHILL!  I.Like.It.  And, will continue to support 1300 on Fillmore.

PWfUci5XRb3lC3WFC-PZ_g.review_text: I've experienced better is an understatement. My sister ordered a dirty martini. It was great. 2nd time around, that same dirty martini tasted SUPER fruity. Dirty shakers = sucky drinks. 4 Re-tries later it still was a fruity-dirty-dirty martini. Our waiter was no where to be seen. It was only after the the manager came to our table and explained how there was an explosive fire, a party of 15, and more than 5 other tables to be fed, we still did not understand why it took over an hour and a half (not exaggerating). The salad on the fixed menu was the best thing besides the wine. But how could one mess up a salad or a glass of wine, exactly. You can't! The fried chicken was basically a waste of a chicken, I've seriously had better fried chicken at fast food take outs.  Don't order the vegetarian acorn squash, it's basically a mix of barley and squash puree, nothing like the description on the menu. There was no music for the first two hours and after that, just sort of came and went as the band kept repeating sound checks. Probably one of the worst meals in San Fran, and such a disappointment. When the chefs were stressed and tickets came in too fast, they couldn't handle it, and the food reflected their inability to stay focused, have a good service from all the staff members, and most importantly make food that is worth the hefty price tags. I wouldn't come back and I wouldn't recommend either. I'll go back to Nopa, at least their food is worth the price and wait. Make reservations because it's impossible to get tables without, especially on the weekends.

4raBwGDmduyu6e0AO8chrg.review_text: Goodness. Gracious. I had no idea this restaurant was tucked just south of Geary. It's in a very busy but unassuming corner and you can see great big lettering for "1300" by the street. I've passed this location countless times and always thought it stood for a condo or a movie thing. Not a gorgeous warm decadent Southern-style restaurant with class!  We arrived early and hung out in the waiting room (which was HUGE with generously sized leather sofas and armchairs and coffee tables everywhere) where we could order drinks and appetizers. Delicious! We had beef spare rib sliders that came with homemade ketchup and not-yet-fully-grounded mustard seeds (delicious!) as well as the wild mushroom grits. I've never had grits before. My mouth dropped at how delicious the grits were! AHHHH! The pomegranate mojito was superb! Minty with real mint leaves and dashes of grapefruit juice to punch up the sweet pomegranate. Oh so good! I was very happily buzzed a third of a way through my mojito.   Later on, we were seated at a real table and the decor in the dining room is just as lush as the waiting room, but in a different way. They had cool vintage-inspired mega-sized lanterns lining the ceiling of the dining room. Wood panels everywhere but glass windows within the room to give it space. All the waiters were just so wonderful. Service is top notch. Waiters and manager and hostess working together for busy crowds. We ordered one prix fix meal and a side because I was just stuffed from the appetizers. Had their butternut squash soup which was cozy and warm to the tongue. There was a dollop of sour cream in the middle which was fun! Then we had the catfish with dirty risotto. FLAVOR COMBUSTION of the best of soul food! I like catfish but many places treat it as if it should be dunked in piping hot spices and fried. Here, they are generous with their spices but they clearly picked certain kinds of spices that would still let the flavor of the catfish shine through. It wasn't too spicy but it had a healthy kick that went away quickly as the fish melts in your mouth. It was a very earthy sort of flavor. So good! And well complemented with the dirty rice which had bits of sausages and veggies in it and was well cooked like risotto should be.  The side of greens with ham and caramelized onions was CRAZY delicious! I think they were collard greens but they had the consistency of spinach (that's how tender they were!) and the flavor was just ripe with the bits of ham they put in there and the caramelized onions lended just enough sweetness to balance the whole dish. It was SO GOOD! Who could imagine a side of green could be so damned good!  I about tossed my napkin in defeat from being so stuffed. But then the apple cobbler came and it was like AGH! The apple cobbler was hoomemade with real cobbler on top of super fresh apples. This is an upscale dessert where they don't pour tons of sugar like other places do. They want the apple to be the star. It is tart though. Nothing their vanilla ice cream can't handle ;-) and it was just the right touch to end a lovely meal! Thank you 1300 On Fillmore! I'm so bringing my friends here for happy hour and good times! Great place for a romantic date!

LnTNztpKiz-7UAZF0aeUrQ.review_text: My husband and I made this the first stop on our date night. The food, ambiance, staff and area were great. We LOVED everything that we ordered. George our waiter was super friendly, well versed on everything on the menu, super attentive and made our experience memorable. Great place to taste and see a piece of beautiful history.

AboDsr79uxgp4XxAJYcwDA.review_text: Date Night: 03.30.13 @ 5:30 pm "Let's get a snack after this."   My guy's statement pretty much sums up our $$ dinner at 1300 on Fillmore. And this time I agreed with him. Just for clarification, the dishes tasted fine and venue was lovely. DECOR/AMBIANCE: yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… The dark chocolate tones, dark leather seats and understated elegant tapestries provided a handsome space. It was contrasted by the more relaxed sexy lounge with black and white photos covering walls on the other bar side of the restaurant. yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… 1300 On Fillmore is big with high ceilings and spacious with well-thought of partitioned dining spaces for groups. The ambiance was elegant, mostly older set (50's, 60s)  but not stuffy. DRINKS/FOOD: JAZZBERRY MARTINI $12 yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… *Sugar-rimmed glass held a tangy drink that to me, tasted like cough syrup. I did not like it. CORN BREAD W/ CHILE DIP AND BUTTER yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… *Provided instead of bread.  The cornbread was fresh, sweet and fluffy but fell apart so badly that I had to use a knife and fork to eat this bread. The chile sauce was sweet and nice. Overall the cornbread was nothing special. DUNGENESS CRAB AVOCADO SALAD $12 yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… *A little mound of very fresh salad with stingy portions of crab flesh over arugula and avocado sauce. Would have been a lovely salad if a little bit more was provided.
