BAKED OYSTERS W/ CAJUN HAM & TABASCO HOLLANDAISE $15 yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… *I was not expecting these oysters to be generously served in cream sauce but I actually like them. Although I could not taste the oysters because the sauce overpowered the meat, I found it very tasty with the flavors of bacon. My guy found it too creamy. PAN ROASTED COLUMBO SPICED DIVERS SCALLOPS $27 yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… *3 very fresh and plump scallops but once again overpowered by the sweetness of the spices. They actually tasted like they were panfried in brown sugar although the description says red wine and star anise. I liked this dish minus the unnecessary extra sweetness. GRILLED RIBEYE STEAK W/ CARAMELIZED ONIONS, YAMS, SWISS CHARD AND FRIED OYSTERS $30 yelp.com/biz_photos/1300… *My guy's dish. He does not remember the fried oysters and reported that overall the steak was good, tender and flavorful. VERDICT: Our meal at 1300 On Fillmore ranks as our most unsatisfying meal in a while.  We do not argue that the ingredients were very fresh and the dishes themselves were well-executed for the most part.  The decor and ambiance were lovely. The servers were efficient and professional. Our biggest complaints have something to do with the portions and price point.  We do not mind paying generously for a nice meal but we also expect to be fed well,  leave the restaurant filled and satisfied even if our wallets are lighter at the end of dinner. ~$9 a piece for scallops? A little mound of ribeye for $30?  A little anthill  of  crab flakes over greens albeit fresh for $12? I get that creativity, culinary genius and love went into each dish and they  did not go unnoticed. But the  bottomline was when we left we had to eat again right after we left 1300 On Fillmore. At the risk of sounding unsavory and cheap, (but it is our pocketbook and appetites we are talking about here, anyway, so no apologies...)  we eat out often enough to know that we did not get our money's worth at this place. And I have been accused of having an appetite of a little bird. My guy's a different story but still..... TOTAL: $125 including tip (And a beer, coke and basket of kettle chips with dips at Sundance Kabuki next door right after dinner before watching "Olympus Has Fallen".) My guy said "It was not for nothing. It was still a nice date night." And it was.

lCmvpQfFpdxhbWVM59eUCg.review_text: The bar/lounge area is much cozier than the main dining area- i recommend nomming on apps and entrees in the lounge area.   There's a really good Happy Hour for their appetizers; 50% off delicious dishes; and the HH timing was very reasonable (doesn't end at 6p or some stupid time like most downtown restaurants. LAME)  The fried chicken was tasty- we shared it between 3 ppl; it was very rich.  We experienced good service- no complaints there

VOJb7-6giwFZTHHvsGQW_w.review_text: Eat, drink, and be merry at the bar! Not only can you order food served in the main dining area but also the bar menu which is not available in the main area. Hence, your sh*t out of luck if you want to order the fried chicken sandwich! I obviously was a fan of their fried chicken entree which was mmm mmm good, not to mention the portions were hefty! We also ordered the okra which was alright. Anyways, yes I would go back for the food and the ambiance! Soul food with a Cali kick!

dmHt5IQkIujJYhRZ2ab__A.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore rates high in my book on service and ambience, but the food, while good, seemed like average fare to me. Well presented, sure, but I wouldn't say this resto has the best fried chicken in the world. Come to think of it, I might just take a bucket of the Colonel's best over the chicken here, but that's what I get when I go into a place with super high expectations (damn you, Yelpers!). The shrimp and grits were great, on par with what The Village Pub in Woodside offers at their Sunday brunch, and the husband really enjoyed his coffee braised short ribs--but nothing special. Our peach cobbler was fantastic, a really delightful way to end the evening, and their coffee is top notch. Overall, I'm more likely to do this again if I get another Blackboard Eats code. ;-)

EzPGqskujPn639ws0QdaTw.review_text: The only good one is the beet salad, the cat fish and apple cobbler are horrible!  Never visit again!

Fgb4jJJ3x5Kw9EJXFmTiNw.review_text: We love having dinner at 1300 -- it's that simple.  The food is wonderful, the ambiance - Sublime.

w9o2BGsg6DuzBHNk_k1tFw.review_text: + Great Date Restaurant - plush seats, 1940s style inside, classy bar - creates a great ambiance for a night out with a small group of friends or a date restaurant + Drinks: loved my Feistry Blood Orange martini Food: I don't think it's very memorable. I liked the chicken and ribs, but it wasn't anything to "ooo" or "aww" over. Chicken liver pate to start with was decent, but the candied bacon tasted like dried out bacon (Sad because I love my pate AND bacon). + Dessert - Loved, loved the cobbler. yum yum, want more of this! The ice cream was so-so, tasted like dryers. Overall: I think the price point is a little high for this restaurant ($110 for two people). However, we booked through savored and got 30% off our bill. ( Link to Savored: svrd.co/q5i3Xa )

XkLK2iBsgqF6mWwDfRgqqQ.review_text: it was a freezing cold night and after another long day, i wasn't sure if i was in the mood for being social but i am making a concerted effort to end my hermit streak so off i went to the city and i'm so glad i did.    the first thing i had was a jazzberry martini.  i have no idea what a jazzberry is but that drink was delicious.  the bar/lounge area was lovely and people were friendly.  the decor of the place fits in perfectly with the jazz district vibe that the area is trying to revitalize.    sometimes i eat weird dinners, meaning no entree and just appetizers or sides.  everybody laughs but i like variety.  that night, i had the poached egg salad, the greens and mac and cheese.  the egg salad was like breakfast with cabbage.  it was so good.  the greens were perfectly cooked and the mac and cheese with the gouda was excellent.  i also tried my friend's fried chicken and it was as fantastic as people have been saying.  the chicken was moist, the breading was perfectly seasoned and the portion was huge.  i'd go back for that chicken alone.  well, and the jazzberry martini.  for dessert, we shared the petit fours, which made my friend proclaim that only in california would they give you 10 pomegranate seeds in a slot of a tic tac toe plate and say that was some sort of dessert.    did you know canadians say kielbasa differently than americans?

kzkAXy9mJS6gMljzC4xGXw.review_text: Wanted to take my gf out to a nice dinner and after a long process of elimination we opted for here.   Although it's not in the best of neighborhoods (I could walk down the street and buy some rock if I wanted to), at least the city is trying to clean up and revive that area.   Upon entering through two huge doors, you emerge into the small lobby area where the host/ess does their thing. The restaurant is dimly lit w/a unique lighting style and lots of black. There's a lounge area and a decent sized bar too. We started w/a few drinks; martini, hurricane, and some cognac sidecars. They pour a pretty decent drink by the way.   After about a 30 minute wait we were finally seated, I would've preferred not to be near the entrance, but oh well. The place was packed so I guess we got lucky only waiting for half an hour. We ordered the Fresh Water Shrimp Hush-puppies to start off with. Before the appetizer came the runner brought out some fresh cornbread w/honey butter and jalapeno jelly. I know knew that we were gonna be stuffed before this meal was done. Bread was soft and delicious, and the jalapeno jelly really balanced the sweetness of the cornbread. The hush-puppies finally came and WOW! I was expecting the typical deep fried hush-puppies in the shape of a ball. These were HUGE tail-on shrimp dipped in batter and then fried. The flavor and texture was almost indescribable!   Then the main dishes finally arrived. I had ordered the Black Skillet Fried Chicken and my gf had the House Brined Grilled Pork Chop. Holy crap that was alot of food! My chicken came w/whipped potatoes and some baked rolls on the side. The chicken while being boneless still had the skin on and was covered in a dark golden brown batter. It was super juicy and loaded with flavor. My gf's pork chop was almost the size of a turkey leg! J/K Anyways, it was one of the best pork-chops I've seen or tasted in my life. The meat was so tender that you didn't need a knife to cut it. Amazing flavors rushed through your mouth upon chewing the succulent meat.   An absolutely great meal. It was so much food though I had to take some home, which isn't a bad thing. Fried chicken for breakfast, yay! 1300 on Fillmore has a new fan in SF.

texqeOsEVLmImPAWxVe0tg.review_text: Well we did it, Gospel Brunch on Sunday, regardless of all the grumpy Yelpers who didn't enjoy it! Well thanks to your cantankerous reviews, it seems they have indeed gotten rid of the $40 prix fix. Thanks, guys!  This was my 2nd visit to 1300 but my first during the daylight hours. The first visit was delightful (sorry, I neglected to write a review probably thanks to their delicious cocktails) and I was anxious to try out this Gospel Brunch after reading the write up in the Chron.  We made a reservation for the 11am seating but it wasn't full so that may not be necessary for you. The booth seats alongside the wall are covered in super soft leather that made me feel like I was in a classy lounge. The decor overall is pretty classy, dressed in dark colors.  I was nervous about the service due to previous reviews but we had George and he was so lovely! Very warm and friendly right off the bat, give that guy a raise!  They brought out complimentary scones and cornbread with delicious pepper jelly. There was both a savory and sweet scone; I definitely preferred the savory scone. With lots of pepper jelly. Did I mention that jelly yet? We also ordered a regular old Mimosa and Boo had a Bloody Mary ($9). The Mary was a little bit on the watery side for me but it was quite spicy. The mimosa was your typical Mimosa except it was $8.  Our mains were the Fried Chicken ($18) which came with 2 more savory scones and whipped mashed potatoes. The chicken was boneless which was surprising and put it into a different category than my usuals. There was one breast piece with 2 smaller dark pieces. The meat was moist and the coating was flavorful. Boo had the 1300 on Fillmore ($14) which was scrambled eggs (a little on the weak side), 2 chicken apple sausage (hot), 2 bacon (alright), bread not toasted (ugh but did come with pear jelly) and the grits. Was entirely TOO stuffed for dessert... glad they don't make you get it anymore.  Can I give the grits its own paragraph?! Holy crap, definitely the star of the show! They were super creamy, great texture, savory and SO SO SO delicious. Order a side for $5 and get a big bowl of it. YUM.  The music! I think I was expecting something a bit more raucous but they were still great. They sang such favorites as What's Going On, Imagine, that Norah Jones song, Lean on Me, and some church-y songs. The female vocalist was WOW and the male vocalist worked the crowd in a fun way. I tried to look freaked out so they wouldn't come over to me, ha ha.  The prices were a little bit steep but being that the food was good, I wasn't as incensed as other people. Maybe if the food had been crappy I'd been a lot angrier because really, $18 for fried chicken is pretty atrocious. However, I acknowledge that I was also paying for the atmosphere and the fact I probably won't be coming very often.  $70 for the two of us for everything above which still puts us $5 under the original prix fix. Next time I'll probably skip the cocktails (although there's something special about having alcohol with your bacon) and I think you can get it down to about $25/person.  Overall, a fun and interesting experience! There is a place in Anaheim that does something similar except they have a choir, can you imagine?! The food was good, the service was great, and company unparalleled :) Try it out if you don't mind splurging for a birthday/special event and it'll be great!

qKgy1I7PcGTh9hd5ujhPNg.review_text: Had a nice evening here with the girls, enjoying cocktails and listening to the nice live jazz.  Being a Southern girl ( I was born in Georgia and went to nursing school in New Orleans ), I wanted to feel a bit nostalgic, hence my choice of drinks - a Sazerac and a mint julep. The Sazerac ranks three on my Bay area list, next to the Razz Room and Absinthe but I thought the mint julep was almost on a par with Churchill Downs!  We had crab cakes in the lounge, prior to dinner - not bad but, also, not the best I've eaten.  We ordered a huge meal and shared everything -  again, some dishes were superb, some didn't appeal to me at all.   I was very disappointed in the bourbon braised pork belly - the sauce was good but I've never had a fattier piece of meat.  The barbecue shrimp in creamy grits  were scrumptious - should have gotten double of  those!  For my entree, I chose the braised short ribs and buttermilk chive mashed potatoes, a definite comfort food - I was soothed all the way down to my hips which I am sure gained another two inches.  I tasted my friend's fried chicken...not quite as good as my grandma used to make.. but pretty close!  We shared macaroni and cheese ( good ), greens ( uhhhhmmmm! ) and fried okra ( I was most disappointed - way too much corn meal breading so I hardly tasted the okra - I'm the rare person who likes okra, slime and all! ).  I would definitely go back to 1300 Fillmore again but it wasn't my favorite spot in San Francisco.  I still miss those great New Orleans restaurants of my youth....talk about fabulous food!

rlDDkE6G-nMO-z0hNqekzA.review_text: I really enjoy interesting takes on Southern cuisine - it's food that's normally so rooted in tradition that it takes some talent to find the essential elements and apply them in a more modernist setting. True enough, the classy and dimly-lit atmosphere of 1300 on Fillmore makes it a great place to grab a drink or chow down on some serious Southern-inspired cooking.  Of course we had to get the fried chicken and the short ribs... and because we were going to wait 20 minutes, might as well try the poached egg and chicken livers dish. And I can't really pass up a chance to get some good pork belly, either. While you can't really argue anything but the chicken livers are straight-up Southern cooking, that doesn't change the fact that both apps were straight-up pretty great.  The short ribs were fork tender, but at the sacrifice of a little bit of juiciness. They were overshadowed by the blue cheese grits atop which they sat, and the sharp, SHARP blue cheese, gave a nice counterpoint to the creamy grits and the sweetness of the ribs. Those are what I'll remember most.  I grabbed a bite of one of my fellow diners' fried chicken. While they were a little ho-hum on the dish, I don't think they realized the technical prowess that goes into deboning an entire piece of chicken, nor the near-impossible combination of skin that was crispy and absolutely in no way greasy. Seasoned rather traditionally, I would order this dish my first time here and then move on to more interesting plates on the menu. Or order it to split with someone else - there's plenty enough for two.  By and large, 1300 can provide some great dishes, though sometimes you'll have to wait for the privilege. In a space like this, having a little extra time to kill isn't necessarily a bad thing.

6OsqYvCScSAcqP9jQcOAlA.review_text: The first time I ate @ 1300 I decided to make it an outting for my 12 and 13 year old.(Children only learn to eat well, if you teach them.) My two are not fast food types and a school lunch send shivers up their spines.  We started on the appetizer page and ordered the shrimp n grits, braised pork bellies, &  sauteed wild mushroom.  ALL were given the thumbs up by the kids, but the pork bellies were the all around winner.  As my son put it, "It just disappears in your mouth!"  As for the rest of the meal(I had porkchops and the kids shared the bass, cuz they were out of the all time favorite fried chicken)  Reaction was still the same, every bite just as scrumptious as the first and the kids cleaned their plates w/out complaint.  We all decided we didnt have room for dessert. Chef David came out to the table and was not to busy to talk with the children to see if they were enjoying themselves.  They explained it was ALL GREAT and they were too full for dessert.  It was almost magical the way not one BUT two desserts promptly hit our table...one being the heavenly beignets and that darn calorie inflating bread pudding.  Did they last?  Of course not.  "We had a little more room left" my daughter commented.  I have been back several times w/out the children and it has been incredible every time.  I will warn you however that the braised greens will not be anything like the sit for hours in a ham hock type.  They are actually quite crisp and sweet, which I personally do not prefer..All in all the dining experience is comfortable and delicious. The jazz on the weekend is also a plus.

LMNXDf-LsqEnwdprxv3OEg.review_text: Four of us were invited here by a dear friend for the Sunday gospel brunch. My first impression was that the restaurant was beautiful with great old photos in the lounge area and a nice dining area. Our server was very good - friendly and attentive. Three of us had the pomosas, a variation of a mimosa, and liked it very much.  Our other friend had a Sapporo beer while I had coffee and ice water. Two of us had the barbeque shrimp with creamy grits while another had scrambled eggs, link sausage, bacon and creamy grits.  Our other friend had a cheeseburger with bacon which came with thin, crispy homemade potato chips. I had the biscuits and gravy with scrambled eggs which was spectacular.  The little biscuits were baked with chive and the sausage gravy was the best I've had in a very long time. The gospel musicians were great.  The one woman had a fantastic voice. I would return again when I have the money or if someone treats me again.

B7TQOD-LHc0bfvyWq7WCqQ.review_text: Beautiful restaurant, great food & service. Live music on certain nights. Would definitely come back.

KzDdqmFfU3hKo3tFnR6uVQ.review_text: Reminder: Happy Hour is Monday - Thursday, although you are the happiest the work week is over on Friday don't show up at 6pm expecting the happy hour deals. It was actually pretty quiet in the place at 6pm.  To start things off I had the Pear Flower - not like anything I have had (not that I have exotic things all the time) but I wanted something that didn't remind me of a G&T or tropical drink of sorts. The Peal Flower is smooth, exotic and tastes like you are sitting in the middle of a Indonesian flower garden, at least that is what I imagined while drinking it, i try to get away from it all when I can.   I had their pulled pork sliders with caramelized onions and blue cheese during the Jazz fest in July which are still my favorite small plate on the menu but this time I had the lamb sliders. Those were nice but not my favorite, I just love cheese.   We also had their shrimp hush puppies. I love hush puppies! These are like prawns with a hush puppy coating - not hush puppies stuffed with shrimp.   Overall delicious, i will come back for dinner when I win the lottery :) probably sooner for dessert!

7DWc5OsN5y7luCLpUcD1ug.review_text: I've been eyeing this restaurant for a while and was actually planning on having the office holiday dinner here but end up not due to office politics. However, they were extremely helpful during the process, answering any question, assisting with menu options and following up. For this reason decided to check them out on my personal time.   The place is well spaced out, not close enough were you can hear your neighbors talk, or far enough you feel you're in the farthest corner of the room.  The restaurant feels intimate and perfect for a first date or a business meeting, as you're able to hear each other without having to yell. The décor is fantastic, if you're a jazz lover and over all American history connoisseurs you'd appreciate some of the pictures hanging on the walls.  The restaurant is divided in two sections:  a lounge and a restaurant; great for grabbing a drink an appetizers or having a full seat down meal.   Service was excellent and didn't skip a beat, not once did we have to flag the waiter. They definitely kept an eye on everyone to make sure drinks were filled and food served.    The food, my God... "Droool!" This is definitely not the healthiest food but I love it. Food was delicious and presentation was excellent. For appetizers we tried the shrimp and grits and shrimp hushpuppies, very rich and lots of butter.  For main entrée I was amazed at how great the catfish tasted, I could have licked the plate. My boyfriend tried the grilled Ribeye and while he says it wasn't the best, I liked it a lot. I suppose the beauty is in the eye of the beholder.   Great food and service. My kind of place!

Fvlszs_a2LZZ75GzlnYEvQ.review_text: We had our department holiday party there last night in the Heritage Lounge.  The room is beautiful and perfect for a smaller group of about 30-40.  Kyla was awesome to work.  In addition, the staff was fantastic, very accommodating and friendly despite many special requests/changes.  Food was great too!

4c2RYnS2mdDSMwyY9xWBaQ.review_text: Smack dab in the ghetto like area of the Fillmore sits a jewel of a fine dining establishment.   I didn't pay for the dinner but it was grand.  Great service, had a steak and shrimp with grits.   Drank a bottle of red - Syrah?  Heard they do a gospel brunch - will definitely need to try it sometimes. What better place to blurt out my Amens and Hallelujahs and dance in the aisles - oh wait, that's the churches next door.

dmFQWTp33HQOvBWNpeZCXQ.review_text: Yummy!  The BBQ shrimp and grits appetizer was the best thing I had there.  The fried chicken, although not my favorite, was delicious.  The dessert- peach cobbler- was uniquely presented with the cobbler in one small dish and some yummy sorbet in another.  The side dishes- the greens and the mac and cheese- were so good!  The server was kinda weird, but adequate. Everyone else was really friendly and the atmosphere was great.  I know many people have written much more interesting reviews of 1300, so the main reason I decided to add my 2 cents was because I read several reviews where people complained about the portion size and the authenticity of the southern food (there are very few complaints overall, but I felt the need to address them).  Specifically, they complained that the size of the BBQ shrimp appetizer was too small- but they were eating it as an entree! Well duh people, appetizers are small, especially in fine dining establishments. If you are going to eat an appetizer as your entire meal, do yourself a favor and order some sides to go with it, and stop complaining.  Secondly, those complaining that the food isn't southern enough, get over it because it's called "north meets south" right on the website. It's a fusion of flavors, not intended to be strictly southern. Enjoy it for what it is rather than being so narrow-minded.  I love this place, the food is great, and I will be back to try the short ribs and the pork chop.

He5pIWsZVyzoIvajJFOvnw.review_text: This place is very nice.  The decor is wonderful.  There are some highlights on the menu but not a total knockout.  The fried chicken is good along with the spare ribs and pork chops.  The green sides (greens, brussel sprots) needs a little work.  As with previous comments the veggies are kinda brown with a little too much pepper flakes in the broth.  The cornbread is great with the butter and jelley, although I wish it would arrive at the table a little hotter.  The service was great, although there was a couple of snaffs.  Our waiter got my order wrong and brought me a port chop, instead or the Artic Char.  The coffee soda was great with the benigets but the glass was chipped along the edges.  A little more attention to detail can take care of these problems. Overall, this restaurant is solid but needs to really refocus and fine tune some of the dishes to make it a all around great place in a newly great area.

ymX_IzyoQZD3E5e9nEShbw.review_text: I came here for my birthday celebration, and it was as good as it gets.  First, I love that it is located in the Jazz District.  They have live music only on Friday nights, but Yoshi's, Sheba Lounge, and Rassella's are just steps away.  The vibe throughout is classy modern with great design features.  I especially love the lounge with all the jazz themed black and white photos, and plenty of couches and comfy chairs for drinking and socializing.    The staff is friendly and attentive without being obnoxious.  It was my birthday and my girlfriend arranged to have a dessert sent out with a candle.  To my great relief they did not start clapping and chanting like some ridiculous chain restaurant.  It was presented simply and beautifully without fanfare.    The food was amazing.  I started with the pork belly, which was seared just perfectly, and whipped yams.  My main course was the ribeye steak.  I ordered it medium well, which came out leaning more towards well done.  I should have ordered it medium.  But the flavor was excellent!    It's tough to beat this place with the great location, excellent cuisine, and top notch service.  Very highly recommended.

zwXuj2aZur5Lc0ypn5ovNw.review_text: We've always enjoyed this restaurant for dinner (delicious food, classy ambiance, excellent cocktails and caring service), but celebrated a birthday at their Gospel Brunch today and LOVED it!  Same excellent food (shrimp and grits, fried chicken, along with some breakfast additions (smoked salmon w/creme fraiche on the world's largest cornmeal pancake) -- worth it for the breakfast basket of baked goods alone ($2 each, and everything's incredible, including the extra chive biscuit we asked them to throw in), not to mention the bottomless Pamosas (Mimosa w/pomegranate). The combo was great, and the leader oozed charm -- got the whole room involved, and his daughter obviously has his DNA -- great pipes. Not classic gospel (just one tune), just very good music. Only problem is that you can't really talk while the music's happening, but that's not the point:  it's a performance, and you can hang out and chat beforehand and afterward. Would do this every Sunday if I could -- it made me happy.

HmqrZgm99Jw1gYQkudeq7g.review_text: A group of us tried 1300 on Fillmore this weekend as a celebration of one person completing her PE (Practice of Engineering) Exam.  Upon entering I noticed the lights were dimmed low enhancing the classy ambiance inside the restaurant.  After ordering we were served the homemade cornbread, a true southern delight.  My friends and I commented on how moist and flavorful the cornbread tasted.  It was the complete opposite of the typical dry, un-flaky cornbread at many BBQ joints.  A couple people also shared the freshwater shrimp hushpuppies as an appetizer.  A large shrimp was covered by a fried crisp, yet moist outer layer.  For the main meal, half of our table had the boneless fried chicken, mashed potatoes and gravy that we had read about on Yelp.  The chicken was very moist, flavored with many seasons, and of course the fried goodness of fat on the outside was delicious!   Another person had the braised beef short rib, friend mini onions, and mashed potatoes, while another choose the catfish.  All meals met or exceeded everyone's expectations.  Finally, we ended the evening by sharing two desserts, the peach cobbler and scoop of vanilla bean ice cream and the warm chocolate beignets with a side of warm milk chocolate to drizzle on top and a shot size coffee soda.    All in all our food was delicious, flavorful, and unique in taste, while the ambiance was perfect for our friend's celebration dinner.

8Z9ugoA4MGwiJVh-CB8bhQ.review_text: 1300 On Fillmore had been bookmarked for some time. So I was pretty excited when I was going through Savored and saw them available the evening and time slot I was looking into. Most of the other restaurants on the site were ones I was not interested in trying or ones I was not interested in returning to.   So we go and ordered the following: -Fried Green Tomato Salad, Warm Panko-Herb Crusted Chevre Goat Cheese, Lavender-Honey Vinaigrette -White Corn & Sweet Pea Risotto, Chefs Mix Mushrooms, Wilted Greens, Tomato Marmalade -The day's porkchop special which accompanied a side of white truffled mac + white cheddar cheese  We started off with the cornbread with sweet butter. Just so-so for me. Their creamy mac and cheese was the best thing we had that night.   Unfortunately, the one that remains in my memory about our dining experience with 1300 is not the meal, the nice-ish modern (but slightly bland) loungey decor or the so-so service but something that happened toward the end of the night. On our way home when we had already driven some distance away from the restaurant I received a call from the host telling me (not even asking if) I took BOTH copies of the receipt and that they needed me to come back and re-sign it. I was caught off guard because I remember with 100% certainty signing the merchant copy and putting it back on the right hand flap of the leather pocket of the bill fold. While on the phone I even checked my purse told them I only had the "customer copy" in my possession and not the "restaurant copy".   Hubs was pissed but we drove back to the restaurant anyway. I should have had them run out to the car to to me with a pen. I'm sure they dropped it somehow when they picked up the bill.   They could have handled it better and I should have refused returning because THEY'RE the one who's misplaced it. They had my credit card info, just run it through. That experience alone puts a bitter taste in my mouth about 1300 Fillmore. Not returning.

4r0-Q5eu4FyGQwYwEcxC3A.review_text: REALLY enjoyed my experience at this restaurant. Service was on the slower side, but I didn't mind. Our waitress was attentive to our needs.   The cornbread is amazing here! So goood.. and then we had the hush puppy shrimp which was also delicious!  I got the ribeye burger, which was good! it is sweet with a bbq sauce flavor. My boyfriend got the short rib- which he said was a bit dry, which was a disappointment, but the chive mashed potatoes were great!  Drinks are really great at this restaurant so make sure to grab a cocktail! It is a smaller restaurant so make sure to make a reservation. Great, romantic ambiance.

GXdWTDTOPKIRwYI1R8tdNQ.review_text: I brought my father to the Gospel and Grits brunch on Sunday as an early father's day present.  It was GREAT!!!  The food was good (rhubard jelly?!) and the service was excellent.  The entertainment was exceptionally uplifting.  I loved the song selections and how the lead male singer got the crowd involved.  I highly recommend their Sunday brunch

ENWTPgCXRqEfSQJ634cY6A.review_text: Let's get one thing out of the way first: I love cheap food.  That being said, I can safely say that I very much enjoyed my dining experience at 1300 on Fillmore. Fancy places such as this aren't my favorite places to go to--I'll take quantity over quality any day of the week--but I decided to take the dive and indulge.   My girlfriend and I went on a lovely Wednesday evening, avoiding the crowd completely. Once seated, she took one look at the menu and immediately asked me if we should leave. Sure, the prices may be high, but we're ADULTS. We can do whatever we want. (We stayed)  I ordered the short-rib and fat fries, while my girlfriend ordered the fried chicken and greens. Also had the BBQ shrimp and grits for an appetizer. Whoa boy. I must say, those were some pretty good grits. Nice and creamy (obviously), but also had some hidden surprises (roasted garlic, for one). Would recommend it to anyone going there whose throat doesn't close up when they put a shrimp in their mouth.   Oh, right. The Cornbread. Two pieces came wrapped in a cozy-looking napkin, served with the jalapeno jelly and honey butter. Unlike most cornbread I've tasted, these weren't overloaded with sugar. Just nice and cornbread-y. That's all you really need.   Dishes finally came and I pick up my knife and fork to cut my short-rib. Two seconds later, I put the knife back down. With meat this tender, who NEEDS one? Delicious, it was. The fat fries were a tad plain, but the house-made ketchup was awesome. My girlfriend didn't seem to like the fried chicken all that much, but I thought it was great. Crispy, perfectly moist and seasoned; you don't really need more gravy to enjoy it (really now, Chie...)  By the end of the night, we were stuffed, and I realized I would be spending the most I have ever spent for a single dinner in my entire life. It was well worth it, though. I would rate this 5-stars if I had the money to ever come back here, so 4 will have to do. But if you're in the mood for some high-class soul food, I can't think of any better place.

426IAYOuscDp4KzKa1_mcg.review_text: I love the ambiance of the place. Its modern and chic and sexy with jazz and ecclectic style. I went here for my girlfriends birthday, she wanted some good ol' soul food- so this was it! The service was A-ok but it was a bonus seating across from former Mayor Willie Brown, =). The menu was altogether appetizing, from the salads with the cornbread touch, to the main entrees with the salmon and yams, and I especially enjoyed the dessert- the beignets was sooo good and light. Altogether, the experience was delightful and I would recommend this spot to anyone who wants to wine and dine anyone for a good time!

qzhHL_ne46WCO2g3BQo6Ug.review_text: My wife and I went to 1300 on a recommendation from my preaching friend who is the minister at the Uptown Church of Christ (about 3 blocks away).  He said 1300 would be our kind of restaurant, so we took his word for it.  When we walked in, we were very impressed by the decor and the ambience.    The service was exceptional.  Although this was our server's 2nd day on the job, she was very pleasant, helpful, friendly with our 3-year-old, and gave her recommendations only on dishes she had actually tried.  Everyone was professional and I had not had the impression that they were impersonal in any way.  For appetizers, my wife had the Corn Bisque that she dove into and thoroughly enjoyed with the touch of sour cream.  I had the Pork Belly (the server said it was highly rated on Food Network) with fried duck egg and braised butter beans...not enough belly for me, but relatively tasty.  I actually wish I had my wife's entree, the catfish over andouille sausage and shrimp jambalaya.  They served a very generous fillet of catfish, and she said it was seasoned very well.  (I did taste it on the leftover side the next day, and I know that dish was made for me!)  I had the maple short rib, which for a meat-and-potatoes type was not enough meat for me; however, the flavor was not disappointing.  We ordered greens and macaroni & cheese as sides: the greens were not cooked through all the way, but we took them home and the wife hooked them up properly; the highlight of my meal was the macaroni & cheese, which I had to take home to really enjoy (I think I tasted some gouda in there)!  We did dessert, which consisted of a bourbon pecan pie (not great, but not bad) and the strawberry-rhubarb cobbler (which my wife finished easily).  We did take home the chocolate chip cookies.  Honestly, they didn't come close to satisfying my sweet tooth like the Safeway-brand "break 'n' bake" cookies; but if you put them in front of me, I would still eat them.  Overall, my wife and I will be back for sure to try something else on the menu so I can get a better handle on their cuisine.

a3D4H3wlmecIGutD4njt8A.review_text: An interesting twist on southern food. The decor is typical loungey and upscale and although the food is the type that is low budget cozy food. 1300 takes classic soul food and puts a beautiful touch to it. The menu has great descriptions of what otherwise might be consider common food.  The BBQ shrimp and grits was fantastic and flavorful yet not heavy. The cornbread was out of this world! My entree was fried chicken and mashed potatoes but although it sounds boring it was very delicious and the chef takes pride in crafting quite a visually appealing ...fried chicken and mashed potatoes ha ha.  the wait staff was great and the crowd and decor was right up my alley. Price wise it is upscale so expect that but well worth it.

Ko860oOVvuFLwLOazYheiw.review_text: Great food, management, service! The manager chris was very courteous and accommodating, the bartenders Patrick and Ricky poured delicious drinks, well knowledgeable of the wonderful wines and top shelf liquids they carried, and the food was delicious!! The mushroom & grits was to die for. I love how they serve a cornbread with a mild dipping sauce and honey infused butter!! Well decorated, great atmosphere and ambiance! Pimosas!!!

7nw20r7LdTqakjdRjUhJtQ.review_text: Went here for a birthday dinner.  Was not impressed with the cornbread "bread"...I thought it was pretty random; however, the food was pretty good. The fried chicken is what I went there for, and it was pretty delish; however, a bit overpriced at $23 (just like the rest of the menu).  If you are looking for somewhere quiet, this is definitely not the place!

Ml9EY3cA-8np9D9h5v9sqA.review_text: Five stars all the way. I'm still dreaming about last night's dinner. A sophisticated, comfortable restaurant with fantastic service and to die for yummy yummy yummy Southern inspired fare. Full menu offered in the lounge as well as late night dining until 1am.  I'll write more after I've recovered from my culinary hangover. Promise.

TMb-OIybIJ3_8j7QEk1PAA.review_text: We were out of town guests who made reservations for Valentines Day several weeks in advance.   Never once during our reservation or confirmation period were we told that there was going to be a pre-fixed menu of $65 per person (no other options).   Upon arriving for our 930pm reservation, we were told that they were running late and to enjoy a drink at the bar in the meantime. The place was packed and it felt impossible to even access the bar; but when we finally did, we had the rudest bar tender ever.   Finally at 10:10pm we were seated to be surprised by this "mandatory" menu.   Appetizer: shrimp and grits. A dish that the waiter told us was FAMOUS. A dish that put them "on the map". The grits were so bland... Accompanied by 5 small shrimp and an ABUNDANCE of cracked black pepper. That's all you tasted. For the record, this menu item on its own is $15 and very overpriced for what you're getting .  Entree: fried chicken. Also told it was famous so you can imagine my excitement when it came to the table. First off, either the plate was so hot or the food sat for so long that the sauce rimmed around the plate was dried onto the plate itself. The chicken, boneless, was not crispy and very dry. As though they anticipated it being their no. 1 seller so they fried it all earlier and then kept it in a warmer. The accompanying mash and biscuits were edible... Nothing special.   Side: truffle mac n cheese. If you're a fan of Mac n Cheese, don't get it here. Pasta was over cooked, cheese sauce was very runny and the "truffle" part of it is oil. Truffle oil, which is a chemical made to taste like truffles. There's nothing real about it... This stuff is made at the same perfume factory as Chanel No. 5.   Dessert was a tasting plate for two. It wasn't anything special.   We had a $200+ bill and left extremely disappointed.   This place is great only for its ambiance, not food. The live band and tiny lounge in the front is a great place to start your night... Just don't eat there.

RFJcFZO0ZOHLVR4hQla_vQ.review_text: Had a chance to try this place out yesterday and wasn't blown away. The bartender and mixed drinks are horrible. But, enjoyed signature appetizers and entrees. The shrimp and grits is quite tasty. Planning to go back and try more food but will stick to the wine list.

IJABCqLsGgT8DxqujUQmiA.review_text: So - I have highs and lows with 1300 on Fillmore lately, but it basically averages out to a four star review (maybe more like 3.5). Service has always been super and the ambiance if wonderful - I am coveting the rose lamps on the walls (shhh) and love the lounge area. The soups are almost always impressive, but some of the main dishes miss the mark. The beef short ribs are consistently delicious (as in "would I look like a glutton if I ordered seconds??") but the fried chicken and hushpuppy shrimp are "meh". The chef is also relying on bacon far too much -  a little goes a long way but the warm poached egg salad had bacon dressing, ham in the salad and a slice of bacon over the top of the salad. The whole salad tasted like crunchy bacon grease, fried in bacon grease, topped with bacon. Horrible.   The side dishes are also hit and miss: the greens (veggie version, skip the extra extra extra bacon please) were super, but the mac and cheese was bland.   Happy Hour here is fantastic - lamb sliders, fat fries and beef short rib sandwiches are at happy hour prices, plus $3 glasses of sparkling.

2oD-vur-aVCsOVdW0iUevw.review_text: Is this what being in love feels like? Great low lighting leading to a lovely relaxed vibe, dark woods, friendly service, good music, cool old black & white photos and a cozy and comfy-looking lounge by the bar. I'm diggin' it!   Fried chicken (maybe they should brine it because it could have been a bit more moist), collard greens, blue cheese grits (OMG - yum!), jalapeño jelly on cornbread, Mac n' cheese (weakest food we tried), and brussel sprouts with bacon. Don't pass up the blue cheese grits, even if you're not generally a grits kinda gal, like me, cuz you'll be missing out!   I'll be back soon to just chill in the bar before dinner reservations. Just loved the vibe!  They're on Open Table.

m2ilZTKmICMMvE2p-HffOQ.review_text: The ambience and the vibe was perfect!  The lounge was warm, welcoming and full of engaging photos from yesteryear.   All of the food was tasty - our husbands ordered the fried chicken and it was juicy and the mashed potatoes were good, too.  My girl and I ordered the catfish, which was tasty, but not as good.  The accompanying Jambalaya was tasty, but not as seasoned and textured as I expected.  I did not like the sweet potatoes nor the greens, and would not recommend either.  The macaroni 'n cheese was tasty, but a little too watery. We also ordered the shrimp 'n grits. While the grits were not as creamy or as seasoned as I like them, the shrimp was truly delicious.  It was on the pricier side, but for a wonderful upscale dinner, it was worth it!

y-OPLQtDHI6lGX5PdoMyBA.review_text: First off, the service and space are great!   BUT I wouldn't go back...food's just not worth it.  I base this on their brunch, btw.  Until I had their lamb burger ("as the chef recommends it, please", in response to "how would you like it cooked?"), I had thought that "bone dry" was a term used only for white wine.

o6nfLjlmvxFOEgQ29YtQSg.review_text: Went here before seeing Josh Ritter at the Fillmore.  Enjoyed it.  Shrimp and grits to open, then catfish for the entree.  Service, ambiance and food were all very good and a lot of fun.  Jazz band playing at the bar.   Our waiter George was great.

SnCon7iAJSDm1lTo4weswA.review_text: Nicely decorated, not what I had expected but I was pleased.   A: Bellinis were yum :)  I think it's bottomless so drink up people  B - : Catfish po boy - it lacked flavor, sauce was a bit bland, could be the catfish as well  B+: Fried Chicken - fried almost to perfection, a little too battered but I enjoyed the juiciness of it  Did I skip dessert? Hmmmm can't recall. They have live music there on Sunday, very loud and high energy.  They charge a $6 entertainment fee so be advise.  I had a great time here, wouldn't mind going here with my gfs, holy hell, I can only imagine our behavior.  Anyways, I do recommend :)

gNzC6OJIdRlSkEQIZuP8QQ.review_text: tl;dr: solid contemporary southern food in an upscale environment  finally came here after three+ years in the neighborhood and loved the twists and  shared some shrimp and grits (not your traditional grits and packed with plenty of flavor beyond salt and butter), shrimp hush puppies (really great twist and fried just right); their famous fried chicken, and shrimp encrusted cat fish over jambalaya.  topped off with great service, it's a classic southern staple in this part of town if you're in the mood for some soulful eats in a relaxed atmosphere.

5lHDAZt627dfOUm71uaa6Q.review_text: sadly unimpressive...  1300 has been my list to try for the past 3 years and thought it'd be a perfect opportunity to treat some friends out to.    When I arrived, the door appeared to be locked..so I naturally walked around looking for another entrance.  Failing, I returned to the same door to find the host standing there with it propped open because he sees it happen to everyone.  Turns out, the door had a major design flaw being that it was just massively heavy, keeping all the new customers from entering.  I know this happens to EVERYONE because i watched it from the lounge while waiting for the rest of my party to arrive.  Bet you can record it and put the footage on one of those "what would you do?" type of shows for some laughs.  Moving on to the food, among the 4 of us, we ordered: The Cornbread was accompanied by an amazing honey butter and jalapeno jam!  (but this was literally the highlight...it all went downhill after) Appetizers: Shrimp & Grits, and Hush Puppies (both uneventful).   Entrees: Braised Short Ribs (a bit dry), Catfish Jambalaya (waiter recommended...eh), Baby Back Ribs Special (best out of all the dishes).   Sides: Truffle Mac & Cheese (not bad), Fat Fries (nothing special)  Perhaps my expectations were set too high...but i was extremely unimpressed with the food.  We steered away from the fried chicken since so many other reviewers rated it poorly...and because I still have the orgasmic aftertaste from Ad Hoc's fried chicken back from a year ago.    On the flip side, the service was great and the ambiance had a classic elegance about it.  Not sure if I'll be venturing back anytime soon though...

LpQCSePebwRdSV7sEuHWIw.review_text: Um, hi, I am another fan of this place!  I just tried the Gospel Sunday brunch yesterday, and let me tell you, "Oh Happy Day!!!"  Here were my thought process and the brunch events from yesterday:  1) ambiance, nice - check 2) looked around, most people dressed up - i'm in my workout clothes (I was going to House of Air immediately after brunch)... hm... felt a bit strange, but everyone was just cool about it - didn't even notice I was in workout clothes after sitting down. 3) hugs all around the table with all the friends (there were eventually 15 of us at brunch) 4) sat down, saw menu, "WTF?  $5 gospel charge?" 5) waiter asked us what we'd like to drink.  he pointed out bottomless pomosa - ok, that sort of off set the $5 gospel charge 6) biscuits and corn bread arrived at our table.  these were delish. 7) table filled, waiter started taking orders.  ordered the eggs benedict - cajun style  8) gospel singing started - WOW.   9) food served while singing was still going on.  really, can you eat with such music?  it was... heavenly? 10) eggs benedict - SO FRIGGIN GOOD.   11) restaurant patrons singing into the microphone - some decent, some awesome 12) OH HAPPY DAY! 13) Cupcake - my friend and her kids baked a giant cupcake that resembled a smurf house.  Waiter saw that and said the Michelin rated pastry chef could not resist but to cut the cake.  Gigantic cupcake went to the back. 14) Cupcakes served. 15) Executive Chef David Lawrence came out and talked with us about this cupcake and a potential job for his pastry chef in the future.   16) Bill came - was so happy with my experience here. Happily paid my portion of the bill, including the $5 gospel charge.   I've got to also mention what great staff work here.  Everyone from the hostess, wait staff (he loved the babies that were at brunch with us), the chef, the gospel leaders.  Yeah - five stars, baby!

AU0ifrgyuY2E1ukRqq2GVw.review_text: This area has really grown up!!! I remember not to long ago when this area was kind of dark an dreary.  There were a couple of underground spots that were nearby but no wow factor.  I admit it has been quite a few years since I frequented this location. I don't know what David Copperfield type magician has been hovering around this locale lately but WOW.  I almost didn't even recognize this location when I arrived.    I got to 1300 and was pleasantly surprised with the event I was attending.  The front area was a bit cramped on space but I was still able to mamuever around without much difficulty.  The ambience was quite nice but I would have liked a bit more lighting.  The noise level was a bit more than I would have liked but it was ok.  For the size crowd that was there, I thought the service was ok.  Probably could have used two servers vs one.  The alcohol menu was decent and they had a few specials.  I decided to keep it light for the night and had a Riesling that was quite delicious.   During my rounds, I did get to meet the owner and she was delightful and pleasant.  Sometimes owners are more interested in how much you are spending before they actually interact with you.  I had a decent conversation about the venue and how much the area changed.  I was having such a good time that the by the time I was ready to eat, the owner let us know the kitchen was closed.  OH MON DIEU!!!!    Soooo you know that means I will be coming back to explore the menu and check this place out once more.  I'll have to try to get there a bit earlier as well just to see if it's as loud as the later time.  Stay tuned!!!

8ft2t3GouU6mzWyeoWqTMg.review_text: I love me some Soul food!    Fried chicken, Cajun catfish, truffle mac and cheese and of course beignets!  All of it was soooo good.    The space was much larger than it looks like from the ouside and the Jazz being played really set the tone for a terrific experience.  I would definitely recommend 1300 on Filmore and will be going back the first chance i get.

RwzUPegzBioX_edNMqXlNg.review_text: My husband and I dropped in for dinner and while they couldn't get us a table (7pm) we were promptly seated in the lounge at a cozy table for two in the corner.  The staff were very attentive.  Having recently been in the Charleston and Savannah area where we had some outright great Southern style food,  we were anxious to try 1300 Fillmore to see if they could come close to that experience.  We had the Shrimp Hush Puppies, Shrimp and Grits, brussel sprouts and short ribs........yummo!!!   Oh, and did I mention the banana cream pie???  Loved the ambiance too!  We'll be back!!

0y6CzsBYUUVApBRbXpGrYQ.review_text: Our waiter is wonderful...service is pretty damn good! Food is amazing so far...only gripe is they brought my soup ..which was tasty but I'm guessing if they would have brought me a spoon with my soup and i could have enjoyed it while it was hot it would have been better!  cornbread is awesome!  fried chicken AMAZING....I can't say enough good things about our waiter.   I didn't b*tch about the soup but i'm sure if I had they would have comped it.

vdZaeSDbsWd_JeNqt92NmA.review_text: I'll give it 4 1/2 stars!  Service was excellent.  We had a party of 5 and our server didn't skip a beat!  Food was delicious and drinks were strong :) We had an order of the fried chicken and catfish at our table, all were delicious!  Dessert was scrumptious too.  Beignets and Apple cobbler.  I also love the decor!  I will come back, I want to try the Gospel brunch  =)  Try it if you haven't.

gSYxTvS3wDauhL4DZWIBEw.review_text: Soul food with little soul.  I really wanted to like this place because the menu looked so good.  I will say that the service was so friendly and the decor was quite nice.  All that said, the food fell so far short of its potential that i can only muster up 2 stars.  The best thing to eat was sadly the cornbread they bring out at the beginning of the meal.  All down hill from there.  Everything I tried was underseasoned.  Soul food is supposed to be rich and flavorful comfort food.  We had braised pork, short ribs, fried chicken, mac and cheese, fries all of the good stuff that is supposed to make you feel guilty (but in a good way).  Everything was bland.  The short ribs and the pork were both extremely dry.  My sense is that they needed to use more fatty meat to hold the moisture and flavor.  The fried chikcen was crispy and juicy, but the flavor was flat--even the dark meat.    A little salt would have gone a long way in helping this food along, but I should never have to say that at a soul food place.    If you are in the neighborhood and would like the grab a drink, the bar area is really cool.  Great vibe and if you get cornbread (with the jalepeno jelly) then you would be having the best thing they serve.    Otherwise I would say pass.

9KGaNA-0Ncg7QPdk30exPQ.review_text: This past Wednesday, my girlfriend and I stopped by for dinner  to use a 30% off discount from Blackboard eats. The experience was awkward and our waiter seemed discontent to be serving a table using a discount code.  We both enjoyed our food, but multiple times during our dinner, the waiter came up to our table to tell us that we did not qualify for the 30% discount. I had to show our waiter the fine print on the discount to prove that we did indeed meet the requirements. Eventually the waiter conceded.  Following dinner, we both agreed that the food was good but not necessarily worth it at full price since the atmosphere/experience was sub-par. We headed home with our leftovers and the following night we were shocked with what we found. Instead of the fried chicken, biscuits and mac n cheese we expected, we had a nasty looking white liquid in the bottom of a take out box. Could this have possibly been another table's leftovers? Could 1300 be so upset by our 30% discount that they decided to take 30% of our food back and give us bacon grease? We probably will never know nor will we venture back to 1300...

IzGMll4gEkw0_x54v1PjzA.review_text: Food was very good.  Service was horrible!    I ordered the catfish, and dinner companions ordered baby back ribs and fried chicken.  All were great.  The portions were substantial and each meal tasted wonderful.  Appetizers were great and the cornbread was super yummy.  But the wait and bus staff were terrible.  Waiter showed up late to the table and it went downhill from there.  Tried not once, not twice, but three annoying times to upsell our wine selection to a $75 bottle.  Give me a break, maybe once ... but three times?  Totally abandoned us during the meal, like nowhere to be found.  Had to eventually stand up and wave at the busboy to get more water.  And then to cap it off the leftovers for take-away never arrived.  We left a paltry tip and walked out.  Go for the food, it is great.  Hope you don't get our waiter, he was just terrible.

jCLG0K5ygx1n4r4jSWGkuQ.review_text: FRIED CHICKEN!!!  I ordered foie gras dish, which was ok. Maple syrup slow braised beef short ribs was good, but little too much fat vs meat in the ribs. I don't like the texture of the fat.  Fried chicken was amazing, but if you think about it, it is $23 fried chicken. It better be good.   Food is consistent and services are good. The chocolate dessert was great! But not sure I would go back.

inK3yLgErKgCPtacqSCi7A.review_text: I love 1300. It has been my bday staple for some time. The bf knows that all he has to do to make me happy is to take me to 1300. Im vegetarian and the BF is not but i love the provisions for me. Tasty and filling. He is happy too! lol Im picky but this place makes me happy..The ambiance is also lovely. I just love this place. It is def one of my faves!

d-5gWThyELEJZdFKUx5Pzg.review_text: Yeah, it's pretty cliché to say I really wanted to like this place, but I really did. They started off on a bad foot with our server not greeting us for a good ten minutes. The appetizers were pretty much the highlight of the meal. The Fried Green Tomato Salad was a good start, and I thought the Sweet Corn Bisque was a good sign of things to come. The House Brined Grilled Pork Chop was juicy and succlent like a brined meat should be, but sadly it was exceedingly salty. The Fulton Valley Farms Organic Black Skillet Fried Chicken also fell below my expectations. Yes, I was damn sad about it because I was giddy like a school girl for some soulful fried chicken. I'd have to say the skin was crisp and flavorful with the meat juicy and tender, but it was ruined by the strong hint of cumin. The Banana Cream Pie dessert was also a let down. The bananas were only half ripe, and that spelled a flat end to an otherwise pleasant meal with good company. The chicken pretty much sealed the deal for a two star rating. I usually eat everything on my plate especially if it's good. It's a bad sign when I don't finish half of my entree and I don't even want to box of the leftovers. I am a garbage can. And if I don't eat it, it's a bad sign...  Oh hell, I forgot about the Macaroni 'n White Cheddar Cheese. Yeah, it was pretty forgettable. The macaroni was cooked well, but the cheese had no bite. Actually there wasn't much cheese sauce, and the sauce that was present was overpowered by the overly herbed bread crumbs. This mac 'n cheese lands near the bottom of my "list."

Z16ZwkNK2I5mj_lm0YKNsA.review_text: If I can be real for 1 minute.  It was SO AWESOME to see such a successful, hip black community at 1300 on Fillmore.  This city really has a lot of White and Asian people all over the place and it was so cool to see the diversity of families, friends, and mixture of people here tonight.  Definitely felt like Chicago, Detroit, Atlanta or NYC when I walked in.  It's like a true melting pot of cultures all there for their love of Jazz.  Major props to the Jazz District for that crazy cool vibe.  AH!  Can't get enough of it :)  Speaking of the Jazz... Not only was the food great, but the live jazz band truly made it enjoyable (although we couldn't hear it from our table, it was fun waiting and listening to the live band in the beginning.)  You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu, although nothing stuck out to me as mind-blowingly good.  The scallops on my surf 'n turf were really great, though.. and so was the surprise chicken liver in my friend's rissoto.  Fried Okra was good... Chicken was good. Bingets were good... :)  It's a solid spin on soul food and I'll be back soon!  (next time I won't spend so much $, though.  $65!!  I should have stuck to the DAT menu...  :P)

AFZcaN_0i7n0ibXYYo6BeQ.review_text: It was around 3pm and we felt like going out to eat so we were surprised that we were able to make a reservation for 6:30pm on the same day, last Saturday.  We showed up early but the hosts were very nice and showed us to our table.  It's a really nice restaurant with a great atmosphere but the best part of the restaurant was our waiter, George.  Very professional, helpful and attentive.    We ordered the skillet fried chicken and the special, half a rack of ribs w/cole slaw and mac n cheese.  The chicken was excellent, crispy and juicy with loads of flavor.  However, the ribs did not deliver.  It was really dry and felt like it was way over cooked.  The outside of the ribs were pretty warm but the inside was room temperature so I'm thinking they tried reheating the ribs backup and that made them so dry.  I also felt like the cole slaw was a little bland but the mac n cheese was pretty tasty.  We ended the meal with a pineapple bread pudding and that was a great finish.   Other than the ribs, we really enjoyed the restaurant and will definitely be going back!  Thanks George for taking good care of us.

cWoTq95aJuNKT26cZnxbAA.review_text: I am so happy and proud to have this relatively new restaurant in my neighborhood. It is one of the finer new establishments to bring the Fillmore district back to life in a positive sense. I have come here for brunch, dinner dates, a company Christmas party, for the drinks at the bar and for apps and drinks in the lounge area. I love decor: the historical jazz pictures with the light behind them on the walls, the unique decorative hanging lamps and the dark wood everywhere. I really like the way this place sections off to make it more intimate whether for private parties or if it's not that busy and they close off certain sections. Oh, the music is jazzy of course. Romantic, classic, soulful, happy and fun. The staff are cheery, helpful and knowledgeable. Ok, the best for last...the food is AMAZING! I have gotten the pork main (YUM!), the shrimp and grits app (YUM!) and the butternut squash soup (YUM again!). I've gotten a lot more than that but that's what comes to mind..haven't had anything bad or even mediocre there basically. This a really classy without being pretentious place and I highly recommend you go there NOW!

hSU4P5OqzJjsxqp5ylCaEg.review_text: Food was not so tasty, maybe it was what we ordered.

0e5nUa15QzfRw8ct3oYOog.review_text: Disappointed with the food. Fried chicken cooked just right but lacking in flavor. Fried green tomatoes hard and overcooked. Cornbread bland.

i_M7MmEJuKfwavwqduX5LQ.review_text: Nice restaurant with Jazz lounge adjacent in gentrified neighborhood. Had an excellent meal with two colleagues.  My beef short ribs werewas excellent. Colleagues had - pork ribs the order being so large it reminded me of the old Fred Flintstone cartoon with the gigantic brontosaurus sized ribs and my colleague had the king salmon. Everyone had strong positives about this place.   All of us eyed the fried chicken making comments we would have loved to try that as well.  Overall highly recommend - great experience.

RMJqH-MxMfhTpbOlYZQiMw.review_text: Food: Yummy; I recommend the salmon dish and the eggs benedict. Food arrived VERY fast Music/entertainment: delightful; an appropriate amount of Whitney Houston tributes were sung and the whole lot was very talented Service: left much to be desired; they were only interested in getting out order, not at all in our bottomless pomosas being refilled. And seemed irritated when we used manners such as a simple "please or thank you".  Hostess: needs to be replaced, or learn how to make eye contact and smile  Go for the food and the music, if you must.

pu00LUtfo9D3CJd_-8NeyA.review_text: Delicious! I went for a special dinner (i.e. cost no option, i.e. I wasn't paying) and it was fabulous.  Mushrooms and grits appetizer was so freaking good- we scraped the plate clean.  They had a watermelon carpaccio special with seared scallops and that too was great.  I don't even eat seafood and I found it tasty.  The short ribs I had fell off the bone and again, was as delicious as everything else.  Get the banana cream pie for dessert!  Only flaw-- mac and cheese.  I have had much better (Bluejay is the best).

_xQu2ynqZIOBsh3xU1zFgQ.review_text: Loved the atmosphere, the service was on point and the band was killing it. Enjoyed the Sunday spirit....and spirits (if you know what I'm saying.)  Had the shrimp and grits, loved. 4 stars because the butter had me bent over in a knot for the rest of the afternoon but overall great food, great times and great music.

ZR0iN7nbtl9BES1vK6dwtQ.review_text: Headed out for soul food before seeing OK Go at San Francisco's own temple to its infantile fixation with the public consumption of cannabis - the Fillmore.  Let's provide some context - we both lived in Charleston, SC, so we feel like we have a pretty solid conceptual understanding of grits.  1300 does the food and service right.  The staff is extremely knowledgeable, the fried chicken is delicious, and the short ribs were melt-in-your mouth good.  Two meh points prevent five stars:  1.  The beignets.  The structural concerns associated with filling a beignet with chocolate apparently leads to a thicker and denser dish that would more properly be considered a doughnut.  The espresso soda, however, was a nice touch.  2.  The cost.  Too pricey for what they're serving.  I get the idea of value capture, but it doesn't mean that I have to like it.

1QzXWTu7PPtCYza4cYNTig.review_text: I love it when you go someplace where you have no pre-conceived expectations, no idea what's on the menu or what other ppl have rated it.    Dinner at 1300 was sort of a spur of the moment thing on Friday night...it was a rough day and I desperately needed a drink, a laugh and some good food.  This place has  a great loungey feel to it - a little unexpected given the menu seems to boast southern comfort food type dishes. We walked in with last minute reservations, so had to wait just a bit, but the bar area is beautiful, with large leather seats setup in little groups.  Great if you want to just grab a few drinks and appetizers! Since this is just a few doors down from Yoshi's I assume that's what lots of people were doing.   When we finally did get seated we were HUNGRY...and we proceeded to order just about every appetizer and side on the menu.    Here's a little breakdown of the food: Cornbread - delicious, think we asked them to refill the basket 3x Shrimp hushpuppies - gold brown spheres of deliciousness Butternut squash soup - had a little tast of this, it was velvety and the portion was huge. Creamy grits - freaking amazing, could have eaten just that and been a happy camper Fried Chicken - omfg, seriously, this is some good freaking chicken. Crispy on the outside, tender juicy on the inside...it's rolled in unexpected spices so beware -  there's a nice healthy dose of paprika and cumin so if you don't like them just beware. Mac and Cheese - disappointment, don't bother with it, completely tasteless. Fries - no idea why we ordered this, it was overkill Begnets - Meh  All in all, while there were a couple of dishes that weren't so hot, it was a really great dinner.  Believe we got out of there for about $180 with tax and tip for all that food - pretty amazing if you ask me.  So much food had to waddle out the door slowly.  Only complaint I had was with the noise level - it was busy and noise is to be expected but the sound seemed to be almost overwhelming at times, we could barely hear each other shit talking over all the other noise.

pJ2lSIr5R2TEjAp9OXPb5g.review_text: So I have to say that it pains me to write this review but I feel that I must.  I'm going to start off by saying that my "relationship" with 1300 Fillmore dates back about 3 years. My partner and I had our first date here on Valentine's Day. Then we celebrated our 1 year anniversary here again and another Valentine's Day. And tonight we went back to join the crowd on the celebration of the 3 year Anniversary of 1300 Fillmore.  Well...I've experienced Bar-mitzvah's that had better soul. We decided to eat in the dining room since the bar was jam-packed due to the anniversary special that the restaurant was holding. No biggie. We'll just sit down and eat. The maitre'd seemed less than enthused to even seat us. Considering the restaurant half was half empty, they could have used the business on a Monday night. I really expected more on their anniversary....even if we were going to be paying full price for dinner and not $3 on the bar side.  Now mind you, our waitress (Iris) was a sweet girl. She was attentive to us...until the point the regulars came in. Now we were fully aware that we were not allowed to have the Anniversary specials unless we were sitting in the bar, but considering we were sitting next to these "regulars" that came in...we overheard her informing them that they could have it instead of sitting in the bar. Fine. That's perfectly fine, except she  didn't even know that even though we didn't come on a weekly basis we had chosen to dine at 1300 for some of the most important occasions in our lives. Doesn't that still make us regulars? We didn't sign-up for the e-list for nothing.  No biggie. Except after the regulars arrived, service completely stopped. I managed to finish my scallops and my partner managed to finish his half order of baby back ribs. No one came by. We waited and waited. Finally I decided to construct a house made of rib bones on top of the dishes that were waiting to be taken away. The maitre'd finally came by and took the dishes away. Then no one came by still.  Finally, my partner said let's just put our credit cards down and see if they get the hint. It wasn't until I saw Iris look through the window from the bar side, that she realized that we were ready to leave. She came to the table and stated that she guessed from the cards that we weren't interested in dessert.  No Iris. We have a perfectly fine Reese's PB cake in the fridge we'll just eat instead.  My partner said that he was disappointed. He said "If I'm going to pay this much for dinner, I'm not coming here again." I think after celebrating these occasions there we kind of felt cheated. But no worries. San Francisco is a foodies paradise. There are many restaurants opening up and some that love to have us *ahem* SAUCE *ahem*.  It's disappointing but I hope they learn that it's the little things like this that can make or break a restaurant. In a city like San Francisco, you have to keep that relationship with your customers in order to keep them coming back.   Sorry 1300, but we won't be back for your 4th and you won't have any of our special occasions.

v5zaGoSF4QOOnJQIKTZ4mg.review_text: oh, the cornbread! A completely unexpectedly delightful dinner

Wccr3a3QlY-MEgP3dTVH7Q.review_text: Sunday brunch: good food, good service, classy casual ambiance, tasty bottomless pomosas and lovely live jazz music.

4x8-emJf6In_Nv7mqlysdg.review_text: I went on a Friday night when they have a live band playing from 8:30 to close.... I loved the band!! I had the pork porterhouse with a side of truffle mac n cheese. Both were delicious. I sat at the bar and the bartender often forgot about me. But she made up for it with doubling my drink and giving me a free dessert. :)

zR01mt_eldV7dQ78rCV0Fg.review_text: This was one of the best meals I have had in San Francisco.  i wen to college in the south, so I know southern cooking and this resaurant has got it right.  They started us off with delicious warm cornbread and two appetizers; the BBQ Shrimp and Grits were amazing.. a little spicy, but otherwise really good and the Shrimp Hushpuppies were phenomenal.  After setting the bar pretty high with the appetizers, we were even more impressed with the main courses we ordered.  The boneless fried chicken with creamy mashed potatoes was delicious.. not greasy like normal fried chicken at all.  We also had the ribeye steak on bleu cheese grits and the short ribs dish.  All three dishes were spectacular.  The service was wonderful and our waitress was very attentive and friendly.  This is definitely my favorite resaurant in the city.

4XYr-Kslo7lOVkwZ0BZftQ.review_text: couldn't imagine a better, more balanced dining experience. the food was to die for (highly recommend the collard greens - particularly for other southerners in the city, short ribs, and fried chicken). thoughtfully designed interior. owner and executive chef david lawrence was extremely welcoming, selected our dishes, and was incredibly gracious. all in all, a much needed addition to our city - i will be back!

IBrL-6twlZmQBGLdV2DQiw.review_text: Give 1300 Fillmore some love!   They are so unappreciated and unknown considering the food is awesome,the space is gorgeous, and there's live jazz.  Just drop in whenever and sit in the sweet comfty lounge area.

7ckiFZbeIWPbwMGIglMV3A.review_text: Based only upon my visit to the lounge area, I am so bummed that I don't live in SF anymore!  What a great place.  We stopped by for an after dinner drink and to check the place out.  We had what is probably the best table in the place with views of the dining room, bar, and lounge.  The owner/chef stopped by to say hello and was very warm and gracious.  The live jazz set a groovy mood and we just people-watched while enjoying our cocktails.  Can't wait to come back to try out all the goodies -  It may just get the coveted 5th star after that.

ReQdzKqmWB00pkQvSnXkBQ.review_text: A big group of us came to 1300 as part of SF Chefs Week. The venue is pretty impressive, the lighting is dimmed, and the attire is dressy. All of the marks of a top-end restaurant.  And like most top-end restaurants, the prices are high and the portions are small. Though we came for the 3-course meal that 1300 had for its Chef Week, all of us ended up ordering our own entrees because the selection they had didn't seem all that appetizing.  Midway through our meal, Kiefer Sutherland walked in covertly. I wasn't sure whether he was there to partake in Chef Week as well, or whether he was there to torture  -- err interrogate someone.  All around, the food was splendid for the most part. My rib-eye steak was cooked just how I like it (red meat please) and trying my friends' fried chicken was a joyous moment.  However, my main grievance of the night was how small the portions were for each entree. While the portions can be expected to be small, I didn't feel satisfied for the money I was throwing down . For being so pricey I would hope for a little bit more food. I can't say I will come back to 1300 anytime in the near future. You could get more bang for your buck at other fancy venues in SF.  3.5 stars for the fried chicken, the company, and Jack Bauer's surprise appearance.

4go2H9Os9mJ8_mfpnnFI0A.review_text: this is for their bar lounge area only.   we came here on my birthday before dinner at state bird provisions for some drinks and light snacking.  The fried chicken is DELICIOUS! Spiced Fat Fries- big thick cut fries, nice and crisp nommy nommy cauliflower- was good (should have gotten it with the bacon) corn bread- mmmm loved it with the honey short rib sliders- were ok, slightly dry  service was good, loved the seating in the bar area. definitely coming back for more fried chicken (we also checked in on yelp and got 50% our specialty cocktail. yay!)

-0jQI-Ru2BAJsGsGcFglPw.review_text: I almost want to give these guys 5 stars for creating a dish with all of my current faves in it. Unfortunately I had spent the day subsisting off of bloody mary's and creme  brulee so my gage was a bit off by the time we arrived for dinner at 7. I'll Definitely have to return to see if they can earn the 5th star. I'm normally not a bullet point reviewer but there's a first time for everything right? Here are the pro's and con. Yes, con.  - Walked in on a Sunday night with out reservations and were seated immediately. Awesome.  -Love Love Love the masculine, inviting interior  - The Jazz band that was playing in the background was entertaining, and not too loud.   - Service was on point. Right down to the busser reminding me to wait for him to return with my doggie bag.  - Pan seared scallops with short ribs, swiss chard and mashed potatoes. Melt in your mouth Delicious  -Yummy corn bread but man it crumbles like no other. Close to impossible to pick up or eat with a fork :(  In short definitely worth a stop in.

7yfwAe066qZDjHedoV2h8w.review_text: I was here for happy hour on a Tuesday and it was packed!  Our server was a total sweetie with enough sass to keep it interesting.  We ordered just about all the food on the happy hour list and loved everything we tried.  Great prices, food, and people, I'm def. coming back next time I'm in the Fillmore.

1f5azxfutLwpxK5dpxC05Q.review_text: Swanky cool place and delicious food.  I've been a few times and usually they have great service, which would be expected with a place this nice. (and $$$)   But, most recently, the service was a bit off (served a glass of wine, instead of the whole bottle that we ordered; messed up my dish, though server had confirmed details when taking order and had to cook all over)  Since I have food allergies (gluten and corn) I am still happy to go to a nice restaurant and be able to order food made so I can eat it!  And I think the decor is fabulous.

O0rghjKRRSFAmuOsAoz6Sg.review_text: Fried chicken, Brussels sprout chips, catfish, and cabbage salad, and farro were all #1 hits!!!!

jeNLNo71VLEdU_5k5K5X-g.review_text: Came here for birthday dinner with my best friends. Made reservations for 7 on a Monday night, and they were able to seat us early. Started off rough, because they gave my friends and I different menus, forgot to give us the cocktail menu, and then told us there was no more pork belly.  Appetizer Chicken Livers and Frisee Salad was cooked nicely and delicious. Fried Chicken with biscuits and potatoes, that was moist and seasoned well. No bones, just chicken breast tenders. Shortrib was fall-off-the-bone tender. Grits were thick, not creamy enough, and too much cheese. Ribeye steak was overcooked and mealy. The bed of vegetable fried stringy things was really tasty. Side order of mac and cheese was terrible. The cheese was not mixed through the macaroni, and the pasta was pre-cooked. Our friend who ordered this ended up feeling very unwell, and had to go outside.  Dark and intimate lighting, most patrons dressed casually.  I would not come here again.

pmKnNkGVgzhMkwJaTU5apA.review_text: Perfection at its finest. Lovin' the JAZZY vibe too!  Came here with the boy for his birthday dinner and so glad I found this place. It's FANCY so dress up. By FANCY I mean dress CLASSY too because this is an upscale restaurant that feels really awkward if you just go casual. The ambiance is great. Right when you walk in to your left is a wall full of really cool frames that have historical photos in them by the bar. To your right is the dining area. The tables are really spacious and it just seems luxurious dining here.   We were seated right away via OpenTable that I had made reservations on. 1300 also provides you with Corn Bread! YUM. Our meal consisted of:   Fried Oysters: YUM! You only get 4 though, but they are big and freshly fried. It is good on its own and doesn't need the sauce that comes with it.   Maple Syrup Braised Boneless Short Rib: DELICIOUS. Wow! Until I can find another restaurant that can do better, this place is my ultimate fave for short ribs. The meat was really tender and juicy. I loved the flavor and texture of it. Not only was it plated elegantly it was full of flavor. It was really sweet and I enjoyed it with the mash potatoes.   Black Skillet Fried Chicken: For $30 this dish was pretty worth it. There were at least 3 big pieces of chicken. The chicken wasn't even greasy even though it was fried and it was very fresh. So fresh, you could taste the meat through each soft bite. The biscuits that came with it was buttery and fresh out the oven.   Warm Chocolate Beignets: Even though we were full, I wanted to try this! SO GOOD! Highly recommended! Chocolate centering the beignet is sweet enough on its own, but tastes so much better when you indulge it with the chocolate sauce and coffee soda. Coffee soda? I know! too good.
