My meal was too amazing. I couldn't get over it after I left. I felt good afterwards! Our server was really nice and friendly. The only negative thing I would have to say would be towards the hostess. I do remember her name, but will not name it on Yelp, but she was RUDE. She gave such attitude and definitely thought she was better than everyone else. She needs to get off that high horse because her attitude is going to drive customers away!

fSvOdnryI9FPJ2ylcsE2ig.review_text: The cornbread - sooo good.  I came today for the gospel brunch for $40. Apparently they have two seatings, one at 11am and the other at 1:00 p.m.  We arrived at 1250 and waited while they cleared the whole dining room. The decor is very old school Fillmore, with pictures of old singers and how Fillmore used to be.   We were seated and they had live singers. It was a tad bit loud, and if you want to have a conversation, I recommend requesting a seat in the back.  First out came the scones and cornbread. So delicious and we asked for second.  You have a choice of entrees and I ordered the fried chicken sandwich, which was really delicious. The chicken skin was yummy and the inside was tender and juicy and off the bone. The bread was also good. I tried the french toast with apples which was also very good.   For the desserts, we ordered one of each, but I liked the lemon meringue the best.   The meal also came with coffee and your choice of drinks, including bellinis and mimosas.

TiPH2ZwSX53uK7IvFSHVYg.review_text: $6 charge per person for brunch music? The fried chicken and burger were decent (and very overpriced once everything was added in), but the music was soo fricking loud (we were the further table from the music) that it was ridiculous. We literally sat there until the end (after they closed for brunch) since we were trying to catch up and no one could hear anything (we were a group of 7) apart from the person next to them screaming.

Pg3Q7516riCrzIXvPgGKQQ.review_text: Went to 1300 on Fillmore for Dine about Town. The atmosphere is simply amazing. This is definitely a really nice looking lounge and it gives off a really relaxing filling.  == Food ==  The choices of dishes are really limited and it wasn't that great for Dine about Town.  The beet salad is the only appetizer to choose. It's tastes like beet. There's a nice sauce they have on the bottom. Kind of zingy, but again, it's just beets.  The cod was pretty awful. Really squishy and chewy. Skip it.  The pork was pretty good. Soft texture and not cooked too dry.  The apple cobbler is alright. It's really sweet. The pie crust part was probably the best thing out of it.  Drinks was pretty good. I had a feisty blood orange drink. It had some kind of red pepper inside of it to make it taste a bit tangy and spicy. It's a nice combo.  == Service ==  Service was really good. Attentive and quick.  == Overall ==  Great place to relax and grab a drink. Chill out. Food is not impressive and not worth it for Dine about Town.

33OzyvMjDhGTUJubr4CWIA.review_text: An opportunity for my group of girlfriends to do Dine About Town which they never got to experience.   Made reservation at 6pm which seem to be a perfect timing. Not too crowded or noisy.  Some of us did DAT but I opted for the normal menu which seem to be more appealing. We ordered:  - Sea & Swine = Whiskey smoked pork belly, bay scallops braised cabbage, mustard gastrique. Pork belly was chewy and tasteless.   - Black Skillet Fried Chicken = Buttermilk whipped potatoes, pan gravy chive herb biscuits. Nicely fried chicken. Huge portion.   - Green Tea Smoked Rainbow Trout = Roasted heirloom potatoes, blue lake beans pistachio brown butter. The potatoes that look like they're from Trader Joe's.   - Barbecue Shrimp N' Grits = I am a grits lover.   - White Truffle Macaroni N' Cheese = Smoked gouda, white cheddar, bleu cheese. Can't go wrong with mac n' cheese!   - Hanger Steak = Fava bean succotash, Point Reyes blue cheese, crispy shallots.   - Pan Roasted Petrale Sole = Braised rapini greens, chive mashed potatoes & caper brown butter. Great portion.   - Apple Cobbler = with vanilla bean ice cream. Decent and nothing you wouldn't expect.    - Warm Chocolate Beignets = with chocolate sauce and coffee soda. My favorite of the night. The coffee soda with piping hot chocolate beignets was divine.   Although the meal did not live up to my expectation, however, the service was outstanding. Attentive staff with likable personality. The place was well decorated with dimmed light. Perfect place for a date.

-Qf4ffBkhYailgZ57ZenOA.review_text: Best Happy Hour Around!  I've lived near this place for a year and a half now and haven't gone until recently.  They have happy hour from 4:30-7:30 M-F, I believe, and it is truly amazing.  Most of their appetizers are half off during happy hour, making them $3-$5 plates which are easily shareable.  They have certain drinks that are $3-$5 as well.  I had champagne for $5/glass and shared the po boy sandwich, sliders, and french fries with my boyfriend.  Altogether I think we paid around $35 including tax and tip for 2 glasses of champagne, three beers, and three apps.  I say that is pretty good!  I've also tried brunch here and loved there blueberry banana pancakes!  Breakfast is a good deal as well.

-TtbBXTW_mCKdZ-mhqubTw.review_text: Great ambiance  Nice wine list Good lounge food Bring a date!

U0V9Vvp4QY7UTcdenVneGQ.review_text: mmm feisty blood orange, shrimp and grits, baby back ribs with mac and cheese (special), and banana cream pie! delish! and live jazz when we went on a friday night!  going back to try the fried chicken soon..

cbehkbJXi_sauQbjco9iaw.review_text: Excellent. We tried quite a few dishes but the favorites included the BBQ shrimp and grits, the french fries, and the brussels spouts/collared greens. I had the fried chicken which was fantastic. I will certainly be bak to try some other dishes.  The atmosphere is very modern yet warm. The service was fantastic and they also have a great drink menu and fun bar. Really fun spot for a special night out.

Lzrc9PLi7ZzX2-Gl8BfT3g.review_text: Shrimp n' grits. Fried green tomatoes. Mac and cheese. Need I say more?? Actually, I will. Their house smoked baby back ribs are mouthwateringly delicious. I always look forward to the warm cornbread served with honey butter and jalapeno jelly. The perfect combination of sweet and savory. The shrimp n' grits has to be my absolute favorite dish on the menu. The perfectly grilled shrimp and creamy grits are covered with the most addicting sauce known to man. We recently ordered the matchstick okra, which are crispy seasoned strips of okra. Not what I was expecting, but it's a must try. Ambiance is great. Service is always spot on. We've been here three times for dinner, and the food continues to leave me longing for more!

OJaBUBe0IwrfId9UNn7yoQ.review_text: What a great concept!  Boy can we get this in Oakland?  California soul food - high quality,  comfort food with a twist. The staff was friendly and savvy, and the fried chicken and barbecue shrimp and grits are outrageous!  Worth the trip to San Francisco.

2SCwWGDNz6wKIXu-DftzrA.review_text: Came here on a whim with my family while having a night out. We were hoping to go to Yoshi's but ended up here, which was great. There was live music and plenty of seating. We had a great waiter and the drinks were great. It had a nice ambiance. Mostly an older crowd, which is a nice change of pace once in a while. Will definitely go back!

Qs42L9LAioeQXUdOpgPYlA.review_text: I truly struggle to find anything wrong with this place.  Outstanding ambience, great cocktails, unbelievable food, and always the best service.  I love the Southern menu with a fine dining experience.  And hey, don't miss the fantastic old Fillmore jazz photos in the lounge!  What a wonderful treat for SF.  Welcome to the city!!!!  Update (July 7, 2012):  I'm very sad to report that 1300 is losing its magic.  We've been back twice recently and have been sorely disappointed each time.  The food and service were terribly off both times.  I just can't figure it out - what changed?  Sigh...  What a bummer - I loved this place.  I'll keep trying, but for now I'm downgrading from 5 to 3.

eKUUCt9gps2ADYhhLSbfNQ.review_text: TGIF and tgfgf (thank god for good food) I came here after work on Friday and I swear I couldn't have start off the weekend any better. Great resturant, great ambiance, great service and of course, great food.  Appetizer - tiger shrimp hush puppies. Not your tradition hush puppies. This one was battered with a shrimp inside like tempura style. Yummy. Grapefood arugula spring salad with lemon citrus vinigarette. Refreshing and loved the fruits in there.  Main dishes - I had the ribs. Super tasty and cooked to perfection. Boyfriend had the baked salmon. The skin was super crispy and I think they seared it then baked it. The other layer was cooked to perfection and the inside was still a little raw. The salmon was amazingly fresh so that's why this worked. My friend had the fried chicken - good and worth ordering.  Side orders - mac and cheese with truffle oil - good but have had better. Corn bread - OH MY GOD so freaking good! It came straight out of the oven the outside was hot and crispy and the inside was soft and flaky. Yum!    Dessert - had the strawberry soufflé type of thing. Good but the strawberry filling was too sweet.  All in all great experience. I love the live band that plays, it heightens the mood and gives the place a even cooler factor ( first cool factor is that it's on Fillmore).

yZb1OGMnBN7aTOK8QweNxA.review_text: I was looking for a place for Sunday dinner after we did the SF wine crawl last July 24 and stumbled upon this restaurant on yelp (thanks, yelp).  Good ol' southern cooking in chilly San Francisco? Sign me up and so I made reservations for 7:00pm.  We arrived 20 minutes early; the restaurant looked pretty empty still and the host immediately seated us with a smile.  I usually order a bottle of wine for occasions like this but I was still a little buzzed from our wine tasting trip.  It was a while before our waitress Nikki came to our table because the table next to us was being DIFFICULT, ugh.  But Nikki kept her composure and was all smiles when she came to us.  She told us about their specials (rack of ribs, yum!) and of course the fried chicken which is why I was here for and after a couple of minutes, I and my companions ordered our entrees.  The other servers brought out some hot from the oven corn bread with butter and a jalapeno jelly spread that was sooo good.  I was tempted to ask for another basket of corn bread but we didnt want to ruin our appetites.  Here's what we had:  Small Plates--  Sweet Corn Bisque, Crème Fraîche, Chive Infused Olive Oil: sweet corn taken to the next level- creamy with just the right amount of sweetness, one of the highlights of this dinner.  Fresh Water Shrimp Hush Puppies, Ancho Chile Rémoulade: crunchy with the remoulade giving it a nice kick, my companions definitely liked this one.  Spiced Fat Fries with homemade ketchup: So good, the ketchup was kinda sweet, reminded me of banana ketchup.  Entrees--  Maple Syrup Braised Boneless Beef Short Rib, Crispy Onion Rings and Fresh Horse-Radish-Chive Mashed Potatoes:  So tender, it just breaks apart when you put a fork to it.    Black Skillet Roasted Catfish, Andouille Sausage, Shrimp Jambalaya, Cornbread Panzanella Salad:  this was not my dish but I had a little bit of the catfish and it was good.  Black Skillet Fried Chicken, Buttermilk Whipped Potatoes, Pan Gravy: Yes its pricey and yes its that good!  It came out piping hot, very juicy as you bite into it.  We all tried to figure out what spices they used hahaha!  I got my mashed potatoes on the side late and they also forgot the gravy.  Oh well, it was still good so I didnt care.  We were so stuffed at the end of dinner we didnt even make it to dessert but there's always a next time.  The restaurant itself is very nice, decked out in warm, brown tones with lots of pictures on the wall depicting jazz musicians (its right next to Yoshi's).  I thought our total bill was reasonable given the quality of the food and the portions were just right.  We found parking at a garage nearby but there is ample street parking when its not so busy.  I would definitely come back even just for the chicken ;)

MMZU89sjUe5XgWECx6-eWg.review_text: I'm a little hesitant to write this review because I was sick the night I ate at 1300 at Fillmore.  But...the review must go on.  The fried chicken, lamb chops and short ribs were battling it out in my head to be the chosen entree.  I knew everyone loved the fried chicken, but I had chicken the night before and just wasn't in the mood.  I ended up going with the lamb chops but wished I'd chosen the short ribs.  There wasn't anything wrong with the lamb, but there was nothing that jumped out at me.  I can't say I was disappointed because all in all, it was a nice evening.  I'll try 1300 at Fillmore again and this time, I'll get the short ribs or the fried chicken.  And, I won't be sick.

Pv4i7H7gk9atcDoO34Jj_w.review_text: Oh the service here is just so professional, so wonderful. And the food is pretty fantastic too, a kind of refined and dressed-up version of soul food. The cocktails seemed to be all pretty sweet, but the wine list has some real winners at reasonable price points. 1300 is a nice celebratory spot, or a date spot if you need some help with the impressing.

0W0TzfO6lnPGHw3iWGOfJw.review_text: Came here last time for the first time and really enjoyed it! The ambience is very cool - a little older of a crowd, which was nice. The decor is awesome...it's almost like you're in a really cool/sexy library - it's sophisticated and classy. The food was delicious  (I had the pork w/gritz - WOW!) and the prices were what I expected. It's really great to have a parking lot as well, even if it was $12 flat fee - i'd rather not hunt for parking in that area anyway! The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because I thought the service was so-so. When you're paying a bit more, you expect a bit more...at least I do.  I'd love to go there for a happy hour at some point and sit in their really cool lounge. It has great pictures of the Fillmore in it's prime back in the day.

kyb9EgY6I7h2_tylFDiFIQ.review_text: This place was pretty bad and on top of that it's expensive.  Expensive, bad food = 1 star.

96SWIePpb2QmY-wrr4A5_A.review_text: Saturday, January 4, 2014.  Its been five years since I last dined here and I am glad I returned.  You know you hit upon a great place when there are so many choices to choose from.  I settled on the grilled rib eye steak which was cooked to perfection [I like it rare!].  The pigeon pea and shisheto pepper stew was an outstanding garnish for the dish.    I was also tempted to have the black skillet fried chicken, which I distinctly remember having the first time I came here to dine.  You could not go wrong with either choice.  The short ribs were the other temptation on the menu.    It just means I have to come back again.    My only minor criticism is that the wine menu, although plentiful with choices, was overpriced.  Not many choices of Cabernet below $50 per bottle.  I will remember to bring my own bottle and pay the corkage the next time around.

V31Un32C9yfWK9xDNvjZrA.review_text: The shrimp and grits are the best!

zMCq1kmujBj_lDDko6g31A.review_text: delicious. try the steak (although the bleu cheese grits are a bit strange).   their drinks are delicious, too! try the jazzberry or the key lime pie.   very swanky atmosphere. youd never guess that the bustling city is right outside.

RFjH5k7pMSxGIEYkDveqyA.review_text: I will definetly come back our waiter was awesome and had a blast. The food was good for the price

hLp1rtFGZ6m7TSSjqe77RQ.review_text: Nice atmosphere.  Lounge is cool with comfy seating.   Communal dishes were rather small. Dont order the sea n swine unless it's just for 2 people. Shrimp n grits was good. Skip the fries.  We were really looking forward to the fried chicken. Sadly, the fried chicken was just ok. Thigh was fine. Breast was dry. Not seasoned enough, IMO. Not spectacular. Although I must say the biscuits that came with were really good.  Maple syrup short ribs were tender but too sweet for my taste. One note dish. Not much depth in the sauce.  The highlights were the cornbread and cocktails! They were fantastic.

PUPb7ahTlJ44qZLGSHAfRw.review_text: pretty damn good overall.  FOOD:~the fried chicken came highly recommended, & it was very good, interesting mix of spices, but a little too cajun/mediterranean for my taste. still, nice offering.  ~pork belly DIVINE.  ~OMG THE F-ING CORNBREAD!!! the free cornbread is the highlight of this whole meal. it is the cornerstone upon which all else flows.  SERVICE: very good.  DECOR: love it! nice, cozy, respecting the neighborhood, definitely beautiful.  BATHROOM: very good.  OVERALL: i'd go back for sure. probably better to eat here than @ yoshi's in the city. fillmore is revitalized!

8XFwq-I7QoCvWpA0jaxsLw.review_text: 3 words: Shrimp N Grits.  Such great soul food, especially since I lived in New Orleans for a while... but definitely a tad overpriced. Came for my birthday and got all this great food, even a birthday dessert and porto, but nothing was compted and waiters were kind of rude about recommendations.  Love the drinks (the pinot noir and grapefruit flirt--?-- are definitely staples)  The owner's cranky and no one seems to know who or what is going on in any of the historic photos that characterize the restaurant's atmosphere. Come if you know someone who works there and get a discount!

tIRh_AmxJhUgzoHUBMPnlA.review_text: It's my turn to take Mr out to this new restaurant in Fillmore.  Love the decor, was told that they will be having live jazz cabaret soon. So glad that I made 8:30 reservation on a Saturday night. A couple walked in without a reservation at 8:30, was told that there's a 2 hour wait. :(  We were seated right away. Ordered a bottle of Selene 2006 SB (pretty acidic and salty).   Foie Grass (good) $17 Black Bass (tasty) $25 Bouillabaise (yummy & spicy) $29  for appetizers: we ordered a chocolate & coffee beignets (delish) $8.  Total damage with tips $163 average tab for our dinner, not bad.   It could of been 5 stars except for the food portion (it's a bit small side). Overall, great experience, good customer service, fast & friendly service.

YGFFpVbQeK4P06lpskOrfA.review_text: This place is good for a change of pace from typical San Francisco fare.  The restaurant has a nice atmosphere and works just as well for a date as it would for a big group.  The menu is a little limited, but what they offer is pretty good. The complimentary cornbread is a nice Southern touch, but was kind of dry.  It doesn't hold a candle to the cornbread at Street on Polk (the best cornbread in all the land).   I started with the mixed green salad, which was a bit over-dressed, but otherwise fresh and crisp. They were out of the halibut - depressing! - so I had the steak.  The first half of the steak was all gristle & fat and basically inedible.  The second half of the steak was cooked perfectly and was deliciously tender & juicy.  I didn't touch the bleu cheese grits (because I'm a freak of nature and don't like cheese) but the spinach it came with was great.  My boyfriend had the ribs, which he said were amazing. I'm thinking I may have had an off-night with this place.  What they did right is definitely enough to get me to come back and give it another try.  Next time, I'll try going in a group.... they have so many delicious-looking sides that would probably be ridiculously good to share.

IB0_DRx-L8O1MtzwPF-lQw.review_text: Not entirely sure why I waited so long to come here. Soul food with a slightly fancy twist? Really should have been a no-brainer for me.  To start, the corn bread was absolutely awesome. With the jalapeno jelly, it was just unbelievably tasty. The fat fries were a little nondescript - just fries, but like 4x thicker.  My favorite thing that I had was the corn pudding, as suggested by the manager.  It was certainly awesome. Like a cross between corn chowder and grits, it was perfect. The crispy poached egg on top was life-changing.    Then we got actual grits, with succulent pieces of shrimp on top, and it was also excellent, as was the beef short rib. The cornmeal breading on the onion rings was a tad too heavy, though.  Then, to top off the already ridiculous meal, we ended with a banana cream pie, which was banana-y and creamy and a pie, so in other words the best.   The service was great. The ambiance was great. We came on a weekday and the table next to us consisted of four gentlemen all 65+, dressed in their weekday best. It was the cutest.

uc21yfSCyk6zx2Cz6J8XUQ.review_text: We had dinner reservations at 8:45pm and didn't get seated until 9:30pm.  During out wait, we went to the bar to get a few cocktails and the bartenders were practically sleep walking because it took them fifteen minutes to notice us and ask for our order!  Okay, so that's the reason they didn't get five stars.  The food was absolutely yummy.  I love the jam that comes with the corn bread, I love the sweet bread, short ribs, and fried ck.  I'm taking my bf there!

t9cze1D9Gb8d-spMoHHSSg.review_text: Back here for Sunday Gospel Brunch.... FUN FUN FUN! Don't come here to talk, listen to the music... YAY! Food is just as great as dinner but no dessert at brunch! Well, as least no added calories! I had the salmon and it was perfect size... did not feel overstuff or still hungry...

8I9unWWsZj8jxci9Ova_MA.review_text: Rand and I had our second dinner at 1300 last night with our friends Sean and Blake.  From the first cocktail to the banana cream pie, the whole experience was really good.  I like the decor, the space, and the overall vibe.  Our service was attentive and friendly.  I began with a Mandarin Cosmo.  It's fantastic and I highly recommend this drink.  I mean, I was going to see Sex and the City afterwards.  What else should I have been drinking?  To start, we had the Warm Poached Egg Salad.  It was like eating a delicious plate of bacon-y goodness.  Sean ordered the Shrimp Hushpuppies and Blake got a Baby Arugula salad.  For our entrees, I had the Fried Chicken.  It's deboned, battered and friend and was really good.  The breading might have been a little thick and crunchy for my taste (if we're splitting hairs here), but I ate every bit and liked the little bit of spiciness.  The truffled potatoes were good, too.  I would have appreciated another veggie, but I'll live.  Blake ordered the lamb with grits.  It was tender and delicious.  We had the best two entrees if I do say so myself.  Rand and Sean both (I think) ordered the halibut.  They said it was good, but the portion seemed a little small.  For dessert, Sean ordered Banana Cream Pie for us all to share.  I had one bite and it was really tasty.  I also had a Pomegranate Martini during dinner.  It was a little too sweet but drinkable.  All in all, I would have to recommend 1300.  I've had two good meals there.  It's a great addition to the neighborhood.

buhUgeRm7OpQtVE68Q2qZQ.review_text: Excellent, excellent, excellent. I had been meaning to try 1300 for quite some time after meeting the chef at a couple of events, and have no idea what took so long. This was a spur-of-the-moment night-before birthday dinner. We were greeted at the door by an exotic beauty who showed us to a table. The first thing I noticed, after the great decor, was how professional and cooperative the staff was. The exotic beauty at the door bussed a table after seating us. The staff was a team and the fact they seemed to enjoy their work just made the food that much better.  My friend did the DAT flank steak and commented it was the best beef she had ever tasted, which was confirmed when she shared a bite.  I had catfish and it was an excellent example of Chef David Lawrence's culinary style.  The atmosphere, the professional service, and the excellent food made for a great evening.

EOV_ho10DmEohT4m6jqL8A.review_text: The short ribs were to die for. The gnocchi were pretty decent as well. The mud pie though... was a bit of a failure. It had too much of a French "flare" to a plain old mud pie. It didn't even resemble anything like a mud pie. BUT.. I have to say that this is the perfect place to go with a date. 1300 is very classy restaraunt.  One thing that I was annoyed about was the entrance.. it was so hard to find! I had to ask the bell boys up the block at Yoshi's to direct me to the door. How sad.

ZSretWXlve11q9hP6SrScQ.review_text: Upscale lounge reminiscent of the jazz era. It's soulful American cuisine with a twist. Décor is convenient and inviting. Drinks are well made, so is the food. Try the shrimp and grits and the blood orange cocktail muddled with jalapeño, most unique drink I've ever had. Come to relax and have a conversation. A great place for a nice evening out.

Equi11nuKInRA0fem4DN4g.review_text: A few friends enjoyed Gospel Brunch there on Sunday and it couldn't have been nicer really.  the ambiance is equisite, the service is fantastiic and the food was delicious.  We each ordered something different:  Eggs Benedict with Cajun Ham on Chive Biscuits with lovely new potatoes and a taste of fresh strawberries; Lovely salad with grilled chicken breast (still moist and hot from the grille that is) and eggs, sausage, bacon and grits.  We were greeted by a basket of warm breads including corn bread and scones with sweet honey butter and a red pepper jelly.  Sunday brunch couldn't be better!

ZwkqKwSASAVHCFsz3-oZmQ.review_text: Came back last night after our first failed attempt at using an opentable deal on a blocked out day.  Went with the tomato salad, short rib, and peach cobbler and wasn't as impressed as the first trip here.    The tomato salad was ok...it came with the set menu, so I can't really judge this, as I'm not a huge fan of tomatoes.  The short rib really was disappointing.  I feel that braised short ribs are slam dunk entrees at any restaurant where having expectations of super tender, slightly fatty, really savory, and generally amazing piece of meat isn't farfetched.  The short rib here was a little bit dry, lacked taste, and wasn't as fatty/savory as I hoped. The mashed potatoes on the side were spot on though.  The peach cobbler was decent, but maybe my disappointment with the short rib tainted my dessert craving.    The service was still spot on and the ambiance was great as expected, but the food fell short this time around.

fcnaLf9n35xD9mQjJ773ug.review_text: Beautiful decor. Good cocktails. Slow service. Very slow. Good cornbread. Fairly pricey.   Food was good. My braised short rib was dry and a disappointment. I think our server forgot about it under a heart lamp. It took forever to get our dinner! Nearly an hour (I timed it :) we were very hungry   My friends rib eye and pork chop were better. I would give it another go... Area is umm eclectic, to be pc. Had to reroute as 2 people were being arrested. Park in the lot!  Overall, beautiful ambiance. They need to work on more efficient service.   But I will give them a "me likey"

0XHUbUz_PfX913kbrGTzbw.review_text: This was without question the most "meh" meal we had in San Fran. Waitress was very nice and the place has a warm, comfortable vibe. The bottle of wine we had was the best part of our dining experience as the $58 bottle of Pinot noir was well worth the price.   The Brussel sprouts and French fry apps weren't that memorable and the rib eye was tiny. The bed of lentils or beans beneath the steak were undercooked. The best dish by far was the ribs. They were a bit on the dry side but the full slab is a great value as it's a ton of food.  Add it all up and you've got yourself a nice place for drinks before eating elsewhere.

waYFYplkgtFcZE0_ixZqqg.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore  Yikes.  (Imma write this in my Southern Style voice - read with a Southern drawl)  I was a hankerin' for some Southern food, but being up here in NorCal, finding real Southern food is like trying find a slice of chocolate cake within 100 miles of a fat kid - it ain't gonna happen (sorry there, no prejudice against fat kids - except for that one back in the 3rd grade that was a bully...I hear he got himself that there diabetes...SUCKAH!)  I wanted me some Cajun Creole, but all I could I find was Roux at the Row...been there, done that....their best item?  The absinthe.  And the hush puppies.  Go ahead, ask for some boudain...the waiter is gonna look at ya funny.  Oops, that's another review.  Anyways, I done said to myself, what do I REALLY want?  Cajun.  Fudge.  Soul food?  Lil bit.  Ain't ya'll ever heard of REAL Soul Food??!!  I Yelp this restaurant and I sez to myself, "Aight, lezz give it a shot."  The restaurant is kind of hard to find, unless you see the sandwich board outside...I valet the car and walk-in.  Interesting.  Lots of loud-ass jazz working the room, a sitting area on the left with some vintage black and whites along the wall and the restaurant was packed.    I are smart.  I made reservations.  I'm seated and the dude takes my jacket.  Thanks sir.  Before I even begin looking at the menu, I order a shot of double Vodka and rum (don't try this at home).  Down it and order another one with a Bud Light chaser.  Perfect.  I grab the menu and peruse this "soul food."  I rolled my dang eyes.  God dang it...freaking FUSION again...sigh.......  I just wanted something inherently bad for me...and I get yet another artist wannabe.  Lemme tell ya'll sumtin' - grits ain't that hard to make.  And it's freaking good.  Hell, I could do it; I wanted to storm back in the kitchen and make'em myself.  I ordered the BBQ Shrimp and the creamy grits.  The grits were the best part - buttery and delicious.  But you don't add no shrimp to that shit...WTH??!!!  I was upset.  The shrimp was...MEH...not impressed.  This ain't soul food.  Imagine Van Gogh, but blind.  Great artist - think he could have painted shit if he was BLIND??!!  I think not.  Due to my sadness at the attempt of this restaurant to be trendy, I ordered another shot...straight gin, rimmed with sugar, and a drop of lemon juice (again, don't try this at home).  Ahhh, much better.  I ordered the Grilled Ribeye steak.  Ouch. NOTTTTTTTTTTTT impressed.  WTH??!!  Where was I??  I wanted freaking soul food.  REAL G*D damn soul food and I end up with...F*^CKING SH&T....ugh....in my hopes of making the food more palatable, I order 2 more shots, a glass of Noir, and a Bud Light.  Ok, I need to stop now; as ya'll can see, I was not happy about this place.  The portions were for a 5 year old, the restaurant so loud you couldn't hear anyone, and the price was exorbitant.........  My bill was $225 after tip.  I got better food at IHOP and back in Texas, I'd just sneak in a flask of whiskey.    Enough with the Fusion already...gimme my old-school food the way it's suppose to be made (by the way, REAL soul food has at least freaking CATFISH on the menu) and I'll be a happy boy.  Keep your damn fusion in your stupid liberal house...gimme the stuff that'll clog my arteries, a shotgun, a six-pack, and food that'll let my cholesterol level shoot through the damn roof.  Thas' what I'm talkin' bout.  2 stars.

6-WRoSY75bgtCL-8yQLr5Q.review_text: I've been to 1300 on four separate occasions. The atmosphere is great! Love the lounge area. During my most recent vist the food was very bland.....surprising for a Louisiana style restaurant. I was looking forward to big New Orleans style flavors and was extremely disappointed. What will keep me from returning again is the service....it was horrible! It took an hour to get our appetizer served. I informed the hostess that we were seeing a show at 8 pm, which only provided 90 minutes for dinner. She was extremely rude as was the waitress. There was however a waiter who stepped up and assisted to insure we made the show in time....kudos to him!

vA8uqA8Q74CmUdEeqBIoPg.review_text: Came here because of a BlackBoard Eats/visa promotion and located in an ideal spot to meet with friends.  The group ordered burger, short rib and fried chicken. The verdict for the burger was ok which didn't surprise me given the restaurant's theme. The short rib was given alot of praise. My fried chicken was bland to say the least. The fried chicken came with these biscuits the size and texture of small hockey pucks. The complimentary cornbread was good to eat. The highlight for me in the entree was the pear flower martini. We also shared the fries and they were good. The house ketchup, I think I prefer regular Heinz. :)  The visa promotion was a complimentary cobbler and we ordered the biegnets too. The desserts were very very good which lightened the meal's perception. Also, our waittress was excellent and super pleasant. I found the hostess stiff and it was a pleasant that the waitress was able to counter it.  Overall, I think the place is great for lounging/desserts but I wouldn't order the entrees.

6NDotpCZlCoWW8r3EC9JXg.review_text: My main issue was the lack of service when we initially came in, and it continued until the food started coming out. But at least the tried?? So we split the shrimp and grits (I don't usually eat shrimp,  but this I would eat again.. a few times!), the braised short rib (it was tender, reasonably flavored, my favorite part was the greens the served with it) and the fried chicken (dark meat, but it was ok fried chicken, biscuits were a tad dry). The cornbread was delicious with the pepper jelly.  Not sure if I'd come back, but I do not regret going.

ycnOVMigqO_iHjhupxh2mQ.review_text: My friends and I went to 1300 for Brunch today.  I must say the decor is fantastic and upscale...but the food was just ok...  We were a party of 11...not too large I assume for a brunch.  The waiter seemed unable to keep up with our drink orders....  the food was yummy, but not worth the price...I would highly recommend the BBQ shrimp and creamy grits, but for me, for 14 dollars, I would of liked to see a little more of it on my plate....the french toast with apple that my friend has was also yummy...  I would definetely go back and give the place another try, not just for brunch, but for me, a little pretentious...

4KGjezSiu1vdfF-5lHjBHA.review_text: It is definitely a place where I could park myself with a nice glass of scotch. Jazz running through my veins. Although the food could be questionable, I will leave it up to your discretion. I do like the pork belly appetizer, mmm, good belly, keep me satisfy in my belly. Very friendly staff, a touch over too concern, who knows. However, it is very interesting how people are able to rate this restaurant much sooner than 3 days ago, where they only have been opened for.

sRVGewx--HgwwlKwAfCO9Q.review_text: Ahh, the return to swellegance!  Actually, Cole Porter is the wrong artist to cite in this jazz-inspired restaurant, but that is the word that came to mind as I looked around at the beautiful setting and saw tables full of parties enjoying the lounge, bar and dining room.  There is an eclectic touch that gives the place a very personal feel, kind of old New York, but also very San Francisco.  Check out the upside down lamps above the booths, the melamine trays on the wall.  It's casual enough so that you don't have to dress up, but I think a fine sportcoat and a flirty dress make the perfect attire and add to the romance of the place.  The food lived up to the surroundings at our dinner for 6 last Friday night.  Everyone in our party loved it, with one guest claiming it as his new favorite restaurant in SF.    We sampled a lot of different appetizers, with the most outstanding one being the Sauteed Wild Mushrooms - a MUST-HAVE.  Others that we enjoyed were the Sweet Potato Gnocchi, BBQ'd Shrimp and Grits (my second favorite), and the Shrimp Hushpuppies.  All good, generously portioned, and full of flavor.  For dinner, I had the Maple Syrup Slow Braised Beef Short Ribs - a gorgeous presentation and delicious dish, with onion rings perched on top and sitting on a bed of chive mashed potatoes.  Tender, seasoned perfectly - a great dish.  Everyone else at the table loved their food, too - from the pescatarians to the vegetarians, and the carnivores.    For dessert, skip the beignets (dry) and get the Peach Cobbler and the Banana Cream Pie.    Prices are in the $25-30 range for entrees, so don't go expecting a down-and-dirty soul food experience.  This is fine dining pulling up its roots from the flavors and recipes from grandmother's kitchen, but with the technique and presentation suited to Saturday night on the town.  An extra shout-out must be made for the hooks on the bathroom sinks in the Women's Room - no more soggy-bottomed purses!

r7C1_zw8VYxLlJJ8zNrNOw.review_text: Great place, wonderful food and most importantly...AMAZING BARTENDERS! Amazing!

2ZfNRQTznraZ6tMXwSc31w.review_text: The best way i can describe this restaurant is "mostly harmless" and "I'll be surprised if this place is still in place in a year." I went with my wife and another couple for dinner last Friday night.   Here are the Highlights: * The fried chicken was delicious. We all agreed that my friend won the dinner lottery that night. I believe the chicken was soaked in buttermilk or brine so that the meat was still quite tender and tender while the crust was crunchy and flavorful. Was it one of the best plates of chicken I've had in SF? Yes. Even better than Farmer Brown? Yup. Worth the $25+ bucks? Not quite. * Appetizers. We had the fried okra and the shrimp hush puppies. I could have eaten an entire meal of shrimp hush puppies but 5+ orders would have been quite expensive. The okra deserves mention because you could taste that the okra was fresh - it was slightly crisp. Other than that, I wouldn't order either again (the shrimp based on the value and the okra because it just wasn't worth it.) * Mac & Cheese side: I'm a big fan of creative mac and cheese dishes and I do appreciate the spice they put into this dish.  * Service & Decor: quite good without being overbearing. I appreciated their prompt, friendly service and complete lack of any attitude or fuss (even when we sent two drinks back -- the Sazeracs). Nice decor and could be a nice romantic place to go.  Now, the lowlights: * The drinks: The hurricanes and Sazeracs were god awful. I think I've had better made by high school kids using a bottle of mix from bed bath and beyond. The sazeracs tasted completely watered down and the hurricane was I don't know if the bar-back had just been promoted or if they just forgot to grab our drinks off of the bar. Luckily though, they had no problem swapping the saveracs for a glass of house red. That was nice and I made sure that the tip reflected such consideration. * The pan roasted snapper. The snapper tasted a bit dried out and the fancy pants foam tasted like you just made bubbles with water/oil + Tony Chachere's Creole seasoning. Not impressive. * The baby back rib special: dried meat. unimpressive sauce. Memphis Minnies ribs are far better at 1/2 the price (although I still believe MM's sauces need work -- I end up bringing in my own). Not impressive. * Beef short rib: tasted like boiled meat on a bone. Not impressive.  Bottom Line: * It's a romantic enough place but there are plenty of better places to regularly spend your dining dollars in SF. * I wouldn't take a foodie girl here if you are trying to impress her. * I'm OK that I tried it at ~$40/head using the Blackboard Eats 30% off coupon. I wouldn't have enjoyed the meal if it had cost ~$60/head. * The front of the house seems well run (we were seated immediately). The back of the house needs a bit of work.

BTKEn9CtLJGWQM7sc1eu2g.review_text: The food, the drinks, the atmosphere, the people... all wonderful.  Cannot start off on the wrong foot with the cornbread, especially with the jalapeno chile sauce.  Wish I had more experience with the appetizers but the shrimp hushpuppies have garnered all of our attention, and rightfully so.  For main event the shortribs are just heavenly - cooked to perfection and no way to keep the meat on the bone; it just slides off and melts in your mouth.  The scallops provide a similar melt-in-your-mouth experience and have a nice crust on the outside as well, just how I like them.  Also worth mentioning are the potatoes with each of those dishes (shortribs and the surf and turf), which compliment really well.  The fried chicken is simply fantastic (and I'm from the south, if you consider Virginia).  All the dishes are presented nicely and are regular sized portions, not oversized like most places, so adding a starter and/or desert is enough to get full but not stuffed.  The drink menu here is also noteworthy.  I'm not a specialty cocktail person but there are quite a few drinks worth trying, all seemingly with fresh ingredients.  The environment is great but hard to explain... nice but not over the top, sort of loungish without the volume and an elegant deep south feel.  Last but not least, the service has been terrific and employees friendly.  Would highly recommend.

i0sCinT5tsi0fgZ7_vF1tQ.review_text: One of my favorite placing in the city.  I love the lounge.  Service is usually great.  Very nice place to go for drinks and food and a little jazz.

gDxSpme9duJavbNusoRRmg.review_text: My roommates and I came here for dinner not too long ago, and I don't think any of us walked away too impressed. The ambiance is really nice, and the hostess was sweet. She was super apologetic for our table not being ready right at 7:15pm for our reservation. Nice of her, but we waited 10 minutes to be seated at a table that had been open since we arrived, lol.  Our waiter was definitely not afraid to make conversation or recommendations. We started off with the mac 'n cheese, which I thought would be amazing, but it really lacked flavor. I ordered the catfish, and the roomies had the fried chicken & short ribs. The catfish was good, but slightly overcooked. The shrimp jambalaya that it sat on top of also lacked the punch in flavor, and I would have much preferred the jambalaya at Angeline's Kitchen in Berkeley.  I didn't try the chicken & short ribs myself, but didn't look like anything special. Funny thing is - my leftovers tasted better the next day, and my roommate said the same thing! Either the flavor took some time to come out, or we all weren't paying enough attention during the meal.  Either way, I would rather have soul food at an affordable price and with more flavor. Can't imagine returning anytime soon, unfortunately.

-g3XIcCb2b-BD0QBCcq2Sw.review_text: So, how did this place get such high reviews? With so many wonderful restaurants in SF and with so many options at the same price point of 1300 On Filmore, I'm not sure how and why people pick here over some other places.  Anyway, I came here for a second birthday dinner with some friends who, like me, were curious about the restaurant.  We sat towards the back of the restaurant in one of their private dining rooms since we were expecting a larger group of people.  We brought our own wine for dinner and asked the waiter to serve one, and pour another into a decanter.  First of all, the wine we brought, which came from our wine fridge, was served in the wine glasses that were on the table.  As in, the waiter didn't bring out a new set of glasses to serve the wine in.  This is one of the fundamental aspects of serving wine!! The cornbread that came was beautiful!  I LOVE LOVE LOVE cornbread and loved the two spreads that came with it.  After perusing the menu, we ordered the following:  Appetizers: -Bourbon-Hickory House Smoked Pork Belly & Duck Egg, Braised Cranberry Beans -White Truffle Macaroni N' White Cheddar Cheese  Greg and I shared the pork belly and duck egg, which came out in an iron skillet.  The pork belly was definitely overcooked, and while the egg was good, the best part about this was the beans.  On top of being overcooked, the pork belly was SO small.  Like it was a small sliver of pork belly.  I had a bite of the mac n cheese and thought that it was delicious!  Entrees: -Black Skillet Fried Chicken, Buttermilk Whipped Potatoes, Pan Gravy, Chive Herb Biscuits -Pan Roasted Columbo Spiced Divers Scallops, Garlic Leeks, Red Wine Star Anis Glaze -Grilled Ribeye Burger, Brioche Bun, Bread & Butter Pickles, House-made Ketchup, Creole Mustard -The Special of the Day: 1/2 rack of BBQ ribs with sides of coleslaw and truffle mac n cheese  I ordered the fried chicken, and it was...OK.  As some people have alluded to previously, the chicken itself is breaded beautifully, but not totally crispy.  It's almost like it was sitting out for too long after being fried.  The potatoes were delicious, and I liked the chive herb biscuits.  One of my friends also got the fried chicken, was so full from everything that she could only eat a small portion of her dish.  More on this to come, but the portions they give are HUGE.  Greg had the ribeye burger and was told that the burger is best eaten medium.  The burger came out medium well...which detracted from the deliciousness of ribeye.  My friend who had the ribs said that they were great with the meat falling off the bone, but the coleslaw left a lot to be desired.    So, my last rant on 1300 on Filmore.  The servers really need to be educated.  On top of being served wine in table glasses, they also overpoured in half the glasses on the table, didn't allow the person who brought the wine to taste it before it being served to the rest of the people at the table, didn't come back to top off the glasses that got significantly less wine than the other half of the table, and poured the second wine into new glasses (thank god) while we still had over half a glass from the first wine.  The other part that peeved me is that my friend who only ate a few pieces from her fried chicken dish asked for a to-go box.  Makes sense since she basically had an entire dish leftover.  We asked twice for the box, and they totally forgot about it.  Never brought it out.  I mean, there's basically an entire meal that went to waste.  So, everything taken into account, the food was OK, nothing out of the ordinary but certainly not bad, and the service was 1-star worthy.  Nets out to two stars, which I think is fair.  Probably won't be returning back here since there are so many other restaurants that are so much better at this price point.

EndbpS-MrxeCIdP4mMo14Q.review_text: You know I really wanted to like this place a lot more than I actually did. It's like a date with a hot guy that just falls flat due to a lack of chemistry. You look at him and think "Woohoo, hot make out session here I come" and then you actually kiss and there is nothing there, like not even a spark.   My bf and I were nearby having some drinks and trying to figure out where we wanted to have dinner. We did a Yelp search and up pops "1300 on Filmore." Looking at the pictures and reading the reviews had us sold.  Expectations were not met.  Service: Great service at both the bar and the restaurant.   Ambiance: It's a little off. I'm not sure. There was just something lacking. Again, how do I put this into words? It felt like shabby chic but not in a classy way. Light fixtures looked cheap (like a bad etsy project). Dusty, etc. Again this is totally just shallow aesthetics.  Food: Hmmmm. This is where they lost me. We had the chicken mousse deviled eggs. Not appetizing. Eggs were slimy and mousse had nasty after taste. Neither of us cared for them. Complementary cornbread was good but not over the top delicious. Chicken and mashed potatoes were GREAT. I will give them that. The chicken was moist and tender and the portion was more than ample. The macaroni and cheese, we took a single bite of each and made the same "gross" face at each other. Just NOT good. There was something so incredibly off with the make up of that mac and cheese. Thankfully our server took it off the bill.  Overall I was not happy to spend nearly $50 bucks for such a lackluster meal.

ozs8PPJgrwFQl41MCZFMKw.review_text: Had no expectations going in, or probably would have been even more disappointed.  Our friends had heard about 1300 Fillmore and said the fried chicken was supposed to be great. We decided to order 3 entrees (for 4 people) and share, family style, since two of us wanted to try the fried chicken but so many other dishes also sounded good. Good thing we shared, because the fried chicken was really mediocre and I would have been *pissed* if that was all I had. The coating had a good texture, not too greasy, but it was totally lacking flavor, like they forgot to add the seasonings, and not as moist as it could have been (my friend, who makes fried chicken herself, said she was afraid that would be the case when she heard it was boneless.) The ribs were pretty good, tender, pretty tasty, with a decent bbq sauce, but nothing special. All the sides were uninteresting: mashed potatoes (one of my favorite foods in the world) were a bit dry and lacking in flavor, and after having one bite of both the cole slaw and mac&cheese, I didn't bother going back for more. The best dish was the catfish over jambalaya, which was also by far the smallest dish: a good size for me (small female), but probably too small for any man with a good appetite. The jambalaya was the only thing with flavor. All the prices seemed high ($25 for fried chicken and mashed potatoes???) but I guess that's because you're paying for the music as well; the food is pretty standard stuff and would be hard to justify the prices without the music, even if it was good (the food, I mean).  I totally lost interest when they said they were out of the pecan pie.  The only thing I would have again is the catfish, but it's unlikely I'll go back unless someone is playing that my friends really want to see.

OVknZ1BXnMGIy_rxoV-TYA.review_text: I enjoyed the decor ambiance and service, but found the food to be mediocre.  The cornbread was delicious and the apps were tastey.  I got the mushroom grits, and my husband the bbq shrimp and grits.  The sweet potato and leek soup looked good, but neither of us tried it.  The entrees were a bit of a disappointment.  I ordered the arctic char, my husband the black bass, and our friend the fried chicken.  Both fish dishes left something to be desired.  They were a little bland and I easily left half the meal uneaten out of boredom.  The fried chicken was much much better.  The mac and cheese side had a lot of bread crumbs and not so much cheese.  I would like to give it another chance as it could have simply been the entree choices that left a bad taste in my mouth (pun intended), but I will not rush back anytime soon.

-uLtfRYb2o8hQtjOrKNNhQ.review_text: I managed to have three servings of pork in a four course meal.  Ain't nothin' wrong with that.  Before you start judging me, the front door of the restaurant was broken, so I really had to yank hard to get inside the so I probably burned a calorie and a half doing it.

kS1MQHYwIfD0462PE61IBw.review_text: 3.5 for me, the best part of the meal was BBQ Shrimp and Creamy Grits.  spicy, flavorful.  better than the sauteed wild mushrooms grits.  soulful american is a good concept.  tried Pan Roasted Crispy Skin Salmon, Lobster-Yukon Hash, Meyer Lemon Confit, Lobster Sauce and Black Skillet Fried Chicken, Buttermilk Whipped Potatoes, Pan Gravy (could use more), including biscuit, but skin not crispy enough, large piece, meat tender.  not exciting as I thought.  cornbread was nice and soft

sXKmP90GCdF0oM0AzYRhaQ.review_text: I'm rating and writing this with regards to their lounge. I dined here a couple of years ago, and although I've forgotten the dishes I ordered, I still remember the warmth of the restaurant and service.  Came here for my birthday with a few friends to chill out at their lounge. Nice lounge couches, not a bad decor at all, great drinks (full bar), amazing bar food. At around 9pm, a live band arrived and started performing. Not a bad spontan although it was really hard to chat with my friends. The lady who was serving our table was really friendly and prompt. She definitely deserve the stars. :)  My friends and I ordered their mushroom and grits, chicken skewers, catfish po boy, salad, bbq shrimp and more mushroom and grits. They are all wonderful and there was nothing wrong with anyone.

W04EtHsub_Q4T5icnJT_9Q.review_text: Wow, what more can be said! We made our reservation using Open Table the restaurant  had our table waiting once we arrived.  The service was spot on Chris was our server and has very helpful in our menu selections. I had the cauliflower soup to start followed by diver scallops as my entree. The soup was smooth and velvety and the scallops were prepared to perfection. This place is now on our favorites list when visiting SF.

disS5oye86976awyFa4Tsw.review_text: We heard about this place a long time ago, as our former roommate checked it out when it first opened. But it wasn't until we stopped by the cooking demo stage at the Jazz Festival that we realized how awesome this place is. The chef cooked prawns over grits and they were amazing!  So, we made a quick reservation on Open Table and were there a week later.   They start you off with cornbread, honey butter and jalapeno jelly which is good enough to be your entire meal. We started with the wild mushrooms over grits and were not disappointed.  Chris had the short rib over chive mashed potatoes and I had the black eye pea cakes and collard greens.  AMAZING! The server recommended the banana cream pie for dessert, and it was perfect because it wasn't too heavy.  The ambiance is swank, the service is friendly and we'll definitely be back!

sYVSUgC_qpSCDAArS0aeXg.review_text: I wasn't thoroughly impressed so not sure I would return a third time.

mb2ZCVoglkfitoBGR1lk2w.review_text: when warm homemade cornbread with jalapeno jelly and honey butter greets you as you sit, when the waitress overhears you debating on what dessert to get and brings you the unpicked dish free, when you're the whitest people on the planet but don't feel out of place in an lower Fillmore jazz bar restaurant, when Willie Brown himself is chilling anonymously at the bar, you know you're in super legit San Francisco and my favorite new restaurant this year, 1300 Fillmore.

S6nXOfpjO4NW5z2cSLb3qw.review_text: So my fiance and I have a tradition where we go to a nice restaurant every Christmas eve. We're working class kids so we don't get the opportunity to enjoy a fancy dinner very often. We went to 1300 Fillmore with high expectations. The ambiance is lovely, the historic photos of the Fillmore district are awesome, and the little band, though a little too smooth jazz for my taste, was charming and very fitting for Xmas eve. We arrived 5 minutes early and were directed to the bar. Fine by me. Well what wasn't fine by me is that they finally sat us 25 minutes after our reservation time. I guess I should have been prepared to lower my expectations on the basis of the $10 vodka/soda I ordered that tasted like water. When we got to our table, it took another 10 minutes for our waiter to even come over and introduce himself! When he did arrive, he was rude and unaccommodating. We're talking zero personality! He'd disappear for 10-15 minutes at a time and never once came over to ask us how our food was. We had some leftovers, which he completely forgot to bring back to the table until we reminded him. He literally misplaced the food in the back as we saw him scrambling around in the kitchen (a hunt that took another 5 minutes or more). Though the food was pretty good, we received some of the worst service we've ever experienced. I highly suggest going for the food and the historical relevance, but don't expect great or even good service.

_lMgCjJO_VVCCycZ784KiA.review_text: I got the maple short ribs and the mac n cheese and they were both delicious!

wsJAUeEFjkXKbtbbNbxs_g.review_text: 1300 Filmore has been one of my faves for awhile but a few months back I went and was disappointed. But because I had liked it so much past times, I took my mother and brother there last week to celebrate their birthdays and I was overjoyed by the love we received. We had reservation at 5pm on a Sunday night for 9 people and first we ran late and then our party of 9 was shorten by 2 and staff there was so accommodating.   Then the food the Shrimp and Grits, the crunchy but moist Fried Chicken, the Short Ribs that fell off the bone, the strong and tasty cocktails, and I could go on and on. The only thing I would change is to have a kids menu, we had both my nephews (4 and 10) with us and it would have helped. But again the staff tried their best to help with this by cutting their burger in half but it still was a bit to sophisticated for their little taste buds.   The only draw back is you pay a lot for what you get...but I guess you can't have it all. I'll be back!

Us4HoJdNxQeAvNBHlwGqeA.review_text: This was my second time eating there and it was just as wonderful of an experience as the first time. The food was tasty and the ambience was great. I had the same waitress as the last time and she was just as attentive as the last time. My only slight negative is that it's so pricey. With that being said, I'll definitely go back and eat there again.

0mDSZJ4NluBXFl-9JXZ9Mw.review_text: The dining room was pretty empty, we got there 10 minutes earlier than our reserved time, well, we still had to wait for another 20 minutes  the table to be ready. Well, that's okay, we ere not in a hurry anyway.  We made reservation through open table's "dine about town" ad. Well, we were told there is no" dine about town menu" after we asked for tit. Well, I don't know whom should be blamed for this glitch. That's okay, too since the regular menu does have the famous fried chicken.  Well, well, we were disappointed at this  "authentic" fried chicken..my husband is from Texas and knows what is "authentic soul food" should taste like - this is far from it even the chicken is tender but it is not "authentic soul food". Yet, we all like the corn muffin which is more authentic than the chicken. The apple wood smoked bacon tastes good also.  We actually think the winner is the fried catfish po boy sandwich - even it can;t compare what we got from Texas, yet, the fish is tender with corn meal batter - at least, the ingredient looks all right.. The live band performed welll, yet, it is way too noisy for this size of room. .

re4QtZbx1Tej8ltVMJ2MPw.review_text: Dinner @ 1300 on Fillmore  Cornbread amazing.  Surf N' Turf plate was excellent.  Half rack of baby back ribs were really good, cold slaw was ok, not too exciting.   Overall had a great experience.

SO6lM6aH_-eKZY2SUxOgGQ.review_text: Great food. Fun atmosphere. Friendly staff. Good service. I'm not sure what else I'd ask for from a restaurant.   We thought we had reservations for 8:00, but it turned out they were for 7:00. Luckily, they were still able to seat us (on a Saturday night no less) within 10 minutes!  The food: From the appetizers to the desserts we were all satisfied, pleased, and happy. Good, fresh ingredients and great flavors.   The service: A little slow to start, but the waiter kept letting us know that he knew we were there and he was on his way (I appreciated that, even if it took us awhile to get waters).

BAtJ1-zmVqzVL5PfZuqoTQ.review_text: Great atmosphere, but the portions for dinner were absurdly small.  $150 for 2 people, including only a 1/2 bottle of wine and I had to have a snack afterward because I was still hungry.  Be sure to order the sides to fill you up, but stay away from the brussels sprouts -- I was feeling their affect well into the next day.

p7smD0Nudp15l2IODpv4tA.review_text: 2 stars for food 3 stars for service  The venue was my choice for date night and I was really excited to showcase what yelpers were calling me in for. First plus, we called in to say we would be late for our dinner reservation due to Bart Strike traffic - they had our table waiting for us with no reprimand. Second plus, the ambiance catered to the occasion for low light romantic dining. Add live music, it seems like we're heading in the right direction.   Unfortunately, the positives end here. Their "famous chicken" priced for $26 set itself up for big shoes to fill. Aside from its crispy exterior, the meat was dry and poorly seasoned. I was better satisfied with chicken from a chicken and waffle spot at half to a third of the price. The other half ordered the rib eye. It was so bland we had to request for steak sauce, which they didn't have so we settled for salt and pepper. Tasteless $30 steak was another strike. We ordered a few drinks, their cocktails didn't have much alcohol at all as well. Their truffle mac and cheese was eh, not much truffle-y at all. Their cornbread with the paired honey butter was the best thing on the table.  Service was ok. For fine dining, servers/bust people usually clear the appetizer dishes prior to serving the main entree. Sitting with a small table for two doesn't leave much space for anything else. We had to ask if they could take the unused dinnerware away.  Ultimately, you're helping pay for their lease and decor because their culinary creations are ridiculously overpriced.

b7s_gfkMlQ5d31UyQnHSEQ.review_text: 5 stars for the decor, ambiance, drinks and service.  2 stars for the food.  I had the fried chicken, which I was told was the most popular item on the menu.  Ehh.  I make better at home without a 20 minute wait.    Final verdict: 3 stars for eating.  5 stars for hanging in the lounge area with a drink and appetizer.  Average those and you get 8 stars.  Or 4.  I've never been good at math....

Z2PISdtGHThSUUbFccGkrA.review_text: I was fortunate enough to be taken out to 1300 with a large party (thank you, Dr. Isaacs) and must have tried nearly every entree and side off their dinner menu.  For myself, I ordered their special: a rack of ribs with sides of coleslaw AND mac and cheese.  The mac and cheese  was delicious and must have had a hint of gorgonzola that added a pleasant "kick" to the dish.  I also managed to try the fried chicken, which was "out of this world; simply perfect", and the short ribs which were as equally yummy.  I highly recommend this place if you're looking for some of what I like to call "fancy southern cookin'"!

Xf5KPJimu8cLFndTL8WPJQ.review_text: I have mixed emotions about this place. While the decor was very intriguing, from the nondescript exterior (I was unsure of whether the door was really the door) to the beautiful jazz-vibe interior, the food was not all that.  I ordered the Little Gem Salad, the fried chicken, and a side of macaroni and cheese. Honestly, the salad was the best part of my meal -- great flavors and accented with candied pecans and cornbread croutons. The fried chicken was decent. It was obviously not as good as the stuff I had in Atlanta, but it beat a few other places in the Bay Area where I've ordered it. It wasn't oily and the meat was moist, so not bad overall. Also, the breading on the chicken had an interesting spice to it, which added a bit of zest. The mac and cheese was a disaster. First of all, for $7, you just get a measly little portion, which was quite disturbing. Secondly, it was bland, and seemed that it was just sprinkled and topped with cheese, rather than actually baked and melted with it. Thirdly, it just supremely lacked the homey, comforting feeling that mac and cheese is supposed to provide. Not good. Save the $7 for dessert instead.  Speaking of dessert, no review on that, since I didn't order it. I was way too stuffed after the meal. As a general recommendation, share the food. The fried chicken dish was huge and definitely enough food for two people. The three items ordered were shared between two people, and made for a nice meal.  Oh, and we had 8pm reservations, but for some reason didn't get seated until nearly 8:45pm. Not sure what was going on with that. The service at the table itself was attentive, however.  Bonus points: The fresh, warm cornbread served was scrumptious! Tempting as it is, try not to fill up on it! ;)

A_lVyoDcALBoD5AWvWZLNw.review_text: Rare is the occasion where I feel I've 'experienced' a meal, rather than merely eaten it. We had an early reservation (5:30 PM), as my party and I were due at the San Francisco symphony by 8:00 PM.  We arrived a little early, so we took seats in the lounge, which was tastefully decorated with many framed photographs of famous jazz and blues musicians. The seating is spacious and comfortable. The lounge decor is understated and elegant, starting with beautiful hardwood plank floors, Oriental rugs, tufted leather chairs and sofas, and coffee tables. Throughout the entire restaurant, the high walls, painted in a deep brown, semi-sheer window treatments, sparse tree branch accents, and Japanese-inspired globe lights lend a soothing, relaxing vibe. Since the weather was quite warm, it felt like a respite from the harsh world on the outside. Think cool, dark decor, clinking glasses, air conditioning, and light jazz background music.  Patrons are offered the option of ordering drinks while waiting to be seated. I must say that the delightful combinations of spirits we consumed were nothing short of magical. I tried the Key Lime Pie, followed with a Honey Sweet Tea, which I'm told was sweet tea flavored vodka mixed with honey and lemon juice.   For an appetizer, I had the Grits & Shrimp. As a native Californian, I'm not necessarily qualified to compare this to the "real thing", but it was delicious all the same. Nuggets of grits, in a rich sauce with perfectly seasoned shrimp. I wanted to lick the plate clean!  My entree was featured on the current prix-fixe menu. It was marinated flank steak in some sort of bourbon-molasses sauce, slices, and laid atop a rich sweet potato gratin, garnished with tiny pieces of deep fried okra. Each bite was a cacophany of taste, flavor, and utter ecstasy exploding in my mouth.  There were two other people in my party. One had the fried chicken on a pillow of mashed potatoes, and tiny chive biscuits. The other had the ribeye steak, with grits and an onion sauce. We were silent most of the way through the meal, as to not disrupt the dreamlike state in which we consumed our meals.  Cornbread was served with our meal; perfectly dry and crumbly, as it should be, served with butter and a red pepper sauce.  The service was excellent, friendly and professional waitstaff, and we never had to ask for a thing. They change out flatware, and clear crumbs between courses, which was a nice touch.  Unfortunately, we had to pass on dessert. The food is amazing, but the portions are quite generous, even for us three girls with hearty appetites. Before we even finished our meals, we were planning when to come back next.  I appreciate that parking is convenient. Just enter the parking garage on Eddy St., and take the elevator up. Yoshi's is next door for those who want to do dinner and catch a show without having to hassle with driving and parking to two different places. I only wish they validated.

ttbXD1QgHBH9mJ_UK3yhcw.review_text: Wasn't impressed to be honest. My food was lukewarm (the plate it was on was hotter than the food itself), and if anyone at your table orders the friend chicken you can expect yours not to be nearly as piping hot as theirs will be (since the chicken takes the longest to prepare).   The service was nice enough, they get three stars for being thoughtful and decorating our shared dessert plate with a "Happy Birthday" for my friend. But the dessert itself was not very exciting at all. I asked for a cocktail off the menu and the bartender decided he would empty out the bottle of liqueur practically doubling the called for amount and making it unbearable.   I definitely won't be traveling across the bridge again for a so-called french-southern experience there when I can get a much better version on this side of the bay at Pican.

4BAft_i6xvmrgvrs6o-E3g.review_text: Nice lounge area. Cocktails were good.  Food just okay. Not impressed. I've had better.

2UHtAm_ZLmgILB6XoEKw_w.review_text: Outstanding! Just outstanding! I'm an avid live music fan and was searching for a culinary alternative to Yoshi's next door (live music venue) before a performance for my birthday weekend. After reading the reviews I suggested this place to my brother and his date mainly due to its convenient location to the venue.   The decor is really warm, modern and comfortable. The unique back-lit framed images on the wall in the front lounge area are awesome. We started there with cocktails and was soon advised our table was ready.   Our server (so wish I could remember his name) was one of the VERY best ever! Since this was our first visit, his description of the chef/owner and the menu items definitely got us going! We were excited! Within a few minutes he brought us cornbread triangles to DIE for! Crispy on the outside, firm, warm and delicious on the inside served with honey-butter and a red pepper dipping sauce.  I had eaten too late in the day so my GF and I decided to share our meal. We started with the Sea & Swine Whiskey Smoked Pork Belly, Bay Scallops Braised Cabbage w/Mustard Gastrique. While this dish was incredibly tasty it consisted of just one small slice of pork belly and one scallop for $15 so I was a little disappointed with the portion.   Next we ordered Black Skillet Roasted Catfish over Andouille Sausage Shrimp Jambalaya, Braised Greens w/Caramelized Sweet Onions, Ham Hock and White Truffle Macaroni N'Cheese w/Smoked Gouda, White Cheddar & Bleu Cheese. My bro and his date ordered something that's not usually on the menu, Smoked & Glazed Baby Back Rib Rack. We all sampled each others dishes and the only thing coming out of everyone's food-laden mouths was "WOW!"   Yes, a bit pricey for sure but we WILL be back!

n0eE8y2Xu1NPGiRDSqU_WA.review_text: It's worth the visit just to see the wall of incredible jazz photos.  All of the food is heavy and delicious, as southern food should be.  The fried chicken rivals my beloved memories of the taste of Roy Rogers fried chicken (yes, I just said that), but I could have easily just eaten three bowls of their buttery grits.  Have some cornbread and mac n' cheese on the side and you're a certifiable lard ass for the next few days...but it feels so good.

6a8XHypxGwNTRWqtqQsylQ.review_text: Hey soul sister, ain't that Mr. Mister? I love this place because it's literally downstairs from my new place - YES! The food reminds me of the days when I was at training in the southern part of Georgia except classier (sorry, GA). I'm talking about that fried chicken! Get in my belly!!!  We ordered the fried chicken and the surf & turf. Food was really tasty. Service was slightly on the slow side though, but no worries, the atmosphere and good conversation made up for it. I really enjoyed my time here. We can't wait to try out the bar - lots of young professionals. Food, drinks, networking galore!

oCPHSSLNymMo0iYJJ34I5g.review_text: Elegant dining and top quality food. I've dined here twice and ordered so much food both times. Everything was spectacularly flavorful. The Shrimp 'n Grits is not to miss: simple but amazingly delicious.

5JDxIIIf1RIPWPm9fB7zTQ.review_text: This Restaraunt is so beautiful.... Wonderfully decorated..... The food WAS excellent, I devoured everything on my plate and even helped out my husband with his plate.... Our waiter was nice, and very knowledgable. We had friends from across the world with us, that spoke very little English. She took the time to listen and offer suggestions regarding their  orders. At the very end of our experience, the owner came by our table and asked how we were, and how our food was.... We took a few minutes to talk about the Restaraunt.. She was SO sweet, and the effort and energy her and her husband put into the Restaraunt truly shows!!!. This is my new favorite restaurant..... I will be back again.... And very soon!  If you want high quality food, and some southern hospitality, This is the place to be....

J28tIsMKedTdkhGRMcOgxg.review_text: Come here to try the restaurant week menu 1st course Winter citrus salad with (salted roasted beets fresh ricotta, wild argula, good balanced  between all the ingredient 2nd course Grill Hanger steak (Peppardaw Potato hash, Blue Cheese, Crispy Shallots Horsedish Creme Fraiche) wow that is really great have horsedish sauce with steak almost never happen nowadays when  having steak. Yummy! 3rd course Apple cobbler with vanilla bean ice cream add on side: white  truffle mac and cheese that fill up the hunger in no time, plus the rcornbread with spicy honey sauce, wow so  yummy I have to take one home for breakfast. All in all a great meal for a cost of $40 plus $7.5 for mac and cheese great.

XvmvSxypXbOY9Td6VLf8-A.review_text: Went to 1300 on Fillmore on Monday evening for the first time...the food was delicious and reasonably priced. The restaurant was quiet being a Monday, but still a lovely atmosphere. We share the Catfish entree, which was delicious and split 2 appetizers and 2 sides. We had the goat cheese salad(small), and the shrimp hushpuppies (small as well). The Mac and Cheese side was good as well as the Brussel sprouts. The cornbread was yummy with the honey butter and jalapeno jelly. I highly recommend the restaurant for some good comfort food.....and this is coming from a southern gal!

CiJat5Up2jAO3B0qTbiN5Q.review_text: I came here one night with friends.  Combine the great company with a delightful atmosphere that includes a live jazz band in the background, and delicious delectable food, and you have a winner.  The lounge area is cozy with comfortable chairs.  The focal point of the room is the stage with the live band.  While we didn't sit there, it did get a little loud, because you would have to talk above the music.  But in the dining room, the music sets up the mood for the evening and it's just right.  For starters I would recommend either the sweet breads or the braised pork belly.  Both have have healthy portions, though they may not be the healthiest for you (as all delicious things usually aren't).  I ordered the short ribs for my entree.  It was so tender and perfectly paired with the buttermilk mashed potatoes.  If I had liked onion rings, I'm sure they would have been a great match to the dish as well.  But don't worry, they didn't go to waste.  My friend benefited from my pickiness.  Don't forget to order a side of the mac and cheese.  It's made with white cheddar and then topped with a crunch layer of bread crumbs.  Yummy.  It wasn't too heavy, but still wonderfully rich.  For dessert, we shared the sorbet with petite fours - but don't think of those little cakes, this was a special plate of a variety of little cookies and chocolates and such.  The sorbets were Meyer lemon and pear flavored.  The pear was mild, but the lemon was very refreshing and a perfect ending to a rich meal.  I would definitely recommend this place.

R5_QYmOZxTnyFU92PUccVA.review_text: Our Bartender Nikki was cool to hang out with. Dinner and Ambiance was good. I liked the Chef/Owner coming out to greet people.  Snap-shots, and video stills dipicting scenes from the Fillmore's Jazz/Bop hey-day.  We haven't tried the "Gospel Brunch" yet, but being that this place is so "quaint" I don't see how they could really pull off such a thing.

CMdFQ0y0zvzBS2x6tjZcWA.review_text: My bf and I decided to take a break from the Fillmore Jazz Festival to relax in brown leather tufted wing chairs in the lounge for some bites and drinks.  The decor in here is classic with dark browns and black and white photos of famous people from the past. The high ceiling and large windows modernize the classic atmosphere in here though.   They have excellent service- clearing tables, filling water glasses and simply friendly.  The food is damn good too.     Matchstick Okra -  This was different.  The okra was cut into slivers and fried lightly with a mayonnaise based dip- quite tasty!  Fat Fries - They were exactly that.  They looked like Yucca fries but so hot and fresh dipped in their homemade ketchup!  Pork Sliders - Wow, this was the best!  Imagine flavorful shreds of pulled pork between a couple warm toasted buns slathered with ketchup and some fancy mustard.    All of this hit the spot.  We were glad to have randomly waltzed in here for a break from the crowd outside.  We would come back for an upscale dinner!

tvOTNC1Qk6ITc-sWbobDCA.review_text: This place is so classy, I have no business being in there. Yet there we were on my birthday, with Wavy Gravy at the table to my left and Too Short at the bar. I felt like a star! A King amongst Kings! I must warn you that the food is small plates, but it is spectacular. I came here after having recently ordered rabbit at two other establishments in the city (damn you Stinking Rose!) and having been severely disappointed I was hoping the 3rd time would be the charm and indeed it was! I made sure to ask if it was 'wascally' and the waiter very seriously assured me that they only serve the wascalliest of wabbits. Thanks for humoring me waiter! As a concierge I send guests there all the time and everyone always comes back delighted. On Saturdays they sell some nice cajun delights at the Fillmore Farmer's Market like shrimp n' grits for just 5 bucks! Shrimps n' grits might not sound too hot but trust me they are delicious.

O6ZWwuCCe7rcKK-1JxB6rg.review_text: I was here, last night, with friends celebrating a friend's birthday.  It's a lounge and restaurant in which its environment seems inviting and classy casual.   The waitress was very personable and knowledgeable about the menu.  My friends and I ordered our entrees in communal and everything we had were delish!  Even if you do not like grits I would recommend trying the BBQ Shrimp & Grits.  This was my first, in a long time, enjoying grits and the dish leaves you wanting more.  The fried chicken was good, but meat was a little dry.  Now for dessert: presentation was elegant and everything came out on a timely manner.  There was a minor mix-up, but still delectable in taste.   Would I come here on a regular basis?  Due to price, no.  However, I would come back again on special occasions.

KGqBaeJioyo1srVlrDP1mQ.review_text: I just love 1300 and the shrimp and grits are so smooth! Definite must try and dress nice while your at it! Merci to the Chef!

5Muo-Bwu09liBqt413iaTw.review_text: Very fun Sunday brunch. We brought our kids and they loved the music too.

9nzenZCTfWk9AiMlXnsafQ.review_text: Yummy yummy yummy! Very flavorful dining, the ambiance is nice, the staff was friendly and I would for sure eat here again! Love all of the decor, the interior design is outstanding. Id like to describe the cuisine as "fancy comfort food". sooo good!

NfKrxI4hUlY3fFQfsFstYQ.review_text: There's a difference between comfort food and grossness.  I went here the other night, and decided to try a lot of stuff, since everything looked interesting. Here's what I had and thoughts:  --Cornbread - this was good.  --Shrimp hushpuppies - these were good too, but I should have known at this point what everything else was going to be like - greasy.  --Charcuterie plate - everything was waaaaay to salty.  --Mac & Cheese - This was not mac & cheese.
