It almost tasted like they mixed cheese with some sort of dry seasonal mixing that you put in those rices in the box - you know the kind you buy from the store and haven't probably eaten since the 80's when you had it for dinner as a kid?  --Little Gem Salad - this was by far the most disgusting salad I have ever tasted. It was like they coated each piece of lettuce with an-inch thick coating of mayonnaise - it was THAT gross.  Overall - When I left, I had hardly taken a few bites of everything I got, ended up paying an arm and a leg for it all, and felt oversalted and overly grossed out thinking about the food that half ate.

ZFTjUb8yPIwxew_MfLIdgg.review_text: For me to give a place two stars there has GOT to be something wrong with it. I mean seriously, besides the ambiance of the 1930's jazz feel the service totally sucked and the food was not all that great. Granted i just threw a birthday bash here and they had to accommodate 20 people, i would think that they would have their stuff in order. The waitress wasn't all that friendly he just went around asking everyone what did they want to order and didn't explain much of anything. we all felt rushed and unwanted. I was thinking about going again...but i rather pass. The only way i would step foot in this place if i was going on a date and he surprised me.....Good thing it was my bday bc i would of cringed spending my money on a piece i fish i could of made in the comfort of my own home.   In all actually you are paying for the atmosphere. But why just pay for the atmosphere where you can pay for good food and atmosphere.

Zcg8WQHGP8kLAIMfbvfgUA.review_text: I had a really great experience at this place. The service was perfect, the food was delicious and the atmosphere was relaxing/chill. We had a very friendly waiter who was very attentive and knew exactly what we wanted. I really liked the complimentary cornbread that was given to us. The Fried Chicken looked like a rip off so I didn't bother with that ($23 for it?). We did order short beef ribs which were delicious along with the Mac. and Cheese and the Shrimp Hush Puppies. All were very good and I thought the portions were just right. The dessert was good too as we ordered a Bread PUdding. I"m usually not a fan of it but I had to agree it was good. I really can't wait to come here again and actually listen to a Jazz show.

Nc4uWHBuFF407t3MzX0tOg.review_text: I almost want to throw on my flapper outfit when I think of this place. It's like a smoooooooooooooooth operator. Sitting down I envisioned a bustling Harlem with the furs galore and the pretty ladies in slinky dresses. "Spotlights" illuminate the sassy restaurant and chic bar. The food was pretty unique. Delicious= the macaroni and white cheddar cheese, the sauteed mushrooms with the grits, the pumpkin spiced potatoes? -with their own special ketchup. YUM! The salmon was good. The black-eyed pea cakes I cold have lived with out...

HlnofZWZtH41ba6S0quaGQ.review_text: so after circling around fillmore for about 20 minutes...  "let's just park in this safeway parking lot"... leaving our car in what we THINK is a public parking lot, we walk into 1300.  the vibe was cool, the jazz music had a nice sound...and the decor was beautiful.  as we wait for our table, we stop by the bar.   "yummy!  you say you have pomegranate mojitos?  i'll take one"!    i would say the service here is great!  the hostess was nice enough to wait while we paid our bar tab, the waitress was nice, the ...ummm...is it manager, dave? was nice...even our busboy was nice (he's the one who brought some tabasco to the table)!  time to order... "let's have the fried chicken, mac n' cheese, spiced fat fries, and some brussel sprouts...oh...and beignets for dessert" ( ...and...no...this wasn't all for me)!  everything that came out was delish!  even our free corn bread was on hit!    as the good times and good food ends...and it was time to leave...we walk back to the safeway parking lot...to what should've been a perfect night of good eats...until...  "oh, hell no!  where's our car?!"

I8qcBf_gSc9eWLDnSumW7A.review_text: Great place, swanktified atmosphere that fits with its neighbor, Yoshi's. Perfect night out, dinner at 1300, show at Yoshi's after or vice versa.   The cornbread biscuits with honey butter were delish, so were the shrimp appetizer with grits.  Loved the mac & cheese, a variety with that one seasoning my grandma used to use in mac and cheese!  (Sadly I don't know what it is).  I had the spare ribs, great presentation and fell off the bone.  My date got the fried chicken.  I once again had food envy because it was really really really good!

HorQ90eiUPfnesQlIraaJA.review_text: This is a review of Happy Hour (5-7:30pm M-F)  I recently got a job and can now imbibe in an after-work cocktail and snack with my bf. Let's set the stage here and say I am still so cheap from my recent unemployment stint that I had spent exactly $2 on lunch all week, so it is fair to say I'm "thrifty"  I read about this deal and it had gotten good reviews, and is in my neighborhood - basically the deal is that some drinks are $5 (well and sparkling wine, some beers are $3.50). Then some asterisked (*) bar snacks are also half price (I would say about 50% of them are included in this deal). My bf had 2 beers, I had one lemon drink cocktail (on special for $8, and seriously tasty) We also ordered 3 bar snacks - in order of tastiest (best at the top): -Short rib sliders- YUM -Mushrooms and grits  - pretty dang delish -Chicken strips (which I think tasted kinda fishy but my bf disagreed)  Bill $45 with tip.  so I guess I won't be back but it was nice to get out.  Oh, and the space is nice, service is attentive its but kinda loud and (ladies) there are purse hooks in the ladies room- bonus! (but no running water the night I was there - so that bonus is null)

miOc5bKHCoZSY6zMAtJ0KQ.review_text: The neighborhood is a little sketchy...hence the 3 rating. However, the food was delicious and the atomosphere was very elegant. We sat in the lounge area in oversized chairs with low tables. It was a very intimate setting. We ordered some of their signature cocktails as well as some of our personal favorites. Their beer selection is a little ritzy but I guess if you are going to a place as nice as 1300 you are not looking for a heiniken light.  Anyways, we ordered a ton of appetizers including their spicy french fries with homemade ketchup and macaroni and cheese, both of which were FANTASTIC! Also, in lieu of bread on the table, they brought over little jalapeno corn bread muffins with honey butter. So tasty, I could have eaten all night.  For dinner, half of the group got the fried chicken and mashed potatoes. It was tasty, as with everything else, but the portion size and plating was off. They seriously gave me three huge chicken breasts piled atop mashed potatoes. My friend got the black eyed pea cake which was delicately placed on the plate. making me think the fried chicken dish, while delicious, is out of place on their menu.   Overall, great place to go. its a little pricey, especially for its location in the 'hood, but that's the price you'll pay anywhere in the city for such a nice, relaxing, intimate setting.

Q8BS0HbtMqH295h46UsL7w.review_text: GOSPEL BRUNCH REVIEW: YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS. I love randomly finding awesome restaurants.  I was walking around Japantown, trying to figure out where to eat for brunch. Then I saw 1300 on Fillmore across the street and spontaneously decided to check out the place. As soon as I entered, I got super excited because 1) the place is well decorated (I really like the lounge with all the pictures!!), 2) extremely talented musicians were singing and playing gospel songs (I didn't start eating until they finished), and 3) there was a table open right in front of the music. Service, atmosphere, decor, and just everything seemed so great that I doubted that the food could be just as amazing. Fortunately, I was pleasantly surprised by the yummmmmy food (I ordered the eggs benedict and my friend got the rib eye burger)... THIS PLACE IS PERFECT; THEY GOT EVERYTHING RIGHT. I'm coming back for the gospel brunch for sure, and I want to try dinner as well!

muPKUHFQnK5_G55k48Avkw.review_text: Wow! I was thoroughly impressed with this place from beginning to end and I rarely get that excited about a restaurant.   Went in with no reservation and got seated immediately even though the restaurant was mostly full. There was a really good jazz band playing in the lobby. The space is really sweet, especially the wall in the lounge with floor to ceiling backlit old pictures. The layout is a bit odd and confusing and I ended up wandering into the kitchen looking for the bathroom.   Our waitress was awesome. She was barely there, but didn't miss a step and was really friendly. Water glasses never went half empty and my conversation with my friend was never interrupted.   Oh yeah, and then the food. The food! Holy Mary mother of god. The pumpkin bisque with vanilla and mascarpone was a gift from Mary's own bosom. The fried chicken was rich and tender and juicy and ahhhh....  The arctic char was just a big ol' protein plate, with an andouille and lobster hash. Yeah, that was probably the best dish of the night. The fish was crispy and flavorful and the hash was a perfect compliment.   I wanted to mention that David, the owner/chef came out during our meal, stopped by the table just to say hello and make sure we were enjoying our food. It's a very small touch that I think few restaurants, if any, seem to take advantage of anymore. I can remember (and count on one hand) every restaurant that I've been greeted by the chef, but it's one of the single most memorable things about a place.   I'll definitely be coming back for more. One of my culinary high points in 2008 was coming to 1300.

hP8by2q4mgfQEvvhfChcbQ.review_text: I had been in a food slump. I feel like I had been paying quite a bit of money for meals that didn't seem to have the San Francisco glam I craved. That is all until I came to 1300 on Fillmore. Amazing. The grits with mushrooms were delight on my tongue, the short ribs so moist and flavorful and fell right from the bone and the macaroni and cheese was more than I could have imagined (even from a Southern style restaurant). The sea bass also ordered at my table ranks among the best I have ever had...just the right amount of fish flavor and flaky beyond what can be expected.   I did think the dcor was a bit odd - I get the idea, but offering different seats to different guests leaves me convinced that someone else's must be better than mine and it makes one table height a bit awkward. The server was interesting - really on par and the start and then we never saw him again...ever. Regardless, I would come here again and again, even if I had to serve myself.

rgLKap9rij7gyTDmJC-4zA.review_text: sooo i came here this past weekend for an 830 p.m. reservation.  we were lead to the first table by the door and i politely asked if we could be seated at the next table over (which was empty) and was met with the response that "it's reserved".  uuuhhh, didn't i have a reservation? and really, who wants to sit next to the door on a freezing cold SF evening? anyways, the server let the hostess (weird right) know that it was just fine (of course it was) to seat our party there and all was fine.  i must say, the decor here is very cool and evokes the jazz vibe of the whole area; however, for me, that might be the highlight of the evening.  our service was snail-like and several times we tried to get his attention and he seemed to blow past our 3top to service larger parties in the dining room.  Our food was just OK.  i got the mixed green salad, which was pretty standard and honestly, it just took me ten minutes to remember what i are for dinner!  I had the super mediocre mac & cheese.  I LOVE mac n cheese and was looking forward to a hot, bubbly, cheesy delight. what i was served was a lukewarm, over breadcrumbed, not cheesy at all bowl of noodles.  I also ordered a side of brussel sprouts - assuming I would be served green, crisp vegetables but lo and behold - my plate had only wilted, soggy, semi-green veggies. what WAS really good was my friend's fried chicken...yum city.  the culinary highlight aside from the fried chicken was the sweet, cornbread brought out with butter and jalapeno jelly.  I dont think i'll return for the food but perhaps will swing by the bar for a cocktail.

2cb3zu1WFEzVnUFil4XPzg.review_text: Let me start by saying the food was excellent.  A friend and I were just saying how we wished yelp reviews were more based on food and not service.   Our one night in the city- one of us from Hawaii and one from San Diego.  We paid for a cab to/from, so excited to try a 4 star (yelp) place.   We sat at the bar but was barely offered one drink in our time there.  We had to cab to another bar for our 2nd drink.  Including water.   Service is not everything but I change my stance that it does matter.

WXhsGQ7UzYOODPV_UOPiMg.review_text: Fantastic service. Every person that we met was over the top nice. The place is beautiful and the food was delicious.  We started with short rib sliders, which were amazing. Even the tiny buns were lightly toasted. The meat was moist and flavorful. The Black Skillet Fried Chicken, Buttermilk Whipped Potatoes was delish, but the chicken a tiny bit too salty. But, our dinners were overall, fantastic and we could not have been treated any better. I will be back.

4YJ-MvlStx9WPDeCKMpaPA.review_text: I've had better... A lot better. Portion size was underwhelming and the meal was overpriced. I ordered the short rib and it tasted like something that you'd get in a high school cafeteria. The wine list was somewhat impressive and reasonably priced so I'll give this place two stars.

9uhOuCTlULaxLZj_j8KWHw.review_text: Ambiance wise this place rocks! Absolutely gorgeous! Service was actually quite good. No issues an super friendly & attentive. The issue was with the food. My fiend got the burger which had a maple glaze and freshcut homemade chips and homemade pickles and ketchup. Love the homemade stuff! We got a side of homemade fries which kicked ass! He said his burger was overly sweet though and only finishes half. The cook made a specialty vegetarian dish for me as they had not one on their menu! It was a parmsean polenta type dish w/ white and green beans. While good, it was like eating baby food. Just a pile of mush. My Mojito was pretty good, though Q-bar does it best. Mt friend and I agreed that we'd definitely go back for the ambiance to have a drink and maybe even dessert, but never again for a meal.

bA6sFAZTIc5ddwpnB_WJUw.review_text: What's this?  Truffle oil in my grits?  Creme fraiche and a fried okra in my oyster bisque?  Thai red pepper jam for my cornbread?  Shrimp in my hushpuppies?  San Francisco's first upscale fusion soul food and it's all kinds of delicious.  Elegant and old school loungey, spot on formal service, you can lean back in a plush couch and eat off a massive wooden coffee table on a Persian-style rug.  The interior has big back-lit historical photos of jazz legends and common folk who used to live in this part of town back in the day.   They promise live jazz soon.  Wooop wooop bring your date this neighborhood is hot.

punt5xNJonD3Z0itZZjdHg.review_text: I rarely write reviews but I've been using yelp so much on our trip to San Fran that I felt it was warranted.  We went here a bit based off a friend of a friend and the yelp reviews. The place was very nice and quiet with a great vibe until a party of 20 showed up, but I don't fault the restaurant for that.  The service was very good and I was very happy with that. As for the food, the pork belly appetizer was good, the gem salad was good, my pork ribs were a little dry but the BBQ sauces were very good and made the difference between a ho hum dish and a good dish. My wife had the fried chicken and It was the best fried chicken I've ever tasted and she loved it. All and all the place was good, but not great, very happy we went but as an out of towner I wouldn't hurry back if I was back in town.

vRjVhl3ONG2GfWY4NXJZbQ.review_text: So I'm still a fan, but now I can definitively say I'm more of a fan of the lounge.  Here's what happened in the dinning area:  The quality, presentation, and taste of the food remained the same as last time, but the overall experience just wasn't as comfort. Most of the blame can be attributed to the seating.  At our table, the chairs on one side were too high and it felt as if you were hovering over the food, but if you sat on the sofa side, you sank below the table and had to hoist yourself up to eat.  There was no happy medium. Can you say awkward?  But the night wasn't a total loss. Here are the highlights for dinner:  The fried green tomato salad was the best I've had.  The tomatoes retained their firm texture on the inside while the outside was crisp and a little spicy.  But what really caught my attention was they weren't greasy: a first for me. The chocolate cake was heavenly.  It was so incredibly light and airy yet still felt very rich.  It's hard to fathom how that was achieved when you consider how dense and decadent the chocolate it tasted.  Outstanding.  On a side note, the fried chicken fell a little flat and I can't explain why.  I know it was missing something and it bothers me to say I don't know what that was exactly. Does that mean I have to go back once again? If it does, I'll be having my meal in the lounge.  Cheers.

WBiBUFlN4BNp_VRbtQwSOQ.review_text: Great lounge area with decent cocktails. Went for the first time this past Saturday night. Had a few drinks in the lounge then sat down for our reservation. Good service, good food. Nothing out of this world, but will eventually go back to try something else on the menu. Was pretty drunk by the time we ate.

fSzJO3tSVQ6DNx6jNf_fzA.review_text: Oh, hello Ms. Fried Chicken. Will you marry me???...Cuz if you did, I would die a happy man! Your chive mashed potato and oh-so-buttery biscuits are worth the $25. Plus your friend Pork Belly with a Fried Egg is amazing too. My only complaint is that you might want to turn down the music so I can concentrate on loving the succulent short ribs, baby (got) backs, and truffle mac which was a bit small (I love big macs and I cannot lie)!

Qv70ohno_2uMSSEVxddNbg.review_text: Our favorite new "fancy" restaurant. Casual, high end, fun all at the same time. Great staff and food! Love it!

GI8gZF8o1n7nUG1df-0P8w.review_text: We went here for my birthday and from reading the reviews I was so excited. Not only was the service bad (and the restaurant was 35% full) but  the over priced food is exactly that. Over priced for average tasting food. Not sure if the kitchen had a bad night but we won't be returning. Fried green tomatoes were ok and the fried chicken was ok. Should have gone to KFC. My fiancé ordered their dinner special rack of ribs for $36 and it tasted like they forgot to season it. We are both total foodies and were so disappointed that we spent a lot of money on a blah meal that lacked flavor and in service.

aBtuLnsvG_z4PLmhhXZ1UA.review_text: such a great friendly vibe! food is great and i don't even like southern style food.  yum yum cornbread!

sTI36pLS61hbU6JMcMu4YQ.review_text: Ok now they came through, there has to be someone new running that kitchen! Instead of infant size portion they gave me a normal human size. They did forget my blue cheese for the chicken but hey can't win them all.

WJfNVm4mXXDt1Vakg13CpA.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore, located next to Yoshi's Jazz Club and Lounge, offers a refreshing contrast of Southern soul food in the heart of Pacific Height's Japan/K-town. The restaurant itself presents itself as a gourmet restaurant with a casual/lounge atmosphere, somewhat similar to Yoshi's. I thought the decorum of the restaurant was quite elegant; my only suggestion is that the lighting could be brighter because the entire time I felt like I was eating with just a candlelight.  Their menu seems mostly consistent, in that most of the suggestions us yelpers mention will be on the menu. Our group shared the Bourbon hickory-smoked pork belly and roasted brussel sprouts. Although I didn't have the pork belly, the bourbon flavors came through well in the braised butter beans that accompanied it. I particularly enjoyed the combination of the flavors that the egg yolk provided.  The brussel sprouts were cooked well but was lacking in flavor, so if you decide to get a side, I would recommend the truffle oil mac and cheese.   Overall, the entrees were delicious, with large portions per order. Think Cheesecake Factory portions, which were good for sharing. My friends were very impressed with the the black skillet fried chicken and catfish with jambalaya; both were packed with flavor and cooked to tender perfection. The braised beef short rib was equally tender but could have been cooked for less because it was a little dry. Initially I planned on ordering the bay scallops but they had ran out, since our reservation was at 9; so I had the butternut squash risotto instead...which was quite disappointing. The sweetness of the butternut squash puree was clean but its texture masked the risotto's. In the end, I felt like I was just eating squash puree which isn't particularly appealing.   Overall, 1300 on Fillmore is an enjoyable restaurant for offering a gourmet, elegant menu of American Southern comfort foods; but is not fine dining or extremely phenomenal to the extent which it is a must-go-to place in SF. Depending on your tastes, you will either really like it or find it mediocre. Since I like soul food, every now and then, I thought it was quite good.

ct4vYvNgmkXdnb3jgureHw.review_text: This place truly has the best food of all time!  It is by far the best restaurant I have been to in San Francisco to date.  The pork chop, beef short ribs and fish are out of this world.  The service is phenomenal, the atmosphere is great, I truly don't have anything negative to say about my experiences at 1300.  I took my brother here when he visited me from Kentucky and he said it was the bar-b-que shrimp and grits are the best dish he'd ever had in a restaurant.  My brother is fairly non-descript and the farthest thing from a foodie, but he was practically salivating when he said this.   It made me extremely happy to see him so excited about eating out!  Overall, I have never had a bad night hanging out at 1300 and eating delicious food, so I highly recommend it to all of you!

QgPGXQqSwxhEAY5zUq3aCg.review_text: I love the live jazz, and the food is pretty good.  But really, you can only fancy up fried chicken and bbq so much.  After that you are trying too hard.  As soon as 1300 realizes that and takes a deep breath, I think they'll end up with 4 stars.

PzsrU6dhIGXbTN_p4mQBTQ.review_text: O.K., so I did alot of eating on my birthday but hey - IT'S MY BIRTHDAY & I'LL DO WHAT I WANT!!!! So after a full-fillng lunch @ Lime Tree Southeast Asian Kitchen, my big b-day dinner was @ the ultra sexy 1300 on Fillmore. After going to a reception during the opening of this restaurant, we were treated to some bites that were considered the highlights of their modern southern menu. I was hooked after trying the small lamb burgers (I am NOT a big fan of lamb!) & swore I was going to try the full menu one day.  They were accommodating when some of us were running late which was very nice. We were seated in a very comfortable corner section of the restaurant with the exception of an annoying 'dead' tree that kept on poking the back of anyone's head (including George our fabulous waiter) when they stood there. We started off with shrimp hushpuppies , bbq shrimp w/grits & the maple braised pork belly. Out of the 3, the pork belly was to die for! Get me bottle of lipitor!!! Tender & succulent, I savored my small morsel of cholesterol (thank God Calvin cut the tiny thing into 7 pieces!)! Then I debated over the signature organic skillet fried chicken & the braised short rib entree. Since 3 of us were getting the fried chicken, I opted for the braised short rib on George the waiter's suggestion hoping my friends would be kind enough to share the chicken. Linda was so generous enough to share 1/2 a piece of the chicken with me & others (she was full from the app's) & all I could do is just enjoy the juiciness of that memorable chicken. I forgot about the short ribs I had ordered. Mind you, what I tasted of the short ribs was awesome but that chicken totally dominated my entire meal!  The rest of the meal was a fuzzy memory & the bill pretty pricey but considering all we ate & drank it was worth it! (considering the week before that we ate next door @ Yoshi's & spent just as much but ate 1/4 of what we had @ 1300 and swore we'd eat here before watching a show there.)

HRsy8rz1ZwcVum2vyoCnXw.review_text: I'm so happy that we decided to have our small wedding reception/dinner of 12 here.  It has that old school-ish glamy jazzy look about it which I thought was the perfect setting for us and nice for pictures (especially if you're sitting on the leather benches along the wall).. We all thought that the food was delicious.  The cornbread, hushpuppies, fried chicken and maple short ribs were the BEST and were the favorites.  Over the course of dinner I heard a series of "mmmmmMm"s.  Everything was SO good.  We also had an excellent and very attentive server (thank you Annette!!).   1300 Fillmore unlike other restaurants we looked into didn't require that we spend a minimum or that we pick just a few items on the menu for everyone to choose from.  So everyone was free to get whatever they wanted...totally no restrictions.  I REALLY appreciated that.  When we were all done w/dinner, they came out with little plates of the cupcakes we brought in and then boxed everything plus extra cupcakes for each of us to take home.  Very very nice!

QPhKwoNEGYzIeidIOh-5gQ.review_text: All seven of us were excited for a tasty dinner at 1300 Fillmore last Monday. We'd all heard amazing things about the food but none of us at been there before. We made reservations for 8:00pm and were sat at a nice round table in the front right when we arrived. And that was the end of things going smoothly. After being sat at our table we were left waiting for about 10 minutes before our waitress came over to take our drink orders. Another 10-15 minutes went by before we got one of the two glasses of wine we'd ordered and two of the three arnold palmers. Luckily the other two people at the table had ordered water and water had been delivered by a bus boy. At this point we grabbed a waiter walking by to ask if he could get our waitress so we could order since the fried chicken said it took 20 minutes to prepare and it was a work night. Surprisingly he said he would take our order and started asking us what we wanted without pulling out a pen or paper. There were seven of us at the table and we were sharing entrees and having salads and substituting a few things so there was definitely some worry about him remembering such a large order without taking any notes. He walked away and another 15 minutes went by during which my friend received her glass of wine but we didn't get the arnold palmer. At this point our original waitress came back and said she unfortunately needed to "reconfirm" our orders as the HOST had forgotten everything we'd said. There was no mention of a free round of drinks or really any acknowledgment of the fact that the three orders of fried chicken were going to take at least 20 minutes from this point, not the point 15 minutes ago when we had ordered the first time. Without letting this drag on too much, I will say that our food finally came, except for the side of mac and cheese that arrived just as we were finished eating and our waitress never mentioned taking anything off the bill to make up for the bad service.   Unfortunately for the restaurant, the food was really good. So good that we had a ten minute conversation at our table about whether we would ever come back since the service was so horrendous but the food was so good. I said that I would only come back if I was already pretty drunk and with a guy that I could make out with at the table while waiting for my food and drinks to come. Overall we decided we'll never come back. San Francisco has a lot of good food and much much better service elsewhere.

QCRq_vZeTtuqeK3e4PejXA.review_text: Found this place on Yelp and decided to try it...  Beautiful place, but the host very rude. They were a bit busy in the lounge area, so we sat in the dining room. The waiter was just alright. He was not very attentive. I just expected better service for dinner. The Pork Belly was to die for! Next time, we'll definitely try to do the lounge area, where it seems to be more relaxed.   Overall, service was a 3. Food was about a 4. Wine bottles? 5 :)  Would go back to it.

ean_YWYLmK7dUVdK6upFlw.review_text: I grew up in the Fillmore, however, due to the crazy housing prices and awful parking situation, I have been living in the East Bay for the past 10 years. During one of my frequent trips to S.F to visit relatives, I was excited to notice 1300 on Fillmore and decided I wanted to dine there on my up coming wedding anniversary. I made reservations via Open Table(7:30), however, I ran late so I called to ask the hostess if there would be a table available at 9:30pm. I was assured there would be a table available. So I thought, GREAT! Upon our arrival I happily advised the hostess I called ahead to secure a table, she quickly cut me off with' right this way'. The place was really busy so I was still very happy that we were accommodated at such short notice.   After being shown to our table, the waiter came over and offered to get us drinks, I ordered a Key Lime cocktail and my husband asked for water. Drinks took about 10 min. ( okay, they are busy)  After receiving our drinks we did not see 'our' waiter for another 10 min. ( okay they are busy) So we get another waiter who happily informs us of the special which my husband ordered ( Ribs). Did no see our waiter for another 20 min. (Okay, they are busy) After receiving our food ( we were starving) we were disappointed to find the food cold. The waiter did not check-in  with us to make sure we were satisfied with our food. My husband attempted to gain the waiters attention several times with no luck. The hostess then comes over, with her back to me, begins to ask my husband if we are enjoying our meal. (huh?) At that point my husband and I decided to leave.   After thinking about my poor experience for over a week I decided to call 1300 to discuss my experience with the manager. To my delight, the manager was attentive and professional. By the end of the week, I received a gift card and personalized apology letter. As a result, my husband and I decided to give 1300 another try...stay tuned.

9PA59Kv8CND03Wa057iG1g.review_text: great vibe, all else is weak. Too much $$$ for too little quality food or service.

x9tpYPYSt8MGZe8v60i8OQ.review_text: One word about this place - yummy! I can't order anything other than the surf-n-turf: scallops, pulled bbq pork, greens...actually, I don't want to order anything else! I have had the bbq shrimp and grits which was finger lickin' good and the sliders were mouth wateringly delicious as well. The surf-n-turf has a special place in my heart though. The decor, drinks, staff, etc. are all perfect. Absolutely perfect (like the surf-n-turf). The only reason it's not a 5 star is because it's oh so pricey. Oh so worth it though!

2xLEMsSeCSsk8hnfw_bg1w.review_text: Very pleased with this new upscale option walking distance from my house.  Looks like the bar will be an awesome spot to hang out and drink.  The restaurant was relatively empty last night, but that may have been because it was Halloween.  My review:  Great wine, list, but poorly organized.  It's about 10 pages long, and the wines that are available by the glass are not listed in each place - there's one or two on each page.  Only one draft beer, Trumer.  Full bar.  We had sauteed mushrooms on marscapone grits to start - SUPER DELICIOUS!!!  We had bouillabaisse, which is "deconstructed" - a wee bit of liquid in the bowl and everything perched on top.  The person who ordered that does not eat meat, and the sausage was on the side so it wasn't a problem. It was very good.  The fried chicken was also very good, but the pieces were different sizes and so some were more done than others.  It was served with truffled mashed potatoes - excellent.  Neither of us liked the mac and cheese, one because it tasted like bacon, the other because it tasted like red pepper.  The service was very good and attentive, but (1) no spoon for the bouillabaisse (2) they took away the cornbread when they cleared the appetizers and (3) no tablecloths, so the plate moves around when you are trying to cut something.  Minor quibbles, of course.

xXTTNR94AmbmdtiemRciXw.review_text: My third visit here. I REALLY want love this place, but the food is SO underwhelming! For starters we ordered the pork belly with the duck egg. I feel like it should have been called baked beans with duck eggs and A small piece of pork belly. I am not sure what I expected, but that was not it.   For the entree, I ordered the short rib dish. It came on a bed of tapioca something or the other. It was totally unpalatable! I sent it back. The server was extremely gracious and offered to have the tapioca stuff replaced with mashed potatoes. It was okay. The food was definitely not hot, but warm-ish. My date ordered the burger, which was "okay". We've had better (I took a bite).   For the amount of money I spent here, I would expect a much better culinary experience. The service is definitely wonderful. Great servers and reception staff.

nwPjw7W9V_7PA2QhwTha-Q.review_text: My wife and I went looking for a hip Jazz bar on Fillmore one Friday night and discovered 1300 (after trying the overcrowded and understaffed Yoshi's next door). It has been a favorite of mine ever since and I try to go here whenever I come to the city, especially for a show at the FIllmore or Kabuki. The food is amazing (personal favorite - Grits with sauteed mushrooms!) and the cocktails are equally good (favorite is the "Hundred Reasons Rye", but they also make a fantastic Gin Martini). Staff is very friendly and the lounge area in the front part of the bar is plush! overstuffed leather couches and chairs, with lots of great old pictures on the walls of the historic Fillmore district. Having cocktails in a highback leather chair while smiling Jazz greats look on behind you makes you feel like a million bucks. Plus on weekends they bring in live jazz trios and the lounge really gets packed in. If you're looking for a classy, low key place to hang out on the Fillmore, look no further than 1300!

V966zuEyKu0Qpt-49PuZGw.review_text: Gospel Brunch review:  First, this is a great idea.  Live gospel with a sunday brunch, I mean, it works out well.  Lets start with the good:    1.  The Music.  The live band really was talented and the provided rich, soulful entertaining music throughout the brunch.  Talented musicians here, and their sound dripped like sweetened butter across our ears  2. The Food.  Classic soul food with classic San Francisco high-endculinary skills fully applied.  Eggs Benedict:  Nice twist with the spiciness.  Cornbread, sweet/hot jelly, check, check, YUM.  Even plain old scrambled eggs were executed perfectly.    So, why only 3 stars?  Well, mainly its the price.  Its fixed-price at $40/person, and thats a lot for a brunch.  Its called a 3-course brunch.  The cornbread and the muffins are delicious and can certainly demand a premium.  The desserts were good, but none of us really needed them.  The last perk you get is "Bottomless Pomosas", which is a sparkling white wine drink.  Ah the legendary bottomless brunch drink.  This alone should have made the $40 price worth it.  And if they executed this critical part of the meal right, and made us feel the $40 was well spent, then this could have been a 4-5 star review.  Unfortunately, the Pomosas were just not that great.  They were sweet but not strong.  None of us even got a small buzz.  Now, don't get me wrong, we were not looking to get trashed or anything, but a cocktail at brunch is Why We Do Brunch.  A bottomless brunch drink should get you buzzed, and hey, if you want to get trashed, that should be an option.  But it wasn't happening.  The other main problem was that after the show ,they rushed us off the table. The giant Pomosa valve was switched off 10 minutes earlier, so there we sat with empty glasses, and they asked us to please move to the lounge so they could set the table for the next sitting.  Now, I am sorry, but the place wasn't even full.  I saw no reason why they had to chase us off our table. Again, I would not care if this was a $20/person brunch.  But it wasn't.  It was $40/each.  They should have allowed us to relax at our table there.  This almost pushed my review down to 2 stars, but I didn't think it was fair because like I said, the music and food was great.  One final nitpick, and this is not reflected in my Rating, its just a suggestion. I appreciate the musicians getting some audience participation going, its fun.  But we can't all sing.  Especially into a mic.  I was approached and I was a sport and tried to sing, but trust me, I suck.  It was a bit embarrassing.  I will chat you up all you want, but please, don't make me sing, okay?  So, in closing, a fun place and a good idea, but if you are going to charge that much $$$ for the experience, you really need to provide a better value.  Don't rush us through, and provide better bottomless drinks.  If this meal was $25/person, it would probably be an easy 5-star experience.  But the value just was not there.

Qdb8U9Tl96o4gVkbQHwyRg.review_text: Well we are giving them another try and so far it's the same whack service as before. And we haven't got our food yet. I asked for Tabasco for my oysters and the server asked if I really wanted Crystal. Did I ask for that? I really don't like this place!

UDDAYVY1Iif10lpogHB_SQ.review_text: Faboo!!!!! I LOVE this place! And it's about 20 steps from my front door. 1300 is everything that everyone has raved about. Awesome decor, delicious yummies, GREAT drinks!  I had some peach, raspberry, lemonade and whiskey concoction. Man was it good. So my gfs and I decided to sit in the lounge and try some drinks and some appetizers before we head out to dinner. We started off with a little bit of bubble while lounging on some luxurious leather couches and club chairs in the lounge area. Soooo comfy! The manager came over to greet us and welcome us to the place. Soo nice! The hostesses was sweet and inviting making sure that we were comfortable and she was really accomodating, even on a busy night.  Our cocktail waitress came over and was super sweet. Wish I knew her name, cuz her boss needs to know that she needs a raise..I'll remember to look for her next time I go over and I'll edit my review to include her name.  So for apps, we got the hushpuppies and the crabcakes. Both were absolutely delicious. We were brought some cornbread with a red pepper jelly and butter to start. Honestly, they were good, but not fabulous. A bit dry for my taste. But we MANAGED to polish off all 4. Haha... :) The hushpuppies came with a delicious aioli served in a ramekin quite delicious. The Crabcakes, had a nice cajun spice kick to them which made them faboo! LOVE THEM! They went perfectly with our glasses of champagne and were devoured within seconds of hitting the table.  Between the awesome, drinks, delicious food, and wonderful service, I will be definitely returning, if not to become a bar regular, then to have some dinner. YAY for awesome eateries mere steps from my home!

agwHHRcxUjMplPVtvQFoag.review_text: I made reservations here months ago and now Yelp keeps reminding me to review this place everytime I login. Okay okay, I get the hint.  I took my companion here for his birthday since he always goes for familiar food and this place seems to serve comfort food stepped up a notch. It feels like a date place with the dim lights, slow music, and proper waitstaff. We were definitely way under-dressed with our jeans and flannels compared to the cocktail dresses and dress shirts sported by other patrons. This might be a soulfood joint, but nobody's dressed like it.   We went with the waiter's recommendations and he didn't disappoint. The cornbread, fried chicken, braised short ribs, and mac and cheese were all succulent, savory, and everything you want them to be. Though it's almost expected to be that good otherwise the price wouldn't be justified.   Solid food and solid service, but on the pricey side for what it is.

6r0OJuAeixaqccCEAOUpbA.review_text: I've been to 1300 on two previous occasions, and if I was writing this about the first time, the rating would be 4 stars.   I ordered the catfish and jambalaya and my date had the fried chicken and mashed potatoes. My dish was served luke warm. The fish didn't have a DROP of seasoning, and a box of Zattaran's tastes better than their jambalaya. My dates chicken must have been triple fried...the white mean was super dry, and the biscuits were like rocks. AND I had to send my cocktail back...to have alcohol added to it.   The hostess was told during the reservation that it was my birthday, but apparently she didn't share that with our server.   If it wasn't for great company and an awesome band, the night might have really sucked.  We basically had fast food in a really nice looking restaurant. 1300 you need to do better.

YSLeae82DBHA5mACSq8KGg.review_text: I give 1300 Fillmore five stars for service, flavor, ambiance, and live music. Our waitress  was  pleasant, knowledgeable, and attentive but not intrusive.   My wife and I had the arugula salad, shrimp and grits, pork chop, catfish and dessert. It was all excellent. I love this place. We've been there four times and each time the service was very good to excellent.   Mr. K

WvZJdjQ7GqShaLPb51QMig.review_text: I've lived in the Bay Area for about 6 years now and have always wanted to visit 1300 On Fillmore.  When I found out that my friend and her boyfriend would be visiting from Chicago, I suggested that we come here.  First of all, GREAT ambiance.  When you think of Soul/Southern food, you don't always think of "classy."  However, this place right here incorporates it just fine.  Our waiter was actually the high point of the evening.  He knew the menu really well and had us dying laughing w/ some off-beat humor.  My friend's boyfriend and I ordered the fried chicken, my girlfriend ordered the catfish, and my husband ordered a steak.  We were all thoroughly impressed with the food.  They also have really really great cornbread.  The drinks were also strong and tasty.  It was definitely pricey but I would totally come back again, at least for happy hour.  Also - we shut the place down.  It was 1am and the manager kindly asked us to leave so they could start cleaning up.  It was nice of them for letting us chatter as long as we did.

fREl4iFU7OzBK0cPYkqI6Q.review_text: I am very impressed by this place. Tasteful decor with huge old photos of the city, really high ceilings and lots of windows, it's sort of feels like a nice hotel bar/lounge. Their happy hour until 7:00 cannot be beat. Well drinks are $5 (and they have decent wells) and the pub food we had was really tasty and plentiful. I had the fried chicken po' boy with yummy coleslaw in the sandwich, accompanied by home made chips and a little bowl of sweet pickles. Delicious! My friend had shrimp hush puppies, which were basically just batter fried shrimp, but she said they were tasty. It's the perfect spot to grab a bite and a drink before a movie at Kabuki, which is just a few blocks away. Check it out!

XmElOb8V73xkDQypksDloA.review_text: Something about jazz just makes me wiggle. Absolutely love it!  Went here the other night for a drink and a bite to eat and had a fabulous time.  A stand out was the warm poached egg salad, which is not something that I'd usually try, but I'm so glad I did!  The flavors were perfectly balanced and it was just terrific.    Both the Chef/Owner and his wife were visible in the dining area, both of whom took a moment to stop by and see how we were enjoying our meal.  I love touches like that.    Live jazz and good food, hell yeah I'll be back!

K5EDoSIgKJBmDLyoZdKLdg.review_text: Atmosphere was good and service was good. Food was okay but overpriced for what it was. I probably wouldn't come back.

YG5EroFMYByZODecz3U_kQ.review_text: I knew I would love this restaurant before stepping foot inside. The menu features items like black skillet fried chicken and white truffle mac 'n cheese -- all my favorite guilty pleasures, only upgraded bigtime.  What I didn't expect was how fancy 1300 On Fillmore would look, sort of like a hotel restaurant as opposed to your average hipster joint.  I expected to be shelling out at least $50-60 based on the appearance alone. Instead, my 3 friends and I shared a ton of dishes, and the bill came out to just $35/person. That bill includes the following:  - Bottle of Cabernet - Fluffy, salty/sweet cornbread, with honey butter and jalapeno jelly for dipping (complimentary) - Fried chicken with buttermilk whipped potatoes, pan gravy and chive herb biscuits - Slow poached crispy egg salad with garlic vinaigrette and blue cheese  - White truffle mac 'n cheese - Barbecue shrimp 'n grits - Pan roasted brussels sprouts - Three chocolate beignets  No joke. 1300 On Fillmore is unbelievably affordable if your group opts for eating family-style (which I'd highly recommend, given how heavy the dishes are) -- and the food is beyond phenomenal.  Every single one of the dishes named above is a must-order, but ESPECIALLY the barbecue shrimp 'n grits. I don't like shrimp. I don't like grits. Yet I was obsessed with this. Apparently it's often spotlighted on the Food Network and is the reason for this restaurant's fame. It also happens to be ideal for sharing.  Come here if you're ready to pig out. Don't forget to wear loose-fitting clothes.

R2yGlvSlUNhzp6nYEbrIiw.review_text: I made a reservation here for a 6 pm dinner this past Sunday to celebrate my gf's birthday. We were both really excited to try out this place considering all the rave reviews. It had a really nice decor and ambiance.   Aside from fancy setting and fine dining atmosphere, I felt the service was not up to par. I don't' mind paying $30 dollars for decent fried chicken and biscuit if the service and experience was great. But it was not and they left out the biscuit on my gf's entree! The male server didn't seem atentative at all. If anything he felt hurried somewhat. He did not ask how the food was and only time we got our drinks refilled was when we called for him as he walked past us.   It was a few minutes into our meal that we realize the biscuit was missing. I also requested a lil cake for my gf for her birthday and it never came! So pissed! I also notice the Chef only came out when he had to greet his "people". Not only once but twice but he didn't even acknowledge other customers nearby and walked passed us and didn't ask how how the food was or apologize for the missing biscuit. This can't be called fine din in any way because it's not even close.   Overall this place needs  to learn about customers service because that is the key to making a successful restaurant especially if you want customers coming back. Good food but sucky service and came out bitter just like their greens...I'll pass

h-jotHjEq95I32N_g-RHJw.review_text: What a hot spot! Pricey but worth the experience!!! Loved the BBQ Shrimp & Grits! Check it out!

rUV1FUhji5xMjNBpcq5SXg.review_text: This is my scene.    Love the lights that illuminate all the photos on the wall, dig the music, service was friendly, and the drinks were absolutely fantastic.    There is a lounge area where you can kick back and relax with your friends and take your time.  There's also the main dining area.  We will definitely be back.

j-6iO8x_qSSB0CcLoCp9GA.review_text: What a find! A stone's throw from the historic Boom Boom Club, 1300on Fillmoreis a throw back to a pre-WWII Supper Club with Southern fare and jazz music playing softly in the background. The service was a little slow, but everyone was so friendly and accommodating that we didn't care. The quality of the food was outstanding, making it worth a drive from the East Bay any night of the week.

g5O-rwJLMerMz4EbafhQ7g.review_text: Deeelish! Great service. Delicious drinks. Nice look/feel - modern with nice blend of traditional. 4 of us when for dinner. Each got a different entree and app. Everyone was pleasantly pleased.

rayDJNy0Hsmgyvz40_amcA.review_text: Great place - love the interior design, staff was friendly and attentive - food was very good. Definitely recommended for a date spot.

UZKXLjSQozAbJyt2UF18RA.review_text: I almost feel badly giving just three stars - even though three stars is still "A-OK" - I really wanted to like this restaurant more than I did. I spent some time talking to the executive chef at the SF Chefs event about a month ago and was anxious to check out the restarurant. Unfortunately, it didn't quite live up to my expectations. I should have known that any time you mix French and Southern styles, you are nearly guaranteed a waist-UN-friendly meal - however, I don't want the heaviness of a dish to essentiall hit me in the face...or gut I should say...and unfortunately, that's what it did.  I ordered the Shrimp and Grits as my main course. One positive aspect of thise restaurant is the portion sizes. They are pretty generous, especially for the appetizers. A appetizer of shrimp and grits is plenty for a dinner. Having gone to school in the South, I became acquainted with shrimp and grits and even had a stellar recipe for them that I would make at home. When I make them, they are rich, but not deadly. My first reaction to the shrimp and grits dish was, "whoa, butter!" Again, I expected butter but it was incredibly rich and unnecessarily so. Perhaps my palate has been spoiled by fresh California cuisine - but I found it to be slightly unjoyable while I was eating it, and even more so afterward while it sat in my stomach. I have to say, though, the shrimp was perfectly cooked and extremely flavorful. This dish would certainly please a palate more accustomed to heavier foods but it wasn't quite my style.  The cornbread also wasn't as good as I would have hoped. As others had said, it was a bit dry.   THE GOOD: Yes, this place definitely had some highlights. The drinks were quite good - I ordered a Pear Vodka with my favorite St. Germain, grapefruit and lemon - delicious. Also, I split the watermelon salad that had proscuitto, melon, mint, and balsamic. It was refreshing and nicely prepared. Service was attentive and the waitress was very nice. Also - I had a bite of the fried chicken which typically isn't my thing, but it was very flavorful and juicy - I was pleasantly surprised.  I'd like to give this place another try - but I think I'll stick to some of the lighter offerings and the cocktails!

FazO2irKvUBVmQB9En6GXw.review_text: The food is beyond description- phenom soul food. Just get the shrimp and grits and call it a day. You will not regret it. Great date night location, great music and occasional live entertainment. I cannot say enough. Just go and eat there, you will not regret it I promise!!!

kzlie0TZMffb9AB2bt0nSw.review_text: yes, i know soul food shouldn't be "upscale," but i'm kicking a hearty helping of fried chicken out of bed even if it is $21. i rolled out of there so full it was well worth it. the service was excellent (even got a chance to chat with the general manager), the food was amazing and did i mention they have grits? can't wait to go there for brunch!!

la973Zrkv2-BuHtCXvyMdQ.review_text: Food as below, was very good.  Corn bread, beet salad, fish and pork and apple cobbler all very good. Only problem was the service.  The waitress was attentive until the main course, then forgot about us.  A long wait for desert, no offer of coffee.  She just walked by and dropped the bill on the table without us even asking for it.  No words, no thanks, nothing.  Wasn't our fault, we were quite nice to her.  Maybe it was too busy.

yEC3Y6ljaYKKACeocOeVoQ.review_text: My friend Vivian and I booked a table for dine about town; through some sort of scheduling mix-up were booked on a night when they had a $95 menu prix fixe with wine tasting/pairing from a local winery instead of the $35 fixed menu. While I was blind-sighted and not prepared to pay over $200 for our dinner on a Wednesday night, the owner, Monetta and her husband chef David were most gracious to us (as we were seated in a full restaurant and would either have to eat the bill or leave to find dinner elsewhere) and asked us to stay and would comp one of our dinners so the pricing would be more similar to what we might pay for Dine About Town with drinks. We are so glad they did!  First of all, we enjoyed the decor, which was very contemporary, with modern furniture, chocolate, taupes, and muted violet, that also celebrated the historical jazz culture of the Fillmore. The lounge, bar, and dining room were well laid out.  The food really was excellent, with modern twists, nice plating and appropriate, if not generous portions of southern food that was prepared in a very upscale fashion. Although I wouldn't call it a light meal, it was definitely satisfying without everything being fried. My only major critiques were that the food was undersalted (unsalted?) and the ribeye steak was tough, although the flavor was good. Otherwise, really excellent. Wines were nice as well, and the vinter/winemaker family was there to chat with us personally and tell us about their wine.  Normally I wouldn't give 5 stars unless ALL the food was truly phenomenal, or had great value for price, but the hospitality of Monetta and David was truly overwhelming, especially in the initially awkward situation. I'll definitely be back to visit again!

vSCSIRx9kz2DNDVdy7Le0A.review_text: I've had the pleasure of visiting 1300 before with friends and wanted to arrange my Mother's birthday brunch, I immediately thought of 1300's Sunday Gospel Brunch. I e-mailed ahead of time and let them know just how special this day was to me and my family and everyone who replied promptly assured me that they would take care of my Mom.   Boy was I NOT disappointed!  We were promptly seated right at our 1:00 PM reservation and were waited on almost immediately. It is one of the most intimate brunch settings in San Francisco, but we had plenty of room to stretch out, laugh and celebrate.   I ended up ordering and devouring the most picturesque plate of Eggs Benedict I've ever laid eyes on. The Tabasco Hollandaise is the best I've had because it's not heavy handed and overtly salty, but I savored it's richness with every bite. To go along with this luxurious plate, I had the flakiest, softest Herb Biscuits on the face of this earth. Add a perfectly poached egg and two slices of Canadian Bacon and you have the perfect brunch treat.   Our host was very engaging and made my mother's first trip to 1300 very comfortable and even the amazing Monetta White surprised us by checking on our table twice! As much as we enjoyed the food, you MUST stay and enjoy the music.   The band featured two extremely talented singers that made American Idol look like Amateur Hour at the Apollo. I wish I got the name of the beautiful female singer who did Aretha Franklin sweet justice. She brought the house down and we were beyond impressed. The male singer and host was just as impressive and really engaged with the audience even getting my shy brother to sing a few bars!   My Mom has had a really hard time adjusting to the move here in Northern California, hardest adjustment was leaving behind her favorite Jazz club. For the first time since we stepped foot in the Bay Area she truly felt at home and I have Monetta White and the amazing staff at 1300 on Fillmore to thank. My Mom made me promise that we would do this brunch every single month with our family and friends and I didn't hesitate to agree. Thank you for showing us what class, fine dining and rich atmosphere should aspire to be.

R6ivgIVpVgktxJXmmWxQDQ.review_text: Where did this building come from?  It's amazing how this neighborhood has totally transformed. A lot of people might not notice 1300 On Fillmore at first, since it is right next to the famous Yoshi's.  My friends and I were seated at a round table for six which was really cool- the perfect table for a group because it is so much more conversational. The only thing was that I had a sore throat at the end of the night because I was talking so loud over the general noise in the restaurant all night! Looking at the acoustics in there I could see why it was so noisy, but it would be nice if it wasn't quite *so* loud (and I am not a person who minds loud!) I love the lighting fixtures in there as well!  We were welcomed by some yummy warm corn bread triangles nestled in a napkin, with sweet honey butter. YUM!   No nightly specials here.. the server mentioned that they just change up the menu fairly often.  My husband and I shared the Organic Baby Arugula salad which was way too small to share (I almost started laughing when it came out!) but it was delicious. A friend ordered the BBQ Shrimp & Grits which was great.  For dinner I ordered the Pan Roasted Black Bass which was ok.. not stellar. My husband had the Maple Braised Short Ribs which literally melted off the bone. And it came with onion rings!  For desert, an amazing Banana Cream Pie.

TGdnpYdQgPnKAd7JoC37pQ.review_text: What was I going to do while I dont have a ticket to watch the show @ Yoshis...........  I just go next door and check out what 1300 is all about. And 1300 is all about eats and drinks which I had more than ample time to learn all about first hand, especially since I got time to kill till the concert is over. The food is soul food elegantly plated and pairs so well with easy going music. The lamb burger sliders were excellently executed. I only wish I was more hungry than I was. The place is richly appointed with wood and leather accoutrement accenting the dark ambiance which gives it an enveloping ambiance that dates back to Fillmore's Jazz history.   My cousin meets up with me for some drinks and we pass the night away catching up on recent events and other summer fun! Nothing like makers and coke to set the night right. I have to admit that the pear goose n tonic is quite the cocktail despite my previous misgivings.  Thank you bff for the heads up! ;D

vRziAXWI72nOFWNml4ldMA.review_text: So went here last night for dinner and saw all the great reviews for this place. They were not wrong. So took my date there and for a Monday there was a fair amount of people. They have a lounge area where they had live jazz which is cozy. But it's really about the food. Finally got to try fired green tomatoes which came with deep friend goat cheese with a lavendar sauce. Super tasty. I ordered the braised short ribs with herb mashed potatoes and she got the fried chicken.  The short ribs required no knife and the fried chicken was good too. Had a some spices we couldn't figure out. She thought it might have been a touch of curry but not sure. I'm no wine officionado but they had a list of wines by the bottle that were in the 30 to 40 dollar range and obviously some more expensive ones too but for a novice wine drinker like me that is perfect. Wanted to try desert but was too stuffed. The service was awsome too. Our waiter I guess had some big order but we didn't even notice he was gone that long but the manager came over to take our order and at the end of the meal we were just sitting and talking after the bill came the waiter came over and offered a glass of wine of the same wine we had at dinner. So man great service great upscale soul food. Definitely will go back for dinner or even just coctails.

bA-nbi3A15By4oQd3S_jtg.review_text: Let me tell you a little something about myself.  I like to celebrate things.   They range from being big occasions, like "I just won the Nobel Peace Prize!" to "Oh my God, your dog just turned 6 months, we need to celebrate!"  With that said, I went out to dinner with my brother and some friends last Friday night to celebrate (shocker!) his 60 days at his company - which means he's now an official employee.  You can decide where that falls in importance on the "reasons to celebrate scale."  I arrived about 15 minutes late to my reservation.  Apparently time flies rather quickly when your bartender friend feels the need to feed you shots like they're water.  I was expecting to be chastised for being so tardy, but they were as pleasant as could be and brushed off my attempts at apologizing for being an insensitive butthole.  Good start to the night.  As I walked to my table, I really dug the ambiance.  It definitely has an air of sophistication to the decor, but there was a liveliness to the patrons that kept it from being stuffy.  Our server George was spot on with everything.  He really took the whole service with a smile adage to a new level.  It's amazing how much better your experience gets when you have a happy, attentive server.  And finally the food.  OMFG, the freaking food.  I ordered the braised short rib, which was described to me as fall of the bone.   You hear this term often, yet it doesn't always live up to the billing.  I literally pulled the bone right off the meat when my plate arrived.  One clean pull, with no trace of meat left on the bone.  THAT'S how you do it!  Others at the table got the fried chicken (sooooo good) and the ribeye steak, which they raved about as well.  Unfortunately, we were too stuffed for dessert, which just gives me another reason to go back there soon.  There's definitely a peach cobbler with my name on it when I come back.

N_-rbw8pxE_-OiHbkVm2Lw.review_text: The place to go for happy hour. Hands down. Enough said.  P.S Its a swanky ass place! I wish I'd worn a collard shirt or polo or something, although they don't trip at all, you look around and you just feel that outta place vibe.   In closing. Good spot for happy hour, have great little appetizers like the sliders and the fat fries.

0xNIPLIIkG9YIYER30LWFw.review_text: I'd like to say this review first started with 4 stars, then I remembered our waitress which made me knock it down to 3..   The food here is AMAZING. I haven't had such great soul food since I've been to Houston, and even then it wasn't as good. The restaurant is perfect for the neighborhood. It fits in with that historical jazzy feel. The decor and design is also beautiful. The comfy leather booth couches against the window are amazing and the lighting adds to the dark rich ambiance of the restaurant.   Unfortunately our service didn't match the high expectations of the restaurant. Our server had an attitude like she had so many better things to do then serve us. She was not polite, she rushed us, and let the food come out too fast (our appetizers came out before our bottle of champagne, which we asked for first). She didn't seem to care that our meal was going to be +400$, she still gave us the impression that she was waisting her time with us. There was one very cute server in the restaurant though, and I'm kind of disappointed that we didn't get him.   Now my favorite part... The FOOD! We had the mac and cheese and the grits for our appetizer. The mac and cheese was a little too spicy for me (I have a sensitive mouth) but the grits were amazing! So gooood. They also give you cornbread that is to die for.. For our main course I shared the Maple Syrup Beef Short Ribs and the Organic Fried Chicken. Both were mouthwatering. The short ribs fell off the bone and the chicken was so juicy and tender. I would definitely recommend either dish.. I wish I could remember the name of our wine, because it was perfectly paired with our meal. I recommend asking the sommelier (or wine steward)  for a great wine pairing with your food because he did a fantastic job with ours. I can't wait to come back here, the dishes were great, the portions are huge, and the decor is beautiful. I definitely recommend this place for a nice dinner out.  HINT FOR ALL YOU GUYS: This is a gorgeous restaurant that I would recommend taking any girl to for a special occasion. It's romantic and classy.. SO I hope you all get the hint!!!!

Afq57_KYVBBJlSj1X5-4xQ.review_text: Hmmmm.. Often enough, adventures in dining become foremost about the friends, and lastly about the food... A good thing the eve at 1300 on Fillmore, when enjoined w/ the old college crew (my how we've grown ;), we dined, imbibed, and the food was.. a-ok, but short on spectacular.  In my lil foodie world, i'm seeking the delicates of the refined flavor, petite bite which screams "innovative! organic! mouth-ride!" That said, flavors and food here was too rich n' fryer-friendly to inspire much of the above. I did like the 2nd course available only this month of crab with fennel.. like a beacon in the dark! And while I may be on the far-end-of-health-nut spectrum, even friends who tore into fried chicken with the rush of red-blooded cajun felt food was playing "safe": lacking in either astounding classic rendition or that somethin' special that brings you back in.  The location is fun, and the atmosphere festive. We'd hoped (and thought was advertised?) live jazz, but down the street plenty to be had later. Service was diligent and attentive to be sure.   Doubt we'll be clamoring for encore, but certainly of you're seeking something fillin' from the fryer, you've met yer match.

P3usQcIegPCl-cdH4IDirg.review_text: Quite a nice little change of scene. Cajun/Creole vibe, modern aesthetic, doting servers. The beverages were above-average. The food was tasty if not inspiring; that said, I was in NoLa last month so of course my bar is set way high. After having Luke's shrimp and grits, I'm spoiled for life.  Slightly spendy, but enjoyable.

WzTapC3mZGEcX7Umvy7KtQ.review_text: I've wanted to try this place for the longest time and I finally had the opportunity to do it during restaurant week with my girl. Our table wasn't ready when we arrived so we grabbed a few drinks at the bar chatted it up with the bartender. Once seated our server was very attentive and very friendly and recommended a few dishes for us to start with and try. We ordered their fish of the day and their oysters for appetizer, both were delicious. Overall great place to take your date and have an enjoyable evening.

CDezAwgsr3dN5Kj8vlcMtw.review_text: I had an AWESOME dinner at 1300 with my parents' approval (and they are seriously picky "foodies") I am also picky---especially about fried chicken. Theirs is just perfect to me. Crispy, juicy chicken with the perfect seasoning. I also really love the atmosphere. There's live music in the lounge and the mood is always lively. Now I've done the trifecta.....had a date in the lounge while live jazz played. Did the Gospel Brunch one Sunday with a few friends, and then dinner with the fam most recently. The gal behind the bar took excellent care of my parents and I (Nicki?) which impressed me as it was extremely busy.  This has become one of my favorite spots in the city.

nnw3o9TS5SDBk4htLWjPQQ.review_text: Okay call me picky, call me a food snob, or tell me that my expectations are unrealistic -  whatever, but I think that for $110 per person you should expect great food and great service.  1300 Fillmore delivers neither.  That was the short form, here's the poop:  The room is beautiful, yet awkwardly designed.  Way too long to feel comfortable, with the "private room" behind sliding glass doors, and many different chair styles, the place feels as if it were designed by committee.  When we arrived at the hostess table, she was occupied with someone else.  We told her we'd be in the bar and come to get us when our reservation time had arrived.   We had a drink in the bar.. The bartender was aloof and not very friendly.  When the hostess came to take us to our table, no offer was made to transfer the bill, nor was any effort made to take our drinks for us to the table.    The hostess sat us near the front door and so we asked to be moved.  She huffed and went away, a few minutes later she reseated us.  The appetizers were very well prepared, but a tad expensive for what they were - five fried shrimp and a mayo-based dipping sauce (the menu said "ancho chile remoulade" it seemed like thousand island to me) for $13 and five smaller shrimp and a dollop of grits (really, really good) also for $13.  The mains were fine - vertically stacked short ribs, onion rigs in a way too sugary maple glaze, and a huge plate of fried chicken with biscuits and truffled mashed potatoes - but not inspired, inspirational or anything beyond "fine" .    For upwards of $30 per plate, I expect best in class, too cool for school , or fabulous, not "fine."

7HESPpy_OXPE4LlH9iCNCg.review_text: Great cocktail selection. All of them sounds delish. The atmosphere is really nice. I liked it. The food was alright - I got their catfish with jambalaya. catfish was a little dry but it ended alright because of the jambalaya.

SgHE7BrWEa-mSPQNTezhhA.review_text: The food was pretty good (ribeye, salmon, fried green tomatoes). But the portions were small considering the expense. I didn't even leave with my tummy completely full, which I would expect for an expensive meal! :p

NniDeJ5CCQWsgrALUouOpA.review_text: This classy Fillmore District supper club embraces the jazz vibe of the street's musical history. Chef David Lawrence's soulful Jamaican-English roots cuisine embraces traditional American Southern flavors. The dinner menu offers layers of intrigue with items like "Buttermilk Fried Quail Salad with Bacon-Creole Mustard Vinaigrette". The food will make you "Jump, Jive & Wail" with delight.

TMLVzNYs-zwwREudyvI08A.review_text: This place has a really great vibe to it.  I dig the unmatched chairs.  Get the shrimp and grits.   Strike that.  RUN to 1300 and get the shrimp and grits.  So good.  Service?  Not so much.  They really need to hire a better, friendlier and more attentive staff if they are going to charge upscale prices.

lkwh-l12McNMxpM7VkLf9g.review_text: Came here on a rainy Saturday around 5:30 PM. Yes, I am aware that is senior citizen dining time. Chef and host looked at us quizzically, but probably because we were looking at them quizzically, unsure if they were even open. For a slight moment, we felt a little out of place. Both of us had on jeans and this place was crazy, sexy, cool. But our waiter, Trent, made us feel so comfortable.  We enjoyed the cornbread triangles with dipping sauce. We loved our drinks, he had the hurricane and I had the honey sweet tea (I must say his was way better than mine).  He loved his fried chicken and I loved the short ribs. (Which I was so relieved, since I had read the mixed reviews on the fried chicken, but it was juicy and had that spicy goodness to it.) If we had time and the room, I totally would have dove into some desserts. Service was excellent, we dropped a generous tip. It was a swanky way to celebrate and indulge.

LU7ikPXZ5R8tv4oNQZQkKw.review_text: I want fried chicken!  Skinny cow wouldnt let me order it for an appetizer.  We came in after dinner for dessert.  I really wanted my dessert to be fried chicken.  She wouldn't let me.  WTF?  So we ended up with the chocolate beignets and banana rum cake.  The beignets came with this coffee soda drink.  The cow wouldn't stop raving about it.  She even yelped when she got home so she could have it the next day.  Ridiculous.   I thought the beignets were just ok.  The rum cake was a better dessert.  The desserts didn't have that wow factor for me because I was more interested in the fried chicken.  damn it i want some fried chicken!

NC-hHs4nA7qoNZu2F3n2CA.review_text: After a small panic attack, I chose this place for my birthday dinner thanks to the help of my fellow Yelpers in the talk threads.   Unfortunately I wasn't very hungry, but I managed to eat my small yet delicious portion of Arctic char. The menu said there would be lobster included with the fish but I couldn't find it on the plate. Oh well! I tried the fried chicken and it was very tasty, but still only the "third best" in the world according to my boyfriend. We loved the cornbread and our very personable waitress recommended a good (most expensive) glass of wine. The bathroom smelled wonderful.  Sadly I found the dessert menu severely lacking and didn't get any cake on my birthday. It sucked.

jWflW86Mk8Jvc4hdkl1hlg.review_text: Went there for a friend's birthday party.  Very overcharged soul food and wine.  The dishes were not as "amazing" as the waiter promised.  The only tastey surprise was the house corn bread served with sweet cream and some unknown condiment.  I did appreciate the decor and waitors.

0smhwGl3qTQjsoG2eCwziw.review_text: I only had a couple of drinks and App's at the bar. Decor and food was very nice. - 1 star for bartender chatting to us about his new baby..I mean did we look interested!!!- Live Jazz music twice aweek..Sun & Wed

49E4PTy5nEHdNLeaPhQS7Q.review_text: Perhaps if I had grown up in the deep south I would find the notion of upscale comfort/soul food as absurd as some of the other reviewers. But I didn't. I grew up in Europe. We didn't have mac 'n' cheese. And our only notion of the American south was vended us by Hollywood.   Therefore, naturally, since coming to the US, I've become a huge fan of soul food. However I am forced to enjoy it with no cultural baggage. Fortunately this means I can enjoy the excellent food at 1300 on Fillmore without worrying about what it all means. So here's the lowdown: The fried chicken is superb. The short ribs are delicious. The mac 'n' cheese was a guilty pleasure. And the shrimp hush puppies are one of the most delicious things I've eaten in a long time. My enjoyment of them was enhanced by the fact that ordering them helped me figure out what the hell "hush puppies" actually are...  Oh, and the drinks are tasty too, and the atmosphere is friendly, relaxed and yet not overly casual.   Word of warning: portions are not small. We failed to finish our food, and had no room left for dessert, which is a shame since they seemed well worth trying.   I will certainly return to 1300 on Fillmore.

ca_34ATOWQT9PHQ6qCG0vw.review_text: Only went for brunch but.....  Best damn grits I have ever had.  Pretty damn good scones too!  Neither one has a hint of animal flesh in them and yet..... oh so good.  Everything else is good, including the damn coffee and oj.    Go and enjoy.

mQBtWghC5pE8v98dy-xGUA.review_text: I was really pleasantly surprised by this place! The food and ambiance are equally great. The combination of the jazz combo trickling in from the lounge and the decor make for a wonderful dining experience. The menu is a great take on haute soul food. From the appetizers to the dessert all were prepared to perfection. I can't wait to get back to this place. This may very well be my new hangout!

WNRmgAmR_LR-ey8bOzJ8Og.review_text: I love this place. My review was removed! Love the fried chicken and the shrimp & grits. The grits are super creamy and flavorful, yummy in my tummy.  The play live music here on certain days, the singer is extremely talented. Love sitting at the lounge area, listening to the music, grabbing some dinner and a nice drink. I have been here a few times with friends and for date night. Very cool vibe, check it out.

Jduf71IO8ysJvZgrX-Me-g.review_text: Not impressed! Charged extra for the music! Extra for plates to share a cake! Way over priced and the food is just ok!

I1C05xj8mcWSMpbLEC7QLg.review_text: Yummy!  The grits with shrimp were OUTSTANDING as was the boneless fried chicken. The brussel sprouts were a bit blah but the biscuits and cornbread were stellar. The service was lovely, as was the space. It felt very Chicago or LA, with high ceilings and nice dark lighting & booths. Perfect for a cold night.  1300 Fillmore  gives a nice homage to the cultural heritage of the city and the place was filled with very well-heeled Buppies.  In terms of soul food, it was twice as good as Front Porch (which isn't bad) and about ten times as good as Elite Cafe (which I found disppointing).  Can't wait to go back and try the ribs.

LAamaDM_69UFhhf7g9L3lg.review_text: First of all, I love the decor. It looks like an old school gentlman's club (no, not that kind, the kind that you'd see in a Merchant and Ivory film where men drink single-malt scotch).    And the music, while loud (making it hard if you are trying to have a conversation), was excellent.  So I would come back to enjoy drinks and conversation.  And that is the only reason I gave it a 2nd star.  The food however, is not good.  I'm rapidly coming to realize that you cannot believe reviews of regional foods when it comes to restaurants in NoCal.  If it's not from the Asian continent or south of the border, the reviewers seem to lack the palette to know what they are talking about.  Asking a Californian to judge soul food would be like asking Helen Keller to judge an art competition.  I've yet to have a truly satisfactory culinary experience out here here that didn't involve ramen, sushi, or curry.  1300 on Fillmore is no exception. I'm about 150% Southern (parents, grandparents, great-grandparents from Alabama, and then it loops back on itself b/c some great greats were from Kentucky, which is where I was raised). So a lot of "soul" food, southern food, and other comfort food restaurants get a big side-eye from me, even in places where people know how to cook them. Now in some places, they can get it right...Atlanta, Detroit, southside of Chicago.  Here they don't know what they are doing.  So the food here was not good.  I could not figure out what was going on with the "fried" chicken.  Even if you want to be all California about it and take off the skin, it can be done MUCH better than what they passed off as fried chicken. The biscuits were dry and not tender (buttermilk anyone?)  My opinion is that some things shouldn't be healthy.  If you want to be healthy, then just don't eat those things.  But don't butcher them by leaving out the things that make up their very essence.  And even though there were supposed to be refills, I got exactly ONE mimosa for my $12.  I'm not sure why the waitress couldn't be bothered to bring me another, or re-fill my water glass again.  But yeah, if you want southern/soul food, don't go to anyplace in San Francisco expecting to be pleased.  Thank goodness I can make it myself when the mood strikes.  I think the soul food should be left to people who aren't afraid to "put their foot in it" as we say down south!

D8JswSWcY-fznIm05Y3WZA.review_text: It's a cool and diverse place.

JdD20Erzg_sY4VPkQzPLxQ.review_text: I was taken here for a birthday dinner and had a fantastic experience. The service was beyond good. Our waiter was great. The sommelier helped us pick the perfect bottle wine and much to our surprise the Executive Chef came out to say hi and have a chat with us. I've been to some of the finest restaurants in the city and it is extremely rare for every aspect of a meal to be so enjoyable.
