MRpRQ_CvwospIxfNZazATw.review_text: Hands down THE Best!   1. Excellent HOSPITALITY!  2.FOOD was over my expectation!! So GOOD!  I had a Mai tai $10 - strong but flavorful  Complimentary cornbread.. I thought Hard Knox had the best cornbread..guess what.. 1300 beat them! fresh out the oven (I know because it came out hot!)  Fried Oysters $12 omg the batter was good! And the special sauce..  Oh my it went well and very delicious!   Truffled Mac&Cheese $7 wow. I burned myself tho cuz the dish was hot...yet the waiter DID warn me lol!  Braised Shortrib $28ish Sooo soft! Very good! My BF broke up w me n fell in love w/ the Shortrib  The FAMOUS fried chicken - OMFG hands down the best chicken! Better than Roscoes! Lol extremely flavorful..you can taste that Cajun style!  portions were plennnnntiful!   Food was Sooo good I didn't have any more space in my tummy for dessert!   Now for hospitality..a lot of team work was involved. Every water catered to everyone! Even the Manager came out serving food and asking us if we wanted more cornbread! Our waiter and our neighbor's waiter asked us if we wanted more cornbread lol! (I'm sure they knew the bread was on it!) the waiter put our food in a Togo box....AND gave us fresh cornbread Togo! WOW!  *i left a very generous tip...I've never had service like that ever.  Definately coming back ASAP!   1300, you got yourself a new regular! I'm telling everyone!

gvuvcjAVl1ElyXTgU80VRg.review_text: Another one of those "A-OK" describes it all.  First of all, I wanted to clear up the hype about the fried chicken.  Don't get me wrong the fried chicken was good, but definitely not THE BEST FRIED CHICKEN IN SF, as some people were saying.  The skin was fried pretty well, but it lacked flavor.  The meat portions were pretty generous but come on, fried chicken needs to have bones, plain and simple.  If you want some boneless dry chicken breast strips go to a bar and order chicken fingers.  What was pretty dam good was the BBQ shrimp and grits.  My fellow yelp reviewers you didn't fail me there.  Portions and flavor of the grits and shrimp were perfect.  My friend ordered the rib-eye and it was mediocre as it lacked the nice fatty crust that typical rib-eyes have and felt more like a filet.

g9cXXkNtDmHJ2vcr4cJP1w.review_text: I don't understand the reviews from people on here who complained about the service.  I went today for the Gospel Brunch and could not have been happier.  Everyone was friendly from the hostess to the bartender to our server.  The food was amazing.  The little wedges of cornbread were great, and the grits were possibly the best I've ever had.  The music was a nice addition, and I will absolutely be back for happy hour and dinner.  Oh, and a nice touch which I've never seen before... hooks under the sink in the bathroom for your purse - genius!!!

zU2_yUBf76uUu-jtErzxCA.review_text: My boyfriend brought me here on my birthday and it was fabulous.  We ordered a glass of wine, the mac and cheese, the fried chicken, the pea ravioli and finally the 3 sorbets with the recommended dessert wine.  I love splurging :)  The best part about it all is the vibe.  It's romantic but lively at the same time.  I did come here again recently with a large group and while the fried chicken wasn't quite as good as I remember, the experience was just as nice.  The decor, especially in the bar, really adds a lot.  All in all, great restaurant.

Vd3kKs4gvQ36AF6HQv59dQ.review_text: 1300 Fillmore is fabulous! The decor is grand, modern, and classy. The service is excellent, and the food is out of this world! Anywhere that starts you off with cornbread gets an automatic star from me. I took everyone's reviews to heart and forced someone in my party to get the fried chicken, and it was amazing! The truffle mashed potatoes that come with it really complement the dish. We also got the brussel sprouts, which are mouth-watering, and the shrimp hush puppies (which are more like fried shrimp than hush puppies, but are yummy nonetheless.) The bass and the lamb are also excellent choices, and the beignets for dessert are fantastic!  After dinner, I ran into a group of women in the ladies room, and they were commenting on how full they were, but how glad they had been that they came. I thought to myself, "that's exactly how I feel." What a great place for reflection - gotta love the ladies room!

JQ472bHDvtNQLTKVzuswcw.review_text: Was good. Could have been better service, but they did provide us with compt drinks.

grFjhD2zEzfjo7Gbp8JvoQ.review_text: I love this place!! The food is awesome! The BBQ shrimp with grits is excellent, i might double it as my entreenext time. The shrimp hushpuppies, the calamari , and the scallop appetizers are outstanding. The braised shortribs fell off the bone, a good sign the meat is tender. The rib eye steak is juicy and tender. The cornbread stuffed quails would be a great Thanksgiving item! The beignets for desserts are just plain tasty! Wish i can have that everyday for breakfast!! The chef-owner David Lawrence works the room majestically, saying hello or good bye to his guests. Excellent PR!! Will definitely come back!!

aI5v7ZewzvXMfWxza0m1kw.review_text: The dinner here was awesome from the very first bite. The fried okra was not slimey at all. The cornmeal breading wasn't sticking very well to the okra but the appetizer was still delicious. We devoured the warm cornbread. The jalapeno jam served with it surprisingly had no heat, just sweetness. I probably could have substituted honey and not tasted a difference. We also had the shrimp & grits as a 2nd appetizer. The grits were creamy. Also important, it didn't sit like lead in my tummy afterwards. We had dueling forks at the table, it was that good.   Two of us ordered cocktails. While they were both generous pours, the cocktails were just ok. One, the key lime was too sour.  We ordered the short ribs, red snapper with corn succotash and catfish with jambalaya for our entrees. The short ribs was the runaway hit. This became a dish to share. Succulent and tender. Didn't really need a knife to cut it. The red snapper was tasty with a nice & crispy skin but the succotash was the highlight. This was like eating the freshest, sweetest tasting corn straight from the farm but more elegant and easier than eating corn-on-the-cob. The catfish was my favorite of the 2 fish. Nice, meaty texture. It didn't have that strong fishy normally associate with catfish.  For dessert, we shared the banana cream tart & peach cobbler. The tart was good but the dough used for the crust was not flaky at all. It was hard as a rock and we had difficulty cutting it, even with a knife. The caramel sauce was to die for. The cobbler was ok but again, it was the crust that disappointed. While flaky, it could have used a bit more sweetness. It was also very dry.  Service was very attentive. Hip & trendy vibe but not intimidating. There were some minor execution errors but I'm quibbling. Nothing to keep me from coming back. Overall this is a keeper.

gkjkDvLv4fsMP8b6-Z1d1g.review_text: Best fried chicken and biscuits!! Love this hidden gem! So beautiful from the inside and amazing food.  The steak was delicious as well with very good mashed potatoes.  Drinks here are great and service is excellent.  The chocolate beignets are too die for and are so fresh and soft.  I wish this place was less expensive so that I could make it a regular!

BPkM2rnhMO68Le6Xs-7eVg.review_text: Soul Food that is $$$ isn't soul food, let's start there.  Dinner 4 two with 2 drinks each rang up a $180 bill.  Don't get me wrong the food was good, but you can go get the same soul food for a lot less a lot of other places.  Service was outrageously slow on a night when we showed up early to catch a show at the Fillmore - restaurant wasn't crowded.  Seems like a fun place to grab an app and drink and listen to jazz, but the meal just isn't worth it.

37HswRimgBEf7_US-c3CDA.review_text: Came to 1300 on Fillmore for an after-Kabuki movie event & couldn't have been more impressed  Loved, loved, loved their drinkys!  Mr & I got the Violet Fog which was violet liqueur, sparkling wine & lavender bitters.....totally outstanding  Buddy got the Strawberry-Basil-Lemonade & it was likewise outstanding w/ it's sweet-tartness & the basil just took it over the top  Appies included the Duck Dumpling w/ a poached duck egg on top of this duck-hash like thing that Buddy said was out of this world  Fried Green Tomatoes w/ Stuffed Squash Blossoms - OMG this is the appie to get!  Nice & crunchy coating on tender & perfectly fried tomotoes.  The squash blossoms were stuffed w/ goat cheese & gave it a really nice couple layers of flavor & I'm still dreaming about this!!  Corn Bread for the table was nice & dense & the homemade honey butter was perfect all slathered on top!  Buddy chose the Shrimp & Grits as his entree & there were huge eye rolls - the shrimp were large & tasty while the grits were cheesy & almost pudding like, they were so creamy  Mr & I split the Corn, Pea, Mushroom, & Asiago Farro - I had asked if they could hold the mint since mint is a total showstopper for me & thankfully they were happy to do it b/c this dish was incredible!  Nice black peppery flavor & nutty from the farro, I loved how the freshness of the corn & peas countered the savory mushrooms.  Be sure to have them leave out the mint for you too!  You can thank me later!!  We also got the Truffled Mac N Cheese & would have to recommend to pass on this.  The smoked gouda totally overpowered the truffle & gave it a hammy taste which I did not care for......but that said, if you like smoke, you'll love this dish  Desserts were the Chocolate Filled Beignets for everyone - came w/ a coffee-soda & chocolate dipping sauces.  Buddy discovered if you dipped it in the coffee then the chocolate, it was awesome.  Just the coffee sauce?  Not so much.....but luckily these people know what they're doing when it comes to piecing together fantastic desserts  Can't wait to come back & enjoy more Southern goodness - pre-Fillmore; pre-Kabuki; pre-Yoshi's.....you can't go wrong!

sWOMyRIGWU8_0XLbZAuNBQ.review_text: Good food and the service was excellent. I will certainly recommend.

oKrct4Hc8hZNMYXecitLCw.review_text: I made the reservation for two but it turned out to be just me dining alone. I was en route to a concert at the Fillmore. I had been wanting to try 1300 on Fillmore for a few years now but never had the opportunity. I read the dinner menu online and had an idea what I wanted to try.   Since I was alone, I tried to sit in the bar to order food it was too busy in that section, I preferred to sit at a white tablecloth table.  It is a beautifully designed restaurant.  I like the warm inviting chairs in the lounge and the historical photographs of Jazz musical greats on the walls.  I would definitely come back for the atmosphere and ambiance.   The food was good also. The cornbread is buttery and with jalapeno jelly and honey butter it is delectable.  I had the matchstick okra for an appetizer and the pan fried chicken for an entree. I had a beer for a beverage and it all seemed to be a great combination.  I gobbled up the mash potatoes that came with the entree.   My waitress made a point to ask if I was going to a concert next door, which I thought was attentive. I thought the service was good. There were two other server staff, the more mature of the two was spot on.  He wrapped up my "doggie bag" and kept my water glass full.

C2iUp05zKi0u61SuVSLjrA.review_text: UPDATE, 3/19/08:  a friend and i had dinner at the bar prior to a concert at the fillmore.  the bartender recommended a great bourbon, which we both enjoyed, and then we started out with the lamb sliders and fat fries.  both very good.    but the reason for my update is what i imagine will seem like a very bizzare comment.  we ordered entrees---my friend the short ribs, me the fried chicken, and a side of brussel sprouts---and the food came too fast.  like, WAY too fast.  our entrees arrived in less than 5 minutes, easy.  in general, that made me concerned.  considering that the menu asks diners to "allow for 20 minutes" for the fried chicken, it was a particularly big concern.  the entrees were certainly not bad, but the short rib meat was a little dry and the skin on the fried chicken was definitely tough.  i know these are both popular dishes, but when you're dining at a nice restaurant, you want your food made to order.    i still love the ambience and will definitely go back, but had to knock them down to 3 stars.  who knows...  maybe they just hired a psychic to help them predict orders.  ORIGINAL REVIEW:  just dined here for the first time last week, and really enjoyed it.  i see a natural comparison between 1300 and spruce. both recently opened, with the goal of having upscale cuisine with a lively bar/lounge atmosphere.  where spruce seems poorly laid out and overwhelmed by its crowd, 1300 was as smooth and comfortable as the jazz music in the background.  the food was good across the board. we started with the bbq shrimp & grits... very solid. that and the cornbread easily got us to the main course.  then i had the bouillabaisse... delicious broth and plenty of delicious seafood. the mussels were only OK, but the huge chunks of lobster, crab, and fish were wonderful.    the wife had the short ribs...  a menu item that in my experience always seems to be well-hyped but strangely underperforms. 1300's did not...  perfectly-cooked, tender and delicious. the mashed potatoes were average, and felt like a natural candidate to get dressed up a bit like many of the other sides on the menu.  speaking of which, we got the braised greens and the mac n' cheese. the greens were fine, but the addition of the sweet onions made them better.  the mac was SO good...  very rich with the white cheddar, and a big portion. a light eater could easily get by on a salad or shrimp app and the mac and cheese.  the service was top notch, and we also loved the atmosphere...  lively, but because the bar and lounge area are separated by high partitions the volume didn't prevent us from having a conversation and a normal level.

zw9c4zv6Wf9ligr0HLy8FQ.review_text: From the ambiance to the food this place is great and a much needed addition to the Fillmore district..  One of those places you could put on the once a week list..  We ate in the dinning room but the bar also looked quite appealing..  Food was great and the service was above average which is rare in this city.

Z2AuC5sWT4mjPgt2ga7S0Q.review_text: I love 1300 but last night was the first time I ever been on a miss night when I always go and it was on hit. Did that make since?  I guess what I'm saying 1300 has never been a hit or miss for me.   Last night for dine about town and it was a total miss in the dining room.  The host was seating, taking orders, and pouring water. He was just all over a place.  Maybe someone didn't come into work or something because service was slow.   The Dine About Town menu was pretty lame in my opinion. I understand have a select items for a pre-fixed menu but here was only 1 item for starter, entree, and dessert. So I pretty much skipped over that and ordered my favorites.   The shrimp n grits came out hot and ready to go but after that dinner took a few extra minutes to come out and not hot. The food didn't have to be piping hot but hot enough so that I can still feel some heat coming off the plate. This is the first time I didn't enjoy my dinner.   Now it wasn't all bad, the bar was awesome that pretty much saved the night for me and my guest. Dessert was pretty good and Nikki at the bar made excellent and conversation with us and the other bar patrons.   Not to worry though 1300 is still awesome it just one not so good night for me but others were having a great time and I'm sure when I go again I'll have a great dining experience again.

erxFvHWM214X2Lj0uja4wA.review_text: the food here is really pretty good.  in fact, very good.  we share appetizers, soups and entree. and some appetizers are big enough to be a meal in itself. the highlight of the night was the corn bread with it's cherry Sriracha jam and the shrimp grits.  so good.  didn't get to try the dessert so can't say how it is.  but definitely like to go back.  the service was excellent as well.  Phillip was very attentive and seem to always be around when you need him.

rnRHFIxML6U1euZmN8UekQ.review_text: I love this place.  The ambiance, the drinks, the food...my kind of place.   This last time I was there, my husband and I brought his parents.  They loved it.  First off, the drinks are the bomb.  My favorite is the Jazzberry Martini.  Unlike many places, these folks actually put a good dose of alcohol in their drinks. Nice.  The food is simply delicious.  My husband had the rib eye, I had the catfish, my mother in law had the shrimp and grits and my father in law had the baby back ribs.  All of us enjoyed every bite! Usually one of two of us has some kind of complaint but we had none.  Personally, I thought the catfish was perfectly seasoned.  And it's served over jambalaya rice - how good is that?  I really didn't think anything could top that meal until we decided to try dessert. Warm Chocolate Beignets. Oh. My. God. And they serve them with this odd coffee soda (foam), but it's the perfect accompaniment! Absolute heaven.  As much as I enjoyed the food at Yoshi's, I will be coming back here for our after show meal.

ehdrFZwh1XRxzqR-6Kbg9A.review_text: Went here again this evening, and I need to beg you to please get the short ribs.  You will thank me later.  It/they was/were so good.  The meat was so tender and juicy and delicious.  I almost got this the first time I went, and I am very glad I tried it this time.  I also tried the rack of ribs this evening.  Good stuff.  This place rocks and people really like it here.  I got to chat with someone who took some of the pictures of the old Fillmore jazz scene back in the day that is on their slide show in the bar area, and in the gallery.  I wish I would have been around (and old enough) to have been a part of it then.  I think I might become a regular here.

NEb9uUSfP45mvYTrzOoVmA.review_text: the food is hit or miss. the fried chicken tends to be a bit saltier more often than not, however, the cornbread starter is delicious. the wine list is wonderful and the ambiance is a very cool darkly lit, pricey bar/lounge feel. great space for dinner, plus an additional room for large group dinners is very nice - but keep the doors open for the ambiance of 1300.   overall, very pleased!

JGAtTF-bxLYY5MIcYAPEFw.review_text: In celebration of a friend's new job, a bunch of us dined here before karaoking. A dinner before mass humiliation requires cocktails, and these were quite good... pomegranate mojitos, pear blossoms, and lots of other unique options. The food was some of the best southern cuisine I've had in the Bay Area. Extremely rich, but then southern food usually is right? We tried a ton of things among the group. The favorite was the mushroom risotto. The fried okra was also very good. Fried chicken was so filling, even splitting we couldn't finish. It was nice that they serve it boned but I wasn't as impressed by it as I thought I'd be given all the raves. The mac and cheese is spicy! I like spice, but in this case it just kinda took over the flavor of the dish. I'd go back, get a cocktail and have the risotto and be more than happy. A good option for pairing with the Fillmore/Yoshi's/Japantown adventures.

UuWQtJF1yQXxZW45hEUtTg.review_text: I can't get enough of their fried chicken!! Boneless, but not dry...spicy, but just enough...mashed potatoes, perfect! (And a side of Mac & Cheese don't hurt either!!) I think I've had almost everything on their menu...I Love 1300!!!

2rxVZSvIIBj03PGFBBt_Dg.review_text: I am going to have to agree with the majority of the Yelpers on this place. Wonderful ambiance; great menu; superb service. Definitely worth the taxi from SOMA. I was there on 2/12; visiting SanFran for a month from S Florida, and needed some soul food!  I had the baby arugula salad and a nice chardonnay to start. Very tasty - great portion size. 2nd course, I enjoyed (immensely) the short ribs. They were meaty and very satisfying. The mashed potatoes were really ridiculously delish, and I ordered a side of the greens, which despite being very vinegary - I had a hard time putting my fork down.   I had a NICE pour of Syrah with my 2nd course. Finished the evening talking to 2 guys who were entertaining and mildly deranged as they devoured their food: the bisque and the fat fries (both of which were yummy), and one had the lamb (cooked WELL - what?!?!?), and finished with the chocolate cake, which he was literally crying over it was so good.  The bartender Brittany was superb - a little rushed at first - perhaps she is used to a faster paced service? - but I was there for the long haul, so, I told her to be easy. Smart girl, and very easy to talk to. She made me two killer martinis . . . my total bill was $90, including a 20% tip. NOT BAD!!  The chef/owner stopped by to chat, which was nice.   As I am always looking for black-owned businesses to support, I was glad this was not only upscale, but with good service, superb food, and a wonderful ambiance. In fact, I am taking myself there for dinner tonight!!! OMG - my mouth just watered. I am not kidding!

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: 1300 On Fillmore is one of those places to go to cross off your checklist and nothing else. Decor and ambiance over shines the food at 1300 on Fillmore.  My friends and I came here last Saturday. We arrived at 7:55 PM for reservations at 8 PM and were seated in about 10 minutes.  FOOD: *Cornbread: The cornbread arrived lukewarm in individual triangle blocks. It was not good at all; dry, dense, and had a very grainy texture. The honey butter didn't help as the bread wasn't warm enough to melt the butter. *Ribs w/ Mac & Cheese and Jalapeno Slaw: The ribs were cooked N. Carolina style w/ a dry rub and sauce on the side. Although the ribs were very tender (fall of the bone), I can't say that all pieces were. The rib tips; the portion attached to the lower section of ribs were overcooked and dry. The ribs had great flavor from the rub and the sauce on the side added a great zing and slight heat. The mac & cheese was SUPER YUMMY, although they give you a very small portion in sauce size bowl. It was made with a white cheddar cheese and was super creamy and had toasted bread crumbs throughout and baked on top. Jalapeno slaw was meh. I didn't taste any jalapeno and the slaw wasn't dressed properly. There wasn't enough vinaigrette to coat the slaw, so the acid didn't break down the cabbage which made the texture hard and bitter.   DRINK:  *Sweet Tea (alcoholic): It was ok, it tasted exactly like honey lemon tea and had too much citrus flavor for my taste. Couldn't really taste the vodka.   SERVICE: Our waiter was very friendly and nice. However, because the restaurant was really busy that night, we did have to flag him down to get our orders and bill. Perhaps understaffed.  CROWD: Older sophisticated crowd; late 30s to 50's.   AMBIANCE/DÉCOR: WOW! Kudos to the interior designer who managed to create a thoughtful, warm, stunning, and beautiful restaurant/lounge. As you walk through the huge wooden doors, I was amazed to see a restaurant like this situated in the 'Mo. The main dining room is stunning with gray walls and curtains. The high ceilings have hanging etched spot lights. I love the tree branches in the corner as it gave a wintery feel. The highlight of place has to be the lounge which is artfully decorated with a wall compiled of old jazz pictures that light up.   The restaurant gets LOUD, so keep that in mind, if you're going to bring a date here.   Not sure if the food itself will warrant a return visit. Again, I'm glad at least I can check this off my checklist.

PTY4nk9YobaeagjInz7C_Q.review_text: So fun!!! Great service, WONDERFUL food! The only reason they have 4 stars...umm, it said something about jazz on-line, we were there on a Friday night...until 11ish, no jazz. Bummer.  The warm poached egg salad was AWESOME. Shrimp hush puppies, though not what I expected, also awesome, shrimp was cooked just right, not at all rubbery, or any other such travesty.  I had the fried chicken, believe me, it's worth the 20 minute wait...as is the souffle (order em when you while you're ordering appetizers, it will be timed well!) The wine was also great. While this is high end fare, the price, for two, including appetizers, bottle of wine, and a dessert, VERY reasonable...not CHEAP, but given the nature of the fare, reasonable.  I look forward to going back, and to having a jazz band on site! Highly recommend. mmmm memories of sweet potato souffle. Yumalicious!

dAJOVwXxzOTjM00YTn5t6Q.review_text: This place is definitely going to improve the neighborhood.  The designer looked like they spared no expense.  The decor brings you back to the silver screen era.  It really makes you want to smoke a cigar while listening to some good old jazz.    The food was definitely rich with soul.  I couldn't have expected anything better.  They have a private party room that holds 20 people and i can't wait to set something up.    We had the shrimp with grits (so freaking good), the mushroom with puree (ok), the short ribs (Yummmy) and the Bouillabaisse (super flavorful).  For dessert we had the banana Foster's (it comes out HOT so be careful).  We definitely left there happy.  Service was great!  I hope it stays this way even though it's only been open for one week. =)

2r994k-debvncHxTrNgyvQ.review_text: BEWARE, check your receipt and change, especially when paying cash. Change is short. Reason given; establishment policy if less than a certain, they don't provide. Very presumptuous, unprofessional and cheesy. May be establishment policy to collect every nickel and dime possible. Service is OK, but not stellar.

tlmv_89ARqCtJhqt0_6dAQ.review_text: I have had dinner many times at this lovely restaurant.  The fried chicken and the fish are always amazing, but I recently stopped by for desert and drinks and fell in love.  The bignets with dark chocolate center was orgasmic.  I felt like I was transported to New Orleans.    We went by for a drink on New Years Eve and  were pleasantly surprised by a live band and New Years festivities for free.  Free in San Francisco. Unbelievable.  I would highly recommend this restaurant. Excellent food, great choices and awesome drinks and to die for desserts.  You never know... they may have a live ban.  It has been known to happen

FfZSfwPdooLc2ReXfv7bRg.review_text: First, I love the food here and the restaurant staff is great so go for that. The bar service is the worse and has been for a while. Because of the food, I come back but I think this is it for me:(. I have never had a good bar experience. The bartenders completely lack personality, but even worse is that they have zero customer service skills. I always have to wait and try to get their attention for a drink. I'm here now, have a open tab, my drink has been empty for a good 15 minutes, both - that's right there are 2 - bartenders have looked at it several times,  then washed glasses, stood back and took breaks, left the bar, walked up and down the bar, and just stood with their hands on their hips! I moved my glass up a bit so they could get a better look and still no bites - really??? I just hate it! It happens all the time. Maybe its just me:( that they don't like for no reason. Oops, I was just finally asked, and I say no, just the check please. Sad. A great place with horrible, horrible bar service.

Mfl5zR9o4151OgsrSAGJWw.review_text: Went to celebrate a birthday and was not disappointed.  My man is a BIG eater and the portions were very large (especially by chi-chi standards).  The maitre'd greeted us with a Happy Birthday and didn't forget the special birthday touch on the dessert- I didn't have to remind them, which was very nice.  The waitstaff was right on time- folksy, not snobby, but also very knowledgeable.  The chef came out and spoke to all the diners- he's a handsome, elegant man- just like his cooking!  I had the fried chicken - I couldn't even finish it, there was so much. I've saved my appetite for years to have down-home fried chicken- and thank goodness, this wasn't greasy- just good tastin' chicken done right!   My partner had the short ribs which had a beautiful round presentation- he loved it.  After dinner we hit Yoshi's- couldn't have been more convenient.  We'll be back for the warm atmosphere and delightful food.   The price was right, the atmosphere was elegant but comfortable, and the food was a delight.

Rqg9Rf5ybblqBZ0p5iPn7g.review_text: Another Dine About Town, another try at a new restaurant!  For some reason (other than State Bird and the annual jazz festival) I rarely make it over to Fillmore.  After my delicious mean at 1300 I'll have to come more often!  My fiance and I came on a Sunday night and the space was about halfway full, but with all the seating in the front half of the dining room.  It was surprisingly loud, given the number of diners.  Our hostess seated us immediately and left us with the menus, but it took quite some time for our waitress to arrive.  Once we put in our drink orders they appeared very quickly, but we waited yet again for our waitress to take our orders.  This would be a theme of the night - every employee of 1300 was incredibly quick and efficient, with the exception of our waitress.  The DAT menu offered a watermelon salad, a choice of hangar steak or petrale sole for the entree, and a strawberry "shortcake" for dessert.  I opted for the DAT menu with the sole, and my fiance ordered off the regular menu - artichoke with poached egg for appetizer and their baby back rib special for entree.  The appetizers were very good - I especially loved the interesting flavor combinations in my salad.  The salad included watermelon, pickled watermelon rind, and feta cheese, which I had never tasted in combination before.  The petrale sole was great as well, and came with some wilted chard, mashed potatoes, and the delicious balls of flavor that are capers.  The sole was light, yet flavorful in a way I can never hope to replicate in my home kitchen.  The capers (with browned butter support) really made this dish, though.  My fiance's ribs came with abundant accoutrements (two sauces, a slaw, and mac and cheese), but the ribs themselves were a little bland.  These ribs are rubbed and smoked, but you really need the sauces to introduce serious flavor.  Dessert, while not overwhelming with flavor, was a nice, light end to dinner.  The strawberry "shortcake" consisted of triangles of shortbread, strawberries, and  puffs of whipped cream with strawberry puree, balsamic syrup, and whiffs of basil as well.

ST6wuoNfAhskqoJ66q8ygQ.review_text: I went to 1300 on Fillmore for their weekend gospel brunch, as part of a large group (12 people split into two tables) with an advance reservation.   While the food was decent and the musicians were very talented, we received pretty abysmal service. Consider yourself lucky if you haven't seen me waiting on supremely delayed food, because I can turn into a hangry mofo (especially while nursing a Sunday morning hangover). My dining companions were not as lucky. We waited for over 30 minutes to place our orders (and even then, only because someone at our table waved our waiter over), and then our food didn't arrive for another 30 minutes or so. The party of two next to ours, which was seated much later, had already received their food by the time we were able to place our orders.  When the time came for the bill, we asked for split checks. We mistakenly assumed this wouldn't come as a surprise, since we asked the waiter to split our checks before he took our orders, and he said he would "be able to help [us] out." Instead, he very precisely informed us, "I can help you figure out how much each of you owe, if you can't figure out how to do it yourselves." Apparently he didn't realize that splitting checks is not quite the same as insulting the table's quantitative literacy.  I might come back here again since everyone else seemed to be having a good time, but never with a party of more than 4. Note to management: If you don't have the staff capacity to handle large groups, then just say so!

DodFQgkojJ2hCXuI85RR3A.review_text: I gave it 3 stars due to the strange Happy Hour Server.  4 Stars for the other staff.  5 stars for the ambience and decor of the restaurant.  This is nice elegant place to hang out for happy hour in the lounge.  I love the lounge, it has comfy/cushioned chairs, comfy tables, and a large exhibition of jazz images and the history of the jazz days in the Fillmore.  It is a nice way to learn about the important history of that era.  During 4-7 p.m.  they had a 1/2 price happy hour lounge-only menu.  All the tapas style food was very good. We had mushrooms over grits, short ribs, and some other things I can't remember.  They have a house wine that is 1/2 off as well.    The service was great until we overheard one waiter said, "I can't wait for happy hour to be over!"  Kind of rude to say out-loud.  They he acted strange when we paid our bill.  It came off as if he wanted a tip, but was not sure we wanted all of our money back."  I usually want all my money back, then figure out what the tip is and leave it in the bill container.  I complained to the management and said he was acting strange.    Other than that, we enjoyed our food, the other staff, and piped in music and the over all ambiance and decor of the place.  It is great to get dressed up and just hang in the lounge for some conversation as well.  I love their bathroom.  Nicely appointed, clean and nicely lit.

lXKjU1d7uy4aG0c5dNTATw.review_text: A good friend of mine recommended this restaurant and I couldn't turn it down.  I'm definitely a fan. We ordered a plethora of dishes:  1. Fried Fulton Valley chicken: large hearty portions, definitely not for the faint hearted. This dish came with mashed potatoes and biscuits. The mashed potatoes was a little dry and needed more gravy.   2. Mac 'N Cheese: very good and didn't feel too overwhelmed.  3. Fat Fries with housemade ketchup: these are sooooo good! They were spiced just right.  4. Black Sea Bass: portion was a little small.   5. Banana Cream Pie: this was dubbed as the best dessert in the house. This was, indeed. Thin flaky crust with a very creamy base and fresh chopped bananas with a dribble of caramel on top of the plate. It was off the hook.  I was very happy with our selections. I love the cornbread with its honey butter and jalapeno jelly! Despite we had a grub fest at our table, our server Seth was very helpful and attentive.   The hostess was wonderful and made sure we were comfortable and offered us to get some drinks at the bar before our reservations. We were quite early.   The ambiance was top notch and made me feel I was a part of the Jazz Era, dark woods, lit photographic walls, a jazz and blues band played in house. Everything from the light fixtures, the drapery panels, the carpet to the leather furniture was simply unforgettable. I loved it.   There's public parking in the garage; we paid a flat rate of $12. It was a treat to enjoy some cocktails in the lounge area and lavish on a few gourmet soul comfort food.   Experience it for yourself; it'll be worth the trip.

ElYdBclr7uurfu_Z6qpS8w.review_text: Wow, the service and dinner here was phenomenal. Restaurant decor is very tres chic and classy, very warm environment which was evident with the service we received, everyone was so attentive from beginning to end (loved it). George was our server and he knew it was our 1st time there so he took the time to go over the menu and point out some of the favorites served, we really appreciated his knowledge and input. We started with the shrimp & grits appetizer, the flavor was simply amazing! While waiting for our appetizer some warm cornbread was sent to our table with honey butter and a jalapeño jelly...like seriously, we ate it all and wanted to ask for more but didn't want to ruin our appetites for what was yet to come. So many great choices for dinner, but I opted for the shrimp crusted catfish over a bed of jambalaya and OMG, I can't even begin to explain how good it was. My husband had the maple braised beef short ribs served over greens and mashed potatoes and again, it was truly a divine sensation of flavor in my mouth, the beef was fall-off-the-bone tender. We ended with the chocolate dessert beignets which were a light & flaky choice to top it all off. We thoroughly enjoyed our dining experience and will definitely be back! Highly recommend for a date night ;-)

xIoxkJZsJdSj1vkoPfBQHw.review_text: Came here for drinks and appetizers  before a show and we had an EXCELLENT bartender named Zack. Soooo happy with the cocktails and the service!

N5gDtRPD197lzhmjFgxMNQ.review_text: I am glad that there is an upscale soul food restaurant in the city. This is a nice restaurant with good food. When I walked into 1300, I said that they must be really confident in their food and seasoning not to have any salt or pepper on the table. Well to my surprise it did not need any. The short ribs, fried chicken and corn bread was very delicious. The short ribs were super tender. The macaroni and cheese was ok. The shrimp and grits were interesting; I wasn't expecting the chucks of garlic in it. The service was wonderful. I will be returning.

-sqBGFfmMkrwMiGRyj6poQ.review_text: I was more impressed the first time when I went to this restaurant in the winter  08 for a dinner.  The sould food was amazing, fried chicken out of this world. However we went in for their new Sunday Brunch and was less impressed.  The dishes were tasty, but some items on the plates were unusally cold (like the fried sweet potatos). I had a 1300 Fillmore dish and the grits was out of this world.  the others in our group were happy with steaks, fritters, omlettes.  The portions are large and the price is fair.  Friendly waiter. I would go back for dinner.

I0ViOyrQqguZo-QSH9iDjQ.review_text: I have a Pavlovian reaction to grits. I hear the word "grits" and I start salivating. I love me some grits. I like them boiled simply with water and salt, I like them with melted butter, I like them cheesy, I like them creamy, I like grits on its own, I like it with a side of bacon or ham, I like it for breakfast, lunch or dinner. But by far my favorite (before tonight) were the shrimp and grits I had in Charleston, South Carolina - buttery grits topped with barbecue shrimp in its own gravy.   Whenever I find grits on a menu outside the deep South (and especially in NorCal), I will order it just because I'm happy to see it on the menu. Before tonight, I was a bit disappointed by the grits offerings in SF.   But tonight I discovered what has to be the best grits this side of the Mississippi....and perhaps the best grits on planet earth. The barbecue shrimp and grits at 1300 on Fillmore are TO DIE FOR. Creamy, perfectly cooked grits topped with succulent, savory shrimp, gravy, diced tomatoes and fried garlic slivers. It is a bowl of culinary perfection.   The fried green tomato salad with goat cheese and honey-lavender dressing was also excellent, as was the warm cornbread wedges with honey butter and sweet red pepper marmalade. The fried chicken was juicy and tender and the portion was very generous. I thought the mac n' cheese was disappointingly bland, but this was the only flaw, and one I can happily overlook in my ecstatic glee at discovering this awesome restaurant, which I will definitely be visiting many many many many times in the future. I also love the subdued but classy decor - and I'm loving the revamped area of the Western Addition!  Did I mention the amazing grits?  postscript: I just looked at my receipt and noticed an additional 4% service charge for "SF Health" - the surcharge restaurants are charging so that patrons pick up the healthcare tab of their employees instead of paying it themselves. BOOOOOO!!

AKHX3VbnKrdE_nIOCd5ptA.review_text: I expected a lot more. The environment was ridiculously loud, I could barely hear the person sitting across from me. The food was so lacking in flavor and originality. Around the table we ordered 2 portions of the special, which was a full rack of ribs, catfish dish, and i got the braised short ribs.  I think the catfish dish was okay, but my short ribs were only so-so and something I could easily make at home. It was fall off the bone tender but there was no flavor despite the "maple syrup" label on the menu. The mashed potatoes were also flavorless and below par. So disappointing for a $27 item.  What was not fall of the bone, was the rack of ribs. They were also really bland except for the sauces which you had to dip in. They were not juicy or tender or marinated at all.  Don't bother with the ribs. It looks impressive when it arrives at the table but my bf who never wastes food didn't even want to take the leftovers home.   1 star for being able to get a reservation the day of on a Saturday. 1 star for their truffle mac and cheese.  I didn't try the desserts even thought i wanted to. Maybe that would have made the experience better.

VbE1LgUcOPxkeWZ8eS6OVA.review_text: What a great experience! My man took me here for my birthday, our waiter was really nice and very informative. What I really liked about this place was they made soul food chic, their grits, was like no other!! I could also go on and on about their drink menu, OMG G-O-O-D!!!  I found the desert menu to be a little limited, but other then that, this place was amazing!!    Please do check it out!!

Jf2Mq2mmUmEwvlPbVlpHSQ.review_text: Me and my boyfriend went here on our first date and we have since gone back on the anniversary of that first official encounter. It helps that the food and drinks here are so good!  I like my food "comfortable" as they say, so this menu really serves my palette well. The fried chicken: amazing! the braised short ribs: mouth watering! the pork belly appetizer: shut up! Really, every single item on the menu is exactly what the doctor ordered if you're looking for some high class Southern comfort food. And the desserts are good, too!  Great place for a date, or just if you want a fantastic meal.

KNxH292MIR201pFpxO3KJA.review_text: I have mixed feelings, when rolling over the stars I started to click on the 3, however thinking more about it, it's a solid 4 star.  I liked the food, loved the restaurant and the bar area.    Our server was a really nice guy, however our whole service felt very rushed.  I didn't necessarily get  the impression that they were trying to turn the table, but we made it quite clear that we were there for a leisurely Friday night dinner and yet food felt like it was piled on us.    We started with drinks at the bar, they were both tasty!  Fresh lime juice is always a plus.  Once we moved to our table, like I said earlier the service was rushed.  We ordered the fries: Yum, the sweetbread:  Umm, mixed feeling, they weren't piping hot, I expected them to be a little more crunchy, and then we ordered the poached egg salad.  It was amazing....I liked the way the egg melted into the salad and added to the dressing.  I was getting full after that so I ordered the crab cake appetizer as well as a mushroom/grit appetizer.  OMG, the mushrooms were amazing, my absolute favorite of the night.  It was just a creamy mushroomy comfort in a bowl.  The crab cakes didn't disappoint either....not overly bready, perfectly spiced.  The fried chicken my bf ordered did nothing for me....a little over cooked and the truffled mashed potatoes weren't  that truffely.   BUTTTTTTT, the banana cream pie made up for any negatives I could ever think of.  It was the best dessert I have had in ages and ages.  Oh no....I'm dying for it right now!!!!    It's a bit loud in the restaurant, but it does add to the liveliness.  The private room looks like it would be perfect for a group of 15 or so....I would definitely recommend for groups if you can reserve it.

R2UwY6RpRji3j-LFmb7gSw.review_text: We were quite  late, and although they had the table reserved for another party after us, they were very gracious and never pressured us to move on. When I forgot to print out my tickets to our show and the manager did it for us. No attitude here.    Now the food: my bf had the mussels and thought they were delicious. I had the catfish jambalaya which was excellent.  The flavors were spot on and just the right amount of heat.  I'm from Louisiana so am very particular about my jambalaya and am usually disappointed.  Truly perfection here.  We had the beignet's for dessert and found them very tasty.    If you enjoy your southern food, or are looking for a place to go pre concert you can't go wrong here.

FeANIXy1-ECBm_dOXrocQQ.review_text: Pros: Great ambiance and fantastic service! Cons: I love comfort food but it feels like they are trying too hard to make it fancy. It's also pretty pricey for comfort food.

qa04NQ2wr6G2YVQ_GOEv1g.review_text: I could have fried chicken from KFC for 32 weeks... at the amount I spent here... sigh... came here for a friend's b-day... could not find parking... yep... great area.. but parking would cost 12 bucks... circled a few- and found a spot. (thank god). I ordered the raspberry mojioto upon entering- disappointed. The drink was very diluted with ICE, and I can barely taste the alcohol. I later ordered the fried chicken at the recommendation from Yelp. It was OK... I think the only decent part was that it was deboned for me! Also, the taste was bland... and I had to ask for ketchup... its suppose to be restaurant made specialty... disappointment... sigh...  maybe I am just not into FINE DINING...  I love the ambience though.. it was a great place

7Xca7nk3Ge7pjYMsVVPt9Q.review_text: I want to preface this review that I really wanted to like this place.  As I'm rolling through the yelp reviews and the two star description says it all - "Meh, I've experienced better"  I went with friends after work - we had an amazing dinner a couple weeks before where my co-foodies and I had a great time at Wayfare Tavern and the fried chicken they ordered (and I didn't) was still on my mind.    We were on a quest for fried chicken and Wayfare was booked.  "The one known as Stella" suggested 1300 (she confessed later that she had a douchey date here before and the food was good) and so reso's were made and away we went.  The restaurant is very nice looking - think dark, a little sexy and inevitably a little hipsterish.  We were seated immediately (The tables are close together, so much so that our guest of honor (Lund) kept getting bumped as the server walked past.  We ended up just shifting the table over ourselves - problem solved).  Ok, enough, on to the food (and drinks).  We started out with a round of cocktails - Stella and Lund went a little generic with a glass of Merlot and a gin and tonic.  I went with what they are supposed to be famous for - the Manhattan (our server told me they do Maker's Manhattan's and asked me if that was ok - it was a nice touch, but just a little pretentious?)  Theresa went with a specialty cocktail - something flowery; but, it was good.  For starters:  - Pork belly (with a bourbon sauce that was more mapley than bourboney) - there was a very small piece of pork belly that we practically fought over, a ton of sauce and rounded out with some butter beans.  This dish was really disappointing, it was ok; but, nothing amazing knock your socks off.  Let's face it - pork belly is an extravagance, anything made with it should be like "YES".  this wasn't.   - We also got the mussels - the sauce stole the show here, so good.  Other than that, it was just mussels.  For entrees: - Fried Chicken with mashed potatoes.  This was a very good rendition of fried chicken.  There were three boneless pieces (is something missed if you can't pick up a leg - just saying) and they all had a nice crust (Lund is from the ATL and he took his fork and gave my chicken a smack when it was set down and gave his approval of the crunch) and were very moist.  Again, it was good chicken, but for $25 it should be knock yourself off amazing good - that it wasn't.  - Maple Syrup Braised Short Ribs.  I didn't like this dish at all.  It was cooked wonderfully, fall apart tender; however, for me - it didn't work.  I thought it was too sweet and too mapley and not enough savory.  If you like maple syrup, you very well may love this dish.  - Day Boat Scallops,  Lund didn't share a damn bite of these at all, so I have nothing to report - other than he cleaned his plate.  Whew - this is a long review, congrats if you're still here.  The bill came to about $215 for 4 entrees, 2 apps, a side (brussels sprouts - they were ok, nothing great) and 4 drinks.  I can honestly say I'll most likely not come back.

v5xfQidWLPrRx87tx0dDDg.review_text: I wanted this place to rule, soo much. Alas, my friends and I should have stuck with our usual Southern/Soul Food restaurant of choice that is Farmerbrown for our double date.  The drinks were great (and they have an extensive list) I had the Key Lime Pie, but liked my friend's Pear Flower much better. We started with the truffle mac&cheese and fries as appetizers. The mac&cheese left MUCH to be desired, like some actual cheese! Fries were the thick, steak cut style but since my Irishman liked em, who's to argue with an Irishman and potatoes? House ketchup was great though.  I ordered their friend chicken, soo good! A hefty portion too, I only ate about half and let everyone else pick at it. My friend got their burger which was pretty tasty, but came with this relish/sauce thing that seemed overly sweet to go with a burger. Her date and mine both ordered the short ribs...AVOID! To quote my date "It's the most expensive thing on the menu, and the smallest portion!" And bland too!! Imagine a mound of short ribs, the size of a tangerine.   Our waiter (whose name I don't remember) was incredibly attentive and accommodating, took one of the short ribs off our bill when we said how underwhelming they were. For 4 people with drinks, apps, and no dessert it was about $150.

Q5qMfURihZoZJb5pcejcbw.review_text: started off with a drink and ate dinner at the bar. started off with the pork belly and the mac n cheese. both excellent! then we ordered the char and the fried chicken. again excellent. the only problem I have with this place is that i think its overpriced. the drinks are good though and i would still recomend going there at least once. and the fried chicken is quite excellent~

1fN43CYscPf_dB_3cEwzvQ.review_text: I think that 1300 is one of the few SF Gate top 100 restaurants that is relatively easy to get a primetime Friday reservation for a larger group.  Bonus points for that.  Our group of 7 was seated in the private dining area, which could easily seat well over 20 people.  Service was generally good and attentive throughout the dinner service.  The food was generally good:  I was pleased with their interpretation of Surf 'N Turf.  The scallops and pulled pork were actually quite delicious and in a portion that was actually manageable (unlike the honking big steak and lobster platters that are usually associated with the Surf 'N Turf moniker).  My partner had the Black Skillet Roasted Catfish.  He was not very impressed with this dish, saying it lacked seasoning and was generally bland.  I tried it and agreed with his assessment - the fish could have used a little more "pop" that would be expected with southern cuisine.  We also carbed it up with an order of Fat Fries and Mac and Cheese.  The homemade ketchup for the fries was nice and the mac and cheese solid, but could have used a little more bite as well.  Overall, I was pretty pleased with the service and the food and drink were decent value for the money.

1A-geB-PQr1uveSFOS7Feg.review_text: What a swanky restaurant, which such delicious food.  And good service as well.  The ambiance was my favorite part of this experience - well, other than the company, of course.   The food was pretty good.  A bit pricey, but overall a good experience.    Starters:  1) Scallops - these were okay; probably not worth the price. 2) Cod Fritter - these were decent; probably wouldn't order again.  Mains:  1) Fried Chicken (my selection) - Crisp on the outside, juicy on the inside.  My personal favorite of the food we tried.  The only complaint I had was that I asked for the leftovers to be wrapped up, which the waitress forgot!  Boo... 2) Short Rib (my husband's selection) - So tender, so flavorful.  This was my second choice - so I'm glad my husband ordered it so that I could have a taste! 3) Lamb chop (friend's selection) - the couple we were with ordered the lamb chop and the fried chicken.  I didn't taste the lamb, but my friend said it was delicious.    Desserts:  1) Banana Cream pie - yum.  Very good 2) Pecan pie - by far the best dessert we tried 3) Beignets - decent, but nowhere near as delicious as the others. 4) Bailey's Irish Cream - delicious, obviously.  Can't go wrong with Bailey's!

KVHsaHl9j0-T6eKjd0vm2w.review_text: I have some seriously mixed emotions about this place. The food is awesome (and I'll get to that in a moment), but the heavy smell of the destructive gentrification of the Fillmore was a little much for me. The "Jazzy, Sexy, Historic, Classic, Elegant" vibe they're shooting for (check the website) reminds me a lot of the Fillmore District as it was long before my time, full of musicians, working class families, affordable jazz clubs, and an actual community. I guess that's what 1300 is designed to celebrate, though I can't escape the feeling that its existence takes the Fillmore one step further from the way it used to be. But I digress....  My ex-girlfriend took me here for my birthday shortly after the place opened, as I am a lover of fried chicken. Turns out these meals can get pretty emotional, and things started to fall apart over some delicious braised pork belly. As a Jew, pork belly is about as far over my line of "that's not so far beyond being Kosher that I can't make up for it later in life" as anything, but the lady loves her some tender meat, and so we got it. So guiltily delicious. No regrets.  For dinner, the lady had the Maple Syrup Glazed Short Ribs. Again, super tender and flavorful, but not too much. The fried chicken, our raison d'etre (which I probably just misspelled, but tough shit), was so moist and succulent that I almost didn't notice the emotional chaos going on throughout the meal. I must say, having never before sat through such a dramatic and uncomfortable moment in a restaurant (and I'm not assessing blame, just saying it was an all-around dramatic moment), with that "everyone's looking at me and thinks I'm an asshole" feeling, I imagine that very few plates of food motivate one to weather the storm. This one did.   Skipped dessert (too much storm!), waiter was weird, would come back, but feel like part of the gentrification and a bad Jew. I know. It's a bit neurotic.

IWgBt5RMGIeLECqlNv996w.review_text: Yummerzzzz on the food... Meh on the service!  The Skinny: 1300 is a swanky restaurant of Fillmore next to Yoshi's. They play Jazz, and on some nights have a live Jazz band on some nights. They have great dark, smoked out & swanky decor. It's a cool atmosphere. Men: Don't forget your button up shirt & Fave scotch Women: Sling backs and perfect pinky martinis are appropriate!  This was our 2nd visit to 1300 because although they have poor, rushed & impersonal service, they have this delish Short Rib. Lets get to it:  1. Braised short Rib yummy soaked in a maple type marinade. It's tender and falls apart! TRY IT!  2. MASHED POTATOES are an easy hit, nothing special...just good ol mashed taters  3. Mac N Cheese... pretty good, the pasta is VERY al' dente, the cheese is white n gooey. Hits the spot!  4. Martinis pretty good.  The Meh: This, as I previously stated, was our 2nd visit, different server & a different night. They still missed! They were rushing to get our order, didn't want to make recommendations, and all together scatter  brained. All rushing like ants after their bed has been disheveled.  Go for the food & Jazz, not for the service!

la8qO8xxxoWv1a38NBsy8A.review_text: I have such a food hangover from this place.  I went last night with some friends, as I've been dying to try 1300 on Fillmore based on pcitures and reviews I've seen.  The interior is gorgeous and made me wish we'd had our pre-dinner drink here instead of Yoshi's, which is obviously beautiful but somewhat sterile.  Our meal was great, the wine list is comprehensive, and the service was very good.  I will be back for sure, although I'll try to eat less.   Stand outs: hushpuppies, fried chicken (AMAZING and I'm not even a fan usually), short ribs.

IETqqi0vhMKrFDa3LqrhGQ.review_text: From top to bottom, this was an amazing culinary event!  In large part due to our waiter, John, who was not only attentive and responsive to our every need but also had the most amazing "radio voice" ever.  Seriously, this guy should be doing podcasts for cool people that want to relax or something!  More importantly though, the food was incredible!  The ribs were the best I have had since I left the south east United States, where, and trust me on this, they know BBQ!  Su Chef Juan has for sure got a handle on his kitchen and puts out the most amazing meal.  From the corn bread (as addictive as crack) to the appetizers, entree, and dessert, one of the most amazing meals I've had in quite some time.  Keep up the GREAT work, 1300 Fillmore and thank you for a great experience!

E-VcjSaqij21LkDTz8dE-g.review_text: Well, I finally made it to 1300. First I walked in and I was in love with the decor. I received a warm welcome, from the manager, a warm welcome from the staff, and a horrible glare from the poorly dressed, self important yuppies in the corner of the lounge area. One of whom mentioned to some one at the top of her lungs that she is one of the owners of District so you know I will not be going there. It amazes me that this new era of white people, with new money think that they are the only ones allowed to experience food in San Francisco. This has nothing to do with the restaurant, but when you walk into a place and are overwhelmed with those kind of assholes as your co-patrons, it leaves a bad taste in your mouth. It's like going to your favorite club and those suburban guys with bad hair cuts and shiny shirts are there drinking Bud Light and aggresively trying to hit on you. Well they were so ridiculous and pretentious, that I decided to make them a source of entertainment while I waited for the rest of my party. I had no choice but to listen their conversation since they did not know the meaning of using their inside voice. While they shouted their pretense to every one at 1300, I smirked at them like they were fools who did not know the secret, while the one who owned District looked at me with a great deal of discomfort. Either she knew I thought she was lame or she was afraid I was going to steal her dated designer bag (I am after all black) At least I know how to keep my self busy.   The manager told me they were out of the rabbit and fried chicken. I joked that I was appalled and I was leaving, we laughed and the District lady really looked irritated.   So finally my party showed up. We were all seated at our table and the manager was pleasant and made us feel very welcome.  Let me just mention that I was with my cousins and my one cousin's boyfriend, who is a major star in the NFL, so I think that this seriously affected the service we got. Our server was very nice but also very unprofessional. He kept ease dropping in personal conversation to add his two cents and hitting on my cousin (the single one).  I mentioned to him that with his voice, he should do radio or voice over work. I never should have said anything. He went on about how he has a sports radio talk show and he kept trying to build a re pore w/ my cousin's boyfriend who was not interested in talking about his career as an athlete. He wanted to have a nice dinner with family. The vibe w/ our server went from "oh he's nice" to "he's annoying and no one asked him to co-sign". At one point we were talking, to eachother, about having a child at forty and he decided to tell us about his fertile aunt who had 5 kids after 35. It was really weird, and all of a sudden there was an awkward silence. My cousin's boyfriend did not like him. But he's a nice guy so he did not say anything. I think that sometimes with sports nuts they feel like they can have an odd type of casualness with professional athletes that they would not have with others. Time and time again I have seen people go up to my cousin's boyfriend and talk to him about his stats and football like they know him and can be as casual as they want. They tell him what is wrong with his career, his team mates and the NFL in general as if they can say it on authority. It is really  weird.  Then our food came, not that great.  The cornbread was very dry to the point that I choked on it and had a coughing fit. My cousin and I shared the poached egg and cabbage salad. The blue cheese overwhelmed it. To the point where I had to grimace. The brussel sprouts tasted like mustard and were not cooked properly.  My beef tenderloin was good but the greens, had absolutely no flavor. At this point I really needed salt and I could not find any one to ask for assistance in the purveying of such salt. Let me add that I do not use a lot of salt. The sign of a good chef is not having to add salt or pepper. What ever starch was with it, I did not like. It tasted like maybe it could have been cheese grits w/ blue cheese and the fact that I cannot tell you what it was is also disturbing. The mac and cheese was no bueno, but my cousin liked it. Our desert was alright, chocolate begniets w/ coffee soda were forgettable. Then our server came over with his shirt untucked, his back pack on and no vest or tie to thank us and pick up the check. He explained that it was Easter and he had had a long night.  We were all very surprised.  I can understand he was tired but why would he tell us that? As we left, the chef came out and thanked us, the manger thanked us and asked us to come again and our server hit on my cousin again. At which point I teased about her new boyfriend. So I don't know how I feel about this place. I was not impressed but something tells me I should give it another chance. Maybe I will.

lzd1pUgb_41Ck0AGDEphoA.review_text: yummy and yummy.  This place is right in the middle of Filmore.  Right next to Yoshi's.  I came for dinner prior to a night of Jazz.  Parked under the building and off I went.  This place is handsome and comfortable.  I came for a nice date and the place did not disappoint.  The service was attentive.  Both the waiter and staff were attentive.   Ordered a salad with pistachios,  Salmon with potatoes, and chard.  My friend ordered sage roasted butternut squash.  Ooh so good.   I wished I had more time for the fried chicken.  I will definitely come back.

oAz4s21FA2QjE0kCNIDxOg.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore, you have a new fan.  My boyfriend and I had dinner here before a show a Yoshi's, and we couldn't have been happier. I started with the poached egg salad, which was to die for. Cabbage, dressed perfectly, with plenty of bacony goodness throughout. My boyfriend had the sweetbreads...good, but not the best I've ever had (that honor goes to Les Amis). For entrees, I had the black bass with salsify, which was cooked perfectly. Boyfriend had the fried chicken. WOW. That shit is addictive! Best fried chicken I've ever had. We had a delicious bottle of Tin Barn Zinfandel, for a very reasonable price.  Service was impeccable. Attentive, professional, and personable. Loved the atmosphere, and the lounge had a live jazz band that night. This is my new go to spot before a show at Yoshi's, and it should be yours too! *4 1/2 Stars*

kksXbNL7S-p7-MvUd1x6Gw.review_text: We waited 40 mins to be seated with a reservation however the staff were very apologetic and didn't rush us out afterwards. Service was really good, nice atmosphere although a bit dark and the food was good (but not amazing). There's a really nice bar also. I'd try it again.

u60OkmjDviL9Yr79GnjDAQ.review_text: I just finished watching Christian Siriano win Project Runway. So forgive me when I describe 1300 on Fillmore as 'FIERCE!'  What an amazing experience.  Thank you, George, for being one of the best waiters I've ever had here in SF.  If you get a chance, request George. He'll steer you in the right direction and you won't be disappointed.  So, let's get started.  How about some home made cocktails and a lovely glass of wine while we take in the masterfully decorated main room. Warm, cozy, comfy, open and roomy.  And anyone looks good under this lighting.  Even the front doors ask you to touch them  and feel their texture.  I got my drink on (Hangar One Martini, thank you!). Now I wanted some of this Pork Belly I kept hearing about.  Me? I loved it. Downed my entire portion in 5.2 seconds only coming up for breath once. I don't make a habit of consuming pure pig fat on a regular basis. But, when it's done right, you gotta just dig in.  For our mains, I ordered the AMAZING Maple Syrup Braised Beef Short Ribs with Buttermilk Chive Mash Potatoes (and two onion rings to top it all off).  I ate every morsel on my plate. Fierce. Hot Mess. Tranny!  My partner (here for his birthday) ordered the amazing fried chicken. Yes, the fried chicken is $21, but it's Fulton Valley Chicken (believe me, you can taste the difference). And it came with truffle whipped potatoes and home made gravy, plus home made skillet Corn Bread with a sweet and mild jalapeno jelly and a side of honey cream butter.  To Die For! Tranny Fierce!   As an encore, our fabulous waiter, George, brought out the Chocolate Beignets with Chocolate Dipping Sauce and a side of Chocolate Soda (sort of like long shaped warm donuts with a side of warm chocolate sauce for dipping). And on the side of the plate, written in chocolate - in cursive - were the words "Happy Birthday."  I didn't even have to ask for that. It's little things like that that made our experience at 1300 one of the best in San Francisco.  It so wonderful to see this area getting some much needed financial help, new developments, condos, Yoshis and now 1300 on Fillmore.   I can't wait to go back - if not for the food, then to experience the San Francisco Jazz history that adorns the walls.  Every Jazz aficionado...head to the cozy lounge area, grab a seat in the lounge or at the bar, and look lovingly at our local jazz history.

ozTQCUmK9lUCopa4cznKtg.review_text: more like 3.5 stars. food was alright, prices are pretty high. plate of fried chicken is $21 -$23? something like that....but the decor is amazing. feels more like a lounge where you sit and sip on drinks for hours.

zImXgiRxQ5oURDqFe_-VbA.review_text: My man and I had a fantastic meal - shrimp n' grits, fried chicken, okra, collard greens, fried green tomatoes--- everything came with a unique and delicious twist.  I have not been to the Fillmore in a long time and found it  very lively and safe.   Going back for gospel brunch!

Ue0geihdSeMM2GnzSs6woA.review_text: Noisy cafeteria environment. Food overpriced for the quality provided.

Rto4xWr5gXA2IbrfyAn-Xg.review_text: food was decent. service was a bit slow. place is not as romantic as i thought it would be since the acoustics are very loud and the tables are very close to each other. i tried burger and it was quite raw (ordered medium rare). it was well-seasoned though, which was nice. the cornbread was light, but pretty crumbly thought the pepper jam they served it with was delicious. overall - somewhat hit or miss - probably not worth another visit.

7LrhtqVWzfawWgoZLoHqtg.review_text: I like this cozy restaurant, we have been there for a few times, the food is great, the price is reasonable.

JjTusdmnjHxKe-Kqwr0YGA.review_text: I don't know.  There's just something unsettling about this place.  Perhaps it was the late hour on the a Tuesday night after the long holiday.  Perhaps the stiff front door held closed by a combination of springs and air pressure that left me wondering if they were perhaps closed after all, despite our reservation.  Or the 25 degree temperature drop between our South Bay home and Hayes Valley.  Or the lack of a host at the podium.  Or the nonchalant way a waiter sat us at the small table nearest the door pushed up against two walls ... despite a mostly empty restaurant.  Whatever the case, we did not arrive in a particularly good mood.  After seeing the cocktail list, our mood improved slightly.  This is a place with some interesting offerings.  We had the Corpse Reviver No. 2  ( I passed up The Last Word with some reluctance as well ) and my companion the Kaffir Lime Gimlet.  We were both impressed with the quality of the citrus and the clean flavors.  Further improvements were had going over the menu: a fried green tomato salad ( somewhat tough little fried green tomatoes, but beautiful breaded, fried balls of goat cheese and lavendar honey.  Our request for dressing on the side was graciously honored ), chicken liver pate ( a strongly flavored bar with aspic on top and fresh toasted crostini - lovely ), skillet roasted catfish ( mild flavor, wonderful accompaniments ), and their famous fried chicken ( a huge dish, perhaps a little too salty ) with a side of grits ( buttery goodness if you miss grits ).  By the time we left after a dessert of chocolate filled beignets and strawberry crumble, our mood was much improved.  And you cannot ask much more of a restaurant, really.  We did take advantage of a blackboard eats discount and also a visa signature deal for a free dessert, which again were both graciously accepted.  The service was very friendly, very available after a rough start, and very accommodating.  But still.  Southern cuisine in such a fancy, hip place.  Something unsettling about that, I swear.

pdGxQv4z0gKVxFd2Ejlgdg.review_text: Summary: not worth the hefty price.  We ordered 4 appetizers (shrimp and grits, gnocchi, fried green tomatoes with goat cheese, and shrimp hush puppies) and while the first three were were pretty good to really good, the hush puppies were completely bland and couldn't even be saved by sprinkling some salt on top.  A place specializing in southern food that couldn't make a decent hush puppy?  hmm...  we only ordered two entrees: braised short ribs and the fried chicken.  the fried chicken was a big disappointment.  one piece was way overcooked and both were slightly over seasoned.  since the mashed potatoes were completely bland, eating a bite of chicken and potatoes together was the only way to make the dish tolerable.  on the plus side, the short ribs were pretty damn tasty (and the mashed tatoes that came with that dish actually had flavor).  both dishes had big portions.   dessert was the mud pie which was more like a small piece of bland flourless chocolate cake.  i love chocolate...sadly, this dessert didn't satisfy.  however, i will hand it to the staff.  they provided top notch service.    (see Stacy T's review for a less forgiving account of the same evening.)

pEnPxArLOZlKC94iVkVFxQ.review_text: I don't know the last time I said, "I had impeccable service and enjoyed everything I had!" Well that is exactly how I felt Friday night at 1300 On Fillmore. Talk about a awesome atmosphere, leather loungy chairs and walls covered in photos that make you feel your in a different time.  The food...ooh the corn bread!!!!  Not only do you get great service, a fun place to hang out but you get great happy hour deals as well! Till 7 pm you can have half off appetizers, $3 bubbly and $5 house wines and cocktails.  I highly recommend this spot, perfect for a few foxy ladies trying to relax and have some after work drinks.

CkfoCz-jTpsprhEBf9_cSA.review_text: We have been talking about going to 1300 Fillmore since it's grand opening. We strolled in one evening after enjoying a show at Yoshi's and the look and aroma of the place made us really want to return. So, a couple of weeks ago one of our socially motivated friends decided to get a group of 10 together for dinner. The only workable date was this past Saturday and we had to settle for 9PM reservations. No problem and it actually worked out really well for us. We arrived a bit early and were met by the nice, beautiful people at the front which included Monetta, one of the owners. We had already seen the place so the beauty of it was no surprise. I love the pictures in the lounge and it was quite comfortable. I could have sat there for an hour or two. Oh, wait I think we did!  We joined other folks from our party in the lounge and were served by College Student John who kept the good drinks coming. I had the New Orleans Punch which was quite good. We had a great time catching up in the lounge and enjoying the beverages. While in the lounge a couple of bottles of wine brought by a couple of our connoisseur friends were handed over to be opened/decanted as we waited for our table. Judging from the wine list we would have been fine if they hadn't brought something from their racks. BUT I'm glad they did. We enjoyed them!  The lounge was comfortable and we were in no hurry to get to our table. They didn't rush us either. We ended up with only six in our party showing up due to unforeseen circumstances and we missed them until the food came. :).   Once we made it over to the table Sarah our waitperson took our appetizer orders, one of which was the short rib dinner which we all shared as well as the shrimp hushpuppies and sauteed mushrooms. All delicious! Damn! The short rib was really tender. For dinner the popular choice seemed to be the ribeye steak. Excellent is all I can say. I think though, next time I'd go medium rare instead of medium (my usual default). The fried chicken looked tasty too. David and his staff were jammin' in the kitchen! We were all pretty full from everything we had consumed thus far BUT the dessert menu came out so we went for it. I ordered peach cobbler and a glass of Navarro Late Harvest Riesling. Both very tasty. I opted not to have the ice cream on the side of my cobbler just so I could say I passed on something!  We love this place and will return. Next time I think I'll try the fried chicken or have the short rib all to myself.  The folks that run the place and serve you were fantastic. It was a lot of  fun.

-oY8V9WMCLYQZPCCUubpQg.review_text: We have been to this place several times, because it's right by Yoshi's, which we frequent for shows, and Joe's not into sushi. We were pretty excited about 1300 when we first discovered it. The decor and ambiance are cool and classy.   The menu at 1300 works well for us, because it has the beef dishes for Joe and the alternative things I tend to like. We have been happy with our food every time, but I can't say what we had. I looked at the online menu, and I remember I had the butternut squash risotto one time and liked it, but most of the other things don't sound too familiar, so I wonder if the menu is different in the restaurant.   We did have a problem the last time we visited. We had plans to go to a show at Yoshi's (Alan Parsons, 8 pm). Joe & I always tend to be running a bit late...no, it's not only me, really...and this night I said when he picked me up how thrilled I was that for ONCE we would for sure see the beginning of a show. We ran into some unexpected worse than usual traffic slowness, but when we got to 1300, he said don't worry, we have a little over an hour and Yoshi's is next door.   Well, guess what? The service was SO slow, we had sat there over 20 minutes before we got our cocktails, another long wait just to order, more and more waiting. It was the slowest meal I have ever had, I think. We had an bullet-sweating old-guy waiter who was essentially hiding somewhere the whole time, while we sat & sat and watched all these young waiters practically running table to table with drinks & food.   By 8:10, honestly, I was fuming. Our entrees had not even been delivered and the show was starting at 8. I said to Joe, we should get it boxed and go, IF the waiter ever comes back. Then the food came, and Joe wanted to go ahead & eat it. Joe is a pretty laid back guy and he is not used to seeing the first half of anything. I was too irritated to enjoy my meal at all. Joe quickly wolfed what he wanted, and then we got our take-out boxes (yes, that was slow, too), and we got to the show at least 30 minutes late. Unfortunately, my irritation at the waiter caused Joe to have irritation at me, so it caused a lot of unnecessary stress on the night, to say the least.   My tip is: It is a good restaurant, but it might work best to either make it the night's destination, or post-event, or if you have to go someplace after do not accept the old-guy waiter. Sorry, old dude, you need to step it up a LOT.

-loye23R-J-3ntgRiovWcg.review_text: I had dinner here on Friday night! It was great! One of the best steaks I have had (rib eye) cooked to perfection! The service was great.  I have gone here for drinks before, this was the first time I had dinner. I was impressed by how perfectly staffed it was- not overstaffed/not understaffed- just right.  It was great to see the owners socializing with their patrons- rarity in busy restaurants.  I will definitely be returning.

1CQow86GcCT7tpPfxuVEQQ.review_text: Yum, yum, yum.. I made a reservation for two at y7:30 PM reservation on OpenTable.com. When we got there at 7:29 PM we were greeted and seated immediately. The restaurant has a plush intimate feel and Billie Holiday was softly playing in the background. Our waiter suggested we order the Feisty Blood Orange, which is a spicy blood orange martini, it was very good, I ended up drinking three! The corn bread with butter and pepper jelly was super tasty. We ordered a fried green tomato salad and the BBQ shrimp and grits to start. The green tomatoes were crunchy and hot and we had to seriously think about not licking the bowl of the shrimp and grits, which had the perfect bbq flavor and the cheesy grits rivaled the grits my Grandma (from South Carolina!) makes. We ordered the boneless short ribs and the pork loin for our main course. I didn't taste the short ribs but they looked very good and my pork was cooked to perfection, tender and juicy, and served on the amazing grits. Service was perfect, we had a great time, and the food was well worth the cost. Bottom Line: You will want to eat grits everyday of the week.

C5IN7AR4zUuYQ3ELNL5fIQ.review_text: I'm a fan.  Chef David Lawrence never fails to impress.  He's funny, calm and is not afraid to step out onto the dining room floor to hear how great everything is.  I've been a few times.  Once for a full dinner, once for drinks and once for dessert and coffee.  The decor is amazing.  Dark woods, backlit photographs, inviting lounge (sometimes with live jazz band) and beautiful dining room.    The food is just about the closest you can get to Heaven on a plate.  The short rib is a favorite of mine and the pork belly was to die for.  We also enjoyed the filet and hushpuppies.  Drinks were okay, but poured heavily.  They didn't have the St. Germain's I was looking for.
