I tell the person I may be running late for my reservation and the person just says ok and hangs up....did you even know who I was? They didn't even ask for my name and didn't say anything like thank you we'll see you soon...nothing -_-  Anyways, my bf and I arrive a couple minutes late but are seated immediately. We are scanning through the menu a couple of times and maybe 10 or 15 minutes go by and no one comes by to check on us or give us any water. It's only 5:45 and there was hardly anyone there so not sure what the deal was. Finally our waitress takes our drink and dinner order and from then on she was very attentive to us and we started to enjoy our dinner despite the rude start.   They offered a special Xmas eve dinner so I went with the bay scallops, the catfish entree and then the beignets for dessert. My bf went with the butternut squash soup, the ribeye entree and then the chocolate pot de crime for dessert. Not sue if we had enough food, we also ordered a side of the ham hock greens and the truffle Mac and cheese.  We enjoyed everything really but the butternut squash soup was just ok and we really could have done without the sides as we were really stuffed by the end of our meal. Sides were good but the entree portion sizes filled us up for sure.  All in all the food was ok. Seems like they do a decent brunch so might come back to try that next time.

A9RKvWz-as6hzSKS_xwVrw.review_text: time for an upgrade, yeah!  a group of 9 on a friday with no rezzies?! yes, we braved the wait.  yoshi's was empty except for some older folks but this place was packed and happening.  while the food was just as amazing as last time, this time the service was top notch.   once the back room was free from a private wedding party, we spilled in and claimed a couch and some chairs.  there is a bar menu but you can order from the regular dinner menu as well.  the cornbread was just as delicious as before. the butternut squash soup was perfect for a cold and windy night.  like sweet creamy velvet.  a second visit couldn't go without ordering the pan fried chicken.   a solid hunk was pure white meat while the other two pieces were a bit questionable but anything pan fried is deelish. combo that with some sure fire carbs : mashed potatos and biscuits. yes i could have used a wee more gravy to dunk the biscuits but i probably didn't need to.  thanks to our server chloe for making our night really fun and entertaining!

vnpfnIsSFzInHaXgP4doLQ.review_text: We had reservations for 10 and upon arriving were seated at a large round table near the kitchen. I'm a big bread fan and not a big meat fan, so I had a feeling that the complimentary cornbread would be a highlight of the night for me, and it was. Sadly though, it was not even the best cornbread I've ever had, but drier and more crumbly than that offered by no-frills soup and salad joints near the Berkeley campus. I liked the jalapeno jelly because I could taste real pepper flavor in it, but I fear that they put artificial coloring in it because it was almost disturbingly glowing bright red under the dim lighting of the restaurant. For my main course, I ordered the baby back ribs, which was a special of the night and costs $29 (just a note since it's not on the menu). They are pork ribs and come with coleslaw, macaroni and cheese, a very mustard-y sauce, and a second more traditional BBQ sauce. The ribs are seasoned with a dry rub, which our waiter emphasized was less messy than sauce, but I found the meat pretty tasteless and wouldn't have minded compromising neatness for flavor. The ribs weren't really fall-off-the-bone tender, which I know from watching way too much Food Network over the years is an important criterion. I tasted a bunch of my friends' dishes too, as I'm big on communal eating, and actually thought the pork chop with the unique addition of cherries was most flavorful, and the largest portion.    Food-wise, definitely not worth it, but really I don't even think Angeline's is worth the $$ cost of a meal. I have nothing against and much to the contrary highly respect the deliciousness that is Southern cuisine, but to me it's just hard to make items such as fried chicken gourmet to the point that it'd be worth $30 for a couple pieces. It seems almost wrong to try to elevate comfort foods, as they are supposed to be basic and down-to-earth. As a college student I'm used to eating in order to get full and seeking the most bang out of my buck, but I get that people patron $$$ restaurants for the service and ambiance, as 1300 on Fillmore's walls filled with framed black-and-white historical photos and candlelit tables exude an elegant atmosphere. Surely a classy date spot aesthetically, but don't expect to win someone over with the food.

FsuGxIFvbvgMlp8cKdpI4w.review_text: I've been wanting to go to 1300 on Fillmore for sometime now that I came across an email sent to me to see Celebrity Chef Joey Altman (Bay Cafe) with his band the Sole Peppers. I invited a friend to go with me and was all excited to partake in this event only to be drastically disappointed by the host! We walked in the Band was playing and no host at the front, we waited for almost 10 min and still no host, plus they were not busy. We walked to the bar area and no acknowledgment from the bar tender so we walked towards the dinning area to seat ourselves only to have the Host appear and give us an attitude about how she could help us. I explained to the Host how we waited for 10 min and so on only to have us follow her to the front "again" to set us down to a table. Strike 1 for 1300. Our waiter came by to take our order. He was great but only sad thing was he didn't know when asked who the Chef & Band was. He didn't know. Strike 2! All in all my friend and I had a great time listening to Joey & the Sole Peppers and enjoyed our cocktails and Spicy shrimp &Gritts appetizer. I was referred to 1300 by a good friend who comes into the restaurant quite abit. All in all I would come back to 1300 for their dinner menu but hoping for a better Host/Service.

knReN1F-2WbpQzyhElvnYQ.review_text: I was lucky enough to get to eat at 1300 today for Christmas lunch. (2:30) I absolutely fell in love with everything about the place. The staff was very friendly and prompt, the place is gorgeous and the food was truly delicious.    I had the shrimp n' grits appetizer, the pan seared cod gumbo, and the apple cobbler.  The appetizer was creamy and spicy and I wanted to lick the plate when I was done.  The seared cod was cooked perfectly on top of an andouille sausage and shrimp gumbo, there were orange slices on top which I thought was weird at first but once I had a bite they elevated the taste to an entirely new level.  And last but not least, that cobbler was amazing!  The apples were still crisp but not under cooked and the crust was fluffy and buttery.  There was soooo much food!  I cannot wait to go back and try a regular dinner and brunch!

-61NjhuluAHO4Wh201k4ag.review_text: I am very surprised at the all over the place reviews for this place...I had a great meal here- reminded me of several chefs in NOLA...this chef has real talent and care... is it the best food this side of John Besh? no...but that isnt the point here...this is the kind of food and location that this neighborhood needs reflects the soul of the filmore- and we need to see more serious development of food in the filmore and I hope this leads the way!   we ate our way through the menu and the only weakness was the ribs...all the tables around us loved what they all got and was a nice mix of tourists and locals... this will be my stop before yoshi's or even the filmore from now on...unless sushi or shabu call me....sigh....

B856VSGCvHAB-mil7JVprA.review_text: Beautiful restaurant with a wonderful drinks list. However, food is just ok.  * Pear Flower $12 (5 of 5) - Absolut Pear, St. Germaine, Fresh grapefruit, Lemon juice.Very easy to drink and very pretty and pink. It is like a spiked grapefruit juice. Yummy, * Kaffir Lime Gimlet $12 (4 of 5) - Hanger One Kaffir Lime, Fresh Lime Juice. Stronger drink and pretty sour. Refreshing and pretty colored. But Pear Flower was just easier to drink as a girl.  Complimentary CornBread (3.5 of 5) - Fresh and shaped like a piece of pie. Cute and fresh, but slightly dry ontop where the browning is. * Special of the Day Half Rack of Ribs (3.5 of 5) - Super meaty rack of ribs. Dry rub and needs to be accompanied by sauces. They dish comes with a mustard sauce and a bbq sauce. I personally like it with the mustard sauce.  * Black Skillet Roasted Catfish, Andouille Sauce and Shrimp Jambalaya, Cornbread Panzanella Salad $23 (3 of 5) - The catfish was fresh, and the jambalaya was tasty, but neither were super strong tastes. It was rather mellow. I expected the catfish do be tastier, but it was not.  * Black Skillet Fried Chicken , Buttermilk Whipped Potatoes, Pan Gravy $25 (2.5  of 5) - Most disappointed with this dish. The chicken was boneless, but it was pretty dry. And it looked more like hush puppy pieces, than Fried Chicken. I was disappointed and confused why I didn't like this dish more when everyone else on the yelp was tipping to get the Fried Chicken.  * Maple Syrup Braised Boneless Beef Short Rib, Crispy Onion Rings, Horeseradish Chive Mashed Potatoes $28 (2.5 of 5) - Very dry piece of short rib. Very soft, but also very dry. I thought the short rib would contain more fat and create a melt in your mouth goodness, but our dish was not that moist.   * Spiced Fat Fries, home made ketchup $7 (3 of 5) - It is just a really large cut of fries. Nothing too special. I can skip this next time. * White Truffle Mac N White Cheddar Cheese $7 (3 of 5) - It was a pretty good mac and cheese, but I didn't really smell or taste the truffle. I can also skip this next time.  This place has great ambience. The food was greatly portioned, but the taste was only ok. To balance that out, their drinks were pretty tasty and much more intune with their ambience. Probably recommend for drinks, but pass on the meal.

9eIDB9mIYL3zbbKs8nv4pw.review_text: This place is pretty classy. I liked the way it looked, and the bar and lounge areas were pretty chill. Plenty of places to sit on a Saturday night. I was told this was a jazz lounge, but apparently that describes the decor and vibe. Jazzy, not jazz, since I didn't hear a single note.  I tried their Southern Soul, which had some rye whiskey, some bitters, and some other stuff. It reminded me of grapefruit. Everything's on the pricey side, but at a place that looks as great as this, it's pretty much expected.

odM7WqRsORcMsFymWEMiAw.review_text: Impressive room.  Great service.  Attracts a nice demographic.  I must confess, I'm not a huge fan of the neighborhood, despite its rich musical history.  It takes a deep breath & a real leap of faith to "walk the gauntlet" from Geary St on down to the restaurant, but once you get there, it's lovely.  It's an interesting "Stake in the Ground", so to speak: They're really putting forth an effort to rehabilitate this sketchy part of Fillmore, and they're putting their money where their mouth is (considering the one-two punch of Yoshi's AND this).  I'm sure they're hoping other upscale establishments will follow.  And they just might.  As for the food, I only had a few small things, but they were lovely: The Sautéed Mushrooms with Mascarpone Hominy Grits was unusual, inspired & tasty (unlike any grits I ever had growing up, but REALLY nice), The cornbread was excellent, with a sort of spicy jam beside it, the Fried Green Tomato Salad with Warm, Herb-Crusted Goat Cheese was great, too.  I'd definitely go back, but I think I'd save up a bit of $$$ first, as prices for mains are quite high.  Definitely worth a try, particularly if you're up for something different.

uEaEniJPvwzgbiD-bbcXqw.review_text: Yes, it's silly to pay $25 for fried chicken. But when you feel like fried chicken when your situation deems Popeye's inappropriate, 1300 is a very real and worthy alternative.  Ambience, service, and food were top-notch.   The hostess happened to be walking by our table, and cleared a few dishes for us. Some dude in a suit boxed our food up for us. This is a business whose staff understands that while everyone serves a role within the machine, the bigger picture is to keep the customers happy. I get the feeling "It's not my job" doesn't fly at manager meetings, and, quite frankly, that's how it should be.   It's beautiful, dark, and obviously a top-choice for group parties, as there were two large parties in the main dining room, and the lounge area was reserved for a private party. 1300 has a very sexy, masculine energy to it; perfect for 2nd or 3rd dates and extremely fitting for the neighborhood's late night entertainment. Ladies-don't come here on a first date unless you're okay with breaking that silly little rule. You know what I'm talking about...  We ordered: *Shrimp 'N Grits: shrimp were so so so good, but the grits weren't as creamy as I prefer.   *Fried Chicken: HOLY CRAP, this was the juiciest chicken I've ever had. 1300 is known for this dish, and I can see why.  *Braised Short Rib: I don't even like ribs, but these were falling-off-the-bone tender and wonderfully flavored. I *almost* wish I'd ordered this instead.  *Beignets: Good, but not as amazing as I'd hoped. Served with warm chocolate sauce and coffee soda (which is basically a coffee foam). Definitely a perfectly portioned treat.

RAfLjxFFOBoj4plikfLi5A.review_text: Great looking menu, but potential not met!  The menu has a lot of great looking items on it, but everything we tried missed the mark by several notches.  This is sad because we were really interested and enthusiastic about the dishes we ordered.  Food:   A nice touch is abundant cornbread with both butter and a sweet chili relish on the side.    For appetizers, we ordered the poached egg and cabbage salad and the sweetbreads.    The salad is a great idea.  It was described at a soft poached egg over cabbage with a mustard/bacon vinaigrette.   Bacon vinaigrettes are often made by frying the bacon and using some of the renderings to create the dressing.  In this case, it seemed that the only bacon on the salad was a partially browned piece laid across the top of the salad.  Besides that, the dressing had so much vinegar that it stole the focus from the rest of the salad.    The sweetbreads were fried and served with morel mushrooms.  Oddly the mushrooms had no flavor whatsoever.  Even with dried mushrooms this is surprising!   It also appeared that the sweetbreads were flowered and fried at too high a temperature.  The browning appeared dark but was only at the minimal surface level.  Thus the flavor you'd expect with sauted sweetbreads was simply not there.     For main courses we had the pork chop and the maple braised short ribs with onion rings.    The pork chop itself was well prepared - tender and not over or undercooked.  There was not much apple cider sauce to be seen.  The opening taste from the mashed potatoes was reminiscent of pumpkin pie spices but the finish was actually bitter.  Were the spices used improperly cooked or old?  Either way, when the pork chop is placed on top of the potatoes the problem with them brings down the entire dish.    The short ribs were tender and sweet but maple flavors were not apparent.  The mashed potatoes were made with chives and had EXCELLENT flavor.  The included onion rings seemed to have a seasoned salt mix put on them after they were cooked.  The onion rings were too salty and the spices were dry and unrefined in flavor.  For this style cooking, onion rings could really go well with this dish but the ones served took away from the meal rather than adding to it.    Service:  Friendly.  Staff pushed a prix fix which was less interesting then the main menu.  Dinning Room:  Looks a bit like a mid-level hotel or airport restaurant.  Many tables are very closely packed together.    Summary:  With an amazing menu that has a lot of good concepts on it we were disappointed that everything we ordered missed the mark.  I hope the kitchen improves upon its execution, but at this price point (about $60-80 per person (tip, drinks, desert)), I probably won't return to see if they do.

uqC3ll6vCfqFalbWnPi-Qg.review_text: The happy hour menu is fantastic. The food is prepared with a great deal of care and quality. But the best part, hands-down, is the bartender. Zack is amazing. His cocktails and signature drinks are incredible, His service and attention to the crowd, his attention to detail, I am totally impressed. Bomb. Go to the bar!

xaQ5Ge2zaYxBPZjn6IoesA.review_text: I cannot stop bragging about this place.  The service is phenomenal!  My boyfriend took me here before we went next door to Yoshi's for a concert.  (FYI if you are going to go to Yoshi's for a concert, come here for dinner)  We were a little early, but we were seated promptly.  We had water immediately and ordered a bottle of wine.  The server informed us that he was waiting for a new batch of cornbread which was delicious.  I ordered the cauliflower soup and the scallops with a side of mac and cheese.  The portions were perfect and it was all so tasty!!!  We had bananas foster for desert.  I had been craving for something different and this definitely hit that different spot in a really good way.  Everything was great!  The food was delicious, service was top notch and the ambiance was nice and a little romantic.  I would definitely recommend this place.

OVnID3-sGwB5ZkcI0hQB1w.review_text: Nice ambiance, good place to lounge with drinks.  Had the famous fried chicken - it's like fancy shake and bake.  Chocolate beignets were ok, not thrilling.  Parking can be a pain, we got lucky and parked on the street right near the restaurant - most people had to park several blocks away or pay for parking.    worth checking out if you like fancy southern food with a little french flair.  Worth visiting for the ambiance and fun group night out.  Cost about $72 a person at a party of 12 people for about 6 appetizers, 4 bottles of wine, dinner entrees, and 3 desserts shared among the party.

50ZU5Yaj7SqSVE4VCdXgTw.review_text: Upscale. Fancy. Nice for a date.

np7EYYukClLVE1O_P-7_cw.review_text: Western Addition Renaissance?  Maybe.  The restaurant interior certainly did not match the surrounding area, which is especially apparent if seated by the window (like we were).  It felt funny eating on the posh bench seating while watching passerby dodge the broken glass on the sidewalk from a recent break-in.  Neighborhood aside, the food was outstanding.  Between the three of us, we ordered shrimp hush puppies, poached egg salad, skillet fried chicken, grilled pork chop, roasted black bass (without the shrimp nage), mac n'cheese, spiced fat fries, and the beignets.  Yeah, we pigged out!!!  The standout here was the fried chicken, which was moist and flavorful.  I highly recommend it!  I would definitely return specifically for the chicken.  The complimentary cornbread with jalapeno jelly was awesome as well!!!

P5bUL3Engv-2z6kKohB6qQ.review_text: The Fillmore Heritage Plaza area is off to a great start. A friend and I decided we were in the mood to get some comfort/soul food and having read about this via an article on the development of the area, we headed on down. Now mind you the reigning king of soul food is literally diagonally across the street in Powell's Place. I wouldn't consider this direct competition though because where Powell's offers a familiar, casual eating experience, 1300 evokes a very elegant, upscale, vintage jazz vibe.  Set on the corner of Fillmore and Eddy, there's a grand wooden door that swings out to expose a fairly spacious room. There's a sleek bar/lounge to the left and the main dining room opens up all the way to the back where the kitchen is. There's a glass Enclosed banquet room towards of the back of the dining room also, with curtains drawn to provide privacy. I must say that I've never seen the use of so many shades of brown! Normallly people think brown as an icky color but the  darkwood tones looked very classic throughout. The leather bank booths, curtains, inverse lamp shades, and even the staff were decked out in the various degrees of it. Lithograph style plates, etched glass and a very large painting add some modernity to the art lining the walls.  As we looked through the menu we decided on two starters and two entrees, sharing the following:  - Hush puppied fresh water shrimp - Braised pork belly on whipped potatoes - Short ribs  - Skillet fried chicken and mini biscuits - Side of Mac and Cheese  The food started out with a basket of corn bread triangles accompanies with honey butter and red pepper jelly. Good tasty morsels but not too much to prevent you from filling up. I love hush puppies but let's break down, it's deep fried breaded bread. Like onion rngs, they often are very tasty for the first few bites, then they hit you like a grease bomb. Not these hush puppies. Perfectly fried with the shrimp perfectly cooked with a nice crunchy texture, complementing the the crisp batter. The pork belly was fall apart tender and was my friends favorite of the night. The short ribs were presented in this great cylindrical, upside down lollipop fashion with the rib protruding to give the dish some height. It was also very tender with a subtle hint of maple syrup in the glaze. The fried chicken was the heavy hitter for the night, nreast, thigh and drumstick crisp on the outside and juicy in, just as you'd expect while managing not to be greasy. The mini biscuits like the cornbread that started, were little pieces of savory starches that were great with the butter and jelly. Finally, the mac and cheese was al dente to the bite, tangy and rich from the cheese sauce and had a good kick pf heat from probably the same pepper they use in the jam. Excellent satisfying meal. My friend almost didn't want to go out to dinner and after we ate he definitely reversed is thoughts on that.  The service was also excellent as you'd expect from a place making it's grand opening. We were pressed for time and told our server Jessie up front and she did everything she could to get us our food in a timely manner and moving onward to our next destination. The chef even came out as we were finishing our meal to make sure that we were enjoying ourselves. I've definitely got a new go to place before any Fillmore show and that's going to be doubly true for Yoshi's opening up next door. They've also said that they will be working with Yoshi's to get jazz acts locally so you're going to get 2x the jazz on this block.

8VRz4avxKAT-rRKDPIoeZw.review_text: Southern food for the elite I say... but if great food, great location, and great service is what you love when you go out...this is a place you should consider. it's also a great date spot. i would return to 1300 on Fillmore. and boys if you take a girl here, know that it will be pricey, but she will be impressed... unless of course you end up talking about yourself all night and burp aloud during dinner.

HBwUQFtmgZ2w_vnBMSp-Kw.review_text: great food! loved the ambiance and flavors. Look over the menu and pics to see what you would like the best.

av7GpGxHPC9-faoz_V8vPg.review_text: Fantastic gospel brunch. Good food, service and fantastic food. Perfect place to go for soul food and music. Excellent place to bring out of town guests. We even brought our kids and they were angels. They loved the music.

w1hbc2RJychGWMWg493DXw.review_text: the pork chop was amazing. i closed my eyes with every bite. it was juicy and tender and quite honestly, probably the best pork chop i've ever had. maybe the second best (would have to follow mesa grill in vegas). my friend got the bouillabaisse, which i got to try and was very good. not as good as the pork chop though. ;)  for appetizers, i got the hush puppies, which were yummy. nothing spectacular, but a good way to kick things off. my friend got the frisee salad, which looked and tasted how it sounds. the corn bread was good, but i didn't find it out-of-this-world as some other reviews are making it out to be.  the ambiance was awesome. just how everyone else is describing it. like out of the jazz era. can't wait to check out yoshi's.  and finally, the service. the service was really good, just the right amount of attentiveness and helpful explanation of and recommendations from the menu. i left my credit card there that night, and when i went back to get it a couple days later, the host (or manager maybe?) was very good-natured and gracious about it. as i walked out the door, he said, "see you soon!" which i thought was nice. and i probably will be back soon.

CP7ECIG5MXbZ18LKN2mzrA.review_text: Am I the only one that didn't like the food?    It was girl's night out and decided to try 1300 because it was new and had great reviews.  We easily got a reservation for a table for six on a Friday night.  I was a little surprised.  When the hostess called reconfirm our reservation, it had been pushed back half hour.  No big deal, just meant more time for happy hour.   The ambiance and music was great and we were very excited.  Our server was Jesse and she was a sweetheart.  We ordered a round of drinks and appetizers to start off the night and we were greeted with a round of water and a warm basket of corn bread with honey butter.  The corn bread was great.    Jesse came back about fifteen minutes later to take our order for dinner.  We asked about our drinks and she said they were on their way.  Compliments of the chef, we had a tasting of soup and something else and it was quite tasty and we were looking forward to the meal.   The Torchon Froie Gras came out and it was kind of disappointing.  We made the mistake of ordering two and barely touched the second dish.  We finally got our drinks and they were pretty good and strong.    Two of the girl's order the salmon special, a short rib, bouillabaisse and the fried chicken.  The chicken when it came out was cold and Jesse quickly brought out a second dish.  The plate was hot but the chicken was still just kind of warm but it was warmer.    The best dish was the short ribs (which was really good) and the worst was the salmon.  I think most of us had some sort of mashed potatoes as a side and honestly was disappointed that at that price range it was boxed potatoes.  I've been in the restaurant industry most my life and this was Sysco add hot water and butter potatoes.  Not impressed by the food but I'm sure we'll be there for drinks.  If you want soul food for your money, go to Farmer Brown's.  Yes, it's in the TL and it may not be as swanky but come on, it's GOOD FOOD!  Oh yeah... They brought us out Huckleberry sorbet but I couldn't finish it and if you know me... I don't refuse dessert esp anything frozen.

zujkN7vbDKiTEzCxfwocNA.review_text: This was pretty good if you want to have some soul-food, but don't want to eat it off of styrofoam plates or feel like you need a shower afterward.   To begin with, you HAVE to start with the hush puppies. This is not up for discussion. When they arrive, don't cry out because they are not round- a la long john silvers.  Have faith-they are the best puppies of hush I have ever eaten with some yummy dipping sauce.  Soon, prepare yourself, as the waiter will bring you a plate of warm, napping triangles of cornbread nestled in a warm napkin.  It's okay, go ahead and wake one and bite it's head off. Be ruthless- we don't want an overpopulation of cornbreads running around.  The jalapeno jam is good with those.  For an entree, the ribs were divine and *smoky*, but the coleslaw was under-marinated.  I, personally had the fried chicken with delicate buttermilk mashed potatoes. You don't even have to mess with bones for the chicken- they remove those for you, so if you're going here for a first date, don't despair.  It was served with a cheddar biscuit, which I  thought was good, but a little overkill on the carbs.  Some vegetation could have been a good complement to the chicken and potatoes. Banana cream pie was for dessert.  Pretty good, not too sweet, but the crust was a little unflavored. Overall, a nice ambiance, some interesting cocktails and great service..

iC63wYPcVPK-lRsZa1xIuw.review_text: 3.5 Stars - We came with a large group to dine here on Saturday night.  This place is The W meets Fried Chicken. A very modern establishment - your typical southern food gets upgraded to silverware and fancy plates. I was really happy with all of our apps - shrimp hushpuppies (not your typical hushpuppies fr/ the South but still tasty), pear salad with arugula (nothing special, but still tasty), barbecue shrimp & grits (prob 2nd favorite), and delicious wild mushrooms over a mascarpone grits (yes!!!!!!! get this if you like mushrooms). Please just don't tell me how much butter I ate on Saturday night and I will be fine. The most disappointing thing I had to eat was definitely our Surf & Turf - there was just too much sweetness in the dish... the pulled beef was overwhelming sugary and the sweet potato didn't counter balance it. I think it would have worked better with either a less sweet beef or not sweet potatos (keep the bacon in!). Overall, the dish really fell flat, and I would not recommend it. The foie gras was so small that it might as well have not been on the dish. Very overpriced. Not a bad place to try  before a night at Yoshi's.  So overall a great place, but recognize you are paying for ambiance.

jJE6LkMvO0M_F0QdWFxtvg.review_text: Enjoyed a delicious dinner with friends. Staff was very welcoming and let us relax a bit in the (very inviting) lounge area. Ordered some whisky drinks (100 Rye something or other and a Vieux Carre - both on the rocks) and then "lounged". We were seated at an inviting banquet corner table (gents sat on chairs across from the ladies) covered in tufted leather. Very inviting! Service was friendly and attentive. All the dishes we ordered were excellent and we especially liked the shrimp dishes - stuffed fried shrimps and shrimp 'n grits. Not sure how we had room for the chocolate beignets for dessert but glad we pulled the trigger. So yummy.

lcBxErp_W1aNAPD_2RikcA.review_text: GOSPEL BRUNCH. So fun! The food is pretty good too - the GRITS are amazing! I will definitely be back for gospel brunch!!

Au-eSwYogwoBFB9115S94A.review_text: Went here for Valentine's Day with my boyfriend and it was our first time going.  The ambiance is very classy and romantic.  I love the decor.  The service was great, the food was delicious.  They had a fixed menu for Valentine's Day, which we picked the four course menu.  Everything was perfect.  We would definitely come back here again on a special occasion.  Our waiter did mention they have a good happy hour Monday - Friday and I think we'll look into that one of these days...

O31lT-kZzs-KW_p9u4-SKw.review_text: My good friend took me to 1300 Fillmore for a surprise~ We arrived a little early and had a cocktail in the cozy lounge area. We had a very friendly and attentive server.   We shared shrimp and grits; fried chicken (off the hook), mac and cheese and the banana creme pie for dessert. All were very good. I love Mac and Cheese and still have not found any better than T-Rex (Berkeley) or the Paragon.   A great place for a nice evening out. The owners are both very nice and friendly.

y3FcL4bLy0eLlkb0SDPnBQ.review_text: Where to eat when you're in San Francisco?  There's more than enough restaurants out here and this is how we came to deciding on 1300 on Fillmore.... -1300 On Fillmore was on a recent ROTD by Yelper Cathy Y. on 10/1/2013.  Her fiance had ribs and mac n cheese.  I'm sold, when do we eat? -My cousin, who lives out here, recommended this place -It's less than a mile from our hotel room. Everything was set.  Terri R bookmarked it, made the reservations, and even treated me to this very nice dinner.  Yes, I'm one spoiled dude and I would be the first to admit it.  We arrived about 5 minutes before our reservation and was seated right away.   Here are my thoughts; Ambiance (4 Stars):  The ambiance was pretty chill and wasn't busy for a Friday night.  I loved the decor, including the high ceilings.  NOTE:  Check out the bar with their upside-down lamp shades.   Food:   -Corn Bread:  This was served first.  I didn't realize how much I love me some corn bread.  Our table received 3 triangle shaped slices.  We each had a piece and shared the last.  Their corn bread is served with a churned style honey butter.  The corn bread definitely started the dinner right. (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) -Roasted Sierra Beauty Apple Butternut Squash Bisque:  The name is longer than my review!!  This is the soup that I got. Looks like baby food, tasted like what it sounds...squash.  (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) -Mac N Cheese:  I knew that Terri R would get the mac.  So, I didn't order any and got a few samples from her.  My goodness, it's been awhile since I had mac n cheese.  It's not the best I've had, but it's still good enough to order again if I come back. -Ribeye Burger:  I know, I know, I go to a nice restaurant and I get a burger.  What's wrong with me?  I was in the mood for a steak and in the mood for a burger.  A ribeye burger just made sense and I have no regrets.  The steak was cooked to my liking and was served with their house made BBQ potato chips.  The burger was a little dry, but I had it medium-well which explains it.  Regardless, I liked it. (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) -Pan Roasted Brussels Sprouts:  Caramelized in onions.  Probably the only way I can eat Brussels sprouts. (yelp.com/user_local_phot…) Price/Service: Price for your meal is about right for the location of this restaurant, the ambiance, and type of food here.  Just as an example, my Ribeye Burger cost $15, which I thought was standard.  Service was A+.  Our server was great. Our drinks were kept full and our table kept clean. Overall, I'm a fan of this restaurant and can see myself coming back.   YELP PERSONAL CHALLENGE 2013 - (449/500)

NecVrTISvglHsHO8qrvIKw.review_text: I'm sure it's good food, but service has been horrendous. Our party of 9 made reservations weeks ago for Christmas Eve at 7:30pm. We arrived at 7pm, checked-in and was assured we'd have a table BY 7:30pm. Instead, my family is here waiting for our table after seeing numerous 8+ parties take open tables. 75 minutes after we came in and 45 minutes past our reservation time and after following up we're greeted with a rude "I'll let you know when it's ready"?   Considering it's the holiday season, I'm rating this restaurant a really low one-star based on its rude and non-courteous service. Don't make a reservation here. The staff clearly doesn't know what it means.  Oh, by the way, we're still here, all 9 of us by the bar hungry beyond our minds. God help us.

T29FFOLJWvhif5_vseO4qQ.review_text: I've been here a few times before and the quality of the food and service was always something to keep me wanting to comeback.  Sadly, last night's experience was far from what I'd expect from a fine dining establishment.  The meal started off good.  The poached egg salad was perfectly cooked and everything I'd come to expect from 1300.   It's when we got to the entrees that it went downhill.  The short rib was not the usual bone in cut. Actually, there was no bone to be found which means all that good flavor you get from cooking it with the bone and marrow was absent. The result was a "short rib" that was dry as a bone.  The pork chop came out harder than concrete and we couldn't even saw through it to cut off a piece much less chew it.  This is the first time in years where we've had no choice but to send something back.  But for an entree that cost $27 we wanted to be able to eat it. While one of us was finishing off the Sahara short rib the other waited for a new pork chop.  No consideration was taken by the wait staff or management to make things right or compensate us for our inconvenience.    I guess the icing on the cake was the lukewarm Mac n' cheese.  Not very appetizing when served at room temperature.   I understand restaurants sometimes have an off night.  Maybe thats what last night was.  But with so many great restaurants in the city I'd think that obvious mistakes would be fixed by such an upscale restaurant.  Sadly, fine dining was not how I would sum up last nights 1300 experience.

sDS2DFgAapj7gJ83P425Fg.review_text: -surprised I did not review this place sooner.  -as 2 biz-E eating the leftovers  .   .   .  oso ono -licious.  This is soul food at its height.  The word is not 'cool', it's SWANK.  Where else does one dress up for fried chicken?  Twilight zone of Southern cooking.  You do step into another dimension.  [o, god, Ine beginning to sound like that other writer  .   .   .]  U will know once you step thru the large hardwood door.  N JOY,  C

YYitgZDceckpa-xCwIzj6A.review_text: I went with a group of friends (8 or 9 of us) and start with champagne and a few appetizers. ALL were amazing.   I ordered the bouillabaisse, which I really enjoyed, but there was so much good food on the table that I wished I had ordered something else. Food envy, big time!  The atmosphere and music was great. I ran into Willie Brown in the men's room. We had a quick laugh -- he spilled red wine, but saved his pricey suit.  Overall a great place. Pricier than I would have hoped, but oh well.  (Not sure what happened Suz L., but you might want to try it again.)

WWP06D5BncW30kSOkOC6WA.review_text: This was a DAT attempt that miserably failed. It's not offered on Saturdays and I was made aware of the fact the morning of by a friend. It was late to look for another dinner place for a Saturday night with 9 people so I stuck with it. The good yelp reviews gave me confidence.   We thought we had gotten there early but the parking garage nearby was full and street parking was scarce. We ended up being just on time for our 7:30pm reservation. I always pass by this area of Fillmore but it's a little shady at night. Things do change when it's dark out! Make sure to walk with someone!  I appreciated this place right off the bat. We were given a round table for our party. Yay! Usually when you have a larger party, you're given a long table. I understand it's a space saver in the restaurant but it's hard to interact and have good conversation when you are limited to just the few people sitting around you. We had a great time. I also loved the ambiance here. This place is just snazzy! And I don't use that word often. But you can already tell it will be a great environment after you visit their website. They both have a similiar feel.  After we sat down for sometime, the complimentary cornbread came and it was hot and flaky. It was great with the sweet butter and sweet jalapeno jelly. I don't even like jalapenos! But this was not bad. My bf and I shared the shrimp hushpuppies with ancho chile remoulade. It was a bit of a surprise when we were given six shrimp fried in hushpuppy breading. Nevertheless it was flavorful and tasty.   My friend got a Pear Flower cocktail and I had a sip. I'd say if you don't want a strong tasting drink, this is the one to go with. It smelled and tasted great! For my entree I got the Surf N' Turf of Oven-Roast Divers Scallop-Foie, Beef Short Rib with Mashed Potatoes. I think the scallops could have been more tender but I loved the foie gras on top. The beef short rib was a little too shredded for my taste. I just prefer a more solid piece of meat as my "turf". Still it was enjoyable.   My bf got the Black Skillet Fried Chicken and we both expected that delicious crispy chicken skin. Unfortunutely the skin was soft and a little lacking in the flavors we love about fried chicken. We probably won't skip it next time around. For dessert, we shared the Apple Bread Pudding. Again, it was good but nothing too memorable. I do wish there was a little more ice cream to go with the dessert. For $9, I think I'd rather go to 2223 for their bread pudding which I think is the best in the city.  The DAT menu didn't work out but our date night was a lot of fun. I think even without DAT I got a good sense of the food here. 1300 on Fillmore, thanks for providing a lovely time! I say 3.5 stars.

8Lc3-TTHjExd79GSQIHnAw.review_text: shrimp and grits is amazing! fried chicken is great, but expensive hush puppies are good pork belly is awesome  i love their sunday gospel brunch!!!

58w9pfG8lPi0oHUJctGLow.review_text: Wow, spent $126 on dinner for two! Was expecting the extraordinary, but unfortunately could have done this myself!!! Ambience and atmosphere was great, but flavorful meal was lacking..... Top of my list for soul satisfying since my arrival in SF is Brenda's on Polk St.

dYoxLV8QlHuKw-MHazArrA.review_text: I have been to 1300 numerous times for drinks and appetizers before/after shows at Yoshi's. I had lived near Fillmore Street for many years until recently and like to patronize these businesses.  I, however, had an awful experience there this past NYE and will not be returning. We spent a great deal of money eating and drinking and ordered a expensive bottles of champagne. A group of inebriated people no more than 23 were allowed to continue to drink, act rudely, fall into people who are dressed for NYE and not deal with it. There is a great deal more to this story and it doesn't end well, but I will leave it at that.  The management is not very good and seemed to be more akin to management at a pub vs a nice restaurant.  I know what 1300 would like to be, based on the owners, but they're not there yet. They need to stop hiring their friends and hire some professional hospitality industry types who know how to provide service.  Two notable things - the bar tenders who were not particularly friendly that night continued to server this drunk 23 year olds and made it worse. Second, the manager was so incredibly disrespectful. I would have expected him to ask questions. I will never forget the rude treatment from the manager. The only positive experience we had that night is that the women at the hostess stand were very sweet and polite. My friends who were dealing with the bartenders all night said they were also very rude and we wondered why someone who doesn't seem to like people would want to bartend??

WdozhJg1HGsOajMnAP8vKQ.review_text: What I want to know is how the HECK this place has 4 stars. I came here with a group of friends because of "Dine about town" The food is decent but it is totally overpriced for what it is.   Also, such a nice lounge/bar area -- yet the bartender can't even make a decent drink! All our drinks --- and we ordered different ones --- were "Sour Head" Candy tart (wtf?!). When the 4 of us called our server over, she said "too tart?" clearly this was not the first time. We wanted to send our drinks back, and our server suggested fixing the drink by putting simple syrup in there --- Uhhh NO! Why would I want something super tart with a ton of extra calories from simple syrup. We went with a bottle of wine, it was safer.   We did family style so these are the dishes I tried:  cornbread = warm and yummy with the butter shrimp & grits = OK hushpuppies = Delicious half rack of ribs (dinner special) = dry, overcooked, no flavor, too much sauce oyster chowder soup = good crab salad = STINGY piece of crab for the price fried chicken = good but too much breast meat, nothing special dessert - choc chip cookies + vanilla ice cream = for $7 give me more than a measly scoop of ice cream to go with 2 cookies.  The only reason I'm giving this 3 stars instead of 2 is because the wait staff was really nice and fun -- and the food is decent, even tho it's completely overpriced.

ZIGMkfd9J0-JmOrem4_jSQ.review_text: Absolutely love this place, atmosphere warm and cozy, amazing service, food is amazing!!!  It's one of my favorite SF restaurants!!!  Have had several delightful meals here and plan on going back again soon!

6jR5cK5retT748-qPMJBfg.review_text: Amazing!  I am seriously so happy to have celebrated a big birthday at this beautiful swanky spot.  We were there on a Friday night and were enjoying some of the libations and food at the lounge area with a great server--she was super sweet.  I actually enjoyed the lounge area so much that we didnt even want to be seated at the dining area.    We ordered the following: Shrimp and Grits: amazing, creamy, not fishy tasting at all with a kick of cajun Fried chicken: I mean what else can you say but YUM??  Moist goodness! Cornbread: Buttery and light  The entertainment was amazing--the singers were awesome and it really made my night to be hanging out with family at such a fun and enjoyable place.   1300 i will come back!!!

WeimhnpKXhHMWVAQJAQEHQ.review_text: A TRUE 5 star experience!  The atmosphere of the restaurant is very classy; walls covered in backlit pictures of jazz musicians and an overall "Gentlemanly" vibe.  We ordered drinks which were very good, and not skimpy on alcohol either. We were served Cornbread with a sweet honey butter and a delicious jalapeno jelly.    The Fried Green Tomatoes were delectable and went very well with the fried Chevre goat cheese.  The House specialty was the (boneless) Fried Chicken, spiced very well and very filling.  I ordered the Special of the night: the Half Rack of Pork Ribs.  The meat was so tender, it fell right off the bone.  Served with a side of Mac and Cheese, which was somehow filling but also very light.  For dessert, the Peach Cobbler was scrumptious and not overly sweet, but you can't go wrong with the Chocolate Beignets.  A++!  Service was phenomenal; our waiter George was incredibly friendly and made sure we were well taken care of by the rest of the staff.  You need to be there now!

MOrwpEWfgplLVYF3zXCCEg.review_text: Food was average at best. The service was rushed and the waiters were very inattentive.   When I requested to see the wine labels they were serving, the waiter promised to return but never did... He was much faster giving us the bill!  They even had the nerve to tack on a 20% "special" gratuity!  I realize this was Thanksgiving, but we were a party of two. The service did not match the 20% fee!  In my opinion our meal experience was not worth the money. We will not return to this restaurant.

wL-pr_3Cn6U9baJ3df9VXw.review_text: I have had better.  We went to brunch and that's what we got - eggs at 1 pm.  The menu was really simple and kinda limited, I think I would have liked more choices, I guess you pay $14 for scrambled eggs and sausage because its called brunch.  Last year during our christmas food fest, we went to Lime - and left hungry. So we wanted to try another cool place. This place is cool, and the room is beautiful. But, again, the food was just meh. The service was great tho - there enough yet not in our face all the time.  I think I would like to try it for dinner sometime, I love grits. Good ones. and these were good grits. Nola in Palo Alto has the best I have had. In California. But that was too far away.  It was hard enough to get a cab back to downtown - or anywhere I would guess - we had to call yellow as there were no cabs to be seen.  I don't think I would do brunch here again, I am happier at squat and gobble.

14PEqpq2EPTWMWu0Xli6dA.review_text: The food here is good, but a little over priced for southern food.   Their grits and macaroni and cheese are reallly good. I love southern food so its kind of hard for me to not like anything on their menu.   Its sort of a romantic atmosphere. Very dimly lit and quiet, jazz music playing in the background. There was nothing that was really memorable about this place, nothing spectacular, but it wasnt bad at all. Worth a try.

W0zMF6L5e1WYD8u4ZlU7sg.review_text: My husband and I went here for dinner last night.  We really liked the ambiance, the drinks, and the service was great.  The food was good but not great.  We started with the shrimp and grits (very good), the shrimp hush puppies (eh), and a salad.  Everything could've used some salt.  No salt on the table.  The corn bread was FANTASTIC.  For entrees, I had the fried chicken and he had the catfish.  I agree with the reviews of the chicken that said it has a weird spice.  Yuck. I think it was - of all things - cumin!  Very weird.  I didn't like it at all and only ate the mashed potatoes - which were good.  My husband loved the catfish.  We shared the beignets for dessert.  I agree that the texture was heavier than it should've been.  But they tasted good.  That foamy espresso thing was SUPER sweet and gross.    All in all, I think we'd go back maybe.  But it wasn't great.

tV5LXTaokZ37eDzawqd-Cw.review_text: Crack cocaine -- that's what this place is.  Crack cocaine!  I went last night for a dear and deadly sexy friend's birthday.  We kicked off the evening drinking martinis in the lounge area.  The drinks were lip-smacking, cheek-puckery goodness.    Sufficiently libated, we relocated to the dining room for the second act.  We tried just about every ap on the menu, but my personal favourite was the terrine of foie gras.  I've never tried sweet breads before, but they were excellent (though it's possible that you could deep fry my shoe and I'd tell you it was a slice of heaven).  Also...who doesn't like corn bread?  I don't think I even want to know someone who doesn't partake in the CB.  Hellurrrr??  Fried chicken:  If you read anything in this silly review, read FRIED CHICKEN.  I'm fairly certain I'm due for a quadruple bypass, but it was sewwww worth every succulent bite.  It was moist and seasoned like the pacific northwest -- it reigned!  And boneless!  It's pure genius.  The chicken was atop a bed of garlicy mashed potatoes and hugged by two fresh biscuits.   It's evident that the chef not only has a flare and passion for soul food with a twist, but I'm convinced that what takes the menu over the top, is that there is real love in every dish...mad love.  Lastly...short, shameful confession..  I had to undo the buttons on my jeans on my way home, but it was worth negating every sit-up I've done in the last week.  Do your soul a flavour and make reservations.  You won't be disappointed.    No shinanigans: this place is for serious junkies only.

ra3OzaxpILytSjHRRKoT8g.review_text: Had a quick visit to 1300 for an appetizer and some bubbly in the lounge.  The food was great (perfectly cooked grits), and while I didn't taste enough to be able to pass fair judgment on the whole menu, there was a lot that was appealing on the menu, sort of your classic French/American with twists of the south throughout.   The space itself was attractive: mood (or is that moody) lighting with candles, plush couches and chairs (in the lounge), black-and-white pictures of jazz greats on the walls, and music (that we just missed -- they were packing up).  The wines by the glass (all that I looked at) were varied and interesting, and reasonably priced considering.  Considering what?  Well, long ago, I reached peace with the $10 glass of wine, but what kills me is when you can't get something at least hovering around that (and hovering means higher these days, even for me).   And there were wines here that were priced reasonably enough that I didn't faint from shock.  (Contrast Spruce.)  It was serendipitous that I came here because I hadn't written it on my to-visit list, mostly because I avoid the up-priced restaurants these days in favor of the Slow Clubs, Lolos, and Mavericks of the world.  Yet this was lovely.  Next time a fancy meal's in order (as in, on an expense account), I'll be back.  Or perhaps I'll come back next Friday before I see Charlie Hunter!   As I said, I don't have quite enough data, but I sense that there could be love in this food.

UNnK9nk6kydpXa6ZRFiTRg.review_text: A night out!  Live Jazz band at the lounge/bar area!   Blacked Skillet Catfish - Not so sure about this one. Yes, the seasoning was good, but I felt like the fish was a bit over cooked.  It was served over Gumbo, but I wasn't in love. Pork Chop - This was good. I might have it again. BBQ Shrimp & Grits - Now, this appetizer dish is a must try!   Fries - Nothing crazy. Brussels Sprouts - I actually like veggies, so I really liked the way this was sauteed.  I had a few drinks over dinner and had a glass of wine at the bar while listening to beautiful jazz music, which made my night!

0CaycNoMFFXZSnSr1p3rRg.review_text: I had the fried chicken. It is better at Jollibee and 1/3rd of the price.

mrHhLlan657ynlkKhYNm-Q.review_text: I tried 1300 last night (Tuesday) with a group of six and have to say the good reviews for the food are absolutely true. I'm a bit of a southern girl, and thought the contemporary spin on southern cooking creative and unique....and yes, delicious!   Everyone loved the salads, but I did like my friends warm cabbage salad with poached egg salad over my more traditional choice. They were out of the blackened catfish :( , but the recommended choice they are know for was fried chicken; boneless and crispy. Fabulous! We liked all the choices the group made, so seemed like you couldn't go wrong on the menu.   On the down side, we had reservations and arrived right on time yet had to wait quite a while for them to set up a table. I think they knew we were coming.   The service was very good except for the initial drinks. Waters for everyone, but I nearly had to beg for a martini; not pretty.  We finally got a round of drinks. But the service for the rest of the evening redeemed the initial miss.   The decor, atmosphere and food make this a must return place for me. Good Show!

23heW7lH8orHriDUnmLxSw.review_text: Wow.  This place is incredible.  My boyfriend and I swung by here last Friday night on a complete whim; no reservations but excellent "feed us" puppy dog eyes, prepped.  We waited it out in the bar, enjoying our well made cocktails and took turns stalking the full tables in the lounge area, filled with plush couches, armchairs and tables for 2-6.  The hostess graciously showed us some mercy after about an hour and ta-dah, the true show began.    Cornbread with jalapeno jelly served as the bread basket, followed by our appetizer of shrimp with creamy grits - like butter.  My boyfriend feasted on the maple syrup slow braised short ribs, a melting, mouthwatering pile of meat on bones; my bouillabaisse was chock-full of the sea, containing a lobster tail and absolutely fresh fish, mussels and scallops in a saffron-tastic sauce.  Still, I was jealous for the meat.  Jealousy switched sides of the table, however, at my first bite of beignets, dipped in warm chocolatey goodness and washed down with a frothy, coffee soda - holy explicatives, it was amazing.   The wine list could use some beefing up, as there are many varietals represented but not much selection for each at the moment, but they did represent for the Santa Lucia Highlands pinot noir, our favorite spot for the grape - just bring in vintages earlier than '06, please!    And the service?  High fives, bravo!'s and praise all around - keep up the great work - I'll be around to check on you guys again, soon!

o84PuZsGPbQeJsax5j5oyg.review_text: Ambiance spectacular what a gem on Fillmore!  Was there for a birthday celebration servers & waitstaff all attentive.  I will return to try other items.  The chicken I wasn't impressed by although you get plenty it just wasn't to my fried chicken standards.  Some pieces were dark meat & it appeared to be rolled together instead of a whole boneless chicken breast....we couldn't make out what piece some of our chicken was.  Loved the fries & cornbread.  I will be back soon!

JvNMi2Oh6o6SfcIsq73KNA.review_text: Overall: A  Mimosas, grits and gospel music is probably the best way to start a day! The gospel brunch was one of best dining experiences I've ever had in San Francisco.   Food: A  The gospel brunch offers a three course prix fixe. Shrimp and grits, eggs Benedict w/ham and Tabasco. All very excellent choices and of course they serve great cobbler!   Service: A  Monetta, the owner, is a sweetheart and her attitude permeates to the rest of the staff.   Decor: A  Chic and beautiful. If you want a spot to hold a conversation ask for a table in the back. The music can get kinda loud but that's fine by me.   Value: A  Where else can you get a three course brunch with entertainment for under $40???

920SZSvECa2tmGW8W5byyg.review_text: Dude yelpers, you have all deceived me! This one star is only for the service. Our server/waitress was very patient and calm with our rowdy table of 8 ladies buzzin off cocktails and wine. But the food was a disaster!! all way over priced and not delicious.y'all need to work on your seasoning technique, and portion size. I ordered the crispy skin king salmon dish, and i think it literally had 2 tablespoons of sweet potato risotto. Sorry, you know when food is the bomb when you say "mmmm" and not one person said that at our table. and the white truffle mac and cheese, I've had better mac and cheese from a box , seriously overrated.    the ambience was fabulous, and you kind of feel like your encouraged to use your library voice. i think the only thing i liked was the cornbread and the service. we are most definitely not coming back here, nor am i suggesting this restaurant to anyone.

mEXW3VtHWY9VYBu3VHYyrA.review_text: There are so many restaurants to choose from in SF that when you're in the mood for a splurge it's hard to go back to one you've already enjoyed if, like me, you don't splurge as often as you'd like. Sure you can go back to your favorite burger bar repeatedly but when there are a lot of top end restaurants to try, the risk of going back somewhere that you hold in high regard and finding that it's not as good as you remember or time has embellished your experience, is risky.   I first took The Missus here for her birthday in 2011 and had one of the best meals I've ever eaten in the city. I still dream of the hickory smoked spare ribs that were on special and the cornbread that's lighter on your tongue than Wayne Sleep is lighter on his feet. Looking for a special place to take my folks who were in town from the UK, The Missus and I took the gamble to go back to 1300 Filmore. It offers something you don't get in the UK, Southern style cooking, but it has a lighter, more sophisticated edge.   The ambiance is just as I remembered, if not better. Relaxing, classy but also with a buzz. Jazz legends adorned the walls as we sipped on our cocktails, reclining in leather armchairs but the night was given even more of an oomph when we could hear house music playing subtlety but noticeably in the background. The "European accent" that enhances the food has tripped on into the sound system.   The cornbread remained delicious and I ordered the Maple Syrup Slow Braised Beef Short Ribs. Beef that again dissolved on my tongue. The mash was delicious (though still not as good as the mash served at Maze in London but that was something else entirely). The mac and cheese with truffle was rich and creamy.   For our appetizers we shared the Shrimp Hushpuppies which were, for me, the lowest point of the meal either slightly over done or the oil was a little old but I was in the minority. The rest of the party lapped them up. We were persuaded by the waiter to try the Barbecue Shrimp N Creamy Grits. I really don't like grits but good Lord they were delicious. Light, creamy and not that sloppy grainy texture I'm used to. In true Southern style I couldn't stop myself from mopping the plate with the remnants of the cornbread.   By the time we got to dessert we were all pleasantly full but just for kicks shared the homemade cookies and ice-cream. The texture of the cookies was another melt in the mouth taste sensation though the cinnamon was a little overdone  but, seeing as Americans can't get enough of the spice, I doubt this is a bad thing for most diners.   Dinner was fantastically rounded of with a visit from the chef, a fellow Brit who, like so many I've met, came to SF for a short trip and never went home. I'm so glad he didn't. I'd have no qualms in recommending 1300 Filmore to anyone or indeed to going back again and again.

f0jOh2Sz1J71bEqwgF-S7A.review_text: I prayed for you, 1300 On Fillmore!  I prayed for you.  I knew you'd come.  And here you are.  And we are one, all of us.  And this is how it is in heaven.  Just like this.    And I am SO GLAD we're having a rehearsal on it now ... because I'm totally gonna have that banana cream pie again.  (Apologies and thanks to "Rachel Getting Married")  So!  My husband and I celebrated our anniversary at 1300 On Fillmore last night, and it's my new favorite place.    Our waiter George took incredible care of us all night, suggesting the perfect wines to pair with our dishes.  Start to finish:  such love.  Such care and attention.  And I don't know what they're doing with the mushrooms here, but the texture and taste in the mushroom appetizer somehow extended to a completely different, spotlight entree (the bacon-wrapped filet mignon!  Hello, lover!), like the most beautiful song.    And the dessert?  Whatever you have in your head for "banana cream pie", this is lighter, fresher and more eat-me-now! than that.  I should add that until the end of February, 1300 On Fillmore is featuring a special Black History Month menu:  four courses, all of which are also available a la carte, paired with wines from Black-owned wineries.  Such a lovely idea ... and that Black Coyote Cab (not available, usually, by the glass) has **layers**.  1300 On Fillmore, my answered prayer:  I am so happy we finally met!

cie1b9elyL3Xd-aXLvi6DA.review_text: I really wanted to love this place but eventually walked out just liking it enough to consider going back again. Off the bat, they have a cool main entry door. The interior is decent with a cool vibe about it. Dimly lit, a lounge just off to the left with a live jazz bland playing and the main dining room to the right, this place has all the makings of a great evening out - whether it be fancy or chill.   The food however, lacked the same sort of coolness evoked by the space. Mildly inflated prices aside, I was a little confused by the menu's direction. Self-described as a culinary fusion between jamaican/british/french backgrounds, most of the dishes seemed like embellished "soul food" dishes that sort of missed the mark on the soul or the embellishment. Our table sampled the mac-n-cheese, the shrimp-n-grits, corn bread and I had the catfish.  Ok, ok fine. The catfish was dope. Served over a bed of dirty rice(?), I had the hit dish of the table. The corn bread was also delicious and could have been better if served hot. The shrimp-grits were OK. The mac-n-cheese was terrible but was a highly contested split decision for the table. While some liked it,  I found it bland and watered down; the noodles were mush. That said, I managed to also sample the fried chicken which I swear tasted like an Indian dish.   The service was good. I want to try their short ribs because apparently that is THE must try dish. I think this place has a great idea that fits well for the area (believe me, it's much needed and welcome) but I'm not sold on the food just yet. That said, I'm all for grabbing a drink at this place.

EZiazgC_1y10CW82gae8xA.review_text: Last night we attended a small wedding dinner in the private dining room. We all Congregated in the bar, most of my girlfriends prefer the jazz berry martini, I had a sip, delish! We then proceeded to the small understated private dining room. There were 16 of us, it was fairly tight. I'm sure it would be almost uncomfortable with 18.   On to the food. The bride and groom had already decided the menu. You could choose  either steak or fried chicken. I choose the steak. We started with the shrimp and grits. The shrimp we nicely seasoned, but the way the flavors of the shrimp played with the grits were a delight to my palette! My steak with Brie and spinach was Devine, I will say some of my party does not like rare to medium rare so they were not as pleased as I. For our desert we had a small tart with Chantelle. That desert was a nice cool refresh to my pallet. I even ate my husbands...it was that good.   I found our waitress kind and attentive. In all a solid choice!

GRAosqZNBo6fb-rdHLIwrA.review_text: i love this place, it has the best happy hour in town and the service is great. the inside is absolutely beautiful!

rvxxmHFLzY911MMubS45jQ.review_text: I can;t give it 4 starts because I'm just not a fan at all. I might go back here drinks again sometime, but not for the food. My boyfriend and I ordered the chicken (when I still ate meat) and everything we got, we kinda sorted hated. The chicken was so fat and touch and just plain weirded me out. (probably one the reasons I went vegetarian) It totally grossed me out. Now, it could've just been my chicken, but my boyfriend didn't care for his either. We also ordered a drink each and total with tip our bill was about $90.  I'm sorry, but I just would much rather go to subway, or the grove. The staff was friendly, though! :)  Not exactly my cup of tea!

hNhOidHrbXbMykPOSGlyRg.review_text: Truly wonderful FOOD here with my boyfriend.   +White Truffle Mac and Cheese. Creamy, delicate, and NOT too much truffle flavor. Melty all in my mouth. +Fat Fries= Just as they sound. Soft, yet crispy. Expertly seasoned. +Brussels Sprouts. Yeah, we are just HUGE fans of sprouts in general and so for this cheat meal, had to have them doused in butter, onions, and bacon.  We both got RibEye burgers for dinner because that's what we wanted to for our cheat meal... hot, juicy burgers :) And that's just what we got. The meat was perfectly cooked to Medium-Rare. Beautiful open-face presentation.  Finished off with a seasonal chocolate mousse. Small but still delicious.  Great atmosphere. Would love to try out the bar/lounge area.  Minus a star because parking is quite difficult to traverse / deal with. No valet...which is fine. But then we waited for about 20 minutes after our reservation time to be sat in a tiny corner table right by the Hostess Stand. Waited about 5-10 minutes for anyone to greet us and provide us with anything more than water. No features. Server just seemed flustered and asked us "are you ready to order?"   Regardless. Really overwhelmed with how delicious the food is here....perfect for boyfriend and I's cheat meal.

zO9Z4y6JbyiMYDplbmUc8Q.review_text: I've heard lots of good things about this place so I was excited to try something new in a cool hood that's trying to reinvent itself. Unfortunately we were not impressed with the food and even less so with the service.   The place looks modern with touches of zen style even though the food is Southern inspired. It's a bit loud and the crowed was mixed from locals to non city dwellers.  We were seated promptly and our waiter came by to tell us specials and then a few minutes later to take our order.    We started with the fried oysters and then ordered the risotto and maple short ribs.  I also asked to taste a wine before ordering it.  The bread arrived, then the oysters, still no wine.  Then finally my husbands wine arrives and my taste, but no waiter.  We had to waive him down so I could order my wine, no apology or even acknowledgment that our food arrived before the drinks.   The oysters were good, not oily at all but the dip with it lacked elegance and texture it should be, it was like mayo and overpowered the oysters.  Then our dishes arrive, the short ribs were good, but a but dry.  They were lean and falling off the bone so nicely done dish overall.  The risotto was a different story, it looked more like fried rice shaped into a tartar presentation than risotto and there was so much stuff in it the taste was lost, the flavor was confusing and it just was not risotto by any standard.  It looked and tasted like a mushy mess.    We wanted to finish the meal with dessert and ordered the peach cobbler.  When it arrived it looked like a store dessert and when we tried it, all it was was sugar, no taste of peaches, which were chopped in huge peaces and swimming in water.  My husband who usually never sends things back, sent this back.   When the bill arrived they took the dessert off the tab but charged us for different wine that was more than our selections, we had to explain it twice for them to fix the tab.  Again our waiter was nowhere to be seen.

cRymbgLkvcH9hWp2qV9UGg.review_text: I'm all about ambiance, food quality and presentation. This place was pretty classy soul restaurant. Loved the decor. We had dinner for a group of 4. We had some drinks at the bar first before being seated. It was pretty crowded that day because of a jazz festival going on outside. I ordered a fish dish that was really good. The cornbread that we were given was scrumptious! I don't think we had room for dessert.. But based off these reviews, next time I must try the beignets!

W9oQ8VWADK801tW29JOuBw.review_text: So, I was all set to give this place 5 stars... but then we ordered the chocolate chip cookies for dessert, and they were burnt! Like, not just overcooked, but actually black on the bottom. So minus one star for that.  However, that was the only remotely negative thing about this place! It has this retro, swanky jazz ambiance, complete with photos from The Fillmore's heyday of jazz, dim lighting and cozy lounge feel. We went on a Sunday night and it was not busy at all. The food is sophisticated soul/comfort food, and it is de-lic-ious! They are known for their fried chicken and their braised short ribs, both of which are to die for! Their cocktails are also pretty amazing.  I would definitely come back here, and I would definitely recommend trying this place out!!

OJWfrIgyfh9tH82FUeMtmQ.review_text: food was quite good but not out of this world. they have a gluten free menu which is nice, and the service was very good, not rushed but prompt and attentive. the main huge drawback is the NOISE! wow. the place is so echo-y our table of four had to lean in intensely over the table to hear a word from each other. it was tinny and overwhelming, enough that i would strongly consider whether coming back.

O71eY1POkZl5QGEVvzv_9Q.review_text: The ambiance of this place is really nice - and the appetizers and entrées were all pretty decent, but nothing really stood out. Soul food, fried chicken, hush puppies. I've heard the Gospel brunch is supposed to be pretty solid.  Too many other good places in SF, so probably won't come back here, though I've heard the Gospel brunch is supposed to be pretty solid.

CvUzA3JMJGYNqf4-aBf00A.review_text: This is the place to go right before a night at Yoshi's! Right next door, plenty of space - kick ass bar to chill if not hungry. Some faves are the cornbread with the  sweet jalapeno jelly - scrumptous! and the sweet potato souffle - like the best lightest pumpkin pie you ever had. fried chicken was excellent though it's boneless - which although convinient - is a bit odd. well priced wine list - had the l'automne pinot - yum yum. great service overall.

cmZsjBEXce-L6arBcn0DMg.review_text: I came here for a birthday brunch last Sunday with about 10 of my girlfriends.   The Decor and Ambience:  It was nice inside with a fairly large lounge area for waiting.  I definitely wasn't expecting it to be as nice as it was inside.  The Neighborhood: Pretty sketch, I would not walk around here at night by myself.  The Food: The food was ok and the menu was very limited.  I don't think it was anything that would bring me back again, at least not for the brunch.  Perhaps I may give them another chance by having dinner there sometime.  The fried chicken sandwich wasn't all that and neither were the scones.  The shrimp and grits were pretty tasty but that's about the only thing I really liked.  The Service: Most of the wait staff was pleasant but I did not find our server friendly or warm at all.  Also, they didn't even bother doing anything for our gf's birthdays even though they knew it was a birthday brunch and when we asked them to do so, they said it would take too long and that it was too late.  I mean how hard is it to scoop some ice cream into a bowl?  That was pretty lame.  I probably won't be back but I guess I had to try it!

SYih80f23neAzlbZcO3QYg.review_text: Great ambiance, great drinks & happy hour in the bar area.  Service in the dinning room was pleasant but seemed a bit on the slow side.  We chose this restaurant because it's practically next door to Yoshi's where we had tickets to see a performance that evening.  2 of the 4 of us ordered the "Fried Chicken".  On the menu it says it'll take 20 minutes to prepare so we asked the waitress if this would be a problem because of our time line, she said no.  But we ran late!  We ended up not finishing our meals, had them boxed to go and picked them up after the performance.  I'd still go back again because it's convenient and the food is good, but leave plenty of time in case things run slow.

jJlYRJXPdIolKbuqGiZ-CQ.review_text: It was serendipity that evening...not only did we find street parking, but we also walked in without a reservation and were seated immediately.  2 great signs that my night was going to be good!  I perused the menu and wasn't able to decide what to have.  So, I knew that I wanted to start the night out with a martini and that would help the process.  The perfect pour martini only seemed to confuse me (go figure) and it was a hard decision, but I settled on the foie gras and fried chicken.  Foie Gras with blackberries was heavenly!  HEAVENLY, I tell you.  The Fried Chicken without bones and super crispy and not greasy- AWESOME. Then I was so full, I had to pass on dessert.    But the menu had me from the beginning...so many things to want to come back for. 1300 has just been added to my list of favs!  See you there!

zHBEiSEk7GWiXrTFtq3LzA.review_text: Been here a couple of times, haven't had anything bad yet. We had the ribs and catfish on the last visit, and both were insanely delicious (and, in the case of the ribs, insanely generous). I was particularly impressed by the catfish; I've never considered myself a catfish fan, but got it based on the waiter's recommendation. Definitely didn't regret it. The only component of our meals that wasn't over the top awesome was the cole slaw. It wasn't bad, just so-so in light of everything else, and a little vinegary.  On a previous visit we had fried chicken and macaroni and cheese (b/c we're health nuts), and those were both awesome as well.

EQRvY2oJsLP8ssWdpgxgVQ.review_text: Fried chicken was generous and quite good, loved their version of white macaroni and cheese (but would have enjoyed a slightly cheesier flavor to balance with the mild heat), LOVED the shrimp with grits and the po'boys were perfectly fried.  Stayed for a chocolate dessert, and managed to devour it with a full stomach because it was that good.  Enjoyed the wine and our server was perfect - I let him choose my wine and he brought over really yummy glasses each time.  It is on the pricey side, and I worry for them in "these tough times" but the decor is really special, and the location of such a great place in a such a storied and diverse neighborhood is appreciated.

jPBL-Wl7u-k7t1LOJhlEdA.review_text: Very cool swanky place. Always busy so make sure to go early or make a reservation.  Hands down my favorite place for macaroni and cheese and Fried Chicken. Everything I eat is fantastic there... though its hard to sway from the Mac&Cheese. It's pretty high priced though so have your boyfriend pay. ;) JK men... Excellent place for a wonderful date and dining experience. First date? Wow them with your tastes!

CfOES30jxRXGIJQVxDIvIg.review_text: I'm debating between a 4 and a 5....and I'll think I'll go with a 4.5. I'm feeling like Paula (abdul) today and I'll be a little generous.  I came here the other day and I had a quite memorable experience.  The food, ambiance and service were all fantastic! I came here because it's literally right next door to Yoshi's and thought it would be great to just walk over to Yoshi's after dinner. I mean come on - what's better than soul food and Jazz!?   Upon entering this restaurant, I loved loved the decor. It's modern, homey and welcoming all at the same time. They took some modern pieces and mixed it with some "old school"pieces, but somehow most of everything worked in this restaurant.  Our waiter was funny and gave us some great recommendations and had a great sense of humor. Food was served promptly, water was refilled and dishes were cleared. AWESOME.  In terms of the food and drinks - drinks were fabulous. Most of them tasted like their namesakes like the Key Lime Pie, Jazzberry, Pear Flower (my fav) and the Spicey Blood Orange (not sure of the exact name of this one, but my hubby loved it). Food here is good...for the most part.   Recommended Dishes: 1. Braised Pork Belly (appetizer): Surprisingly a good size portion of meat with very little fat. I wished the meat was more tender, but the dish definitely had enough flavor. 2. Grits with BBQ Shrimp (appetizer): A good solid dish, not exactly out of this world, but definitely good. I like the grit portion more than the Shrimp. 3. Shrimp Hushpuppies (appetizer): another good solid dish, but not mind-blowingly good. 4. Maple Syrup Glazed Short Ribs: MY FAVORITE dish of the night. The meat was fall apart tender and the flavor was melt-in-your-mouth-i'm-in-heaven good. Even my husband said it was good. Which is a HUGE compliment - trust me. I'd come back here just for this dish alone. 5. Fried Chicken: Yes it was good, tender and flavorful. I've had better chicken but this dish seemed to be a big hit with everyone at the table except for my husband and I. Perhaps it's cause we're low class chicken eaters (if there is such a thing). But I'm assuming that this is how authentic fried chicken tastes like.  6. Spiced Fat Fries (side): Contrary to other reviews, these fries do have spice AND the homemade ketchup that comes on the side gives this dish a nice tang!   NOT RECOMMENDED: 1. Filet Mignon: Lacks in flavor 2. Rib Eye: Good in flavor, but cooked incorrectly. My friend had to send this dish back because the first time it was overdone and the second time it was underdone.  Some other highlights are the FREE cornbread with the jalapeno jelly and honey better. While the cornbread is not exactly moist, the jalapeno jelly adds a nice kick!  The chocolate beignettes...good. Not the best. But how can you go wrong with fried batter stuffed with chocolate?! I think not!  All in all, a good meal and a good time. I would highly recommend this place, esp. if you're going to Yoshi's to afterwards. There's a parking garage across the street and around the corner as well as street parking. Expect to pay about $60-$85/person. We ordered drinks (one per person), a bottle of wine, 4 appetizers and a main dish for everyone and ended up paying $85/person. While this is pricey, trust me...we INDULGED in every way we possibly could.   Definitely recommended.

OFNFtTc48LmXNk_NeZe9dw.review_text: I am so happy this restaurant has opened...   So... the food... yes, while it is a bit pricey... it is tasty... I love everything I have had there.. and I pretty much have had lots of the appetizers... drinks and what not... but as simple as it may sound... my favorite dish is the fried chicken.... it was moist... truffle whipped mashed potatoes (DELISH!) and I just wish I had more more more!  BBQ Shrimp and grits.. yummy!, Sauteed Wild Mushrooms are delightful!
