For desert we had the apple cobbler....huge disappointment!  They give the smallest portion of ice cream that i have ever seen, and the cobbler was just pretty good.   Now onto service. We had Trent. He had the strangest style. He would ask me a question (what would you like to drink, to eat), i would tell him then he would then just stare at my husband. No "ok", "sounds great", or "and for you sir"? Just stare at you blankly then walk off. Also the waiter from the next section (i think his name was Jonathan) waited on us more than Trent. He brought my husband a new glass of wine, refilled my tea, cleared our table and packed up our left over, and picked up our check. He also took care of all his tables too. Wish the tip could have gone to him.  Overall, It was a good experience with a good meal. But not a place that i will think of one night craving to go back to.

RIGOL8DnNLz-7prhDdP-EA.review_text: Upscale soul food. 3.5 stars, tops.  A double date at the War Memorial Opera House for the Nutcracker ended at 1300 on Fillmore.  The atmosphere was great and perfect for dates and small gatherings.  They served cornbread as a starter --which was good, nothing extraordinary.  I ordered the FRIED CHICKEN, BF got the DRY RUB RIBS w/multi dipping sauces, and split the TRUFFLE MAC&CHEESE.  I would order the fried chicken again, neither of us loved the rubs or mac & cheese.  Overall the ambiance was great, but the food wasn't good enough to bring me back.

FrVdzvPtzIBDBcvVJTixQg.review_text: I have been here twice and it has been really on point both times. Really great and unique food (uniqueness, in my book, is a key criteria for getting that fifth star). On Fridays they have an amazing live band called Hot Pocket. Everything about this place is pretty great. Value for the money. Quality of food. Atmosphere. Our waiter last time was pretty spacey but thats a pretty forgivable sin at this price point.

VOD79PseKkg08eIMvNbNHA.review_text: Came here with the intention of not ordering the fried chicken ($26 for chicken...CHICKEN...is just ridiculous to me) and in fact I was completely  content with my non-fried-chicken entree selection until the waiter pointed out that no one at the table ordered the house special fried chicken...at that point I caved.  Waiting for our entrees, I saw numerous fried chicken orders flowing from the kitchen and people devouring it with, to my surprise, a fork and knife. What ever happened to our god-given utensils called hands I thought. Anyhow, my dish came out, and what the heck, I dug in with a fork and knife. First thought, where's the bone? Second thought, oh-my-god this is good! The chicken captured the essence of any good fried chicken...it was super mouth-burning hot, crisp, tender, juicy, and ultimately lip-smacking good.  Enough with the chicken....the fresh cornbread and jalapeno jelly really typify southern flavors and are a nice substitute for the normal bread and butter. I also very much enjoyed the shrimp n grits and smoked pork belly. Both were explosive and robust in flavors.  The short ribs are a great option if you're not into the $26 fried chicken, but take it from an original non-believer, get the chicken.   By the way, been back since my first visit, and the chicken still kicks some serious butt.

D18gDZwJE7zPeRrHq-xRJw.review_text: Sunday Gospel Brunch....can I get an amen??  Barbequed shrimp n grits, corn bread, big bad bloody Mary's, and full on gospel singing.   This is IT.  There is NO better spot for Sunday brunch.

vj8hf9IRzDdMFKulR74DZw.review_text: All you need to know is..... order the fried chicken! If your into really good fried chicken. or just like chicken in general. Or thought you have tasted good fried chicken before. or think since your in a nicer restaurant that chicken is not what you would want ..your wrong ORDER THE FRIED CHICKEN! its really good. but also everything else we ordered was great too. bbq shrimp with creamy grits,  foie gras with rassberry jam and the short ribs! They also serve you warm corn bread with honey butter and chili jam. I wish I wasn't so stuff to tried the dessert cuz I could have tried about 3 things...just I'll have to go back......fried chicken, fried chicken, fried chicken.

7iF-6RIVvUfk_ibomp5Xig.review_text: Man oh man. Fried chicken was bomb. So delicious that this review will consist of fragments. Just kidding. It was worth the $23 and the 20 minutes of waiting which didn't feel like 20 minutes at all, maybe because we had a fairly large group (8 ladies) and we were choppin it up, eatin delicious cornbread the whole time. We didn't even have appetizers and we weren't suffering from hunger pangs (hahah..pang).  The service was great, very friendly. I love the decor, it's dim but it's nice, cool shadows casted from the lighting! There was no jazz though, that's only Sunday through Wednesday. It's right next door to Yoshi's so you can get your jazz fix there if you want.  I'm definitely coming back to try more of the menu (entree, dessert, and cocktail)!

vy-DcE2Zbj9ljNCLY-hN_A.review_text: Ambiance - perfect 5 stars.  Drinks good. Steak with the asparagus and butter BBQ sauce  - totally sucked. Chewy. Couldn't even cut it right. Soups with corn was good.  Was here for a work dinner with a pre - fixed dinner. The person next to me had the same problem with the rib eye steak.  I was not a fan of the food but it's a great date place or after work drink venue. Sorry to be so negative but it was really not that great food served.

ce9Hhdi-B1d-YwhHX1CC-g.review_text: Having been to only Southern inspired places on S.F. my knowledge is limited however my family is from various places in the South so I think it evens out.  Going here I was prepared to be underwhelmed like I am at most Southern inspired places (Elite Cafe, the overrated Town Hall, the "Why are they still open" farmer brown and Blue Jay Cafe, and Front Porch [although that food is more Caribbean than U.S. Southern so they don't get knocked as hard]).  Knowing that the chef is born and raised in London only helped with my skepticism.  I went on a Thursday night and was seated immediately.  I had to wait for my waitress (a manager/host) came by and asked if I'd been waited on yet and I told him, no.  It was few minutes more before she arrived.  It was not packed or anything so maybe they're still working out some kinks.  I had the crabcakes to start.  I think I tasted a little curry and maybe there was too much seasoning in there but they were okay and of course, came with the typical citrus salad.  I ordered the fried chicken getting the mac&cheese instead of the truffled potatoes because I must be the only person who does not get the truffle love.  Anyway, it comes 3 pcs and boneless.  I put salt on mine because it was pretty bland without it.  It was crisp, hot and cooked through though.  It wasn't the best I've had nor the worst.  Actually Cafe Rex on Polk Street has better chicken and so does Street on Polk on Sundays.  Front Porch's chicken is coated with flour and cornmeal so if you like that type of crunch and the extra seasoning this might seem bland to you although Front Porch's chicken isn't really Southern style.  The mac&cheese came in a container that looked as though half of the order was missing.  It tasted okay, again, I've had worse and better.  It's not traditional either as bell pepper and bacon are not usually in mac&cheese not to mention that most folks in the South don't really use white sauces to make mac&cheese.  For dessert I had the beignets.  Traditionally, the come in a diamond shape.  They weren't greasy which is good.  The coffee soda was bizarre as has been mentioned.  I took a sip and found it cloyingly sweet.  I dipped a beignet in and it was not only sweet but I was getting the feeling of eating something spoiled.  All in all, while the space is nice and the bar area seems comfortable I won't be going back.  The cheapest thing on the menu is the vegi black eyed pea cake for $18.  Seeing as the now shuttered Powell's was paying 10k per month in rent I don't even want to know what the price must be on this place.  If you don't want the cuisine served at Yoshi's and don't mind paying the price and want something close by then by all means help yourself.  For decent New Orleans type food you're probably better off going to Brenda's in the city.  Bottom line, S.F. still doesn't have a nice authentic Southern eatery and if I need a quick fried chicken fix I'll just go to Popeye's.

4yyurnwLMFm3eYisctyU9w.review_text: I made reservation for a Sunday night to take my fiance here for his birthday. My gosh was I blown away by their food, drinks and service! The night we went, it was not very crowded in the beginning. However, more and more people came later. They have specials each day, and the waiter/waitress will announce those items.   We ordered drinks and I had a fancy cocktail while fiance ordered a red wine. If you're into fruity cocktail drinks, then you'll love their cocktail menu. Fortunately for us, the appetizer of the day sounded really good and we ordered that as our starter. It was their charcuterie platter. I do not remember specifically which type of cured meats I ate (one may be duck meat?), but I do remember their pate spread. The combination of the spread, mustards, pickled onions and cured meats melted away in my mouth! It tasted like heaven and above... I'm drooling just thinking about it.  For our main courses, we had their traditional fried chicken (with masked potatoes and small side of mac and cheese), ribs (special of the day) and a side of mac and cheese. One thing I would have done differently would be to skip the mac and cheese if I knew the fried chicken came with a small cup of it already. Either way, the mac and cheese was not disappointing. Firstly, the fried chicken was not greasy at all but still maintained its crunchy outside and the juiciness of the meat on the inside. My fiance loved their mashed potato. Then came the ribs... my my my were they delicious. The ribs came with no sauce on them (but still had flavor) but two small side sauces. I think one of was a sweet barbeque type of sauce while the other was a more mustard type? Either way, I ended up using both sauces on the ribs and the fried chicken! We ate and ate and ate until we were going to get sick. Even though, we had plenty to pack to-go. I wanted fiance to order dessert as it was his birthday but he told me he absolutely cannot eat anymore. I can't force feed him on his birthday and so I heeded to his request.   I think the bill ended up being around $100.00 per person and this is with two drinks each, appetizer, two entrees and a side. I have been to more expensive places and those places did not leave me feeling this way. I will have to come back here in the future and I highly recommend this place for a special occasion or if you feel like splurging!

WRc1yA_1Lddz6YKC9VtPUQ.review_text: Fried Chicken, Rib Eye, Fried Green Tomato Salad, Beignets, and Banana Cream Pie. Way to ring in a birthday with some hearty, heart clogging, dam good food!  Wandered down Fillmore after a beautiful day soaking in the sun and jazz at the festival. Entered through the giant wood door to experience 1300 on Fillmore.   Menu was expansive, and offered choices for anyone. You could pick a few appetizers like the fried green tomato salad with goat cheese. Of course fried. A distinct and tasty dish. Or go for the artery special of their famous fried chicken. Three pieces of OMG. Served up with mashed potatoes to give it that extra should not have eaten that. Rib Eye was my favorite since I ordered it. Big piece of meat, cooked Medium. Excellent over the blue cheese grits.   Now comes the dessert. If you even have an inkling to order something please do so. Banana Cream Pie is king, closely followed by the Beignets with a chocolate and a coffee and soda dipping sauce.

cSvwgRq74ElhrE6AQEm3DQ.review_text: Loved this place. The live music was awesome. The Pocket turned the place out! The lead singer has so much swag. He kept the party going all night. Sadly, they only play until 11:30 PM every Friday. Luckily were able to see them again at Farmer Brown's on Sunday for brunch.  Service was friendly and attentive. I noted the manager giving extra special service and complimentary food to a table of two just in front of us. Perhaps it was a special occasion.   The food was also delicious. We initially ordered rib-eye burger. It was what drew us in for dinner. However, within minutes we were told that they ran out. This is unacceptable for a restaurant of this caliber. We opted for the black skillet roasted catfish instead. It came with andouille sausage and shrimp jambalaya, and cornbread panzanella salad. It was packed with flavor. The complimentary cornbread served with honey butter and jalapeno sauce...OMG! I was in heaven. Serve a sista some hot cornbread and a stiff drink and I'm good.  Thank you 1300 Filmore. Great food, great service and excellent live entertainment. I'll be back!

EfLECHdYuO5z8RsPCzGaDA.review_text: The atmosphere is a little upper crust but not stiff and it is decorated to create a warm atmosphere.  You can be dressed or casual and still fit in although I wouldn't wear sweats or sneakers.  The fried chicken was okay: moist and tender but not lit with flavor-a gravy or sauce would've helped. :\  The ribs are huge (enough for two to share), plenty of meat and the sauces that accompanies them are awesome but the ribs themselves are flavorless. :(  Mashed potatoes are AWESOME! :)  Corn bread is good: :)  Peach Cobbler:  Is more like a peach pot pie with a heavy crust...ehhh :/  The ambiance is very nice. They had a jazz band playing in the lounge area on the Friday that we went.  Service is pretty attentive.  I think the next time I go...and yes, I will try it again, I will go during HH and sit at the bar.  I will let you know how that goes.  I would honestly give it a 3.5 but that's not an option.

uPFnpvKmNW6EtfRhrFqtbQ.review_text: Love this place. I can't believe how beautifully decorated this restaurant was. I had made reservations for 8:30, we arrived about 10 minutes ahead of time and checked in with the hostess.  She was really sweet and showed us to a table right behind the podium. I wasn't quite satisfied with the table and I asked if we could wait for another one. She said of course...  My friend and I go to the bar.. which was elegant and simple... the drinks were fabulous.  Our hostess came to the bar and got my friend and I and showed us to our table. It was a perfect table in a cozy corner of a luxurious couch!  The menus were presented to us... and for the month of February, 1300 is offering a prix fixe menu which included a 4 course meal, including a warm chocolate cake for dessert! Everything was scrumptious, hot cornbread for the table. A Dungeness crab salad for starter, then a little fois gras... followed by delicious beef medallion... rounded out with a yummy and exquisite warm flour-less chocolate cake.   I will come again. and again. and again  and again.

FXtFiNuUL7A5ODAoP9gSew.review_text: Yesss!! Sunday brunch with Mom's in the Fillmore listening to live R&B/Jazz while grubbing on some crazy good soul food!  Thank god they didn't ask us to sing because there's a good chance of that sitting in the front dining area.  The whole thing was very entertaining and the food was great.  I had the catfish sandwich...po boy style, I recommend it.  My wife had her favorite fried chicken but wasn't crazy about her order...go figure.  Definitely coming back...had a great time!

srj-v0WSYa-1gpmffbeypg.review_text: We came here last night for dinner.  Made a 6 pm reservation and it was pretty empty when we arrived.  We ordered a couple of dishes from the happy hour menu, the ribs and the wild mushrooms with grits.  Both were quite outstanding and, at half the price of the regular menu, quite a deal.  We also ordered the watermelon salad.  Such an inventive dish, with a hint of mint, truly refreshing.  We also ordered the fried chicken and the succotash.  I was really looking forward to the chicken because many reviewers spoke so highly of it and I love a good fried chicken.  I ended up being the most disappointed with it.  It tasted rather dry to me, though not as unhealthy as most fried chicken tend to taste.  It did not have any greasy taste to it, so maybe the lesson here is don't expect the food that is normally bad for you but you love be served in a style that is not so bad for you but that you'll still love??  I don't know...  Anyway, the service was great, the place looks beautiful and it was quite packed by the time we were leaving.  Definitely will be worth a 2nd, 3rd, etc., visit.

jtCumoFQqFVUbyzX-vYfEA.review_text: Great restaurant, the food is delicious!  So nice to go somewhere that has a beautiful interior, cool ambiance and most importantly, great food.  Would definitely recommend.

WAGVbrDAtFoCCjME9Bd_BQ.review_text: Wonderful dinner hosted by Nicky!  Great food, great service!  We'll be back!

F8UXRG5R_TgSNJmKKQMTSA.review_text: I came here for Dine About Town and I wasn't that impressed. The fried chicken was tasty! but in my opinion not worth the $

TNo1aPj4p9mXkHBR0uHfEg.review_text: I cannot say enough about this gem in our city.  The chef/owner David Lawrence, is a genius, besides being a sweet and lovely man.  The ambiance is absolutely gorgeous, warm, inviting, modern yet cozy.  The service is attentive, friendly, efficient and just perfect. The food. What does one say about the food?  You start with a bite of the corn bread...which should be illegal its so good.  Then you get your starter, mine was the poached egg salad.  This dish was so delicious I don't think I said a single word until I had eaten every bit of it...the warm egg yolk on the bacon and cabbage was divine. Then you get your entree.  I had the surf and turf, perfectly cooked scallops, perfectly cooked short ribs, creamy potatoes...unbelievable. I wont even mention dessert...ok fine I will! Chocolate raspberry cake that was so rich and delicious it totally put me over the edge!  And for a coffee fanatic as I am, their coffee was absolutely delicious!  I had to ride 100 miles the next day to burn off the calories, seriously. But it was worth every single grueling pedal stroke, and as I was climbing my last hill with tired legs and saddle sores, I was planning my next trip to 1300 Fillmore! Just go, you will NOT be sorry!

dmP6zH3s6Qz0Yv8XPEQeMA.review_text: Was delighted to hear my Aunt's wedding reception was being held at 1300! Had heard so many good things and was pleased that the food had met my expectations!  We had a pre-fixed menu which included the  organic baby lettuce salad and grilled chicken and grits. The salad was very tasty! The dressing was light but flavorful and the pickled okra was a delicious! The chicken was especially wonderful- super tender and juicy. Definitely one of the best chickens I've ever had.  I can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu. The fried chicken sounds amazing!! The only reason I give it a 4 and not a 5 is because it lacks good vegetarian options (but it's southern so not unexpected).

GtAvwG3oTH4RxlpiDbO0tw.review_text: I just got home from one of the best dining expereince...and it all happend by accident.   My intentions were to go to Yoshi's tonight for some Jazz and sushi. After circling around a couple times and having second thoughts about parking beyond Eddy street, I found the perfect parking spot right on Fillmore. I look up and see this dark lounge on the corner of Fillmore and Eddy. As soon as we got out of the car, I was bragging to my sister that I have good parking karma--we got a sweet spot right in front of Yoshi's.  We walk into this lounge with large wooden doors. The decor is so unique -- upside down lampshades paired with large paintings of the Fillmore past. My sister tells the hostess that we reserved a table for two. She looks down the list twice and doesn't find us. Meanwhile I picked up a business card and was wondering why Yoshi's would ever make their address "1300 Fillmore" so prominant. Hmmm....  Guess what??? We stumbled into 1300 on Fillmore by accident. The general manager, Dave, was so awesome about it. He was telling us all about the food and my stomach wouldn't shut up. We thanked Dave and proceeded to Yoshi's half a block down. Halfway into Yoshi's, I didn't want sushi anymore -- I wanted a hot plate of soul food. I wanted the fried chicken, spicy fries, spare ribs, collard greens. I desired the comforts of cornbread, biscuits, and mashed potatoes. I love sushi just not tonight. (Yoshi's, I'll definitely come back to neighborhood and make a special trip to visit you very soon).   We were seated immediately despite the fact that we didn't have reservations. Dave, the general manager, also became our server and was very knowledeable on food culture and the restaurant, and had a great sense of humor which lighten the night. The food was absolutely heavenly.   In the 2 hours I spent at 1300 on Fillmore, I ate food that was like heaven on earth, I learned about the history of Fillmore, I saw our former mayor Willie Brown, and met a local dwellor of the Fillmore neighborhood, Reverend Townsend, who parted some of his wisdom to us. Now that's what you call an awesome dining experience. I guess it's true what they say: Sometimes, the best experiences aren't planned, but come by accident!!!

HTugWamLf6OIRZXiEfa83A.review_text: I reserved a table at 1300 Fillmoore for my 5 year anniversary using yelp. The decor is impeccable! I loved the vibe and the service was friendly. There was no wait time with the Friday night reservation. Our dessert plate of chocolate filled beignets was specially decorated with  "Happy Anniversary" written in fine chocolate scrolls. We will definitely return!

9TAq1yTRxQu5dZkIOGd1-Q.review_text: WOW...Once again my Lil San Francisco oasis has not forsaken me... I have found my new favorite restaurant and it is amazing...the decor is quaint and romantic (well in the lounge) that's where we sat (I cant judge the main dining room too much)...they had these amazing back lit pictures covering a whole 18 feet  floor to ceiling wall. They gave the whole room a soft and romantic glow...The ambiance was perfect for me and my "special someones date"  I always pick the restaurants and he has never complained (cause we're just connected like that ;o)...we are both foodies who love to tickle our pallets with new and creative dishes..but we need the whole package...gorgeous decor...not too loud (unless that's what we're going for) and impeccable customer service and BOY WERE WE PLEASED!!  So we sat in the more loungy area...with the beautiful leather chairs (think King and Queen in a castle very Louis the 15th)  For starters we had the fresh water shrimp hush puppies and the BBQ Shrimp in creamy grits and those two apps were amazing...everything was cooked to perfection and the none of the dishes were over seasoned or bland.  For drinks I had the 3 of the jazz berry martinis and he had 3 crown royal,coke,grenadine and lime concoctions...(He created his drink) It was great though..I have to give him that.   On to the main course...I had the pan roasted black sea bass (flaky and cooked to please) and asparagus (sauteed and succulent) and he had the Maple braised beef short ribs (which were so tender they just fell right off the bone and smelled so delicious) with mashed potatoes and onion rings..we also ordered a side of the Mac and cheese and the caramelized  sweet onion braised greens!! Not a one of our dishes left us disappointed...we both had that good kind of full...you know satisfied not stuffed.  And for dessert we had the banana cream pie, drizzled in Carmel with a flaky crust!!! OMG!!!  Last night was an absolutely fabulous night...I now have a new favorite restaurant tucked away in the culture filled hustle and bustle of the Fillmore district...we made a same day reservation and were seated quickly when we arrived...the hostess was so accommodating and our server was very knowledgeable of all the dishes...our bill came out to be about 200 dollars (that's with tip) but for 2 appetizers...6 cocktails...2 main courses...2 additional sides and dessert in a 5 star restaurant is more then reasonable to me. For me its experience, ambiance and the meal itself...I was more then pleased and I will definitely be back again..very very soon. (Plus there is a parking GARAGE...yep you heard me GARAGE...no looking for while your stomach eats itself going on here...parking less then 60 feet from the restaurant)...Can we say convenient?? This was definitely a night to remember.  PS. And the cornbread with sweet creamy butter and jalapeno jelly that they serve before the meal is mouth watering...anyone that knows me knows that I have a secret weakness for cornbread...well its not a secret anymore I guess ;o)  **If I could give it 10 stars I would...anyone who doubts this establishment or doesnt try it is cheating themselves**

rRnrg6trTXxnGF3uZsUUfQ.review_text: From the moment I walked into 1300 on Fillmore, I sensed a disconnect. The elegant room alongside the pleasant but not-overpowering smell of barbecue were almost impossible to reconcile. In the end, I left with the feeling that I liked the room and the servers more than the food - and I really don't like when that happens.  The decor and layout are truly a pleasure - warm browns, old photos, and a very distinct lounging area alongside the bar, separate from the dining room. Fit and finish is very high quality.   My meal was less inspiring. A salad with pears had decent, if mild, flavor, but the pears, while bearing grill marks, were just too hard. I wasn't expecting them to crunch, and they did.  I had the short ribs, and the meat itself was cooked well, toothsome and yielding, but a bit uninspired in flavor. the bed of mashed pototoes underneath lacked salt and was a too-bland foil for the meat.  We shared three desserts, and unfortunately, none were really exciting. Beignets were quite good, though the coffee soda accompaniement was too strong and far too sticky-sweet. Banana cream pie wasn't the classical version you'd expect - no issues with that - but the powerfully ripe banana flavor was not adequately offset by the sweet creaminess of custard. It just didn't work right.  I'd try it again, though probably for drinks and an app in the very cool lounge space. Too many other inspiring places to have dinner.

68ZWynKpipZGPWCEtl5EcA.review_text: Came here with the girl friend for Valentines day last year.    We both dressed up a little bit (I wore a nice shirt/tie/pants) and we fit right in.  I'm not sure how people usually dress there, but it was nicer than usual on that day (probably because of valentines day) ?  We had a reservation for 5:30 so we arrived around 5:20 but didn't get seated until 5.45ish.  The wait was not bad at all though, they had a lounge/waiting area with a live band and a bar so we had plenty to keep ourselves occupied with.    Once we sat down, the service was great.  No complaints there.  I ordered the fried chicken and she ordered the braised short ribs.  Both were awesome.  BIG portions, but still quality food.  The music was not too loud, despite what other reviews have said.  This place was a fancy, yet lively place.  Elegant AND fun.  It was a great night!.

xYf9oB8-coHeAkvvEdq79Q.review_text: Excellent service from the entire staff (Stephanie was our server) and very good food all the way around....Fried chicken, mashed potatoes, biscuits, jalapeno cornbread with strawberry jam... Pure South, right here in The Fillmore, the Harlem of the West. That said, the wine is expensive...very good quality, but very expensive at $15 per glass. Anyway, you only live once, so visit 1300 when in the city.

hr2syHT1AM4tvCK7a4jwDg.review_text: We actually had our Holiday Party at this location.  I'm a little late writing the review but better late than never.  I had the short ribs.  They were tender and fabulous.  No knife needed!  The appetizer were simple and good,  potatos, mini sandwiches etc.  I enjoyed my chocolate cake for dessert.  I plan to visit again.

0XIlxTlnrxNw_ZcnLyfoRA.review_text: Incredible surprise! Had no idea it would be this good.   We were expecting a take on New California and got down-home soul food.  The BBQ Shrimp on cheese grits and the mussels in mustard, cream, white wine and garlic were amazing starters with lots of crusty bread for sopping.  And then, a huge plate of unbelievable house-smoked baby back ribs that came "undressed" with the sauces on the side.  We never touched the sauces--the meat was that fantastic.  Great food, great wine list, and the incomparable Robert as our server.  Be sure and ask for Robert-- he was a real treat.

zIeWHm_nGnomfNm_-Ta1Uw.review_text: Background: I had heard fabulous things about this restaurant from two foodie friends so I came in with very high expectations.  -----------------------------------------  So much potential -- beautiful decor (including the lounge/bar area), elegant presentation, and innovative idea (for SF) but the food and service leave much to be desired considering the prices.  All the dishes lacked the sort of complexity and elegance you would expect from $9-$11 apps and $25-$30 entrees. For example, the fried chicken had a tasty and unique breading (lots of cumin, so stay away if you're not a fan), but the meat itself was a bit bland. The rabbit came recommended by the server, but the white meat was VERY dry. The lamb chops were perfectly pink on the inside but tasted like a big chunk of meat without the subtleness you would normally taste in a lamb chop. The accompanying lamb sausage however, was awesome.  The shrimp hushpuppies were like the chicken -- really good breading, but the shrimp itself was severely undercooked and the garlic aoli nothing out of the ordinary.  No complaints with the sides: fries w/ homemade ketchup and mac 'n cheese.   The chocolate beignets, like the entrees, were good but not great. Very fried, but not as soft and fluffy as I expected and the chocolate syrup and coffee foam (?) were average.  The service was okay -- the waiter was not very knowledgeable but tried his best.   Bottom line: Underwhelming based on my expectations, but definitely willing to give it another try.

rxCQ_8TjQLIHZnzn2_aarA.review_text: We went to 1300 Fillmore with high expectations, after reading the menu. In general, it seems to be a place that would suit specific attributes, but otherwise would not be a place we'd frequent much from the peninsula.  Ambiance: The ambiance here is great. The decor, lighting, music and mood are good for an after work gathering, or large party. They have private and semi-private rooms available as well. Street parking is difficult and can be kind of scary (we were heckled twice while walking to our vehicle), so you may prefer garage parking.  Service: We loved our waiter. He was witty and engaging.  Food: Ah, after reading the menu, we were expecting the best pan fried chicken in the world. While the chicken had a great flavor that seemed like it had been brined or otherwise prepped, the overall combination did not seem to exceed other local offerings like Hard Knox cafe, not to mention the joints we grew up with in the south. However, the mushroom appetizer did exceed our expectations. We also found the ribs to be ok. Not as savory as the sloooow cooked offerings in the south, not as tender as the parbroiled offerings like at Houston's restaurant.  So, if you have a party, event, or want to host an event, or live in the city, consider trying this place out.

-40hChgdlI5clkagmyoh5g.review_text: Very nice and somewhat sensual environment for enjoying a drink with a date.  The atmosphere is dark, seductive, yet classy.  I really enjoyed the ambiance.    The drinks are pretty good.  HOWEVER, my DH ordered a manhattan and it looked more like a pinkish/red liquid concoction and tasted disgusting.  I guess this should deserve minus one star; if you can't get a classic drink right (actually destroy the drink), then you shouldn't be behind the bar. But since overall the experience was good, I'll keep it at 4 stars.  Oh, and I tried their THICK steak fries and WOW they were so delicious and meaty.

wN4gFGx3srNtWU-DXvZG7Q.review_text: I am actually only rating the lounge area, where we stopped for drinks before our dinner at State Bird. I did love my spicy orange martini they had on the menu, as i am always in search of good cocktails with the hot pepper mix. However, i felt the service was slow, despite not being very crowded & the seating is designed for couples, not anything larger. This could be a plus, when only 2 of you are looking for cozy armchairs.  But if you come with 2 couples as we did, the seating is not conducive. The appys we ordered didn't standout - in fact I can't remember what we even had, if that says anything. But the smells coming out of the dining room were enticing, so I just might be back for dinner, and give it a higher rating.

h5XPl57iisW60jd0-6fB1Q.review_text: Monday night. Sittin' at the bar. Live Jazz. Best fried chicken I've had. Ever. Those few small criticisms crumble when that sweet delicious fried chicken hits my soul. First time in my memory when the chef / owner approached me & my date to say hello and introduce  himself. Perfect example of "touching tables for real". Classic place. Go!

8iAALNo2OyxPfaJiyHt6gw.review_text: this place does southern food, except expensive.  Not horribly good, and certainly not original.  ambiance is OK.  Noise is about a 5/10 which for this city is a pretty good rating

usfxR3pe7NUcdx9rVb5Btg.review_text: I've heard so much about this place, so decided to try it out with a few friends. Went on a Friday night. Our reservation was for 7:15pm. First, the atmosphere is phenomenal. I thought the decor was great and very friendly vibe. I love the lounge area near the bar. It was a great place to relax and talk before we were seated. On the other hand, the food was "ok". I didn't think it was anything spectacular. And a bit pricey for me. I mean c'mon the fried chicken was ok, but nothing to write home to mom about. Our waiter was a hoot! Nice, a little forgetful, and kind of odd too (he circled our table about 2 times for no apparent reason). I believe his name is Adam. Adam, were you on something? C'mon you can tell me. Lol....Oh and he likes to say "yeeees" alot. :) My suggestion is to try it out, at least once.

Jb_CChaEcgE787IDYNvx5A.review_text: I came here for dine about town, but the DAT menu was not as appetizing as the regular menu, so we opted for the latter!  First up, the bread.  Not just bread...corn bread.  I loved the sweet butter that they served with it and my friend loved the jalapeno jelly.  Then we ordered the sea and swine for our appetizer...I loved the pork belly, but the crust on the scallop was the big winner.  I can't even begin to explain how amazing it tasted.  So many complex flavors in one bite!  Then for our entrees my friend and I shared the blackened catfish with jambalaya, and the fried chicken with chive biscuits.    I loved the catfish, but thought the jambalaya was just okay.  Then again I am not a big fan of jambalaya so maybe that's why.  My friend loved it though!    The fried chicken on the other hand was AMAZING.  First things first, it was boneless, and had both white and dark meat!  The batter was crispy and perfectly seasoned.  The chicken was tender and juicy.  And the chive biscuits...buttery and absolutely perfect!  Definitely in my top 3 SF fried chicken dishes!  We also ordered a side of white truffle mac and cheese.  It was good, but not the greatest.  It was a little watery and I couldn't really taste the truffle much.  Then for dessert we got their signature banana cream pie.  Light, fluffy, chunks of banana, and not overly sweet.  Delicious!  I am definitely coming back to try the duck and waffles, which sadly they were out of...

LXgl2wcReiN-q0k2ccAmhw.review_text: Great place, great wine list, excellent ambiance, excellent staff... perfect addition to the neighborhood.    I went there for my birthday with my partner and bro- and sis- in law.  We had a great time, ordered a bottle of Malbec which was fantastic--thanks to the sommelier!  The cornbread biscuits were quite tasty.  I had the lamb chops with the lamb sausage.  Slightly on the salty side of things, and the portion could have been larger.  Still it tasted very good.  Bro and sis in law both ordered the fried chicken which smelled fantasic and planted a seed in me.  I'll definitely try the fried chicken next time I'm there.  Word to the wise: the food is slightly on the fatty, high cholesterol side, but that should come as no surprise given the theme of the place.

ubc4IKVSiy_aUQEx78k8kQ.review_text: solid. everything we had was cooked perfectly and tasted great. it may have been the things we ordered but I did find it a little light on the "soul food" but i don't care cause good food is good food. also, we ate in the lounge which was awesome; very comfortable and relaxed. the best part, even with a full belly  i had a mental note of all the things I was looking forward to trying the next time.

3KtdczMtTSB0fWCNLvUWag.review_text: wandered in here while waiting for a show to start next door at Yoshi's. super surprised at how good the food was. easily my favorite (non-sushi) spot in this neighborhood. its like high end soul food. i look forward to returning many times.

wXeUXpe0aCYAhjdnsxf0sg.review_text: The food was below expectations but what really killed it was the waitress running after us after we left the restaurant b/c she thought we didn't give tip. We had to explain to her that we added the tip to our totals since we split the bill. That made me determined never to return. Nice atmosphere, overrated food and very entitled waitress!!

uUUtWWrDq3NMsu1nR03I9w.review_text: Came here for dinner with a girlfriend of mine.  We had high hopes for this place, however, we were both pretty disappointed in our meal.  I think if it weren't for the beignets and their lounge area it would have been a complete flop.   The overall atmosphere of this place is really nice, I'd come back for drinks/dessert and skip the meal next time.

iAgeUjprA28AQDa80mDuTg.review_text: I AM IN LOVE. they have pork belly on their menu. how can you not love pork belly?    they also have these wonderful beignets you must try dipped in coffee soda and chocolate... ahhhhh... wash it down with riesling as you listen to a silky voice singing "them there eyes..."  the staff is attentive, friendly and surprisingly un-stuffy given the venue. (hi dan! adam!)  elegance, thy address is 1300 fillmore.

vOfgzbeS8igE_nYj8Y3DQA.review_text: Glorified and glamorized soul food. Definitely tasty and quality, but nothing to get excited about.  All stuff your grandma or neighborhood greasy spoon could crank out if they were given fancy plates to put it on.  We got the fried okra, shrimp hush puppies (nothing remotely like a hush puppy - think shirmp corndogs), fat fries (steak fries sprinkled with lawrys), fried chicken (meh), baby back ribs (pretty good) and shrimp with grits (very tasty).  The ambiance and decor are classy.  But the place is way too dark.  I could barely see my food!  They do have a nice bar and stiff drinks so they get an extra star for that.

m5IjjKl9hzR9r8yLUgKJ9Q.review_text: Dined here last night.  I wish I can rave about this place, but I can't!  I'm so disappointed!!  I've heard so many wonderful things about it and sadly it didn't meet my expectations.  I will say this, the restaurant is beautiful, and definitely fits the "first date" vibe.  Here's where it goes all wrong... We had dinner reservations at 8:30pm thinking it'll give us plenty of time to enjoy our dinner before heading next door to Yoshi's to see a concert at 10:30pm. We we're running late, so we got there at 8:45pm. We order almost immediately because we were starving. Tell me why we didn't get our food until 9:50pm? We made it known to our waiter that we were on a time crunch and still he didn't do anything to make sure our orders came out on a timely manner. As a matter of fact, a group of 6 people sitting next to us, who arrived 30 minutes after we got seated, got their food before us!  We were a party of 3 - I'm confused... I think you know what comes next - we had to inhale our food!  NO BUENO!  I ordered their burger and a side of mac 'n cheese (what else). At the time I thought it was delicious, but thinking about it now, I'm sure a piece of cardboard would've tasted just as good because I was beyond starved.  Their mac 'n cheese has a spicy twist to it, so I liked that, but it lacks the cheesy, yummy goodness that I look for.  All I can say about the burger is that its so-so.  That's pretty bad if all I can say about a burger is "so-so".  Sorry 1300, I probably would've enjoyed the drive-thru @ McDonalds down the street just the same.  It would've saved me a $50+ tab, that's for sure!

k5wIVQtBZQx2IROdJoMg9A.review_text: I have been looking forward to eating at 1300 on Fillmore and I was not disappointed.  The facade of the building is warm and inviting and I loved the heavy double doors (no escaping)  but who would want to with such a fantastic cuisine.  As you enter, your first visual is the bar/lounge area which was warm, elegant and inviting.  To the immediate right is the dining area with low lights (actually kinda sexy and seductive - enticing you to enter) I did and . . . .   We started the evening with: Mache Salad with Dungeness Crab Meat, Blood Orange Aioli, Shaved Fennel and Apples.  Absolutely Delicious!  Roasted Colorado Lamb Chops, Roasted Garlic, Rosemary Sausage, Tomato Confit, Roasted Porcini   Grill Tenderloin of Beef - Blue Cheese Scented Yellow Hominy Grits, Balsamic Sweet Onions, Brandy Sauce and perfectly grilled.   Spiced Fat Fries with House Made Ketchup  (I always always order Fries - my true self indulgent test)  and they were.  Dessert:  Banana Creme Pie with Lime . . a 3" tower of the most delicious Banana Creme Pie with ( Caramel Sauce I have ever tasted.   Presentation on the the above dishes was a work of art.   The over sized plates worked well with each dish and service staff was very very attentive, so we never had the-crowding-of-plates situation.  Just before we left, the chef/owner David Lawrence came out to thanks us for coming to his restaurant   and ladies "He is Hot". . .

rAI_guXz_FC9ngMYcbit-g.review_text: GREAT ambiance for a romantic date night.   Above par southern cuisine  with a twist and awesome service.

q-cnaQU2yhCjXUquxRjgUg.review_text: Super place to hide from the dreary SF weather.  Snuck in here one rainy afternoon for a romantic little Happy Hour.  Floor-to-ceiling windows make for excellent people-watching, and if that bores you, there's also the wall of intriguing floor-to-ceiling vintage photos.  Oh, and the DRINKS!  Delicious, strong, and fairly reasonably priced for SF.  BF and I probably tried most of their cocktails, between the two of us.  LOVED the gimlet, dark n stormy, and pear flower.  You can't go wrong!

N-2TGpX9rD1J252POItTAA.review_text: This is such a beautiful place. I took my boyfriend, Jason, for dinner on his birthday and he definitely loved it.  We had: Shrimp Hushpuppies - 5 stars BBQ shrimp with grits - 4.5 stars Fried green tomatoes - 4.5 stars Pork belly - 4 stars  They also serve corn bread with this red pepper spread. The corn bread was so delicious, not dry at all! And with the red pepper jam it was a divine combination.  Service was impeccable, nice friendly people. Attentitve and down to earth. You know you are in fine dining when you leave the table to use the bathroom and when you get back your table napkin has been folded for you and put back on the table.   We also, loved how the staff was multi-cultural. You don't see much diversity on the floor in a fine dining restaurant. Sad but true. Our waiter was so nice, down to earth and very knowledgeable about the food. It was very impressive.  I think 1300 on Fillmore is one of those restaurants that is trying to encapsulate the history of Fillmore as well as pushing it to another level. I was blown away. I will definitely go back and don't mind paying $$$, its worth it.

xQwp_9V1O71m-ynSgig0nA.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore exceeded my expectations as a restaurant taking on Dine About Town. Friendly, professional, and attentive staff, amazing cocktails, delicious corn bread, beautiful décor, these were only the betas to an awesome night.    I came on a Thursday night. Being that it was a girl's night out, we all know it can call for a lot of high-pitch squeals, roaring laughter, hugs, running around photo-whoring, and inappropriate discussions with inappropriate language usage. Evidently, this can be seen as obnoxious and intrusive behavior to some. Fortunately though, the staff and our neighboring patrons were very accepting throughout the night. Beautiful murals framed their sophisticated lounge area. Fixed with leather arm chairs and welcoming sofas, it has a jazzy, old library appeal to it.   When it came to service, they set the bar. Early in the night, a friend arrived and excitedly came to hug everyone. In the heat of the moment, she knocked over a cocktail, broke the glass, and spilled the drink all over the floor. The staff gently asked us to let them clean it up and even whipped up a new one for my friend. Whoo-hoo to southern hospitality. Courtesy +1. Given that it was DAT week, they were pretty busy, but never did I feel like they were overwhelmed or unorganized. The service was top-notch throughout.   I wouldn't constitute the food as real southern soul food though they offered mac and cheese, grits, and cornbread. A gourmet flair was definitely implemented if not influential to the menu. My grits came with shrimp, the cornbread had a very deep, rich, honey flavor to it and my key-lime pie came as a martini, a very tasty and memorable one though, might I add. The mac and cheese was actual macaroni noodles and had bread crumbs tossed in, but it was just OK for me. My favorite was probably the creamy, savory, shrimp and grits. YUMMAY. My main was a catfish and pilaf or risotto. Major aromas and flavors pockets emanated from the fish and rice. Holy mole, it was soo good. I regretted chowing down on multiple triangles of cornbread right then and there. Even grumpy enjoyed leftovers (he's been a perennial hater of fish, unless it's fried or sushi).   A place with great food and beautiful decor will score a decent review from me, but an entity that aims to go above and beyond deserves the best review I can offer. 5 stars it is! Right next to Yoshis, I have every incentive to return even if it's just to pick up another key-lime martini.

Ym2XGcjoZbzxXamjIkQYxg.review_text: Wow, 1300 totally missed the mark with me. The ambiance is great, awesome cocktails, but overpriced wines. The 2 stars is generous when it comes to their food. The cauliflower soup was extremely bland, and under seasoned. The salmon was extremely dry, border line burnt, with absolutely no taste. I agree with fellow yelpers on needing work on their seasoning technique, it was horrendous. Great place for drinks, but they really need to work on their food.

zhThVRq126Z4-4wzAxLnuA.review_text: I went for the second seating for brunch on Easter. The food was fantastic and the ambiance was really "uptown" as we southerners would say. I had the 1300 Fillmore breakfast, perfectly cooked scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage.....My only wish is that the wait staff could spend a week-end in New Orleans and see how service with a smile can make the world of difference. The only person who even acknowledged us was the runner who had a wonderful kind demeanor. 1300 on Fillmore ain't no Galatoire's of New Orleans but it was a good experience. They need a strong, welcoming personality at the door to say the least. I guess a wanted a little of "home" in my experience, you could feel the tension seething from the staff.  You can bet your top dollar that it trickles down from the management. 3 stars for the food....for sure.

hkSTeVnKsPM_dQeD5GWsTQ.review_text: I was here for the dine about town promotion.  Overall, the food is very ordinary.  In terms of the venue, the furnishings and environment are quite stylish.  I liked the tall ceilings, the cylindrical light fixtures, and the black and white pictures lining the walls.  I am not into jazz, but my companions agreed that it fit in well with the atmosphere.    Unfortunately, that and the good service was the best part of the dining experience.  I am not a fan of cornbread and I found the offering here a bit too dry and crumbly.  The mixed greens with grapefruit was spot on with a nice blend of acidity and savoriness.  For my main course, I had the cod which I found too be cooked well, but way underseasoned.  The creme brulee and spice cookies were unexceptional.  We also tried the fries, mac and cheese, and greens as sides, which were all solid, but not great.  I also got to sample the short ribs which I found to be too dry, and the fried chicken which was moist and tasty.  As far as dine about town options, I have experienced much better.  I would only consider coming back for perhaps the fried chicken, but I would probably go to the Popeye's just a few blocks away.

zJXDM_o7TFPqoyIWMImxbw.review_text: Actually more like 3.5 stars but slightly closer to "A-ok". The food is filled with flavor which at times was a bit overpowering and too rich for my taste. Went with a group of 6, which it was well suited for, and got to sample a variety of dished including the pork belly, chicken sticks, catfish, steak, and my favorite of the meal mac and cheese. If anything would probably go back for the happy hour.

                               *  {@} *   *  *    *    *  [Review No. 268]  Why the Sexy Sax?  My relationship with food and music comes from my heart  I could  simply say this place "Rocks like other reviews but  More!  It's smooth, sexy and delectable!  I have tracked  many places (homes, restaurants, cafes, etc.) for the ultimate "Fried Chicken".  You sink your chops into this evenly tasty deep fried buttermilk crust so moist, tender and fresh.  With every bite~it was serendipity and the fried chicken sang to me such a groooooovy hummmm yum!  Yes, I am regressing to a fetal position in a warm safe place!  The price is definitely worth every dollar.

57MS2UYQuOXk50sjK4g90g.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore has a rather special place in my heart since it was my first dining experience in San Francisco having just moved up to the Bay Area from Los Angeles (land of the pretty people who don't eat, but if they do, they will voluntarily puke it out later).  Came here on a Friday evening and absolutely loved the ambiance. The setting was ever so intimate and I loved the dim lighting. I opted for the pan roasted black sea bass and immediately fell in love. Yes, SF was my kind of city. You see, I get a little superstitious about new restaurants, new cities, new homes. My first dining experience has to be impeccable in any new city I move to, and if that happens, it's a sign that I would have a great time during my tenure there. And 1300 on Fillmore was definitely impeccable. For dessert, we shared the warm chocolate beignets. Melt-in-your mouth happiness. That's all I have to say...  And in case you were wondering, no, I didn't stick my finger down my throat after the meal. LA's skinny inhabitants can kiss my big fat ass. City of San Francisco - I am here to stay!

lNQcG57E05Zqn--eKThgHg.review_text: Why didn't I give 5 stars? Stupid, but valid reasons. The champagne beverages were a little "meh." We got there right when brunch opened and they're already out of peach puree for my bellini. The pom mimosa was also a little "meh" tasting. But other than that, the food was divine, and the Gospel Brunch was AMAZING! Get your lungs ready and be prepared to sing! Grits were super yum (minus that weird stuff decorated on top... I couldn't figure out what it was - like candied something or other?). Fried catfish BLT (minus the B) was super yum! That bread was perfection. Fried chicken was also yum! Will definitely be back.

e-8mxbsxWj5lSLt1fzsTZg.review_text: AWESOME! Food is great atmosphere is fabulous.....

Bn8w45_LSwItWqDTm4RHwg.review_text: We've been here twice now and have had a similar experience. The food is great but we felt rushed both times by our server. If they can work through this, I think they can make 1300 amazing. I also noticed they have a great room to reserve for large parties (10-20 ppl), FYI.

599lvnTQ2tLYEhkIbUeL4w.review_text: Wow. Gorgeous space! Great HH specials - we tried the okra and the shrimp hushpuppies. Both were delicious. The restaurant was crowded but the lounge was mostly empty all evening - even on a Thursday. Lovely spot.

Ohhrhu1RkqfVciIVx_W5HQ.review_text: We stopped in here for a cocktail and snack before a show at the Fillmore last night.    The ambiance is nice, but it feels a little sterile, sort of like a restaurant in a Conrad  hotel. Which is nice...but you still feel like you're at a hotel.   Drinks were good, bar snacks just ok. We had the spiced fat fries (was not expecting cinnamon to be part of the "spiced" in "spiced fat fries") and the shrimp hush puppies.  Both hit the spot, but were not really "outstanding". Which seems to be what they are going for.   We know this is a fact since we were asked every two minutes "how is everything, aren't they FABULOUS (well...actually no), "Hello, I'm the owner.....".  Not sure who the heck they though we were, but they were laying it on thick. In a very uncomfortable way.   The place is nice, it would have been a much better experience if they backed off a bit.

NibzGjnQIre2Xq3khW5CaQ.review_text: 1300 On Fillmore opened to a great deal of fanfare over two years ago and, in my honest opinion, hasn't missed a beat with its cuisine. I decided to have my birthday dinner here with friends and had a fantastic meal. The fish I had was cooked just right and my friends ALL enjoyed their meals. I had the salmon prix fixe option on the menu which I highly recommend.  What shocked me was how empty the place was on a Saturday night. I know we're in a recession, but as far as nice restaurants in San Francisco are concerned, 1300 On Fillmore is relatively affordable. The light traffic somewhat killed the ambiance and made me sacrifice a star. Still love the spot and would suggest the place to anyone curious about it.

lxOcZ1VZ58nSCFgcunecjw.review_text: So finally we got the chance to have dinner at 1300 Fillmore and the wait was worth it.  We had an excellent meal and everything about the place was very nice (except for the parking...just do the valet outside).  We went last Saturday and it was very busy which is always a good sign especially during times like these.    The ambiance inside is very cool and we liked the decor all throughout.  For appetizers we shared the grilled pears and arugula salad which was very tasty.  The goat cheese actually made this meal.    We had the mac and cheese as a side (I mean can you ever go wrong with mac and cheese?).  For the main meal I had the fried chicken which is a staple here and I was not disappointed.  There was a lot of chicken too so I got a nice meal the next day as well.    A great meal and atmosphere so definitely a place we would head back to.

DvcAC_nlKaTDsHcA8Slagw.review_text: The lounge at 1300 on Filmore is a great place for drinks, bites, and conversation. I came here for a post-event happy hour and had a good time.   Between glasses of gin & tonics, I noshed on some pretty delicious bites. The shrimp hushpuppies are truly exceptional. Fresh, plump, and succluent shrimp encased within a moist hushpuppy. Delicious and super convinient to eat. The fried chicken sticks with  the blue cheese dip were also really enjoyable. I mean what's not to love about fried chicken, and a crispy-fried-but-moist-on-the-inside one at that. Plus it's on a stick so again really easy to eat as you engage in conversation. The braised beef short rib sliders and fries are pretty decent and yummy too.   1300 on Fillmore is a sophisticated but comfortable space with attentive and friendly service. I'lll have to come back for dinner some time but I definitely reconmend the lounge for happy hour in the area.

0Gebvgd4Z9VSiLANOkcn6Q.review_text: visited again last week, Very energetic attractive place. I had superb scallops and my friends enjoyed their appetizers and main courses. Everyone loved the food. Service could be a bit more attentive but overall my experience was very pleasant

G0XeV_we20JDvIx0djPAMQ.review_text: incredible service, atmosphere and most importantly food!   we loved the shrimp/grits appetizer, ribs special and wine selection.  will come back soon...

aB8ixYhATXFRTELyFan3Hw.review_text: I've been to the lounge area twice now as I really wanted to fall in love with this place. I like the art work and decor but that's about it.  Each time I've visited the service has been bit slow but friendly. As for the food, I definitely have had better. I probably will try again in hopes of a better experience, but I don't have high hopes.

HcciAbTkNzkPjrA3uNrYnw.review_text: Great Southern-style grourmet soulfood. The waiter, Adam was very congenial and the atmosphere was relaxing and comfortable. I would definintely be coming back to 1300. It is right down the street from the Fillmore and was the perect pre-show meal. Stiff cocktails too!

pQMbjcDfr7A1aKtU_ls00w.review_text: The second I walked in, I was blown away by the decorations-the posh seating, the pictures with back light, the digital picture frames...EVERYTHING.  I was not able to make reservations because it was a very last minute decision to go there. If we decided to sit at a table...the wait would've been AN HOUR (keep in mind that this was Friday night at 7:30) so we opted on waiting for the lounge area. It took all of 10 minutes before a party left and we quickly swooped in on the seat. Everything we ordered was very very good; however, when our "sweet bread" came, it was nothing like what I expected. Our waitress tried to tell us that it's a little misleading with the name and all but we decided to order it anyways (we couldn't really hear her over the loud music and the busy crowd), but it ended up being the glands from a calf! Needless to say, I did not have any =(  All in all, the food was very tasty but the ambiance and the decoration is what really sold this place for me.   hint: When you get a doggy bag, they give you a little tag for it and so before you leave you show it to the maitre de and they get it for you. Nice touch.

8Bx7StPmiE9EQQQJSQz-ww.review_text: Addicted to their fried chicken. Don't tell anyone!   Oh, no the secret is out.

rcDBuRcYAJgtJCGzxJoYYg.review_text: Great ambiance and the food was tasty. We had an unfortunate incident happen while taking my Mother out. We were eating the cornbread when husband pulled out a 7 inch hair out of his mouth. When we told our server he didn't say anything except take the infected cornbread away.   At the end of our dinner we asked the server if he had told the manager what happened, he said "yes" and then the manager came over. He was rude and not empathetic to the situation. In fact, his first statement was, "tell me about the incident" as though we were making it up. He never apologized and then tried to convince us to order dessert. He said that we should have told him before the end of our dinner , we reminded him that we had told our server right away. He said, well we are really busy in here.  Ok, but you are the manager and it is your job to fix those "hairy" situations. At that point it was too late for us,we left angry because of the way it was handled.

XtTe0SLLEXjonEsrLYr6OA.review_text: Brunch Experience on Sunday  The food was delicious can came out surprisingly fast! Also, the ambience is quite tasteful and is a perfect setting for a Sunday brunch.  The reason for the 4 stars is due to the band. On Sunday a band entertains while you eat, and they're voices are excellent. I personally have nothing against their performance, but the volume is just a tad too loud for me while I'm trying to enjoy my meal while conversing with my friends. Again, the bad is wonderful, but I just wished they turned down the volume a bit.

XmEywucVDyUP9VJ4SXGjzw.review_text: 1300 Fillmore is almost immediately adjacent to Yoshi's.  One or two more good places and this part of Fillmore Street will have its own restaurant row. The venue is stylish, bi-level and becomes lively as it fills with a crowd from everywhere.    Notice that  all of the patrons sitting on a sofa along the wall are a few inches shorter than their mates who are on chairs opposite.  The sofa is a few inches too low.   Ask to not be seated at a sofa-table lest the food get thrust towards you.  I start with barbecue shrimp and creamy grits.  No grits expert here.  But they are creamy and satisfying, the shrimp just cooked through and tasty.  Some crunch is provided by almond slivers dispersed here and there.  Some bite comes from a taste of pepper that slowly becomes apparent as I work my way through the food.  Nice, tasty.    Pan roasted black bass is served over salsify, artichokes and shrimp nage.  The skin of the bass is crisped, the flesh beneath moist, tender, tasty, perfect.  The salsify taste like a cross of carrot and baby turnips, as advertised.   The artichoke are OK, the shrimp nage (broth) adds nothing to the plate.  But really, this is all about the bass, and rightly so.    Dessert is a circular 3 inch mound of banana cream pie.  It's freshly made, filled with chunks of banana and not too sweet.  It is sided by an astringent caramel-lime sauce that bites back at the somewhat sweet pie.  Lovely way to end a meal.  This place serves up-dated, stylish, lightened plates of southern-inspired food.  A really nice addition to the San Francisco restaurant scene.

ls2xiZF5Lf2hq9Wl3uac4g.review_text: Crazy sexy cool atmosphere and awesome drinks.  The lounge section I would definitely go back to and spend more time there.  As for the food, I had high expectations from all the yelp reviews and found myself just a tad bit disappointed considering each item I ordered, I have had at other places and found the flavor to be much better. Star rating for food: Shaved artichoke fennel salad **** Maple braised boneless beef short ribs*** a bit dry but good flavor; mash potatoes a bit starchy  Black skillet fried chicken*** not so impressed (Try Pican in Oakland!!) White truffle mac n cheese *** cheese tasted a bit clumpy and not creamy like I expected 2007 Syrah, Consilence, Santa Barbara County **** I thoroughly enjoyed this wine!  Overall..I would return and try some other dishes on the menu and spend more time in the lounge area.  I also want to try their Sunday brunch menu.  The waiter said it's great.

yq_qqNHc3zR1Zi1Qj0sB3A.review_text: I really like 1300. I might be a bit biased since it's down the block and a wonderfully easy place for me to go, but truly the food is fantastic. Try the fried chicken it's amazing! And their fried green tomatoes, BBQ shrimp, mmmm. They had a wonderful pumpkin bisque in the fall last year as well that was simply to die for. The food is southern style so be prepared for a heavy meal but you will leave happy!  In addition, they have a cool little lounge area if you just want to hang out at the bar - and they also serve their full menu there I believe. It's a nice place to hang out with a group of friends or a date - not too loud and big comfy leather seats.   I'm a huge fan of this place, anyone who likes southern food must try it!

pOsSRzm0ZOXE9FcJ5pWxYg.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore is making some beautiful music.  The talented jazz trio was music to my ears.  The elegantly decorated space was a visual melody for the eyes.  The homey yet sophisticated food was a delicious song for the tastebuds.  The High Notes:  Spacious yet Intimate Candlelit Dining Room * Swanky Lounge with Live Music * Sauteed Wild Mushrooms with Grits * Pan Roasted Black Bass * Flavorful, Moist, Crunchy Fried Chicken * Wonderfully Airy Citrus-y Sweet Potato Souffle  The Middle Notes:  Good Complimentary Cornbread * Mediocre Chocolate Beignets * Long Wait for Entrees but Overall Good Service  The Flat Notes:  Disappointing Soup-y Roasted Brussels Sprouts * Bland Shrimp Hushpuppies   Bravo 1300!  (Will definitely be back for an encore!)

vzuA7AVvJ6Tonoy2-aazLA.review_text: Friends suggested we go to this restaurant. I read some reviews and thought, wow pretty all over the map. So we went, the cocktails were great, the atmosphere and the looks of the restaurant was really nice. We perused the menu, and they had a pretty ecclectic menu "southern" menu.  We asked our waiter what would he recommend as a starter he recommended the "grits and shrimp". Than we proceeded to order like the heirloom tomatoes, and I ordered the pork belly. The grits and shrimp were great, the tomato dish had what looked like "bottled french dressing" (mayonnaise and catchup) and it tasted like that. The pork belly was mushy, including the skin, I mentioned to the waiter the skin could've been crisped to give it some textural contrast. The entreés weren't that exciting, the ribs still had their "silver skin"on it, the cod had the same "french"dressing the tomatoes sat on. The vegetarian entrée looked and tasted like mush and the macaroni and cheese with truffle oil was just bland, bland, bland.  However, the dessert were hits and misses. The chocolate dessert combo was good, the banana cream pie was boring.  Normally I would have rated this 2-stars, but because the grits/shrimp was really good, cocktails were really good, and the service great, I bumped it up a star. For this kind of money (bill came to $344, including tip for 4-people, I say go somewhere else. SF has so many good choices.

daQF05zGhX1fXVOBVXQPrg.review_text: I was completely thrilled when I walked in here to meet friends for drinks. What a great atmosphere and overall vibe.  However, the drink I ordered from the cocktail specials was only ok, so I switched to my usual grey goose martini and it was perfect.  The bar menu looked quite appetizing so we were ready to order a few things to get the party started. The food came out promptly but surprisingly the food was not hot enough. The shrimp were soggy. One of the dishes needed salt and the execution was just slightly off.  I was a bit disappointed in the food but the fresh take on soul food is perfect for 1300 Fillmore.  I really want this place to succeed. i hope they read my review so they can be all that they can be.

UYX7ZxP1QjI-eyKQRQ3X9Q.review_text: I enjoyed my visit to 1300 Fillmore, so I am giving it 4 stars. It lost 1 star for the verrrry slow service. My waiter was slow and was very obvious about it. He definitely forgot to put in our order so we waited a long time just for my appetizer. I am a fan of the restaurant itself and the atmosphere.   I got the baby back ribs and the portions were very generous. I am a huge mac n cheese fan and I would have to say I was slightly disappointed with theirs. If the occasion calls for it, I would go again.

HSFXuYnNMGCJuRu_DvzLRg.review_text: This place is classy but not snooty, classic yet modern. I was pretty excited walking up to the place and thinking of what I was going to order, as I checked out the menu the minute my girlfriends and I decided to go to 1300 for our annual holiday dinner. Fried Chicken or Braised Beef, Fried Chicken or Braised Beef, I repeatedly asked myself from where we parked in the free Safeway Parking Lot to the big heavy door that opened to a wonderful dimly lite restaurant, and was filled w/the sound of a saxophone playing some great jazz beats. When you walk in to await the hostess, you look to your left and there is a nice sized bar area w/some seating to lounge, sip some specialty cocktails and listen to the live band play. We were greeted, met the rest of our party and was escorted straight ahead to the dinning room and seated at a roomy circular table w/plenty of elbow room. No booths here (from what I seen), just round tables for smaller parties in the middle of the room with longer tables bordering the dinning room for larger parties.   We began to gaze through the drink menu, and for one of my girlfriends and I we targeted the Feisty Blood Orange - Absolute Mandarin Orange, Oranges, Cranberry Juice and Sliced jalapeño. This was delicious, not too sweet with a touch of heat, however it may be an acquired taste and a bit weird tasting if you're not into that kind of stuff.   Out came the complimentary cornbread accompanied w/honey butter in one dish and a strawberry jalapeño jam in another. Very different, which is why it may have been very good. The cornbread itself was good, not to gritty w/the right amount of crumble. Topped w/a spread of honey butter and a dollop of the strawberry jalapeño jam, it went from good to great. Some of our party decided to order the oysters to share, which I didn't try the oyster itself, but did taste test the mignonette which was nice, the meal was off to a great start.   Fried Chicken or Braised Beef, I debated one last time and decided to go w/the............ MAPLE SYRUP BRAIED BEEF SHORT RIB w/Chive Mashed Potatoes and Onion Rings. The worse culinary decision I have made, this dish didn't have as much flavor as the description made it seem to have. The meat itself was fall off the bone with the right amount of fatty goodness, onions rings were crunchy and not oily, mashed potatoes were, well mashed potatoes, but the flavor of the beef was not what I was expecting. I thought it would be more packed w/flavor with a touch of sweetness, however found it somewhat bland, and the other 2 that ordered thought the same. One of my girlfriends ordered the Fried Chicken and was kind enough to share and let us try. WOW!!! It was juicy, flavorful and crispy w/out all the batter. I think I will give it another try, but will opt for the Fried Chicken.

Ju1w8df5bTxp0K2b0wZ9Sg.review_text: Typical, "upscale" hipster SF restaurant that is outrageously overpriced and the only reason it deserves two stars is the service!  Other than that, the front door person was an ass hole and told us I couldn't bring in my "outside beverage and had to throw it away and could give it him before coming in at all." I was appalled.  It was a cup of coffee!  Both my husband and I were disappointed with our meals which were the risotto and burger.  My father got the risotto as well and felt the same as myself, which was the portion left us hungry afterwards and it was terribly under-seasoned.  I generally believe this establishment needs some serious alterations to either the cooks, the recipes or BOTH.

002slNgnEtAvsNYFLw7rGA.review_text: the food, upscale soul, is great.  We were there for drinks and appetizers -- the lamb sliders were quite possibly the best "low class meets high class" bar food i have had at a restaurant.  I wish we stayed for dinner instead of going to SPQR.  manhattans were stiff.  decor was really well done.  I was impressed and will definitely be back

awmRirDC7WWig6R07XZ_oA.review_text: 5 stars for the pear flower cocktail - my favorite cocktail in SF.

NjXzQBML1jiHAxqIEcYaNw.review_text: Hey, hey, hey....have lately been voyaging into the....um...Fillmore Jazz District.  I find this to be a funny sorta strip....basically, the Redevelopment agency plowed-under a vibrant and diverse n'hood in the '60's and '70's to cure urban blight....and replaced it with concrete hi-rises and soulless storefronts.  Retail tenants of the old 'hood were given vouchers and promsed they could have their merchant spaces reclaimed in the new development....but, gosh...when the time came...that never happened !!!  Guess what....that whole bit of urban renewal...failed ! (Surprise).  So now we get the second version, new-millenium style.  This time around, we have concrete and stucco mid-rises in multi-colors with...um....soulless storefronts...PLUS...brick sidewalks which tell us what funky, cool ol' establishments USED to be in biz when the Fillmore was the Fillmore.  With that, however, came (at least) some potential magnets to draw nitelife back across the great divide known as Geary Blvd.  Talkin' Yoshi's and 1300 as the major players, along w/ the likes of Sheba's and Rassellas (which was originally intended to be the major jazz player).  Not a bad idea, not a bad idea...although, as my taxi driver once said upon pullling-up to the just opened Yoshi's - "oh, goody, another expensive place for white people to come see jazz".  hehehe...had to give him a big tip for that chestnut....  Now, this entire entry is not one big digression...it's really not.  1300....I really hope that this place makes it.  I have been there 3x thus far...once for drinks, once for drinks and snacks, and once for din-din.  The food is very good.  We had the char (which as mentioned in other reviews, doesn't seem to come with the specified lobster anywhere to be seen) which was still pretty good...and then the killer item in my book was the barbequed shrimp with grits...dang, slay me !  Their fries w/ homemade ketchup also really kick, as does their cornbread. Also, the head chef makes rounds of the tables and bar area and is a very engaging Jamaican/British fellow....David Lawrence.  I like that...he seemed genuinely interested to converse and see how his establishment was being received.  On the other hand....his managerial assistant was a rather stern woman who walked around doing the same thing...although on all 3 occassions she glanced at our table and bypassed it.  Hmmm...not that I take such things personally....this was OK with me, since if I found David to be affable...my impression of her was that, well....she seems the kind of lass who would smile at you sweetly, grab you by the jugular, and then not let go until you stopped twitching....so, probably all the better for both of us.  I like the bar lounge area better than the dining area...it's cozier...the dining area seems too much of been-there-done-that fancy-schmancy-california-cuisiney-interior-vibe stuff.  It's pleasant enuff...just not very unique or comfortable (albeit an improvement over Yoshi's 'is there any way we can seat you in a colder environment ?" Japanese chic).  Also, the lounge area has this amazing photo of the old Fillmore (ironically, of a particular block which no longer exists....the surface street between Post and O'Farrell - now an overpass). Urban designers would have done well to take notice of the photos such as this....because they could have very much informed what sort of NEW storefronts SHOULD have been erected along Fillmore...instead of what WAS)...  Oops...digression again....anyways...  Good food, friendly service (forgetting the aforementioned, um, sprite), nice atmosphere...and a great, great, great mix of clientele. Matter of fact, the crowd may be what I like best about this place...there's a lotta fun people-watching to be had here....  Bad points:  troppo caro !!!!  $$$$$$$ !!!!  Aye, aye.  On one visit, we split an entree, 2 appetizers, and 3 glasses of vino...and the bill was $85 !!!!!  ouch....For $85, I like at least feeling relatively full when I leave.  I shudder to think what it would'a run if we had ordered separate entrees.  Drinks were a bit pricey too.  They should drop their prices a bit....because although the style of the food may warrant such...the portion sizes do not.....so don't come here particularly hungry.  Also, the waitstaff doesn't quite have it together yet...but I don't mind that, since they were all pretty nice.  Although, I must agree with other reviews...for a place trying to be of this calibre....they better get their hosting situation all shook-out....'cuz on two visits, there was a major backlog of hungry folk at the hosts station apparently w/ reservations who weren't gettin' seated anytime fast....  Now that the strip has it's expensive magnet places, it needs some more down-home cheap places (that are NOT chain-stores)....a dive bar or two, a souvlaki stand run by some grumpy old guy, a fried catfish place....then the Fillmore'd really be in bizness.....

PojmG4zjqc6SAqMFF9s7Ew.review_text: I cannot figure out why I haven't written a review of this place before as I go there all the time...seriously...I looked up my opentable reservation history and a full 1/3 of the time I'm eating at 1300...and I don't even always make reservations, sometimes we just head in for dinner.  I grew up in the South, so I have some pretty high standards and I love this place.  It's down home food done for foodies, so everything has a little bit of a foodie-edge to it.  My favorites:  - Little gem salad with pecans and green goddess dressing - Mushroom grits (or any of their grits for that matter) - creamy and delicious...brought my fiance around to grits in general (he's from the NE so he claimed not to "do grits") - for those of you lucky enough to live in the Fillmore, they sometimes have a stand at the Farmers Market that's three different versions of grits...a little bit of heaven. - Short ribs - melt in your mouth deliciousness with mashed potatoes and greens - Fried chicken - deboned, with a little kick in the flouring of it...totally worth the 20 minute wait - Whatever they are doing with in-season fruit - whether it's the peach cobbler, apple bread pudding or pretty much anything else, it's all amazing  My fiance loves the warm egg salad with cabbage, the mac and cheese, greens, and the brunch with Tasso ham.  Service is great and always friendly.  Cocktails are fun.  Great for dinner with the fiance, with the girls or with family.  Go now.  Seriously.

5-YgAM7xwHite5wAshFAgA.review_text: We were brought to dinner here tonight with dear friends. The atmosphere was really nice, and the service was great. Between the six of us we tried the shrimp & grits, hushpuppy shrimp, fried chicken, baby back ribs and matchstick okra.  Everything was wonderful.  My wife who does not like okra, loved the matchstick okra, fried to perfection.  One of the party was having a birthday, and had the chocolate filled beignets and shared them.  They were really great.  We all shared the banana cream pie which was also really great.  Altogether, it was a wonderful evening with great food and great stories to tell.

fitXjNnwVB_HzqaBSrIGXQ.review_text: Very classy place for business or dates. Service is friendly and attentive. Food is excellent.  Fried chicken is good here with a healthy portion. The short rib is much smaller portion in comparison and much richer.   Drinks are expertly made!

FsE3Ol4yUfJZZX8pGV0Rvw.review_text: Been here twice. Great food. Excellent services. Very classy loungy atmosphere but on the loud side~ since they play live music. I would definitely recommend House-Cured Duck Pastrami for appetizer and the Pear Flower cocktail was so good. Love love love their corn bread too.

sGucD4iCPSuf6AIx5lKEYA.review_text: Love the food here.  Finally an upscale soul food place worth talking about. I have been here a few times and each time I have a different experience and it only gets better. The drink selection at the bar are ideal in flavor and the atmosphere is very inviting. The decor and warm feeling makes me feel at home and the music complements the style of the place as well as the people.
