J_QxknTPX0jAhTdsCJoKpA.review_text: I did my homework before going here on yelp, and found the tips that helped me have a super meal! I ordered the short rib, and my wife got the   Fried chicken, both were great. We had mac' n cheese sides and we both liked there take on an old fravorite. Some reviews mentioned spotty service however our server was fantastic!

WRqUdziXa7I_gR6AHQF1HQ.review_text: Went here for brunch today with a friend, the food was good, but the service was soooooooooooo lacking. We had to flag down our waitress no less than 3 times, to ask for stuff like more coffee etc. Not impressed. The ambiance is really nice, very pretty decor and furniture. We both had the french toast which was pretty darn tasty, and the grits...oh the grits...get a giant bowl and just chow on them. They are to die for! Parking was easy on a Sunday am so that was a plus. Overall good but not great.

40u5hF_FWzx5vYkEXZeT9g.review_text: Nothing says romantic like 1300 with warm brown interior and jazzy feel of the lounge. Came here for Valentine's Day dinner and swooned over the ambiance, food, and the handsome man sitting across from me in a pink tie :)  Valentine's dinner proceeded in following order: (Starter) Complimentary Cornbreads-Moist and not grainy. Thought the Jalapeno Jelly would be spicy, but not at all and rather pleasantly sweet. Honey butter was fluffy and light.   (Drinks) Glass of wine for him Southern Soul cocktail for me-I think the mixture had Southern Comfort & Orange juice. The concoction was definitely strong enough for me to titter totter home.   (Appetizers) 1300 Charcuterie Platter for him-The Duck Rillete (tasted like unsalty dumpling filling) and the House-Cured Tasso Ham were delicious. The Creole Mustard...OMG...I honestly never tasted mustard this good in my life. DEFINITELY ask for more bread with this dish. It's not enough to enjoy everything on this platter Barbecue Shrimp N' Creamy Grits-Definitely a D^3 (drop dead delicious) in my book. The grits were so savory and the shrimps so plump and juicy that I wanted to cancel the entree and just fill up on grits for the night  (Entree)  Black Skillet Fried Chicken for him- Impressed with the choice of spices used with the fried chicken and non-greasiness. Came with Buttermilk whipped potatoes and 2 biscuits. Just wish it was crispier.  1/2 Rack of Dry Rub Ribs for me-I came into the restaurant thinking with my mind set on Short Rib, but as soon as our server mentioned "Mac & Cheese" and "BBQ sauce" I changed my mind. I should've just stuck with the first choice. The ribs were a tad dry and the mashed potato & mac n cheese were a miss.   (Dessert) Couldn't have any because we were TOO FULL. But have to come back for those beignets and coffee soda.   The servers were attentive especially ours with her sweet smile and always checking on us. The silverwares were always changed for each course and the waters filled to the brim. Hope to be back for the short ribs, beignets, and if allowed, a cauldron of grits.

nMHhO2A2XMtVuuweiT8pUQ.review_text: I had the pleasure of dining here on a Wednesday evening. I had a reservation so there was no problem getting seated. This place is what San Francisco has been missing. This is a jewel.   As for the food, we started with the hush puppies and cornbread. For my entree, I had the house brine pork chop and a  "sample" of the skillet fried chicken.  Both were outstanding.   For dessert, we shared the banana cream pie. Small diced bananas, chocolate shavings and a drizzle of caramel sauce. Delicious!   As for the location, parking may be a problem. But hey, you're in San Francisco. You can valet park for $12 or park on your own for $12. Sorry. No validation.   I'll still travel from Fremont to enjoy the ambiance and a fine meal.  BTW: Server earned her 20%.

vAfCCm-sJ-fZCi6PrC38Uw.review_text: I'm surprised this place has the hype it does. The food is standard for a restaurant of its caliber in a city like San Francisco, but the prices are exorbitant for what you get. $26 Fried Chicken, $30 pork chop, $32 Catfish. The starters are about $15 - $17 and quite small. Furthermore, I found it to be really pretentious that the sides of fries and macaroni and cheese, etc were $7.50  So I ordered the ribeye burger, mostly because I was on a budget this trip. When the burger came out, it was TINY made more obvious by the fact that the bun was literally twice the size of the patty. They only serve the burger with house made potato chips, which despite being tasty, seem odd for a dinner entree and they will not allow you to substitute for the fries that are available as a side. I think it's ridiculous that they won't do this. I would have no problem paying an upcharge for the substitution but they resounded a flat NO.  So I was disappointed with my burger and when I told the server about it, she seemed very put out. After I gave my feedback about the food, she never returned to the table the entire time we were eating, while being totally attentive and busy with all the surrounding tables.  Despite being on a budget, I would have been unhappy paying the prices for any of the other food. There are SO many other MUCH BETTER places in SF to spend that kind of money where you get SO much more.  As far as Southern inspired cuisine, I'd be much happier at the Front Porch. It's far more funky, fun, cool, and has much better direction in their kitchen,  I will not return to 1300, it is simply not a "must visit"

EEFx8erroKj5pK07iv85fQ.review_text: Okay, so I have a love/hate relationship with 1300.  I think if we could have half stars I'd probably give it more like 3 1/2 stars.  When I first went here, it was within the first 2 months that it opened and I think I was just so overwhelmed with the ambiance that I didn't pay attention to the food as much.  I have to admit, I am biased, my husband worked here for some period of time, but hey I'm being honest!  But you'd think I would've been there more often with that being the case, and I only ate here twice in that year (or less).  I do remember that I got the salmon for dinner that first time, and I was disappointed that even with prompting to the waitress to have it well done, that it still came back a bit rare.  Granted again that was 2 months or so after opening, so maybe they were ironing out the wrinkles.  However, the next time I did go, I had the braised short rib and that was pretty darn good.    I do have to say though that my favorite aspect about the cuisine itself is that the pastry chef is very sweet and you can tell she's a perfectionist.  Everything that gal makes is ridiculously perfect and delicious with every bite.  My favorite desserts there are the chocolate beignets and Noriko's rendition of the banana creme pie which I swear I need to eat again.    On one hand, I think my hopes for 1300 was that it would help to just transform the ambiance of the lower Fillmore itself.  As a teen, I remember going to the Fillmore to go buy my Tupac shirts and just felt like this area had so much promise.  In a lot of ways I think 1300 does this.  The other part of me, can't get over $23 for fried chicken.  I mean, I get that the preparation for it is very intensive, very intensive...yet $23 is pretty high priced. Makes me feel like 1300 can't be the catalyst for change in that area unless it means to usher all the lower income people out and to bring in all the yuppies.  I get it, upscale.. have to keep reminding myself of that.  It's kind of like my review of Harput's adidas (which I highly recommend you read).  Yet you know, sometimes when you're in the mood for good food, and with this economy, I can't help but think that at Hard Knox it's like $9 for 3 pieces, 2 sides and cornbread.    I'd go to 1300 just to support the business itself, and the owners who seem to be great people.  But again it's not a spot you can just up and decide to go to, not in this economy anyway.

dmnankQk0Fv92cU8dxvJzA.review_text: If you're planning to knock a few drinks back and enjoy jazz or blues later at Yoshi's, then you cannot beat the convenience of this restaurant being right next door.  The ambiance is sleek and modern and the location ideal.  Unfortunately, the food was not.  The best dish was the fried chicken.  Can you believe that?!  I would usually not think of ordering this traditionally comfort food in a SF restaurant, but our friends did and I was ultimately envious.  For some reason this place was not able to cook a decent steak.  I was anticipating enjoying a rib-eye and blue cheese grits with our Joseph Phelps cab.  However, the "medium-rare" came out brown and dry (how do you mess up a fatty cut like rib-eye?).  The server was very apologetic and promptly took the steak back.  Unfortunately, the steak then came out rare; not bloody rare, but rare enough to be chewy.  So they were 0-2 so far.  My wife had the special of the night, the filet mignon, and it had almost no seasoning and was accompanied by bland sides.  Make that 0-3.  The bright moments were the fried chicken (which was very moist inside and not greasy), the grits, and the robust coffee.  The server was friendly and handled the food fiasco quite professionally.  I just couldn't give it higher than 3 stars because the quality to price ratio was not favorable.  The ultimate saving grace was when we strolled a mere 20 feet over to Yoshi's and enjoyed a great concert.

JseBksW8DVL596kJ18GGpA.review_text: Finally we got to go! Thank you Jennifer H. for taking the green-eyed birthday boy and I out to 1300 on Fillmore. I am loving the soul food renaissance that's been hitting America (some will say it's never left). 1300 adds it's own authentic flare by being in the historic jazz district of SF and displaying cool black and white slides of the area along a wall of one of the side lounge rooms.   1300 also brings some of the most experienced restaurateurs, chefs, and servers from throughout the city, so expect high quality ingredients, perfectly prepared (the pork chop in brine with apple cider sauce was mouth watering), and all from California, including the wine list. My southern grandma would be proud of the grits, even with the yuppie touch of marscapone cheese.   This would be a destination restaurant even if I didn't live in the city.

qK1GKo3gh2J-avGSocfANw.review_text: I treated my BF to an Easter dinner here at 1300 On Fillmore. The decor of the restaurant was really nice. The service was great and there was a jazz singer singing in the lounge area that completed the vibe of the restaurant. With that being said I have to say I was a bit disappointed with the food. The food was really expensive, so be prepared to spend $$$ for what I thought was somewhat mediocre. They brought out corn bread, which was tasty and we started with the BBQ Shrimp and Grits (the grits tasted more like risotto then grits), as well as the Shrimp Hush puppies (they are shrimp versions of a corn dog). Both were different then what I'm used to, but tasted good. For dinner we ordered the the Arctic Char (Salmon) over lobster and sausage hash and the pan fried chicken w/mash potatoes and two mini biscuits. We also ordered a side of greens. I didn't taste or see any lobster in the hash and it was drowned in some kind of reduced wine sauce. The salmon was cooked well, but it failed in an attempt to make me want to spend another $27 for it. The fried chicken was tasty along with the mashed potatoes and mini biscuits, but with Popeye's Chicken a block away I doubt I'll be returning to spend $23. The greens had a good taste to them, but I thought they were under cooked. The Strawberry Rhubarb champagne cocktails were really good and my BF really enjoyed his mint julep. I give the whole experience 4 stars (I subtracted 1 star due to food experience). I would totally encourage people to go check out the lounge, and have a few cocktails.

AgvjzJ7iNd3XysmRxe3u3Q.review_text: My recent escapades into the world of soul food has reached its pinnacle, in terms of style and elegance, with 1300 On Fillmore.  This classy restaurant scores huge points for its lounge, bar and dining area. It's a shame that I had an early dinner because I wanted to see this place illuminate during the evening. My only quibble is for the uneven seating at my table. One side of the table had a laid back sofa, while the other side had some high seated chairs. I ended up looking down at my friends who were slumped down on their sofa.  Besides the awkward seats, the atmosphere here is outstanding and most of the food shines bright.  The Fried Green Tomato Salad and the Sauteed Wild Mushroom appetizers were both very tasty. I would like to try some of the other appetizers next time based on these two winners.  On the other hand, the two sides that accompanied the main course both fell flat. The Mac and White Cheddar Cheese was too dry and overwhelmed by too much cheese. The Caramelized Sweet Onion Ham Hock Braised Greens (say that 3 times fast) was drowned by too much of the sweet liquids from the onion and ham, which killed the flavor and texture of the greens.  Overall, I did enjoy the Fried Chicken. The meat was juicy but I did not particularly like the spices used here; mainly the cumin. The mash potatoes accompanying this dish was a little too rich.  The Braised Beef Short Ribs fell just a little short of perfection, but it's a huge triumph. Although the rib needed just a little fat to give it that extra flavor and texture, the dish tasted sublime and the presentation was splendid.   You get two onion rings around one tender meaty rib, on top of a bed of fresh greens, on top of some of the best mash potatoes I've ever experienced. The maple syrup gives the meat, which falls right off the bone, a touch of sweetness. The mash potatoes had the right texture and flavors, but left light on the cream to counterbalance the richness of the ribs. Perfecto.  I applaud the chef here for bringing out the great flavor of the collard greens for this dish, by leaving the greens alone to exhibit its freshness and flavors.  To finish off the meal, I got to enjoy the light and airy Mud Cake and the sweet and tantalizing Chocolate Beignets. Both desserts were delicious. I just have to say... what a nice way to end dinner.

WxsysBPYG6qb-bTZtu8EMQ.review_text: Wonderfully accommodating staff. Great food. Very comfortable atmosphere.

qe9vn38gBVeHdEYPYxMUiw.review_text: Great, great place.   Beautiful inside and a great ambiance. Attentive service.   Started with the BBQ shrimp and grits - fantastic.   I had the fried chicken which was as good as any I've ever had an my gf had the short rib - fall of the bone tender. Sides were excellent as well. You could feel the passion and love in the food.   Would highly recommend.

E8m8EL6sV10AcMeASUY3hA.review_text: I am a fan of this place....corn bread, shrimp and grits (AMAZING), fried chicken, short ribs and mac n' cheese, Yummers!   the food is always good and i love to sit in the lounge area for dinner instead of the main dining room because it makes for a more relaxed atmosphere.  sometimes they even have a jazz band playing which is a bonus.  With 1300 coming into the neighborhood it has changed things around.  i haven't tried the brunch yet, but it looks amazing.  will update when i do.

ufCPOztHrcSCLP5CH1KvnQ.review_text: Very good southern food but pretty pricey, not sure it's worth all the hype. Good fried chicken- interesting hint of cumin in the batter (and it's enormous - 1 is enough for 2 ppl) and great bbq pork belly. Mac and cheese is weak. Cornbread is excellent, as expected.

B43n4T1W1kZm708hAMvseA.review_text: I went here for happy hour and really liked it. I got the $5 sparkling wine, and it was great, we also got some fries, which were fine. Overall, the drinks/food were good and well-priced for happy hour. The decor was cool, and I liked the whole vibe of the place. The bartender was cool, but it kind of bothered me how to servers/bartender would chat right in front of us super loudly, to the point that it made us unable to have a conversation. I really don't mind if they are talking in the back or farther away from us, but it was kind of disturbing our conversation for them to be literally a yard away from us. A couple of drinks got me over that lol, but it was still just awkward. Overall, I'd go back...maybe for a different seat next time.

vgH_pWo11HfMjs0WUDaD7w.review_text: Yeah, a new place in the fillmore. I've eaten here once during there opening week and loved it. There last night with a friend, we tried a tasting of starters The wild mushroom grit are woderful, rich and creamy. Also tried the Maple braised short rib which was melted off the bone and fork tender. The pork belly was off the " Chain " as well. Service was very good, but a bit stiff. We will be back. Oh, the bass.....get the bass.

YklfpGFHiC8EdLZhdBHlPA.review_text: 5 stars for the service, ambiance, and cleanliness.  I wish these were matched by the food.  Presentation of the food was good, but both the catfish and the ribs were bland.  They needed salt, at a minimum.  The mac and cheese and cornbread were good.  I hope they improve the food because it is an attractive place in other ways, and it's convenient to Yoshi's.

ghOQ3yUgAc6v2_ZhAqL5Ag.review_text: Really fun, Jazz Fillmore-themed restaurant. Took a client out to dinner here. Great menu for a broad array of palates, all with a more African American flair. Corn soup for appetizer was forgettable. Catfish was very tasty, but fried chicken was a little salty. Beignets dessert were incredible. Service was very attentive, friendly. Atmosphere was comfortable, but elegant. Definitely will return.

ZHjE-YKJSIwXIiV23RDxuw.review_text: The food is excellent. The crowd is diverse. The music is great. Avoid prime-time dinner if noise is an issue.

IUWtkUPblSqDIBplWGJe-w.review_text: Haven't eaten or had the drinks here, but this review is a BIG THANK YOU to the staff who mailed me my ID they found.    Signed, sealed, and delivered it came & with a cute note to boot!- just in the nick of time as I was about to order a new one!  Thank goodness for good people!~~

cSe2YWpamHnVADFaX2o3MA.review_text: I love hanging out at this place.  The jazzy southern vibe, big armchairs, a glass of  glass of wine and a the white macaroni and cheese...mmm good.

AT6NwNkLKxgW2fsQGNs-gA.review_text: Okay, so it only took me and Gwynnie P. two months and some change to finally go out and celebrate our respective Piscean birthdays together, but dining at 1300 made it well worth the wait. Located in the new jazz heritage building, this upscale Southern food experience was pretty incredible. My personal favorites were the shrimp hush puppies appetizer and the champagne sorbet soup dessert ... but the standout was my gorgeous dinner companion across the table. Happy belated birthday to us!

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: I finally made my way to 1300. I live nearby and love "Southern" fare. I wasn't disappointed one bit. The place looks fantastic! The crowd has a great mix of couples, groups and people on the prowl. I loved my food and so did everyone in our group. I've been attempting to replicate their brussel sprouts.

Ct456aEICzDfn03MHZCzsw.review_text: Wow, this is really making the neighborhood on the two blocks here really UPSCALE in time to welcome Yoshi's in November. I didn't get a chance to sample food, but I'm like thinking ...yeah...I support the look and like la-aaa--mmmm-b chops and want to have an alternative cocktail place where I can just get my diverse crowd vibe. (Although, I must say that the dudes, hanging for a smoke outside, dressed like Justin T. singing Getcho Sexy On suit body language, were a little too ..forced...IMHO...whatevah...)  Well...will update when have a chance to see them in real time operation.My friend almost couldn't find the door, but once in, quite impressed with the atmosphere and seemed to enjoy the glass of wine...Best wishes to Monetta White and the folks at 1300 Fillmore..the interior is very welcoming (There was a notice of an entertainment license hearing set for November 7th, 2007...same day as Yoshi's San Francisco hearing)!

kGTSc09yPmnsySAXh-reZg.review_text: As part of my Fried Chicken Quest my friends and I visited 1300 Fillmore - and we were pleased.   The space is swank, with an LA-high production feel. But the food is distinctly apart of San Francisco's food tradition.    We spoiled our appetites by having cornbread to start. Taste and texture were well-balanced although a bit dry, served with a choice of Pepper Jelly (you could taste the pepper skins) or Honey Truffle Butter (mmm).   For entries, we got Fried Chicken, Pork Chops and the Maple Syrup Seared Pork Shortribs.  The Fried Chicken: A bed of truffled mash potatoes infused the chicken, itself moist and battered in a well-seasoned batter, to give a earthy and rich taste. The batter was even better because the chicken's natural shape allowed extra pools of batter to glam together creating extra pockets of goodness.  The Shortrib was on a bed of chived mashed potatoes, which were well-seasoned, earthy and light despite the meat's heaviness. The ribs were glazed and cooked with maple syrup that was tender to the touch and flavorful.  The Porkchop was cooked very well. Served medium, the chop wasn't tough nor dry, but rather moist, warm and tender  Dessert: Beignets have a special place in my heart and 1300's ranks up there. Warm, fluffy and served with a bowl of chocolate sauce and an "Espresso Soda" with a kick that cut through the sweetness.  All in all 1300 is a winner, and currently, it's number in my Fried Chicken Quest, knocking the Blue Jay cafe and Bake Sale Betty's (which is an admittedly different creature) out of that spot.

0WcUP0kdhdx4A-L9d7mHgw.review_text: My girlfriends and I finally got to try 1300 last night as the start of our girls-night-out.  Reading some of the other reviews, I agree the decor is very soothing and upscale.  A very nice environment to dine in.  The food itself, for the price it is, wasn't the best I've ever had.  The cornbread with honey butter and jalapeno jam we started off with was so good.  Our waiter, bless his heart, very sweet, but mixed up out order and instead of mushrooms we got the shrimp and grits, which was probably the most delicious of all our dishes and we tried many.  They ran out of goat cheese so we couldn't have the special fried green tomato salad, but had an arugula salad which was tasty.  We also ordered, the Bouillabaise, which was very fishy tasting and a little bland, the Halibut, which was cooked and seasoned well, and the gnnocci, which wasn't the best we've ever had.  I am a lover of fried chicken, and while the batter and the cooking of the chicken were very authentic, it still wasn't the best fried chicken I've ever had.  It was moist and cooked well, but the batter was under-seasoned.  Fortunately, the batter was crispy and stayed crispy.  And finally, the side of mac and cheese was quite delicious.  It was made with a Bechamel base and I did feel like I was eating a gourmet mac and cheese, so that was nice.

31Q4UnPAd7WB3qQfd3ETKQ.review_text: My visits to this restaurant have consistently been met with a warm and inviting feeling, nice ambiance, and tasty drinks. The menu offers many tasty items but I must admit not all are great. My favorite item (as well as my husbands), hands down, is the shrimp and grits!! Other tasty items include the fried chicken and the ribs. However, the lamb entree did not work well with me ... felt it could have been seasoned a bit better (but was tender).  I will continue to try different items in the future since this is a nice restaurant to visit.

H-gcQo3NjAdQuyOWiq7gmQ.review_text: mmm i love soul food.. a bit on the pricier side, but the atmosphere and service are great... not to mention the food.   i love the shrimp hush puppies to start... and the short ribs are my fav. seriously, the meat is just too damn tender! love it. my friend had the fried chicken which is also delish~! try the mac and cheese for the side option.. and extra greens if you like it.   not the best soul food i've tasted, but i really like the whole experience - the food, atmosphere, drinks

eItGirsuz7QJCgFORZmh7g.review_text: By far my favorite place of all times.  The food is awesome!  The service is spectacular!   I left my doggy bag and they sent a driver to bring it to me.  They came all the way to at a night club I was at near the Marina - NOW THAT IS CUSTOMER SERVICE. The photos in the bar and sitting room are displayed magically.  There are history photos of the Filmore district.  I love the ambiance of this place.  if in town please try it - but make reservations, it is very popular.

gEx19xm2RZQo4XdobKGkWQ.review_text: i wanted to like 1300 of Fillmore a lot more but there was a bit too many misses to truly make it a great or even a very good restaurant.  the ambiance of the restaurant is top notch.  the lounge and bar area are warm and inviting with nice big comfortable chairs and the dining are is pretty big w/ all tables far enough apart from one another to give each dining party ample space.  for apps, we got the cassoulet, shrimp hush puppies and fried okra.  the girls at the table got some sides like mac and cheese, fat fries and the buttermilk chive mashed potatoes but the server messed up and brought this out w/ the main meal instead of the appetizer course.  the cassoulet was OK and not a traditional cassoulet but the pork belly was well liked.  the mac and cheese was a bit too burned.  the hush puppies weren't true hush puppies and was more a fried shrimp dish.  tasty though.  the fried okra was so-so.  for mains, people went and tried a number of things.  fried chicken, bacon wrapped beef tenderloin and risotto.  the fried chicken was very very good with the meat being nice, moist and very well flavored.  the skin was nice a crispy with a nice blend of spices.  the beef was good but nothing great and the risotto was so-so.  we got a few dessert items and thought them to be OK as well.  since i can't remember what they were says a lot.  the service was non-existent at times and our waitress, when she was around, was rude.  once again, this was a place that was on my radar for over a year and it was disappointing to see misses in the hush puppies, mac and cheese and dessert.

SCFQ71_LVOz83B5xhRsi2w.review_text: My very 1st review on this great site isn't such a great one.  Tonight I carried my overrated expectations from the great reviews I read about 1300 on Fillmore, and got a slap in the face.  I made the reservation at 7pm, and arrived with my brother and 2 of his friends at 6:50. The 3 guys are all underage so no wine for them, too bad. The bartender passed us a couple times, never asked or even looked at us. I didn't know if there was a cocktail list at all. The wait wasn't bad though, we were seated at 7 pm sharp.  As we look at the menu, the waiter asked to bring water to us. When the water arrived, he asked if we wanted anything to drink. Since I was the only person at the table who's over 21, I decided not to be the only person drinking at our table. Everything is fine up until this point, when we found out we were the only all-Asian and the youngest table in the whole place.  Once we said no drinks, it took the waiter 20 mins to come back, after we looked around trying to "cue" him to come. I didn't know if it was too loud in the restaurant, but each one of us had to repeat our order for 3 times, almost yelling the last time.  The cornbread was the best of the night. The waiter who brought the bread had a nice smile, compared to the other guy. Anyways, the appetizer (the palate and the fried shrimp) was okay, maybe again I was expecting too much. The fired chicken and the ribeye arrived as stated on the menu, 20 minutes after the appetizers were cleaned from our table.  The waiter came and asked us if the food was okay before I could take a bite, so I said everything is fine. The chicken was pretty salty, and given the price of it, I'd say I would go to Popeye's and peel the bones and serve it at home. I guess the ambience is worth $12 more. I couldn't finish it, so when the waiter came back after another 20 mins, I asked him to box the chicken.  I asked for a dessert menu, and we were to get one of those chocolate things... However, the waiter decided that even though we were one of the 5 tables left while 3 of them belonged to another waiter, he wanted to give us another 15 mins to find the dessert we wanted. So, not wanting to wait another 30 mins to finish this dinner, we didn't want the dessert anymore, and asked for the check.  The check came fairly quickly. It's been 25 mins passed since the table was cleaned, and I still hadn't seen my fried chickens in a box. I didn't want to waste my time anymore, and I was sure the waiter wasn't going to suddenly remember to bring it out to me, since we signed the bill already, so we left. It was probably going to be pointless to even ask since the chicken was probably in the garbage. This 6-dish-dinner wasn't worth the $170 we paid.  Not that I'm saying they didn't care for us being there, but that's what we felt.  I would give this place another chance in 4,5 years, when I come back as, and with a bunch of 25 year olds+ non Asian friends, who look like they will spend at least $60 more only on alcohols.

7XMf7N_3wDBANvtGkpbiAQ.review_text: Wow. Food was amazing. The Violet Fog might be the best drink I have ever had.  The wild mushroom grits were glorious. And how is it they even made ketchup taste fabulous!?   Love this place!

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: Numeric synergy: 1300 for 2000.  It was a Southern-inspired celebration. Yelp 2000 (actually #2322 with updates counted, but that doesn't work quite as well) called for a nice dinner out. 1300 did not disappoint.  Food (very good) and service (warm and friendly though the food took its sweet time) aside, I like 1300 for what it signals to the neighborhood. Revival. Acknowledging history. Trying to turn things around.  And by dining here you support it. Fortunately support means such good eats as creamy mushroom grits. And maple braised short ribs (not mine, neighbors, who loved it). And catfish on a bed of sausage and shrimp jambalaya (mine, also loved).  Not as heavy and rich as expected, which meant we rallied for dessert. A few bites into the caramelized apple bread pudding and banana cream pie with a caramel lime sauce we knew the rally was worth it. Save room, both were outstanding.  Space evokes the heritage of the neighborhood. There are photos of jazz musicians. Live jazz adds the perfect ambiance to the lounge. The dining room is spacious with a dark wood atheistic. Nicely done.  Yelp 2000 or something else entirely, 1300 is a worthy place to celebrate.

R-gESyPKw7Sy_4Dbzlvw1A.review_text: The decor is amazing and stepping through the doors gives a great feel and would be a great place to meet for drinks.  The bar is stunning.  The food had it's moments, went with a party of 5 of which we had a couple of non-eaters.    The table cornbread is good, but slather on the jalepano jam and you have one hell of a treat.  Hard to go back to just bread and butter.    Started off with the mac n' cheese, warm poached egg salad and bbq shrimp with grits.  Mac n' cheese was the highlight of the 3, the egg salad didn't have much substance to it, tasty but nothing too exciting and the shrimp and grits were good on their own, but combined didn't do it for us.  One of the non-eaters ordered the oyster bisque as the entree and it was terrible-too garlicky and way too sweet, no hint of oyster whatsoever.  Others ordered the short-rib, that at times was dry, tasteless and almost standard.  The boneless fried chicken was awesome, both dark and white meat were juicy, tender, well seasoned and gets props for keeping me classy with my fork and knife.   No room for dessert since we kept pounding the cornbread, but did look good.  Service was decent, but when asked to pack the leftover cornbread, they forgot and sent us on our way.  Oh well, next time I'll have to bring my own bag.

EECn_fIduYT1QsuKuhggOw.review_text: Never been to a restaurant where they take your reservations and still make you wait 35 minutes!!! 25 dollars for fried chicken? Really? The best? Really? I do not think so! If people think that this is the best fried chicken in town, then they need to get out more. I've had far better chicken for a lot cheaper! High end soul food? More like over priced soul food! Although I like the ambiance of the place, it lacks the delivery in good food.

b1Iu7lgKqMB6i-6-bXjmfQ.review_text: great service and really good southern style food. Great space.

vqKY7OTAM4qvVvxbnGpQ3A.review_text: Good but LOUD!!!  If you want to catch up with some friends you haven't seen in a while or you and your honey want to have a nice romantic cozy dinner, this probably isn't the place for you. It's way TOO LOUD to have a decent conversation at least on a Friday night. I have said it before but it bears repeating. ENOUGH WITH THE LOUD RESTURANTS!  I mean I shouldn't have to scream at my friends just to be a part of the conversation and they also agreed that the volume was one of the loudest they had experienced in a long time.  Did I mention that their was no jazz performance at the time of our dinner so I can only imagine the volume during a jazz session.   The food is very tasty but I was so distracted trying to keep up with the conversation that I think missed out on really savoring the food. The decor is also quite beautiful and is worth a second look. Great drinks too...Jazz berry....oh baby...make me another.   It is certainly worth a try but maybe on a Wed. or Thurs. so you can enjoy your meal and the conversation.

QM2t0ran-7RLZXhd0nX4ug.review_text: Cornbread & jalapeño jelly, shrimp & grits, and chicken definitely are delicious. Great spot for special occasions and date nights.

ch46FyfmASh0XnnkA8YE0Q.review_text: Nice place. I miss the finer dining experiences that school doesn't afford me.  I would definitely recommend the short ribs. OMG no knife necessary. You can use the butter knife to manage the bone as you gently lift the meat away. It is soooo tender and falls right off! Oh, presentation was great! But it didn't last long, for me. I had to dig in. Did I mention that the meat just fell off the bone? With no effort, that bone was CLEAN! That meant no sucking the bone dry, but that probably wouldn't have been appropriate there? Yeah, it came with mashed potatoes and onion rings. They were tasty, but that's just filler. The meat was freaking yummy!  The grilled tenderloin of beef was alright. Not as tender. More dry and a teeeeeeensy bit tough (mind you the toughness and juiciness is now being compared to the short ribs, which really ruined any comparison). The short ribs won that round by a long shot.  Also tried the barbecue shrimp with creamy grits.  Doesn't that just sound intriguing?  And it was!  I wouldn't order it again next time, but that's only because it spiked my taste buds and curiosity, and now I really want to try the other appetizers, too.    I wish I saw the wine list, but I was driving, and I didn't want to tempt myself. =( bum deal  As for the restaurant itself?  They were busy for a wednesday!  I couldn't really hear the jazz playing in the background, but when I strained, I could. It would have been nice to hear it, but that means gotta go on a slower night.  Ah, and the table wasn't stable. It was definitely a lean-two....two must lean to balance it out. But I didn't complain because I was in a highly entertained mood, and it was adding to my entertainment.  As was our server. We had a freakin awesome server. He was super helpful and had a good sense of humor, even when he thought we were laughing at him and took forever to explain that we were laughing at our own silliness.

-ANqJ2lHAGm4jYNGPTR6PQ.review_text: Disappointing food quality, service, and experience.

_WUo7P4YtQi9fj_957fYzQ.review_text: With all the hype it's been getting, my friend and I finally decided to give it a shot. What can go wrong with a little French twist on soul food right?   We met on a Tuesday evening and to my surprise, the restaurant was not that busy. (Was this a sign?)  Our server was pleasant though at times intrusive. He interrupted our busy catch-up session several times, which I found mildly bothersome. Since it had been awhile since we'd seen each other, we wanted to take our time with the meal.  On to the food. My appetizer was delicious. An oyster bisque with fried okra and creme fraiche. It was rich and tangy. Perfect start for me.   The entree was where the problem came in. My fried chicken was tasty, but not mind blowing. But my friend's Bouillabaisse was awful!  All the ingredients were incredibly overcooked. The scallop was solid all the way through.  When we sent the dish back, they did not offer a re-cook or new order but was nice enough to take care of it on the bill for us. One time place for me. Worth a visit for jazzy deco and lounge.   Stop by to grab a drink before heading next door to Yoshi's.

A_v3R-ViSSTdonogrg8TKg.review_text: I was planning a going away dinner for my roommate and we live right across the street from this new place, so we decided to check it out.   We had a big party of 14, and they accommodated us with a long (Knights of the Roundtable like) table in a pseudo private room.  Originally it was opened to the dining room, but since we were getting a bit rowdy, they closed the sliding door and curtain, and it made for a great private room where we could be as obnoxious as we wanted.    As for the food, I really enjoyed the stuff I ordered.  The complimentary cornbread with honey butter and pepper jelly (put them together) was amazing and I couldn't stop eating it (and they kept it coming!).  The braised pork belly appetizer was incredibly tender, and whatever was underneath it (mashed potatoes or leeks?) complimented it well.  I also shared the shrimp hush puppies with some spicy aioli, and those were pretty good as well.  For the entree, my roomie and I shared the mashed potato's and short ribs, which we really enjoyed.  The ribs just fell off the bone and were super tender and flavorful.  Unfortunately my buddy who ordered the other pork dish, was very unimpressed.  I also tasted the lamb, mac'n'cheese and lobster bouillabaisse.  The bouillabaisse was different cause it was more like seafood plate with sauce, but it was good none the less.  Lamb was a bit dry, but good, and mac and cheese was awesome and I will def. order it next time around.  The one thing no one liked was the cabbage salad, so I would stay clear of that.    The wine list was pretty good, though the by the glass selection wasn't extensive.  I had a bottle of the pinot gris, which was a good deal for $28.  The only beers they had was an IPA and Pilsner (draft) but the boys at the table seemed to enjoy them.  I also got the bananas foster for dessert, and it was pretty good, though I was stuffed at that point.    Service was pretty fast, especially considering our large party and we couldn't complain there at all.  Prices are standard for a nice place (entrees around 25, appetizers 8-10) and there's a lot of street parking.  They have a bar menu that goes till 1am if you're looking for snacks and a night cap.    Overall, this place is more upscale than I expected and is classing up Western Addition/Lower Pac Heights.  I didn't really hang at the bar area, but it looked nice and mellow.  Once Yoshi's opens up in a few weeks, it will be nice to finally offer my neighborhood  to my friends as a place to get a nice meal, some drinks and some jazz.

Kmrxlnndu3zvB8e6wnboQw.review_text: I came here for Happy Hour in the sitting bar area with nice big chairs and comfy couches.  The decor is beautiful, the food was great (especially the sliders!), and the cocktails were strong 'n tasty as they ought to be.  The best part of it all, though, was the PRICE!  Nothing, absolutely NOTHING, makes me happier than 1/2-off drinks and appetizers.  Even so, I'm willing to shell out the extra bucks to have a sit-down dinner here in their main dining room.

BtOPYCQgOI9HM8gPCSyffw.review_text: 1300 MISTAKES.  Well, at least it felt like it.  I really should have written the review after the dinner. I'm all for chi chi poo poo experience, but for the most part, the food backs it up.  I can't think of anything good about the experience. 4 out of 12 entrees we're returned. The wait staff was inattentive and aloof. The food was not hot, maybe sat waiting too long.   Save your money and spend it somewhere else.

txvgzVJIv7kyHNnyZWUFDA.review_text: "The best fried chicken I've ever had" - friend  I love fried chicken and I wanted to believe so bad. Perhaps it was the insanely high expectations. Perhaps it was from filling up on all the delicious cornbread. While the fried chicken was great, I can't endorse it as the best I've ever had.  On the positive side, it's extremely flavorful, to the point where it's borderline salty. You can tell the chicken was brined for a long time. The outside has a nice soft crunch of a chicken fried with generous amounts of care and shortening on a cast iron skillet. Just like mom would make it... if mom were from the American South. While I can't say it was dry, I would have preferred it taken off the grill just a tad bit earlier.  I'd put the fried chicken in a tie for third place for fried chicken in San Francisco, right up there with Hard Knox. Maverick's gets the nod at number two on my list, and Brenda's is number one (drool....).  The side dishes at 1300 were hit and miss. The cornbread and accompanying jalapeno jam and honey butter were excellent. The grits were also fantastic, which paired fantastically with the combination of shrimp and gravy over the grits. The fried okra was okay. The mac and cheese (one of my favorite foods) I'm sorry to say, should have been a pass; there was no truffle flavor, I found it way too oily, and to each his own, but I'm not a huge fan of bleu cheese in mac and cheese, even in small doses.  It's a beautiful, well decorated, very handsome space inside, but you'd never know it from the outside.  Props on the spot on service and the great drinks at the bar. Old Fashioned with Russell's 10 Yr was a winner. Definitely coming back for drinks at the lounge and to take in some live jazz.

82dCHyU-ANOgdhxUgZsUeg.review_text: I grabbed some dinner here before a show at Yoshi's (Brian McKnight). Since it's located in a busy area and it looks nice inside, I was expecting the placed to be more packed. Alas, it wasn't at all on a Saturday night during dinnertime so I want to say that you probably don't need reservations here unless you're in a huge party and want to be sure to get a table.  The food was pretty delicious. I tried these items: 1) barbecue shrimp n' grits  2) black skillet fried chicken buttermilk whipped potatoes, pan gravy chive herb biscuits I recommend getting either of these. The chicken was tender and the grits were buttery goodness. I'm no soul food expert, but I think I've had enough around the southern US to deem the food here good.  I had the sweet tea cocktail which was pretty tasty, but like most times, it's a small amount of fluid for a ~$10. Probably not the best place to splurge on alcohol--there are cheap bars close by (Boom Boom Room).  I wish there was live music while I was there around 6:00PM--probably too early. The lounge that you see when walking in looks really nice. If I ever come here just for drinks, it would be cool to hang out in that room. Generally, the furniture and decor is very elegant and lighting is romantic.  Service was good, the experience was smooth, the food was on point and filling. I would recommend checking this joint out before a show at Yoshi's or if you can't get a table at State Bird Provisions right away.  Is it rude that for any restaurant I review around State Bird Provisions, I say something about not getting a table right away at SBP to go to this secondary place?

G-gO4g3cSF_OqCU9m_itPw.review_text: I made a reservation and upon arriving the host told us our table was not ready but to have a seat in this little area where there are couches, but also other people eating at two top tables. About thirty minutes after sitting down a girl came by and told us our table was ready. We followed her back to the host area and are told by the host the table is not actually ready, and we're just left standing there awkwardly.   Ok, so fast forward, we're finally seated and are given no menus. The waiter appears and asks us why we have no menus as if we would know. The table we were sat at was near the bar area which has clear glass and there were tons of people pressed up against the glass staring at us while we ate. I was completely uncomfortable. I ordered the fried chicken with mashed potatoes. The chicken was dry and flavorless, Popeye's has better fried chicken than this place.   Our table was not far from the host station and the "chef"/manager was speaking to the host telling them to "take care of" a couple who had just arrived. This chef/host was the same individual who asked us what we were doing standing awkwardly waiting to be sat after we were told our table was ready and it wasn't. This guy looked like a piece of work walking around the restaurant wearing a chef's outfit trying to look important.   What was really interesting is that after we placed our order we never saw our waiter again. The bus boy then miraculously became the waiter. I asked him for a to go box and he took my plate to box it up and was supposed to bring the box back. The bus boy then also disappeared and a woman approached our table apologizing about our waiter disappearing and explained he had an emergency. We had already paid and I was waiting for my to go box and had to ask someone else to track it down. This was an awful experience. Usually a restaurant will have off service or off food but not typically both at the same time. In this case it was terrible food and terrible service. This place left an awful taste in my mouth. I would not recommend it to anyone and I would not return.

ZBK27WKYiR6EHS1upQ8TuA.review_text: My girlfriend took me here for my birthday.  We were a bit early for our reservation, so we thought we would get a drink and appetizer while we were waiting.  We ordered 2 dirty Martini's and the lamb sliders in the lounge and since it was still happy hour the appetizers were half price.  There was a nice onion relish on sliders and they were tasty, but I was glad they were half price as the lamb was about the diameter of a silver dollar and if I paid full price I would have to fork over 9 of them (dollars that is) for an order of 3 sliders.  The Martini's were good, but they were small given the fact they were $14 each (can't figure out the $2 charge to be served up).  On to dinner.  We got seated quickly and our waiter was professional and attentive.  I ordered the smoked rib special which was served with the mac and cheese and my girlfriend ordered the prix fix menu with a citrus fennel salad, crispy skin salmon with sweet potato risotto, followed by an apple cobbler.  I asked how they smoked the ribs in the restaurant and the waiter told me they do it early in the morning in the restaurant.  My girlfriend's salad was quite good.  On to the entrees-the salmon was very good, but the risotto was not risotto at all, it was creamy potato cubes.  We asked the waiter what it was and he stated it was the chef's "take" on risotto.  I don't know what others expect, but I am thinking creamy arborio rice laced with a mashed sweet potato mixture.  My advice is if you are going to serve an interpretation of a dish, you should put it in quotes and explain what you are serving.  The "smoked" ribs were a bit dry but overall not bad, although a bit bland.  Having lived in the midwest for a number of years, I have had considerable experience with ribs.  They were not tender enough and did not taste smokey, and definitely lacked the nice pink ring on the outer edge of the meat.  THERE IS NO WAY THESE RIBS ARE SMOKED.  It was a good thing I ordered the full rack because there were 4 forkfulls of Mac and Cheese.  On to dessert.  My girlfriend got her prix fix dessert and on the plate was written happy bithday!    Overall, I give the food a 3 as well as the service, but the food and service coupled with what I believe to be EXTREMELY overpriced for the quality.  If you charge $35 for a rack of smoked ribs...they should be smoked.

pBMfwaiCkB_VO-lpie1XBw.review_text: I would like to preface this by saying that I moved to the Bay Area from the South - and not the fake South like Texas, Virginia, or Atlanta, Georgia - the real South, from a city largely famous for its food, in fact.  When I read the menu of 1300 on Fillmore on their website my fiance and I both said, "We have to go there."   Reservation at 6:45, got seated right away. I walked in and LOVED the decor. It was totally unique, dark, and lucious. The lounge was full and the front 1/3 of the restaurant was too (it filled up to about 3/4 by the time we were finished).  We were seated by a nice host and had the most delightful waiter (ask for Jonothon, he's adorable). We were immediately BLOWN AWAY by the delicious corn bread triangles and honey butter. They also give you jalapeño jelly which the waiter assistant assured us was not spicey and it wasn't, but it was very tasty, however I devoured the honey butter because - hello - honey butter! We finished two helpings and had to force ourselves to not say yes when we were asked if we wanted more. It wasn't just, "good for San Francisco" good corn bread - it was good for anywhere corn bread, for real.   I'm a total grits snob and have been severly disappointed/disgusted by the grits I've had in California. I refer to these typical runny, flavorless grits as "California grits" (I'm clever). When we ordered the Barbecue Shrimp and Grits the waiter applauded our selection, and I couldn't help but mention my hesitation due to my Southern-food-bitchness, then I explained "California grits" to him. He was adament that they are not "California grits".   These grits were unlike any grits I'd had before - they were stiff (which is good) but still juicy (which is awesome) with the right consistency. The fancy yummy barbecue flavored sauce I could've lived without since I love the grit flavor, but it was still delicious. And my fiance, a shrimp lover, couldn't get enough of the plump shrimp.  After the appetizer I asked the adorable waiter if the chef was from the South - turns out he was born in Jamaica, lived in England a lot of his life, then moved to San Francisco. Fascinating! The waiter told us a lot more about how the chef came to cook Southern inspired food and I was just delighted.   Then the waiter said chef David Lawrence was floating around the restaurant and he'd send him over. I was kind of like, "Yeah sure he'll come over, but it's nice of you to pretend" A few minutes later, the chef came to our table with a smile and chatted with us. It was just so nice!  My fiance got the fried chicken which came with whipped potatoes and delicious little biscuits. It was too spicey for my liking but definitely well made. I had...just...HEAVEN on a plate. I'm not a big non-poultry meat eater but decided to try the Maple Syrup Slow Braised Beef Short Rib. It was so succulent and tender - it's last meal good, there's no other way to put it.  Stuffed and ready to die, we sat and digested and made ourselves push through to dessert (and I loved that they don't ask if you want to see the dessert menu, they just give it). Though the decision was tough, we went with the pineapple bread pudding (which made me go say what? when I saw it on the menu) with coconut ice cream on top and a delicious cherry sauce with big halves of cherries around the edge of the plate. It was a perfect little dessert. Absolutely delicious and just enough.   Honestly, the dining experience could not have been better and I am a tough customer, I admit.  My fiance and I decided that this could be the perfect place to have our rehearsal dinner - that's how much we loved our experience! As we were walking out the chef told us goodbye and shook my hand, and I told him about us wanting to have our rehearsal dinner there. He seemed genuinely pleased and excited that we enjoyed the restaurant so much and told us he'd love to have us!  They have a private room for parties but when I told him how much I liked the decor in the main room he said, "Well we'll just reserve the back half for you then!" Awesome.

JaM6R4V9ssFP5k27JJUmpw.review_text: 4 Stars for brunch atmosphere and live music.  Although not completely gospel music as advertised, we had a great Easter Sunday brunch.  Bottomless Pimosas were fabulous, service pretty good and the food just okay.  Growing up in the South, I've had my fair share of shrimp and grits, fried chicken and cobbler.  Not on par with some of the dishes I've had over the years but the overall experience was worth the visit.

Wmx35wh-_dt8cjjDmDsGtA.review_text: YES.   Great appetizers, great salads, great entrees, great desserts and great drinks! Seriously yummy.  please check out my food blog for a full review with photos!

5UyQ-1mzlHZgAJDroaFl_A.review_text: Damn good happy hour!  Cheap wines.. even prosecco!  Their apps are half off and they are really good.  The servers are super chill, which I love.  Their lounge is super comfy and the atomsphere is just great.  We came here before going to a concert and I will definitely be back to try their brunch.  Overall.. I love the area and love love love the restaurant.  It is somewhere you can definitely hang out for hours without feeling rushed.

OTz5U2rzRfyaZhV_LwKzXg.review_text: Went with a group of 6 before Count Basie at Yoshi's.  We were blown away as soon as we walked in the door.  Amazing decor - sexy, jazzy, upscale, but still comfortable.  The lounge has a great feel, with old-time photos on the wall.   Our waiter did a great job guiding us to the "hush puppies" (more like shrimp tempura), fried chicken (best i've ever had... boneless), macaroni & cheese and even brusell sprouts, which were so good they've made me reconsider the species!  Others at the table were raving about the short ribs.  We skipped the wine list, since they offered a reasonable $15 corkage. Best restaurant I've been to in ages - my new gold standard in SF!

RhUQ1Vz3-bDMLbIGlcyzfA.review_text: 1300 on Fillmore is a great addition to the neighborhood -- classy, upscale, rich, and swanky.  It's brining up the average just in time for Yoshi's.  The food is great, the wine list is well-priced and fun to read, and the servers are really "on it."  1300 on Fillmore has a cool vibe with upscale clientele.  Reminds me of Bix without so much attitude.  Can't wait until they get their entertainment license.  It'll be a geat place to take in some good jazz while partaking of their excellent food.

dnIeFi2EK_aOEbg19ADWvA.review_text: The best comfort food in town! I chose the dine about town option. The portion is good. I really love the corn bread, which were served warm!!! They have an extensive menu of wines, cocktails but too bad I drove there. I love the rock snapper entree that I got with the dine about town. It was perfectly cooked with layers of flavors. The dessert was the amazing apple cobbler, which was freshly made with vanilla bean ice cream.   Besides the great food and lively ambiance in the restaurant, I have to compliment the customer service! I wasn't feeling well so my bf asked for warm water. Our waiter got it right away and got me some slices of lemon. Also, since I love their corn bread so much, I asked to pack the last piece of corn bread to go. Our waiter packed the last piece as requested and even threw in two more pieces of freshly made corn bread! I was very happy walking out of the restaurant!

IbStExJUL_Alfcylu-8FCQ.review_text: this place is just fantastic, we went here a few weeks ago with a friend from out of town and we drank and ate til we were just stuffed.  If you go please try the watermelon scallop dish, and the bbq shrimp grits, and you just have to wait for the fried chicken it is just to die for, and it will probably kill you with all that grease.  This is a great place in a fairly dodgy neighborhood, but it is getting better and thank god for that, i hope and wish that more places that this spring up in this neighborhood.

Bs6fYv-bwNIuGNYEhvRKOA.review_text: Nice ambience, good wine, but food quality was not really on par with what I expected at the price level. Had ribs (the special), ribs were dry, coleslaw and mac and cheese sides were tasteless.  Others in our party had ok food, but again not really good value for the money.

TVJoa1isoHj02_iToGaXcA.review_text: I can't say I'm one of those people who looks for healthy food when I go out to eat. I know what I'm signing up for and I happily accept it. So, imagine my surprise when I discovered 1300 Fillmore had somehow managed to find a healthy and delicious way to make fried chicken.   Given that I'm a rabid red meat eater, the chicken was my friend's dish. I had the steak on blue cheese grits. Now, I'm not even a big fan of grits, but the flavor and consistency of the blue cheese coupled with the texture of the grits was perfect. Add a big slab of meat of top of that and you've just made my night. On a side, but just as important, note, try their mixed drinks..delicious.   Also, the ambiance of this place is noteworthy. Look to one side and you'll see your typical SF yuppie couple, look to the other and you'll see a swank, elderly couple depicting the bluesy vibe this restaurant gives off. It's a great place to people watch while enjoying a good meal.   The only reason I would give it 4 stars is because this place is horrible for groups. They made us wait for almost an hour and a half because they didn't want to tell the people at the table we were supposed to be at to leave. A sweet gesture..for them maybe, but they could have just as easily offered to buy them a round of drinks in return for moving to the bar/lounge area. We mentioned this to them but for whatever reason they didn't want to do this. They seemed to have feigned remorse about the situation and only after demanding that the manager act like he cared did he do so.   So, my recommendation - Go in a small group, order, in this order, a cocktail, the steak then the chicken, enjoy the bluesy ambiance and crowd and, if you want to make a night of it, go to a show at Yoshi's next door afterwards.

0ZvvFyeLM8wzRm_CX21UDw.review_text: My friend Jamie showed me the way to this amazing place before I left SF.  Great ambiance with great JAZZ vibes/art work.  Wine list is GREAT, and FOOD is even better.  The GRITS are a MUST and they are willing create it to your liking.  And the Banana's Foster for dessert is AMAZING!!!!!

DyLBl58MFqihQAPch0vilg.review_text: Skip the fried chicken, get the short ribs instead. This place is supposed to be known for its fried chicken, and while it certainly was tasty, it was nowhere near mindblowing. People may hate on me for this...but 1300 has nothing on KFC when it comes to chicken! The meat was mostly moist but the skin had no crunchie crispness to it - perhaps from sitting out too long before being served to our table.   On the other hand, the maple syrup slow braised beef short ribs were done to perfection. The meat tenderly fell apart at the slightest touch of the fork, and came with a generous helping of chive mashed potatoes and three delicate deep fried onion rings. If you're looking for a side to try, pick the caramelized sweet onion ham hock braised greens. It was suggested to us by our waitress and absolutely exploding with flavor.  Overall, good food, live music, sleek decor. Come here for DAT or a special occasion.

VVCHWev0ejvlh6Z6ErGr_A.review_text: Very mediocre.  We went with high hopes after seeing the plug for this place in a recent Food and Wine magazine.  The atmosphere is nice, especially the bar area, but the service was mediocre (the waiter could be intrusive at times) and the food was more misses than hits.  We started out with the cornbread, which honestly was the best part of the evening.  We also shared a fried green tomato salad that lacked any spark, an arugula salad which was quite nice, shrimp and grits with over-cooked shrimp and bland grits, the fried chicken which was dry, mac and cheese which was globular, and a very nice dessert of chocolate beignets.  Despite a few nice bites, overall the 3 of us left feeling very disappointed considering the money we dropped.  The Elite cafe further up Fillmore has better food at a better value.

n0j_WX6RxpHUBsaeoLcjXg.review_text: I hate to say this (because the place looks awesome and service is excellent) but the fried chicken was a disappointment.   It seems they removed the bone and all the flavor from the chicken, because it was extremely bland.  The batter tasted weird too, not sure what herbs they used but it did not help.  The fries were good tho.  Next time, I'd go two blocks down to the KFC, or to Popeyes (mmmm....) or even Farmer Brown (cringe)....

0AlnetQ_-a4f7kY0Sker2w.review_text: Susan loved her (second) birthday dinner.  Susan's pork chop with grits & greens was served by a sweet waiter in a beautiful restaurant with a great cocktail.  Susan's taste buds savored a moment in paradise.  Susan's stomach was sad it couldn't hold any more.    Susan also enjoyed writing her first review in the third-person in a while.

_Ie6aS62erzbMO_BbLMFrg.review_text: We were VERY pleased with our experience at 1300. Things got off to a rocky start when our cocktail waitress didn't know what rye was (no joke), but she recovered quickly and everything was perfect thereafter. The lounge, by the way, is beautifully designed (as is the rest of the place), and it's now definitely on my list of places to stop by for a drink.  We had amazingly attentive and thoughtful service the entire night. Really spot on. Surprising for opening week, as well. The food itself was delicious, intriguing, well plated without being fussy. Totally satisfying. Apps we had were pork belly (truly divine, and the table favorite), shrimp and gritz (simple, perfectly cooked and satisfying), "poached egg salad" which was a warm cabbage salad served on rye crostini with a poached egg on top (surprising combo and a definite must for gourmands). Last app was shrimp hushpuppies. Everybody loved them, but they were straight-up hush puppies, nothing exciting.  Main dishes were also strong, all cooked perfectly. Short ribs, jambalaya, seared black bass and fried chicken. The fried chicken was great: juicy chicken wrapped around sturdy, crunchy batter. Yumm. The jamabalaya was served in a shallow bowl without much broth, which sounds disappointing but was actually a great move. You really got to appreciate all the different fish, sausage and other flavors. Short ribs were an interesting cut I'm not familiar with. Only one bone; lots of meat. A little more dense and not as fatty as the short ribs I'm accustomed to, but it was damn tasty. The black bass was the most simple and lightest entree, served with grilled artichoke hearts and something else like a ramp or leek or something in that family. Table thought the bass was boring, but I was really appreciated the light, flavorful fish cooked perfectly, with a tasty seasoning on the skin.  Dessert we ordered chocolate beignet and sweet potato souffle. The former: not as good as Brenda's on Polk, but tasty in their own way. Came with a coffee sauce that they could've left off. Souffle was a little light on flavor, but ever so fluffy and came with these little pieces of candied sweet potato on the side that were truly inspired.  Would definitely go again, and have been raving about it and recommending it to all my friends.

hYIX-Hh1jMWb__EJ3Vwwfw.review_text: 1300 Fillmore is one of my two favorite spots in the city for fried chicken (the other being Town Hall). If forced to choose, I might give the slight edge to Town Hall, but the styles are very similar and delightfully pleasing, regardless.  I find this to be one of the most elegant restaurants in San Francisco - the decor is an excellent reflection of the district's jazz history. Service is smooth and friendly. And if parking gets you down, there seem to now be more lot options than the $14 Yoshi's valet next door - yikes.

87JTyKAl7nJUEp3U1_OT3A.review_text: you must have the mushroom dish with truffle oil grits. best grits to ever touch my tongue.  mmmm.

mLJPd4jqQkGPeb8ASp0Xsg.review_text: I REALLY REALLY REALLY WANT TO LOVE THIS PLACE. I actually do...just not the food :( service 5 stars, jazz art wall 5 stars (one of my favorite walls), music 5 stars, food *pause* maybe 1 star....maybe it was an off night for them because I've been here before and the food was delicious...granted that was over a year ago :(...

EK9hrg3OVV9KS6qLbMFvsg.review_text: Yep I was here last night too, right before the ConFunkshun show at Yoshi's which is practically next door.  Beautiful place, great food and I had two of the BEST dirty martini's ever.  Really really had a good time and the waitstaff is SUPER.  The hostess greets with a beautiful smile, our waiter was charming and right on time.  Even the guy who brought the water was completely professional and SMILES not distracted, just a wonderful experience.   I can not wait to bring other people ...wonderful.

ib-vUU5hvckrGSQqlJ1VYg.review_text: So-so, uninspiring food, way overpriced. Stuffy atmosphere. Not cool. Meah

Bp-TQEtc6Vs6ldnLgjqglg.review_text: incredibly warm service, very intimate interior with an abundance of chocolate colors and steel; this is a place for lovers, quiet conversations or a group of your best friends who want something comforting yet a cut above the usual soul food restaurants.  my friend and i made reservations for the friday evening after thanksgiving and the dining room was half empty at 8:00pm. we headed to the ultra cool lounge/bar for a glass of scotch and talked a bit with our bartender who was attentive, but kept himself busy stocking and cleaning even though it was a rather slow evening.  fresh cornbread with butter and red pepper jam was dropped at our table upon arrival, and the server was extremely helpful in her recommendations. we decided to do a sampling of the appetizers: squeezing in a combo of the foie gras, braised pork belly and shrimp hushpuppies. i loved the pork belly; the meat was so tender, i was cutting it with my fork. the shrimp hushpuppies were a terrific idea, but could have been excellent if the shrimp were a tad bit fresher and didn't have the slight taste of being pulled from a freezer. the foie gras was nice, but i felt it lacked depth i felt like i was tasting an adulterated version of the real deal. the toasts which accompanied the foie gras had too much butter which left a thick coat on my fingertips.   the wine selection was decent, and went very well with the food; i had a glass of cuvaison with the meal.   one word of advice: if you're on a diet or plan on sticking to "healthful" alternatives, you may want to reconsider coming here. between the two of us and sampling 3 appetizers, i left there mighty full and satisfied. the food is richrichrich.

ZIR96Kh35GvW2eLyQHJh1Q.review_text: At long last I've been to 1300 on Fillmore and was quite impressed. Elegant decor matched with friendly hands-off service along with tasty food made it worth the prices.   Iced tea was a bit blah, but with a generous addition of simple syrup, was  much more potable. Fresh corn bread with honey butter was yummy as was the gem salad with toasted pecans and goddess dressing. The 20-minute wait for the fried chicken and mashed potatoes was worth it, although I could have done without the gravy made with red peppers. Icky. My nana's cream gravy would have been better. Skipped dessert as I was too full, but the homemade chocolate chip cookies with vanilla ice cream was tempting.

QGEa0LrCsv0XZu_Iq1HPTg.review_text: Had a great dinner @ 1300 this weekend.  I've heard good things, but this place was even better than I expected!  We went all out and ordered shrimp and grits to start and a side order of mac and cheese.  Fried chicken as a main and wow... (granted, I can't remember the last time I had fried chicken prepared by anyone other than Colonel Sanders, but this was the most deliciously decadent meal I've enjoyed in a while!).  The hostess very accommodating (I had called earlier in the day to change my res from 2 people to 4). Hat's off to 1300!

MbJbdgr_ft3rjiFC1sju1Q.review_text: Good location and decor inside but I am not a fan of the food.  My fried chicken tasted funny and my side order of fries had a similar taste.  Maybe it was the oil they fried everything in?  However the macaroni and cheese was very good.  The food came out promptly and the service was good but I probably won't eat here again unless it's another mandatory birthday dinner.

AqwTAjoyG5HfhQi2-ab4cw.review_text: I was forewarned that the food here is average at best and they were right. I do love the decor here, though. And the cocktails were excellent.  I tried their burger and it was terrible. It wasn't hot, not juicy (I ordered it medium rare) and just bland. I tried a bite of my friend's fried chicken and it was surprisingly good, though. We also shared the mac and cheese, which was too thin and small portions.  I would just come here for drinks and listen to the live jazz. Skip the over priced and underwhelming food.

bFOx4POcWSyC_ltemq27jg.review_text: I love the pork belly, rib entree, and side car - I love fatty meat (to eat, not on people) and robust cocktais. Here, I get exactly what I want. Overall, the food here is consistently good and dependable (and they have much more than just fatty meat and strong cocktails).  I adore the ambience here. 1300 On Fillmore offers oldskool glamour mixed with urban-hip elements (note: not the Mission "hipster" type hip). It's stylish and upscale yet comfortable.  It makes me feel glamourous - like, um, Asian Diana Ross!  Hey!

7nXSYT0_GSc9vQw4xf4a4g.review_text: I am actually shocked at the positive reviews this restaurant has received. I made my decision to make a reservation for dinner there based on the positive Yelp reviews and we walked out mid-meal because the food and drinks were terrible.  Let me start by saying our waitress was very professional and pleasant. She was polite when I asked for the check and said that I had changed my mind and wanted to go somewhere else.  I cant say the same for the food or drinks though. We ordered two cocktails off the menu, and both tasted like something you would get at your neighborhood dive bar. There was no sophistication to the drinks whatsoever. For the prices they charge I think I deserved a fresh lime wedge on my margarita. Instead, it was one of those lime wedges that looked like it had been cut the night before and left out to dry. The drinks were strong but kind of gross. Anyway, even though the drinks sucked what was worse was the food.  We ordered appetizers and entrees but asked for the check immediately after the appetizers arrived so we didn't end up trying their entrees. The deviled eggs were okay, but nothing out of this world. The oysters on the other hand were DISGUSTING. I cannot forgive a restaurant that serves anything from the sea that isn't fresh. The oysters were anything but fresh. We managed to eat 3 of them, and coupled with the underwhelming eggs and nasty drinks we asked for the check and left our food and drinks almost untouched.  A restaurant that prides itself on elevated dining but offers subpar food and crappy drinks will not get another visit from me. We left and finished our dinner somewhere else.  If you are looking for an elevated dining experience, 1300 is so far off its almost sad.

V5OHkE7QACOzYSV1TxIHSw.review_text: I found this restaurant and lounge by a lucky chance! I was in need of a quiet place for a group dinner with wifi accessible. After the intended restaurant we stopped at didn't keep their wifi on past 5pm, a new place was needed.   Just walking into 1300 on Fillmore was a pleasure. There drinks where delicious! I got the aviation and a zesty orange, both were amazing! I got their macaroni dish, and it was incredible! We sat in some comfy chairs and couches, while dining and working away.   I will defiantly be going again soon! XOXO

tQgyeDEUd9RwuQrAmUQyYQ.review_text: Came here for my boyfriends birthday. I don't have a lot of money but its nice to go out somewhere fancy on special occasions. I had high expectations for this place. I wanted oysters and steak and delicious cocktails. But it sucked. The oysters tasted delicious but for $15 you only get six, which I guess is common in the area. The chicken liver mousse deviled eggs had a horrible color palette and the taste was a little off. Then the steaks. The $30 steaks. While they were cooked perfectly they were not seasoned. They were topped with brie, which in the culinary world, adding dairy to something as already awesome as a rib eye means you are masking something and it was horrible. The meat was tough. Im a sucker and just said everything was fine and got out of there as quickly as possible. So depressing. Never going back. And its possible that other items on the menu are better but im so disappointed. My only experiences in san fran dining so far have been over priced and horrid. Going back to Seattle for some real flavor.

Iv09JxxupYrmzGAqFWaSjQ.review_text: Upscale martini bar. Dark wood and decor feels like days gone by without feeling old and worn out.   The drinks are creative and fun. I didn't try the food but it's a great place for a drink for sure.

Tb3hVSr9RqEYXLIk4rrMUg.review_text: Best Fried Chicken, ribs, corn bread, Best customer service. Very good ambient Reasonable price for what you get. Nothing more needs to be said.

WJ8hvqTQ5GWIM6LpUFdosA.review_text: Came here Friday night with a group of friends for a b-day celebration. The decor was very sleek and modern, and the cocktail drinks are nice and strong. As the group waited for our table (a delay of a hour beyond our reservation time), we couldn't fend off our hunger pangs any longer and ordered a slew of appetizers, such as fries, shrimp hushpuppies, and warm poached egg salad.   When we were finally seated, we ordered more of the hushpuppies (probably the best thing there). Hubby ordered the (overpriced) fried chicken, while I ordered the (overcooked) ribeye steak. After sampling our friend's (average) entrees, I came away from dinner (barely) satisfied.

wkAl7GleLMb-UQbNK3GNQQ.review_text: I find dining experiences in which you have no prior information(preconceptions and potential biases) usually the most rewarding regardless of the outcome. You may leave with some degree of disappointment or perhaps, you may leave with your stomach and feet floating off the ground tingling with euphoria and gastrointestinal joy.  Unfortunately, I left with neither of the aforementioned feelings and instead with the more typical feeling of indifference and not wishing to return unless by circumstance.  Beginning with the appetizers, the mac 'n cheese was pedestrian, the pork belly was literally barely there and medicore, the fried green tomatoes was decent, and the duck fat fries which sounded promising, turned out to be nothing to shout from the roof about. Moving on to the sampling of entrees we ordered, the grilled rib-eye steak tasted gamy to me, the pan roasted pork chop was meh, and my greatest hope for spectacular taste bud excitement, the black skillet fired chicken, landed with a soft thud. Our group shared a few plates of the warm chocolate beignets with two dipping sauces(chocolate and coffee soda) and it was lighter and fluffier than I would have preferred but was the highlight of my meal.  The private dining room is adjacent to the bar and comfortably seats 18. It provides middling privacy but rates in my book, a cool spot to host something such as a private birthday party. Our waitress was attentive and prompt, if not solemn, during the entire experience.   A few notes about the ambiance, dark woods, floor to ceiling lavender drapes, large back-lit black and white prints that line the entire back wall of the lounge area provide an elegant, sophisticated, vintage jazz joint feel. On this particular Friday evening, there was a pumping modern jazz band that began playing about 10 pm, which convinced us to have another drink at the bar.

-oJ4OOEVghGp_HmOQbvJiw.review_text: Chose this place for date night and all the great things I had heard and read about it. Had reservations at 7:00 on a Saturday night and we were seated as soon as we arrived. The hostess was very friendly and our server was even better. Very surprised to read about bad service there??? Being our first time there he took the time to explain the menu and make great recommendations. Being that I have grown up eating southern food (dads from Alabama) I already knew I wanted, FRIED CHICKEN!!!! My BF decided to go with the short ribs, we also had the mac n cheese and an order of fried okra. The first to arrive was the corn bread which came out quickly with our wine. The corn bread was warm, very moist and quit tasty. All though it states on the menu and our server had reminded me my chicken was going to take about 20-30 min it did not seem as long but it could have been the few glasses of wine and wonderful ambiance... Once we received our meal we dug in!!! Fried chicken was great, don't go there expecting to get your grandmas fried chicken, it's not!!! It's a bit more elegant but still flavorful, juicy and the skin was that perfect crunch. The mac n cheese was good but I've had better, the fried okra was flavord perfect. Then came the shocker of the evening, I have never been a big fan of pork or beef but I will always try it, the short ribs that my BF got was the highlight of the meal. I think it melted in my mouth, yes they were that good and again this is coming from a girl who's usually not a fan. Unfortunately I ate to much of my delicious entree and my BF's I had no room for dessert but will be getting the banana cream pie next time I'm there. All and all I would come back in here anytime.

63mohShztFN0qKjhFsHFVg.review_text: Well done all around. Ate at the bar and service was prompt and pleasant. Food was very good. Shrimp and grits were especially yummy.  Great place for a bite before show at Kubuki or Yoshii's.

fi3tGL3ii3BVpCjoy-h97A.review_text: A restaurant that serves soul food would not be on the top of our must-try list, mainly because we know very little about this cuisine. Friends of ours selected it because they had been there and liked it, and the restaurant is only a block from The Addition (formerly Yoshi's) where we had tickets for a Sunday night 7 pm show.  My companion and I had a Little Gem Salad, Barbecued Shrimp 'n Grits, and Baby-back Ribs, which was the special of the day. We shared all the items. The restaurant provided extra plates for us to split the dishes. We enjoyed all our selections, especially the Shrimp 'n Grits. I liked the ribs, but my companion thought they were a little tough. We chose the half-rack version. There were 6-7 ribs, more than adequate to share between small to moderate eaters. The ribs come with three little bowls: barbecue sauce, coleslaw, and Mac and Cheese.
