I'm not overly fond of Mac and Cheese, and thought this version tasted a little odd. Was it the truffle oil? My companion, a big fan of Mac and Cheese, also thought it tasted a little strange. We did not finish it.  The other couple also shared all of their items which included Deviled Eggs and boneless Fried Chicken. We also ordered a side dish of Braised Greens with caramelized onions and ham hock, which is perhaps the best thing on the menu: juicy, tender, and savory.  The wines seem a bit too pricey for the kind of food being served, so beer is a good option here. The dining room is elegant without being fussy, and the service is professional, helpful and non-intrusive.

PlNYOwihoRTeEoQa5t-YbA.review_text: This one falls under the "I don't get it" category. Truly, the most memorable part of our meal was the free cornbread and jalapeno jelly that started the evening. Drinks were average, fat fries were sorrowfully under-spiced, fried okra was so bland I almost pooled the table with tears. To make matters worse, they didn't even have a vegetarian main course option, which for San Francisco, is truly unacceptable, soul food or not. The gentlemen at the table loved their ribs and steak (and I have to admit, the grits were excellent), but...I still don't get it.

_mNcNaZ4jnZlTdAAQStgSw.review_text: Ended up here on a Sunday night after passing on a nearly 2-hour wait for a table at Nopa. Got a table for 6 easily in a main room that was about 2/3 full. Took a while to get drinks, the waiter added that the bar was jammed and he had trouble getting our order. Service was lame. The waiter seemed uninformed about the menu and the entire table thought he must have been a last-minute hire for the night. (He reminded me of Jonesy from Reno 911).     I really enjoyed the poached foie gras  ($17) w/ blueberry jam on toasted brioche, but my husband's bourbon braised pork belly ($12) was the winner between the two. Had a taste of the sauteed wild mushroom w/ mascarpone hominy grits which was good, but would have been better with a little less black pepper.   The fried chicken ($23) was too salty as I could only eat one of the three boneless pieces. It had a nice crunchy texture, but it may have sat in the brine too long. Never had issues polishing off a plate of fried chicken ever. Loved the mini biscuits on the side and the whipped potatoes was tasty.   His grilled ribeye steak ($29) w/ blue cheese scented hominy grits in brandy sauce was not as special as it sounds. I had a couple of bites and found it too rich. He was very disappointed with this dish considering how pricey it was.   Had a bite of the brined pork chop $25) and was surprised how good it tasted. It was tender and  well seasoned.   We had the warm chocolate beignets ($9) for dessert that came w/ chocolate sauce & coffee soda for dipping.  Nicely presented, but there's just 3 pieces and no one was blown away by the texture.  It wasn't as light as it should be.   Unfortunately I don't think we'll be returning anytime soon. Very hard not to expect better service with these prices. Later on we found out that they charged us for a salad that we had cancelled.......minus 1 star.

Ylmv-YxetMeMZJ1d6R4N7w.review_text: Couldn't fathom giving this place anything less than 5-YelpStars.  The meal started with the Barbeque Shrimp N' Creamy Grits, the Grits being the MVP of the dish.  Complimentary Cornbread with a jalapeno jelly started to convince me that this place was forreal.  The mains, 1300's Organic Fried Chicken totally destroys Hard Knox's, granted it's $13 more expensive, but the freshness and quality is unmatched.  Maple Syrup Beef Short Ribs fell from the bone after poking at it a bit with my fork.  Yea, true definition of tender ribs.  Finished it off with the Warm Chocolate Beignets and it was a wrapp.

a5bVNQAqI_oYrHq0oLMGkQ.review_text: Made reservations for four- seated right on time- upscale soul food restaurant -beautiful decor and the bar/lounge area is nicely done-comfortable and has framed art..  First thing was the cornbread that came before we ordered. Very very good!  Merlot : very good! We got the fried okra, grits and mac n cheese to start with..okra was amazing, mac n cheese was a little spicy and different and was not my favorite, grits was very good!  By the time our main course came, i was already too full so i could not finish the entree! I got the fried chicken with mash potatoes..OMG! Really really good. i regret that i could not finish it and when asked for a to-go bag, it never came!! Then of course after few glasses of merlot, i forgot about it b/c i was way too full and tipsy then the next morning, i regretted big time that i forgot the doggy bag!.. that was going to be my leftover fried chicken!.. that i was going to eat with a huge smile on my face!! ..sigh!... pls. pls. if they forget your to-go bag, make sure to remind them!!=)  I would come back here again. Next on my list is some good ol'chicken and waffles! ..hmm, never had combo before! .Stay tuned!   This place is a little pricey for soul food but it delivers..the food, the ambiance and the service were all perfect! (except they forgot to bring my leftover fried chicken!=()..heuheuheu..  =)

23wQqI-DYwKkIp1av55A1Q.review_text: Such high hopes.  I was really let down.    There were two things that stood out here--the shrimp and grits appetizer was flavorful, delicious, and excellent.  The decor is beautiful in a muted, soft brown tone.  I felt like I could really relax and it led to this feeling of intimacy at each table, despite not being so far from other patrons.  But, things fell short with the service and the main dishes.  Our waiter was quite overextended--it seemed like he was serving at least 6 or 7 tables on a busy Friday night.  Because of that, our wine didn't arrive for at least 20 minutes and after we had just about finished the appetizer.   We ordered the catfish and the fried chicken.  Both lacked simple seasoning--salt and pepper.  There are no shakers on the table, so we had to ask and wait longer for our seasoning.  The fried chicken breading was crispy, which was good, but the flavor was of a cumin explosion and nothing else.  I was kind of sickened by that taste after one bite and just couldn't stand to eat it.  The catfish was extremely bland, even after adding salt and pepper.  It came with a risotto with sausage, which was okay, but a bit gluey.  We passed on desserts, which looked okay, but nothing special.  Instead, we considered going to Popeye's next door to get our fill of fried chicken.

fndYlWBXCGu1vL5y8-kr4Q.review_text: This place is swanky, romantic and exudes the coolest kind of cool.  BF and I went for our four year anniversary and were treated impeccably.  I highly recommend going to the bar/lounge early and trying every cocktail on the menu (especially the sidecar).  Drinks cost about $9-10 but are really fancy and delicious.  There are also wine by the glass selections ranging from $6-13.  We kind of went down the list....and then ordered a really great bottle of cabarnet sauvignon (Gladiator) with dinner.  Be careful though, this approach to the drink menu got us in a bit of hangover trouble (oh well, it was worth it!).  About the food, it's French soul food.  The reviews rave about the pork belly appetizer...I thought it was alright, I think they increased the price to $11 ($9 on the online menu).  I just don't think I was in the mood for that kind of fattiness that night....but the BBQ shrimp and grits were AMAZING!!!  So were the short ribs and fat fries....mmm mmm good.  Beignets were so so (donuty things that you dip in a chocolate sauce).  BUT five stars all the way for ambiance and service....it was a highly enjoyable experience.

MDfkElmi8zNT7TByqosuRg.review_text: Excellent addition to western addition. Too bad we don't live right on western addition anymore, however 1300 was worth the 15-20(lets settle for 18 mins walk).  Lying on the warm cozy bed of skin city and getting my eyebrows plucked, Kelly P had mentioned the fried chicken at 1300. Quote " It was the best chicken I had in a long long long long time".  Well, having a husband who doesn't like chicken but only does fried chicken, we decided to check this, 1300 out. Dressed in our best, (men in black), we marched to fillmore only to be greeted by a very nice host. Immediately, we were given a table for two. The first time, remember the first time in my restaurant dinning experience I was a little disappointed that we got the table right away coz I wanted to look around. With its dim light, the place looked mysterious and sexy...like a kid in a candy store my eyes peeking everywhere, i didn't want to seat down, but the hostess was waiting, and I had to sit down but I immediately excused myself to the restroom only to look around.   Pretending to be lost (dear host/waiter whoever you were, i wasn't lost, sorry), i looked around and was really impressed with the work. It reminded me of Michael MIna, but Roshan said he was more comfortable than MIchael Mina because 1300 is nice but not overwhelming.  They have excellent wine list. We started with a bottle of pinot gris, which by the way was delicious. We started with the arugula salad and pork belly. The arugula salad was perfect but Roshan liked the belly better.  Moving on we had to do the fried chicken. It was time to test, Kelly P taste, and yeah yeah it was delicious..the truffel infused mashed potato made a perfect combination. For dessert, (yes yes we can eat more, we are in the verge of having big-fat bellies,) we picked the beigniets, which were baked to perfection.  Did I mention they serve corn bread in the beginning?  Did I mention I think their pastry chef is really good?  Did I also mention that they have consultant pasty chef? How do I know this? It is written on the menu, you stupid. But Why?  Well, it was a great dinning experience. I am very happy for fillmore. Plan your evening at fillmore with jazz at Yushi's. Service was good too. Be nice to the server. He just moved from NM. Lets welcome him to crazy San Francisco.   Overall, this review is the longest I have ever written. Roshan would come and say to write a longer one for Metro. I can't do it now. My hand hurts. I will send Yelp the bill, if  my hands are fractured. It is all your fault.

BNQ2ZTmK13yfvFEbGfhLLw.review_text: Had an epic dinner at 1300 last night and i strongly recommend this place to fellow SF foodies.  We had six people and ate just about every item on the menu.  The Southern exposed fried chicken, the BBQ shrimp and grits, the foie gras tourchon with huckleberry jam and the desserts were our favorite parts of the meal although there really wasn't much of a weak link.  The room is flat out incredible, evoking a Jazzy-American feel with big leather couches and roomy accommodations.  We met the owner, the chef, and the manager Tony Elum (who I recognized from his days at Frascatti) and all of them were so charming and welcoming.  The wine list is downright affordable and delicious.  And I really can't say enough about the service - our waiter, Adam G., was professional and knowledgeable and really seemed to celebrate what the restaurant had to offer.  I really can't say enough about "Ace's" service.  It's so nice to see this neighborhood turning around.  I'd recommend that everyone go here before November 28th when Yoshi's moves in next door and it's officially impossible to get a prime time reservation at 1300.    So damn yummy.

WtqzJcXEt5lc0hSeJ-bAJg.review_text: I went back to 1300 on a Monday night.   We had a 7pm reservation but we arrived a bit early, we checked in and went to the bar for a drink while our table was getting prepped. The restaurant was not very busy so I am not sure why the maitre'd did not come back to say the table was ready. I went back over at 7 and had to ask to be brought to the table.   The cornbread appetizer of course is just wonderful.....   I tried the entree special, which was fried chicken with a soup/salad and apple cobble desert. The soup was a butternut squash with some kind of apple accent.....I thought it was very nice although my partner felt it was sort of bland...maybe it was, I liked it thought.   Now to the chicken, this is my 2nd time having this dish and once again, 1 bite made me fall out of my chair thats how good it is. I also ordered a side of greens.....the greens are cooked with sweet onions and I believe turkey ham hocks, the greens were a bit crisp for me (I like them well done) but when eaten with a bit of the onion it was just perfect. The flavor is wonderful.   My partner had the same dish as I but my mom had the catfish. She said it was really good and there was not any bones in the fish, I don't personally like fish so I didn't try a piece but I will take her word for it.   For desert there was apple cobbler, the crust was rich and buttery and the apples were done to the perfect level of sweetness and consistancy.   The server however was less than perfect, we saw him maybe 2 or 3 times over a 2 1/2 hour period. He did not even bring the drinks (a food runner did), we ordered a bottle of wine and brought out the wrong one, then someone else came back with the correct one and they poured it. When we left the food that we had boxed did not come back, we had to find the food runner to go back and get it.   Not sure I want to deduct from the score too much for the service this time though since the food was so good. With the bottle of wine, tip and drinks for 3 at the bar before hand the bill came to about $250, not too bad for deserts (for 2 of us), coffee afterwards, a bottle of wine, which was $51, 3 drinks and 3 entries.   Food Quality - A-  Service - C+  Atmosphere A  Value A- Overall - B+

AKje4BpZb8TjvkI38QHg9g.review_text: Yummy. Fried chicken was the best I've every had. However, usually I'm not a fried chicken eater. Good combination of spices and crunchy batter. Interesting decor. The night that my friends and I went it was pretty busy and the crowds in the bar added to the atmosphere. Overall hip restaurant with good food and a lively crowd. We sat at a large communal table that appeared to be an excellent table for a large party.

UYm3H-3butwgIpXvobOh0w.review_text: I went here for my friend Maggie's Bday before seeing Flogging Molly at the Fillmore.  The place was pretty, a little on the dark side and we struggled to hear at times.  This might be due to our age or the choice I have made to not wear earplugs when advised.  The live background music was pleasant.  After reading about the place I was set on having the shrimp appetizer.  I truly enjoyed it and could have just had the appetizers.  For me grits could be a meal.  For the first time, I tried a taste of pork belly, which I enjoyed.  I did order the short ribs and was impressed with the presentation and taste. The meat was very tender.  I took most of this dish home.  They were out of the port that I wanted and the dessert was disappointing.  I hate donuts and the dish that was ordered seemed like a fancy donut.   Overall this was a good experience but I felt as if the price was high for the meal.  It might have been the company and the occasion that made it so great.  I would go back and have the shrimp/grits appetizer if I was going to the Fillmore but would not make the trip if I wasn't in the area.

c7ffJwemR6psfvnGN-cDlg.review_text: THE BEST FRIED CHICKEN AND PORK CHOP IN THE BAY AREA!!! I know that's a serious statement, but I believe this place can handle the title. Had never been here before so didn't know what to expect. I figured since I was so close to Yoshi's this was going to be one of those tourist traps / mediocre restaurants. The service was extremely professional and the food delicious. If you find yourself in SF for a show or just in the Fillmore neighborhood, I suggest dropping in for a meal -- you won't regret it.

K16ex1N3JMZuoIQAZT-_AA.review_text: Pretty cool vibe, fried chicken was good (although I still love my Popeyes), would actually recommend getting the fish dishes though.  Friendly staff, price is right, etc.

WZy-cjB_zOgwl4BJZ_-itA.review_text: Was just here with a bacherlorette party. Upon entering, I thought the restaurant was very chic. High ceilings and the open feeling of the restaurant is definitely a plus in a city where space is limited. The decor was modern and hip and the lighting was moody and warm.   There were about 6 of us and we found that even with a larger group, the service was good. Our waitress stopped back frequently to check on us.   Food, however, was not the greatest. It wasn't bad but not particularly above average either. I guess I would dub it as "so so". We ate community-style and ordered a bunch of the main courses. There was only one beef dish that I actually thought was good out of the 6. The fried chicken, that people were rating high on Yelp! was kind of a let down in my opinion. It wasn't particularly as crispy as I was hoping.  We, unfortunately, were running behind so couldn't stay and enjoy the bar or the music. Wish I had though. It would have been a more thorough experience.

m1O6JzV76rHoHP0ioGkDjA.review_text: Had an awesome time in the lounge... Hit and misses in the kitchen.  It was a late dinner night so I opted for lighter eating. Had the cauliflower soup, crab & avacado salad, and a side of brussel sprouts.  The salad was delicious. My soup was meh, it tasted of just heavy cream and definitely needed more flavor (maybe roasting the cauliflower,  adding parmesan, nutmeg... something), all I tasted was cream.  My brussel sprouts were very bland, had some of the husbands which were delicious, but his had bacon in them. So I guess that's how I'll order next time.  Overall okay place, will go back to try some of the regular dinner items.

nwWhxOT70FAitWkqdGd9-Q.review_text: Some good food here. Attentive service, but perhaps too attentive at times. I got the ribs with side of jalapeño slaw and a small portion of Mac and cheese. They have some quality mac and cheese at that place. They also serve cornbread to start with jalapeño jelly which was fantastic!   You got to try this place out. Well worth it.

8oFZEpX00zZS1Dku2aKfcQ.review_text: In all honesty, I had high hopes for this place, that were not completely met.  One random comment, out of our 6 person group, 75% completely passed the door because it was too discrete and not obvious...anyways onto the actual restaurant/food.  Went here yesterday with a group of lovely ladies for Dine About Town. The Dine About Town menu that was on the Dine About Town website seemed a lot more heartier than the actual menu that was present at the restaurant. Thus, I did not go with the Dine About Town menu. Instead I went with the special, Carolina Rubbed Full Rack of Baby Back Ribs with Mac/Cheese and Cole slaw.  So I was excited when the ribs came out and it wasn't smothered in BBQ sauce; however, the meat was very dry and very tasteless, definitely needed a lot more rub than was put on it. I've also never had my ribs already individually cut up for me on the plate. The two sauces that it came with, the mustard and the bbq sauce were nice complementary sauces. But the portion of mac and cheese, was the same size as the sauces...what a rip off!  However the Corn bread that comes out was pretty good, or the sauces were. The cornbread was a bit dry and too crumbly. Would've been awesome if it was still warm and more moist. But the jalapeno sauces and honey butter that came with it was quite tasty.  I tried the Fennel/Citrus salad that my friend got as part of the Dine About Town. The ingredients were fresh but a bit too much fennel. She had also mentioned that she was not a big fan of the dressing--too 'mustardy'.  Other friends got the catfish and the scallops. The scallops looked legit, the catfish was such a small portion but I believe she enjoyed it.  For dessert, we tried the bread pudding, and it was quite tasty. The bread pudding was alright and very 'apple cobbler'-tasting. But the ice cream was PHENOMENAL, although they only give you a small scoop, but it was more than enough to share. Their espresso con panna was also pretty good, but I wish it was hotter, it had definitely cooled off by the time they brought it out.  Overall, service was great, ambiance is amazing, and I definitely would like to head back to try some other items on their menu. Sadly, it did not meet my expectations and definitely was pricey for what it was. I think this place would be ideal to have small plates/apps and drinks but not a full on dinner. Or maybe after dinner desserts/drinks. I do want to try out their GOSPEL Brunch one day!  Cool place, but didn't spark my interest as much as I had hoped. Maybe next time...

uxL9y2jlVOpUfJFeofkuOQ.review_text: This review is how they handled private events. I don't live in the Bay Area and had to make all arrangements with event coordinator Kyla via email. She is the WORST at communicating in a timely fashion. I would wait and wait for a response. I've had to wait up to a week and half for a response. The only way I got a response from her was if I emailed her again asking her why she hasn't gotten back to me.   So once the day of the event came (my wedding reception) we were greeted by smiling wait staff and Kyla who wasn't particularly the warmest. My guests were filtering in and the ones who were there started to be seated at the table. During this time my new husband and I are we're taking photos in the lounge when Kyla came out to ask us where everyone else was (at this point we were 10 people short and an hour behind schedule)  we told her they were on there way and Kyla wanted to know an exact time on when they would be here so that the kitchen could start cooking. So right then and there during my photos i had to call the rest of my guests to see where they were.   Through miscommunication neither she or I understood fully what we were trying to convey which resulted in both of us being frustrated with each other. So other than that being a pain in the neck, the food was amazing and I got nothing but compliments from my guests about the food. Just wish the coordinator was better at coordinating and being considerate of her paying customers.

EDQK3ALeaDMFIEOGVyDKuQ.review_text: I don't know that much about soul food, but this place was pretty damn good. Fried chicken was awesome and so were the biscuits they gave you at the beginning  I really liked the vibe/decor in there too. Live Jazz at the bar while you wait or if you just go for a drink. Dark room with and both times I've gone the owners have walked around and talked to our table. Seemed like cool people.

auU2dt62RbnGaQpprzHrVQ.review_text: i swear i fell into a portal that took me back to the height of the roaring twenties the moment the heavy wooden door shut behind me.    as i stepped into the swanky dark interior of the lounge, i was completely blown away by the elegance of the space.  all the meticulous details from the handsome studded leather furniture, to the wall of back lit black and white photographs of scenes from fillmore's past, to the curious upside down lamps hanging from the ceiling, all melded together to achieve the perfect balance of speakeasy sexiness and jazz era chic.  i sank into a sleek armchair and wish i had on an outfit to match: a bell shaped hat pulled snugly over bobbed hair, a fur lined collared coat over a slinky low waist dress, a swinging beaded necklace, a long cigarette in one hand, and a shallow, wide mouth champagne glass in the other...   maybe gazing hopelessly into a dapper young gentleman's eyes...  okay, end daydream.  but here's a hint, dress nice.  i adore the twenties.  i love scott fitzgerald and the great gatsby, jazz from louie armstrong to duke ellington, art deco, bootleg liquor... (just kidding. or am i?)  i even watched charlie chaplin shorts growing up.  and now im starting to think that i may have lived in the twenties in a past life.  anyway.  the food was every bit as amazing as the atmosphere.  the four of us shared a bunch of appetizers:  complimentary cornbread - homemade triangles of fresh cornbread served warm with red pepper jelly and butter.  sigh, i love cornbread.  bbq shrimp and creamy grits - the smoky bbq sauce was to die for  warm poached egg salad - a warm cabbage salad that reminded me a little bit of sauerkraut... but in a good way... or maybe its because i just like egg everything...  sauted assorted mushrooms - the mushrooms really shine, we swore we tasted a hint of truffles... and the mascarpone hominy grits were the perfect accompaniment in both taste and texture  spiced fat fries - as delicious as hot, crispy-on-the-outside-soft-on-the-inside french fries can be    mac and white cheddar cheese - my absolute favorite dish of the night!  i've never had mac n cheese quite like this before... macaroni baked in a gooey white cheddar cheese bechamel sauce with lots and lots of thyme... im not usually a big mac n cheese fan but this... this was insanely good.  we also split two entrees:  maple syrup slow braised pork short ribs - I cant speak to this as I didn't have any, but I can tell you that it looked good and that the "crispy onion rings" are actually one singular onion ring  black eye pea cake - like crabcakes but made with black eye peas!    we also shared a bottle of the anderson valley pinot noir.  and the beignets served with coffee soda for dessert.  ... all for $40 per person.  with $6 sides, appetizers in the $10 range, and entrees all over the $20 range, i would not classify this place as inexpensive.  so... $40 per person... HOW?!!!!  we even double checked the receipt, and it was definitely ours.  amazing!!  service was impeccable.  our server was knowledgeable, our water glasses were never empty - i noticed the manager refilled our glasses at one point... a very nice touch, the pacing of the food was right on point, plates and dirty silverware were cleared and renewed after each course... i couldn't really ask for more.  everyone seemed excited to be there and work there, and their energy is contagious.  live jazz to come on friday and saturday nights.  i'm already trying to think of who i can get to go with me next time.    preferably sometime very soon.    and perhaps in full on flapper outfits.

xCnYbl-vFzCmxSI9nJ7OwQ.review_text: The braised beef short rib is great.  The service could've been better, but the food and decor made up for our waitor's shortcomings.

B0FqPalBVzVSqaDuJ8g61w.review_text: In my opinion the Chicken is Overrated and over priced. Seasoned with a lot of cumin n it's boneless?!!! Took the left over home n poured spicy buffalo Wing sauce all over it.  The best item is the corn bread n biscuits.

2bHSZhM0huV8LRh3YHaOSQ.review_text: Still love this place, still questionable on the cocktails (though the one I tried last night at the Fillmore Cocktail Crawl isn't typically on the menu), STILL HAVE NOT EATEN A SCRAP OF FOOD HERE; wtf am I doing?

qGi0xjK3HM3Lfr6kSwKZdw.review_text: In all my of my culinary adventures, I've come to learn that any place who dares to just use the address as it's name--is pretty damn ballsy. Because it's like FUCK, you don't need to the know the name, you just need to where it's at. And most of the time, those are the places I love to try, because the execution is interesting and different - or is just done perfectly.  So, 1300 on Fillmore...  The only hiccup I had with this place was that it was hard to get a cab back to the Union Square where we staying.  This place was recommended by the concierge of the hotel. And it was the better recommendation we had out of the two reservations we had.  The brunch we had was good, my Spinach and Goat Cheese (your fat girl tip would be to ADD some BACON to that shizz, cause I sure did...) omelette was delicious. The potatoes were spiced heavy, just enough to pack flavor but not to be overwhelming. I tried grits here for the first time off of someone else's plate... I can't say I took to it.  Service was leisurely at the end, but everything was on point throughout. And even though somehow our concierge reservation got cancelled, we were seated upon a few minutes after arrival. The decor is nice, inviting and warm... I'd definitely be interested to come back and try some of their dinner.  And well, my homo self... says that I'd love to feel like Lisa, from the Real Housewives of Atlanta again.

Y3QU8Jj3lYuVa2LmunvnRg.review_text: This place is sexy... But it totally caught me off guard.   Met up with lovely Miss Tiff and Mister Jeff for some good down home southern soul food cookin'. I've been hearing about the fried chicken for a while now and wanted to try it.   We met at the bar. What a sexy bar it was. Low lighting with candles. Sexy bar stools. Sexy drinks. Yeah baby. Sexy. I had some type of margarita. Not my normal drink of choice, but it was really really good. We mosied on over to our table. The entire place is just dark and mysterious and yes, you got it. Sexy!   The decor makes you think that you are in someones study. Or maybe cigar room. Big plush button leather couches. Dark carpet and dark curtains. Low lighting. Everything just looks really comfortable. Miss Tiff sure did look comfortable all cuddled up in the corner of that really oversize leather sofa.   Down to the food. We started with a few appetizers. I went for the shrimp and grits. WOW. WONDERFUL. The grits were cooked perfectly. Eugy had the shrimp hushpuppies. They were ok. A bit dry. But I have to say. I'm not happy about the charge for appetizers these days. Our appetizers where the same price as some entrees. That's a little over the top and totally not worth it. Yes, my shrimp and grits were good, but $16 good? No sir. Especially when you know grits are SUPER cheap. Anyways...   3 of us had the fried chicken. I love the way the chicken was prepared and executed, but to be honest, the seasoning was weird and in no way "southern". The chicken itself was super tender and juicy. I just didn't care for the breaded seasoned part. The mashed potatoes and greens that came with it were WONDERFUL though.   For dessert, I had the banana cream pie. Again, it was a twist on the southern style. It was delightful! Well made and the presentation was really good.   Overall, it was a good dinner, but spending that kind of money on stuff my grandma can make for less than $30 (and it would taste A LOT better) just didn't settle with me.
